talk.start.para: —A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: ANU and CSIRO: Fellowships
petition.para: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1.Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nations national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.
2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship continue to be tenable at the Institute of Advanced Studies of ANU and CSIRO.

para.tab: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

tab.tab: (i)the people of Tasmania have valued the freight equalisation scheme introduced by the Coalition Government in 1976 to redress the disadvantages suffered by Tasmania as a result of the high costs of freight crossing Bass Strait, compared with the costs of land transport, and

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

para.tab: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

tab.tab: (i)on 19 May 1993 the Lake Eyre Catchment Protection Group voted against the nomination of Lake Eyre for World Heritage Listing because local pastoralists and landowners and mining industry representatives believe the plan would threaten the viability of local properties and commercial activities, and

para.tab: (b)supports the Conservation Council's statement;
(c)urges the Governments of South Australia and the Commonwealth to allay those fears immediately through a local program of information dissemination and consultation;
(d)strongly supports the proposal announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during the 1993 election campaign to proceed with nomination of the Lake Eyre region; and
(e)urges both Governments involved to maintain their resolve to nominate the area, while being sensitive to local concerns.

tab.tab: (i)the submission to the Government by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) on industrial reform, and

(A)joint federal-state laws on enterprise bargaining to remove the need for small work places to create an interstate dispute in order to register an agreement,
(B)removal of the requirement for unions to be involved in agreements,

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

proctext.para: [COGNATE BILL:
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993]

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by
Senator Faulkner
:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para: —This morning we are debating cognately two taxation Bills: the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1993 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill No. 2. Yesterday my colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Short outlined the main points of the Bills. I intend to go through these Bills and address what I believe are the good points. I will also raise some of the concerns I have.

para.tab: I believe that, once again, the Government is just tinkering at the edges of the Australian taxation laws rather than getting around to finally doing a complete rewrite on them. If I have time towards the end of my delivery, I will mention a couple of comments of former Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, in this morning's press.

The first point—I congratulate the Tax Office for fixing this up—is the capital gains tax amendment whereby property installed on crown leases is depreciable. Crown leases all around Australia have always been a problem not only with the depreciating of property, plant and installations but also with various other things. A lot of those concerns will be taken away by this measure.

The amendment seeks to amend capital gains tax provisions so that disposal of interest in plant erected on crown leases is treated consistently with the depreciation lease provisions. In other words, the build-up of interest will be treated in exactly the same way; depreciation will be treated on the same basis as are capital gains. The amendment seeks to prevent capital gains and losses from accruing in respect of plant installed on crown leases after the lease has terminated. This is to enable taxpayers to obtain depreciation for plant installed on crown leases. This is rather messy. I know for sure that plant has been depreciated on certain leases before, let alone crown leases, but the area has always remained grey for as long as I can remember. This amendment at least should put it into perspective.

To date, any land on which there was depreciable plant had to be owned by the entity that was claiming the depreciation, whereas we could never say that that was the case with a crown lease. Notable industries that will be affected are the mining industry, probably the biggest user of crown leases; the pastoral industry; some primary industries; and small businesses in cases where they lease land. The sort of land that they lease in Western Australia that comes to mind is former railway land.

Another provision deals with accrued leave. I welcome this amendment because under the present situation a deduction for accrued leave is not available unless it is actually paid out to the employee who is eligible for accrued leave. Of course, it then can be paid out only in the case of retirement, death or whatever. There are a lot of businesses sold on a walk in, walk out basis where a new owner takes everything over lock, stock and barrel and also takes on the employees who worked for the old employer. That part of the takeover or selling price of the business that took into account accrued leave was not then a deduction from the income of the person buying the business.

Under the new provision, that part of the purchase price will be deductible—and so it should be, too. In the former situation, if the previous owner paid the employees out, and they did not want early payment—for various reasons they may not have been ready to retire—perhaps they would then have spent the money. So it is better for everybody all round, and the employers, the unions and the employees themselves all welcome it. I welcome the measure and I believe it is a victory for commonsense at last.

The March or February statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) referred to depreciation schedule broadbanding, and the figures for depreciation were brought back to virtually half. The new depreciation figures were 33 1/3 20, 15, 10, 7 1/2, 5 and 2 1/2 per cent.

If the rate applying to a person then lay between the figures, the taxpayer had the right—and still has the right—to go to the next highest figure. Unfortunately, the legislation was not written properly—which happens quite often in the federal sphere, especially in the House of Representatives where there is virtually no scrutiny of Bills because of the guillotine and the limited time available for debate—and the provision was not very definite. So taxpayers are able to slip up to the next band, even if they were on the 20 per cent band, simply because of the way the legislation has been written. I do welcome that measure because it makes very definite where a taxpayer stands in relation to depreciation.

The next point I would like to address is the definition affecting PAYE provisions in this Bill. The purpose of this amendment is to require PAYE provisions to cover training allowances payable under the landcare environmental programs. It also extends the definition affecting remuneration allowances provisions to cover members of local government bodies. This worries me a little because the whole elected council has to agree to bring the payments received by local government councillors into the provisions of PAYE. Councillors are almost like members of parliament; some are virtually full-time and they receive a fairly high remuneration. There are problems if there are no PAYE deductions, because towards the end of the year the councillors receive a large bill which causes quite a blimp in their cash flow.

Of course I presume that, where local government councillors do get high remuneration and there are no PAYE deductions, they would come under the provisional tax provisions. I am not fully aware whether that has been the case but, for instance, if councillors were paid anywhere near what members of parliament are paid—and that is not very high, I can tell you; everyone knows that—I presume they would come under the provisional tax provisions.

I ask the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) to advise in due course the implications for fringe benefits tax. In an employer-employee relationship PAYE provisions apply. From my past experience as a councillor, there were rulings from the Taxation Office to the effect that no employer-employee relationship existed between a council and its councillors. But once an employee becomes eligible to contribute PAYE deductions, then I presume that fringe benefits tax will apply.

Does that mean then—as I am sure it will mean—that the meals provided at council meetings will come under the provisions of FBT? I refer to the odd drink that hard working councillors have after a meeting—not towards the end of the meeting. The council that I belonged to was not one of those that opened the bar at lunchtime or afternoon teatime or anything like that. But hard working councillors are entitled to an odd drink towards the end of the day, so I presume that that will come under FBT, as will the odd end of the year function that councils have at which a few cigarettes are smoked. I presume that those things will come under FBT. In due course I would like the Minister to address the matter of the allowance that a councillor is paid, as well as a few other matters.

To be fair to the Government, there is a provision to undo the PAYE connection with local government, should that be desired. However, the provisions require that there must be a full council decision to that effect. Once a full council decision has been made to introduce PAYE conditions, then that decision would be very hard to undo. I am not worried about the PAYE provisions if councillors are fairly highly paid. In my own local government experience, I used to get the princely sum of $3.32 per meeting to travel from the furthest distance of my constituency, which was about two kilometres from the council chambers. But for the ones who receive a high remuneration, I believe that it is a good measure. My concern is how far the FBT provisions will extend.

Another welcome provision in this legislation allows an employee to apply to the commissioner for a special rate of deduction where the employee has more than one employer. This has been a sore point for a very long time for these employees. It may be the case that an employee works during the week and does part-time work over the weekend. This applies in the shearing industry to those who press wool or shear sheep—although the ones who shear sheep make enough during the week and they do not need it, but shedhands and others do work over the weekend. Of course, they have not been able to sign a rebate form because they have already lodged one with their employer during the week and then, of course, for any extra work that is done they are taxed at the highest rate. At the end of the day, after having all that tax taken out, they would say, `God'—I am a believer, so I will not say that. After having all that tax taken out, they say, `This job doesn't pay very much. I don't think I'll come next week'. I welcome that aspect of the legislation. I think once again it is a victory for commonsense.

I now address capital gains tax and make clear what will happen now when a statutory licence is cancelled. No capital gains tax will be paid where a statutory licence, be it a taxi licence, a fishing licence or whatever, is cancelled for one reason or another. The way in which the tax was applied previously, on the market value at the time, was totally unfair.

There is also a good capital gains tax rollover measure for transfer of assets between company groups. For instance, when an asset is passed between four related companies, from company A to B to C to D, the capital gains tax will apply only to the last transaction. No capital gains tax will be paid on the transactions in between. I welcome and applaud that measure.

I now move on to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the provisions relating to exemptions from fringe benefits tax for child care and to priority of access. Senator Kernot addressed this issue very well yesterday, so I will not go into it at this stage. I have only a limited knowledge of child-care issues as I am one of those who believe that child care should take place in the home, as happened in my time; but I will not get into that argument at this time, Madam Acting Deputy President. I do welcome that measure for those affected.

In the limited time that I have to speak, I would now like to draw attention to the reduction of company tax from 39 per cent to 33 per cent. Both Senator Watson and I commented on this at the time of the announcement by the Prime Minister. We hammered the press to raise the point that this is not as glossy as it seems on the surface, but the press did not take it up. When one goes into this further, the problems really emerge. However, I do believe that the reduction of company tax from 39 per cent to 33 per cent is a big advantage to companies to enable them to reinvest in and expand their companies. They can employ more people and buy more plant, with a build-up of the economy around a company. As far as that goes, it is good. Then the profits of the company are distributed. If a person is on a tax rate of 48c in the dollar, the Government will be collecting more tax. I know that the taxation authorities, in the explanatory memorandum, have admitted—

talk.start.para: —There is less tax if you are a foreigner.

—Yes, as Senator Watson says, it is certainly an advantage to foreigners. But I do not believe in scaring off foreign investment in Australia. This measure will involve a clawback in taxation collection and in the long term I believe as much or more tax will be collected. So to a certain extent I believe it was an election gimmick.

para.tab: When the Minister addresses the chamber, I would like him to tell us when division 7, which provided that all companies had to distribute a certain percentage of their after tax profits, is to be re-implemented. If it is re-implemented, the Government will certainly be collecting a lot more tax. I would like the Minister to tell us about that.

talk.start.para:
—Senator Watson is right; he is always abreast of the taxation situation in Australia. I draw the Senate's attention to comments in today's
Australian
by a former Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs. He described the taxation system at the present moment as:

speech.para: . . . complex, costly to adhere to, unfair to the less well-off and too harsh on "honest and conscientious" people.

Now that the Government has another three years in office—unfortunately—I call upon it to bring the taxation Act properly into line. It should start to rewrite the Act and reduce its 5,000-odd pages to a manageable size. I look forward to seeing what the Government will be doing about this matter over the next three years.

talk.start.para: —I would like to pick up on the comment that my colleague Senator Panizza just made concerning those remarks by Sir Harry Gibbs. I think it has become quite well known that the complexity and the uncertainty within the taxation law make the law uncertain as a whole and, therefore, we are effectively reducing the major principle of the rule of law. I think it is not without significance that in looking at the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1993 and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993, which are before us, we find that the second Bill has 58 pages and the explanatory memorandum has 116 pages. Continually we are enacting legislation which means that there is more confusion in the system.

para.tab: In addressing the question of reducing the corporate rate, at the outset I think we can say it is a pea and thimble trick. It is proposed by the Government as bringing down a universal benefit on all people who are subject to paying corporate tax. In fact, that is just not the case. Some people will be worse off; some people will be better off. But at the end of the day what offends me most is a point that was raised by my colleague Senator Watson yesterday, which deals with the fact that what we are doing is giving an advantage to foreign companies. When we put this legislation together with the double tax agreements we see that if an Australian company becomes the subject of a takeover bid, and another Australian company wants to use its investing powers to take over that company in competition with a foreign company with foreign investment, the foreign investors have an advantage because the returns that will flow to them make it more attractive for the foreign investors to be able to bid more for that company.

This legislation has been touted—first during the election period and now that it has been brought into the Parliament—as supposedly being of benefit to Australians. I think others of my colleagues have made the point that because of the manner of the collection of the taxation we will literally get to the stage where Australian residents can be paying more tax but foreign investors are paying less. That is not my idea of making laws for the Australian people.

The disparity between the top rate of personal tax and the reduced rate of corporate tax again raises the question of whether or not it becomes attractive for people to incorporate and use the lower rate. In a press release put out by the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia the point is made that many small business people looking forward to the promised tax cut in company rates from the present 39 per cent to 33 per cent for the 1993-94 tax year will be disappointed because under current Tax Office practice they will end up distributing the after tax profits after dividend imputation at full individual marginal tax rates. According to the New South Wales chairman of the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the general anti-tax avoidance rules prevent individual taxpayers alienating income from personal exemption.

In other words, a further element of confusion is put into the tax system. The Government purports to say that it is passing laws in the interest of Australian citizens; it purports to say that there are universal benefits being bestowed when there are not; and we see this downright un-Australian advantage being given to foreign investors.

With the disparity between the top marginal rate and the corporate rate, there is a general expectation that some people will seek to incorporate. Business has queried whether the Government might not consider the reactivation of the old division 7, at least in relation to private companies that do not earn the majority of their income from active businesses. A significant report from the Economic Planning Advisory Council suggests that the reduction of the company tax rate will only deliver marginal benefit to local firms. The reduction will mean that Australia will become one of the cheapest countries in the developed world for foreigners to invest in, which is the point that I made earlier.

The report notes that the promised six per cent cut to the company tax rate would reduce the final tax cost to foreigners for new investments in Australia by 5.2 percentage points to 28.1 per cent.
The lower company rate will only reduce the real tax costs to local investors by 1.5 percentage points to 31.8 per cent. In other words, the Government's own advisory council has spelt out the point that I made: that the Government is giving advantage to people who are not Australians.

It is in the area of finance, tax and debt that the question of our independence as a nation is really relevant. By the year 2000 we will have an international debt of around $400 billion, largely because of the tax policy that this Government has pursued for the last 10 years. Because just over 60 per cent of all federal taxation revenue collected is personal income tax, we have seen a downgrading and a lessening of Australian savings. At the end of the day there are no savings against which Australian companies or individuals can borrow in order to expand or build new businesses. The result has been that we have had to go overseas to borrow other people's savings—hence the debt.

If in our personal circumstances we had a huge debt on our house or business and we were not earning enough to meet the monthly repayments, we know what would happen to us: in would come the bailiff, we would be sold up, and down would go our standard of living. The situation is not much different for countries. We have an international debt and we are not earning enough to meet the monthly repayments.

If we look at the balance of payment figures each month, we will see that the one consistent area where we continue to go into debt is the payments we have to make to service our international debt—somewhere between $1 billion and $1.4 billion a month. It is not our imports and exports that cause us great hardship. Over a 12-month period we export about as much as we import. We build that foreign debt every month because of the interest and dividend payments that we are obliged to make every month. On average, we are paying somewhere around 7.1 per cent on the money we are borrowing. Even the most optimistic figures published by the Government indicate that, of that gross international debt figure of $200 billion, about $86 billion is government sector debt on current figures. That is the debt racked up by State and Federal governments and their agencies.

This situation cannot go on. Here again, we are not attacking the problem of how to create indigenous savings or how we are to encourage ordinary Australian taxpayers to invest their money. Ordinary Australian taxpayers who have invested in shares with an imputed dividend of 39c will have their income lessened again. Again, it will not be an attractive form of savings or investment.

At every turn the Government seems to ignore the fact that our debt is getting greater and greater and hanging over our heads as a threat to our independence. I said that if it were in our personal circumstances it would be the bailiff who would come in. In other countries it is not the bailiff who comes in, it is the International Monetary Fund—it has already made a strong visit to Canada. If the International Monetary Fund decides that it is necessary to reschedule our debts, or take action with regard to Australia, it will simply say, `We will do it, but in turn you will have to put in place the following policies'. Then our standard of living goes down and our independence as a nation goes with it.

To be an independent Australian nation we have to be in a position to make decisions for us and by us so that we control our own destiny. My colleagues, such as Senator Kemp, have raised the question of the way that the Government is using the external affairs power to make more and more Australian decisions subject to review by international bodies which are constituted by persons unknown to the Australian people, and certainly over whom we have no control. More and more this Government is exposing us to the likelihood of an intervention by the International Monetary Fund.

We have to tackle the debt problem. We must have policies to increase savings by ordinary Australians. Unless we start to create that indigenous capital, unless we lessen the burden on ordinary Australians so that they are encouraged to save, we are putting our independence as a nation at risk. In this legislation—complicated by the explanatory memorandum having to be twice the size of the enacting legislation—we see foreign investors being advantaged over Australians. That is not my definition of a government that is governing in the interests of the Australian people.

When we discuss the question of what it means to be Australian, we should start to look at the pea and thimble tricks that the Government tends to pull on the Australian people. We are dealing in areas of complexity. It is not good enough for a government which was elected on a scare campaign to turn round now, break its promises and try to implement ways and means of wrenching more money by way of taxation out of ordinary Australians to pay for the folly of its policies in the last 10 years. Debt is our major problem. Encouraging Australians to create indigenous savings so that we can again be independent and prosperous is the task that all of us have to address.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —People choose interesting forums to advance their leadership aspirations; it is a pity they do not do it better. I will come back to that in a moment. Notwithstanding some of the later contributions, we have had a series of sensible and substantial contributions to the debate. In something of an economic treatise, Senator Short spoke more broadly about the economic and political implications. It is perfectly legitimate to do that in a second reading debate on a tax Bill, and he is entitled to make them. I was going to make some comments that are not germane to the Bill, and have some fun at Senator Short's expense, but I will not do that in his absence. I will find plenty of opportunities to respond.

para.tab: They are mainly issues that have to be resolved in the Budget context; they are not matters that are going to be dealt with in a particular tax Bill. Senator Short knows that and was using this as a forum to make his points, and he is right. He and the other speakers who actually addressed the Bill gave general support to the Bill and raised a number of queries, some of which were of a general nature to which I would like to respond today, and some were of a more detailed nature which would be more appropriately dealt with in the committee tomorrow. I will not take the Senate's time duplicating what can be dealt with tomorrow.

I thank the Senate for its general support for the second reading of these Bills. The queries that people raised came under a number of categories. I would like to take a bit of time on those that come under the general privacy heading. I understand the concerns that people raised there and, although there may be some things to be raised tomorrow, I think they are more of a second reading nature. They are more a statement of a general concern about the principles rather than the detail of a clause. The concerns, as I understand it, principally relate to matters dealing with the migration information in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), although a little concern was also raised about any potential extension arising from the amendments relating to the Queensland CJC.

talk.start.para: —What about complementary legislation through the Privacy Act?

—I understand that there were issues raised with regard to privacy. That is very much what I want to respond to. It is important that anybody who may read or hear the debate has reinforced to them the fact that officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs who have access to any information arising from this Bill will be under an obligation not to disclose any tax related information directly or indirectly except in the performance of their duty. Neither can they make a record of such information or divulge the information to any other person. The Income Tax Assessment Act imposes this very strict obligation on anybody who gets information under the income tax Act. I know that all the people who participated in the debate knew that but, out of context, some of their comments may have raised a concern that that was not the case.

para.tab: I want to assure the Senate that, on the basis of the advice I have received, in the deliberations and discussions leading up to the formulation of these amendments the Privacy Commissioner, through his officers, was involved at every stage and did not express concern or did not oppose this change being made. I want to again reassure the Senate that, on the basis of my advice, the Privacy Commissioner already has the ability to inquire into any breaches of the Privacy Act by the provision of information under this measure. We do not need a new provision to authorise the Privacy Commissioner to act with regard to this measure. That Act is not a matter about which I have detailed first-hand knowledge, but that is my understanding and advice.

Concern was expressed about the amendment relating to the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission. I want to put on the record that there will not be any open-ended access. What we are talking about here is access to information only where the CJC satisfies the Commissioner of Taxation that the provision of information is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence has been or is being committed, or to the making of a proceeds of crime order. So it has limited access and it is of the order which the Senate has approved in the past—in fact, which the Senate has quite actively sought in the past—with regard to other similar bodies. I think we do need to be consistent, and I am sure that that is in the main what people would intend and wish to do.

talk.start.para: —You missed the point. The Privacy Commissioner should be authorised to audit and see who has used the information and for what purpose—not that those people should not get it.

—I appreciate that nobody here was saying they should not get it. I was simply trying to say some things for the record so that people who may have got things out of context are reassured that there is not going to be open-ended access. I know people here know that is not the case because we have all debated these sorts of issues with regard to royal commissions, et cetera. I just wanted to make sure the record was accurate.

para.tab: A number of concerns were raised with regard to the company tax reduction. To the extent they were saying that this is not a cure for all ills, of course they were right. It is a beneficial move. Senator Panizza acknowledged that and expressed some support for it, but he also had some reservations about it. I do not want to oversell it and make people think that just by reducing company tax a magic wand appears and all sorts of economic ills disappear. That is not the case. But it is an economically beneficial move because it creates for some companies operating in Australia—depending on their profit and investment plans and other business situations—the opportunity to undertake new investment and to create more jobs. For that reason this change has been broadly welcomed. It would be inappropriate to oversell it, but I do not think the Government has tried to do that. This is part of a package of measures. More is needed. I suppose it is, in the conventional way of expressing things, necessary but not sufficient for solving all our economic ills. It is a step in the right direction and worthy of the support of the Senate.

I have been a bit puzzled as to why there is this recurrent enthusiasm to drag across the possibility of the reintroduction of the old division 7 tax. Everybody seems to want to dangle this about in the hope that somebody will pick up on a bit of a scare and maybe run a story on the front page for a day or two.

talk.start.para: —That has nothing to do with the scheme whatsoever.

—It really has, because I understand that this matter was raised in the House of Representatives and the responsible Minister made it absolutely clear that there is no intention of doing that. I realise that it is beneath the dignity of most honourable senators to deign to read the House of Representatives
Hansard
, but just on this one occasion it would have been helpful.

para.tab:
Honourable senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to have got bipartisan support for at least one thing I have said in the course of today's contribution. I want to reiterate the Minister's remarks although, given that he is the responsible Minister and I am not, I really do not need to do that. At the end of the debate there was an attempt by someone to re-run her leadership credentials by reading a speech she did not understand. We were struck by an interconnected series of assertions; some of which made sense when taken in isolation, but when interconnected they made none. Then there were allegations that we were about to have the IMF knocking on our door. There have been various attempts to run that furphy for a while. Fortunately, the IMF treats them with disdain and so, in the main, do the Australian people.

para.tab: There was a disturbing attempt to imply that in some way these changes will be relatively adverse to the circumstance of Australian business. This was linked to questions about takeovers. The outcome relating to takeovers will depend on a whole range of factors. For example, an Australian company may distribute only part of its profits to shareholders. Where profits are retained for reinvestment, the tax rate on those profits will operate at this company tax level, and the marginal tax rate in the foreign country from which the company comes is, of course, also an independent factor in this. It is true that if a company has its origin in a country with lower taxes than ours, at the end of the day it pays lower taxes. As the corollary applies—particularly as a result of these changes—a company which has its headquarters in, and operates out of, a country with a higher tax base pays higher taxes. If that is the sum total of the point—which is very profound—it is true. But I do not want to pursue that.

talk.start.para: —There is less revenue flowing to the Australian tax authorities where the money primarily ends up overseas. What about double tax arrangements?

—Double tax and imputation continue to operate, that is true. That has not changed. But to try to turn that into some great blinding revelation is really raising the tedious to a new order of magnitude. Not even in the Senate's history is that usually required.

para.tab: The unnecessary reiteration of the obvious does not enhance anything very much. I know Senator Watson did not do it. It was not him to whom I was referring, but he does not need to support it so enthusiastically. I do not want to waste any more time on those red herrings.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)
—Thank you, Minister.

talk.start.para: —It was a response to the second reading debate, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am sure the matter to which I was referring was in order, even though it was a wide ranging red herring. The Bills are worthy of the second reading support of the Senate—the first one substantially being a reiteration of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7), which lapsed with the calling of the election. The only major change to that Bill as previously introduced is the transitional measure. It makes a number of amendments to the legislation but they are those which we outlined on that occasion.

para.tab:
As was said in the second reading, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), broadly summarised, is an implementation of the measures announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in
Investing
in the nation
on 9 February. It makes a number of changes regarding general investment allowance in addition to the company tax changes that have been the subject of some discussion this morning and others outlined by honourable senators.

talk.start.para: —Senator Panizza! Please! A bit of order, thank you.
—I will be happy to deal with that tomorrow.
—We won't be here tomorrow.

—You are asking: if a local authority votes to apply the PAYE to itself, does FBT apply as well? As far as I know, the answer is yes. There is no doubt about that. To the best of my knowledge, that is clearly the case, and I do not think anybody making a resolution would be in any doubt that that is the case. If Senator Panizza wants me to check whether that is the understanding of the Minister, I would be happy to do that. To the best of my knowledge, that is not a matter of any contention.

para.tab: People raised some detailed matters, but they are essentially matters better dealt with in the committee tomorrow. I have tried only to deal with the second reading type matters of general principle here. I welcome the general support for the second reading and thank the Senate for its support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by
Senator Faulkner
:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I say at the outset, in handling the Telecommunications Amendment Bill on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, that the Opposition will be supporting the passage of the legislation. The Opposition does not have any major objections to this Bill; in fact, we would welcome any Bill which, however slightly, seeks to extend and ensure competition within the telecommunications industry.

para.tab: This Bill will extend to the three mobile telephone carriers—Telstra Corporation Ltd, Optus Mobile Pty Ltd and Vodafone Pty Ltd—the benefit of land access; that is, the ability to enter privately owned land in order to inspect, evaluate or construct telecommunications facilities for the provision of general telecommunications services. In short, this is a Bill which, if passed, we hope will strengthen and provide for true competition in the telecommunications area, an initiative which is very long overdue.

Currently, these three general carriers of mobile phone services have restricted powers under the Telecommunications Act 1991 to enter privately owned land in order to inspect, evaluate, and to install or construct telecommunications facilities for the provision of general services. The Telecommunications Amendment Act 1993 seeks to redress that situation in that it will provide mobile carriers with the same statutory land access rights as are currently applied to the general carrier; that is, Telecom.

For the Government to claim, however, that this Bill will support, in principle at least, a fairer and more competitive environment is a somewhat optimistic view, given the humbug which has been going on for almost all of this year with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), the Government and the department with regard to the pay television fiasco, and given the embarrassing situation in which the Minister has found himself in this place in recent weeks.

talk.start.para: —What's that got to do with this issue?

—The Minister interjects, `What has that got to do with this issue?'. It has got a lot to do with the issue of competition, because among the problems that have arisen in the pay television fiasco is the determination on the part of this Government to restrict the degree of competition on pay television.

para.tab: Competition within the industry has hardly been the focus of the Government's telecommunications reform, as the Opposition has long witnessed. It is hardly a word that even exists in the Government's vocabulary when it comes to the real implementation of policy. This Government only discovered the word `competition' in recent times and is still trying to come to terms with its real meaning in terms of actually applying it in practical policy terms. It seems that under this Government telecommunications policy appears to be about inadequate departmental advice, interference, meddling and ministerial bungling.

The Bill before us, however, does seek to provide Austel with the power to issue directions to carriers about compliance with the new obligations under the land access code, which will provide for procedures which must be followed by carriers relating to land, owners of land and occupiers of land. It will set down procedures for consultation between land owners, land occupiers and carriers in the event of a dispute or disagreement about a carrier exercising its land access powers. It will set up procedures for consultation between carriers to share facilities when new facilities are proposed in the vicinity of existing facilities.

It is the intention of this Bill to safeguard the interests of property owners by introducing a land access code under which Austel may deal with any contravention. At least now, carriers who contravene directions will be subject to a strict enforcement regime. In past years Telecom as the sole carrier had unquestionably broad access rights over land access under the Act, and it is not unreasonable that the Government should be redressing them, reining them back somewhat.

Carte blanche in this respect is no longer the preserve of Telecom, and the newer players in the industry will operate under identical arrangements. The Australian Telecommunications Authority will be provided with the power to issue written directions to carriers about how they are to comply with the land access code and to ensure that such directions are enforceable. Indeed, the obligations require the giving of reasonable written notice to the owner of the land and, in certain cases, to the owner and occupier of the land on which the carrier is intending to exercise its powers. This is timely because, in the past, arrangements between the carrier and the landowners or occupiers were somewhat different. In past years, although complaints concerning Telecom's access rights have been very few, the rights of land-holders or occupiers were virtually non-existent. Now landowners and occupiers will have much greater rights, and the restrictions will now be placed on carriers to meet these requirements when installations are made.

Previously, if they were unhappy about Telecom activities, there was technically very little that land-holders could do. If they had genuine problems regarding, say, trees being pulled down, the installation of cables underground which may disturb their crops, or even with the ripping up of their land, they had very little leverage with which to negotiate. Understandably, that will now change with the passage of this legislation and the rights of landowners will therefore be re-established. As the Opposition therefore has no objections to this legislation, we support its passage through the chamber.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Chapman for his indication of Opposition support for the Telecommunications Amendment Bill. I want to make one point in response to Senator Chapman's concern about lack of competition. Just in recent days, it has become very fashionable to portray the Department of Transport and Communications as a department of scorched earth economic rationalist zealots that want to let her rip. That is in fact the view on everything by the Opposition. It wants an open skies aviation policy which I have described—
—Don't tell lies.

—It is in the Fightback document—as outrageous. In other words, to hell with the interests of our own carriers, let us give away these extraordinarily valuable rights to the carriers from everywhere else and not protect the rights of our own Australian carriers. This scorched earth stuff is Opposition policy. The Opposition has the same policy with regard to telecommunications: let her rip. The problem about letting her rip in telecommunications, as far as I am concerned, is that the real result would be not more competition but less. The policy of the Government, effectively supported by the Department of Transport and Communications, is not scorched earth, the devil take the hindmost and the market rules—and properly so. To establish a mobile phone network takes an enormous amount of capital. We have to expend a very large amount of money—like pay television—before we get a dollar back.

para.tab: In my view—and I do not apologise for saying this—the competition which this Government with its sound policies is introducing into telecommunications has to be carefully managed. It is not a case of let her rip. We could get into the situation in which, if open slather were allowed in telecommunications rather than the careful approach that we are taking, the financial viability of the operators that are now effectively providing competition to Telecom could be undermined to such an extent that the final result could be less consumer benefit, not more.

One of the things that the telecommunications and broadcasting industry was telling me for most of last year—and at the last ATUG conference that I went to this was said to me again and again during the evening—was, `We support fully the Government's changes in telecommunications. We support the establishment of the Spectrum Management Agency to handle the management of spectrum'. This all happened last year at the Australian Broadcasting Authority. Of course, those two agencies will manage all future tender processes for radio spectrum sales and broadcasting licences. Members of the industry also said, `We support the competition which has now been effectively provided to Telecom by Optus, and now by Vodafone in the mobile market. We support all of that'.

It has been a very commendable record of public policy, but it is enough now. I have said publicly several times that I agree with that view. What the industry was telling me for six months last year was, `Look, we now need a period of consolidation in the communications side of this portfolio. We need a period in which industry can adjust to all these massive changes'. During this period the broadcasting industry can get used to dealing with the new ABA and the new broadcasting Act; all of these other agencies can find their feet, and Optus and Telecom and, eventually, Vodaphone can effectively work out their roles. Of course, that is currently happening and, I am pleased to say, getting a lot of public attention in respect of Optus and Telecom balloting for phone services.

I simply want to assert that it is managed change, not the `let her rip' approach that the Opposition has consistently advocated for a long time, that is the policy of the Government, and it is being effectively delivered by the Department of Transport and Communications. With those few comments, I thank the Opposition for its support of this legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

talk.start.para: —Could I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) whether this Bill deals with the digital signal capability to mobile phones that was mentioned in the press in the last few weeks.

—I do not really see that it is very helpful to actually extend the debate on this Bill, which is a mechanical Bill allowing access to land for the installation of the necessary hardware to provide the competition which the Opposition is so desperately saying it needs, by canvassing issues that are in fact totally beyond the Bill. The answer is no, it does not.
—I thank the Minister for his answer. I would observe that we all understand that he is in the dying stages of his career, but he should reflect on the old saying that courtesy costs nothing.
—Was that a question?
—It was a statement. I realise that you would not have the intelligence to understand it.

—Just ignoring the abuse opposite, I reiterate—and this is the final thing I will say about the matter—that the answer to the question that Senator MacGibbon just asked is no. This Bill deals only with providing access by mobile phone operators to land in order to install the necessary transmission facilities to operate the service.

para.tab: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

speech.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That this Bill be now read a second time.

speech.para:
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The speech read as follows
—

speech.para: This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to decrease the excise duty payable on gasoline for use in aircraft, or avgas, and to increase the excise duty payable on tobacco and tobacco products.
Avgas

The proposed decreases in avgas occur in two stages. The first is effective from 7 May 1992 and the second decrease is effective from 19 August 1992. The decreases result from two sources. The first is from the Government's policy of transferring Commonwealth owned aerodromes to full local ownership and encouraging aerodrome owners who are receiving funding under the aerodrome local ownership plan to accept full financial responsibility for their aerodromes. The second is from a reduction in Civil Aviation Authority costs.

The resulting reduction in funding is then passed on to the aviation industry in the form of decreases in the rate of excise duty to be paid on the avgas. This Bill proposes a total decrease of 2.1 cents per litre. A decrease of two cents per litre is attributable to the aerodrome cost recovery program. The other 0.1 cents per litre is attributable to the CAA achieving cost savings in the provision of its rescue and firefighting services. These cost savings result in a corresponding reduction to the proportion of excise duty used to fund that service.
Tobacco

The proposed increase in excise duty on tobacco products amounts to $5.00 per kilogram. The Government is concerned about the social costs of smoking. However, it realises a balance must be struck with this concern and placing an unfair burden on tobacco users which may also have an undesirable inflationary impact. The Government considers that the proposed increase is a responsible measure which adequately satisfies this balance.

Both the decrease in the duty payable on avgas and the increase in duty payable on tobacco took effect last year pursuant to Excise Tariff Proposals Nos. 1 and 2 of 1992. These proposals lapsed upon the dissolution of the House on 8 February this year and then their effect was reinstated by Excise Tariff Proposal No. 1 of 1993. Notwithstanding their lapsing, duty collections continued at the rates specified in the proposals and therefore this Bill proposes to validate those collections as well as incorporating Excise Tariff Proposal No. 1 of 1993 into the Excise Tariff Act 1921.
Financial Impact Statement
Gasoline for use in aircraft

The reduction of 2 cents per litre in respect of the Department of Transport and Communication's aerodrome cost recovery program will result in a reduction of revenue in the order of $1.8 million in 1992-93 and $2 million in 1993-94.
The decrease of 0.1 cents per litre requested by the Civil Aviation Authority is balanced by the reductions in moneys appropriated to it, so therefore there will be no net financial impact.
Tobacco Products

The increase in the excise duty on tobacco products, together with the corresponding increase in the Customs duty, was estimated as part of the 1992 Budget to result in an increase of $80 million for 1992-93 and $100 million for 1993-94.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its explanatory memorandum.

speech.speaker: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I indicate at the outset that as with the previous Bill, which dealt with a different subject, the Opposition will be supporting the passage of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1993. The Bill amends the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and seeks to validate duty collections pursuant to excise tariff proposals which lapsed following the dissolution of the Parliament earlier this year.

para.tab: The excise tariff proposals I have just mentioned provide for a reduction in excise duty on gasoline used in aircraft—that is, avgas—as well as an increase in the excise duty on tobacco and its products. In respect of avgas, it has already occurred in two stages with the blessing of this enabling legislation. The first stage was effective from 7 May 1992 and the second from 19 August 1992. As a result, the price of avgas falls by a total of 2.1c per litre. But not unlike petrol, as motorists would know, the cost of avgas varies according to location. For instance, in Canberra it is currently available at 89.9c a litre, which includes a 5c freight charge. In my home city of Adelaide it is available for about 84c a litre. Overall, the excise still represents about 30 per cent of the cost of a litre of avgas.

Under the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1992, the excise was reduced by about 1.02c per litre, from 26.4c per litre to 25.38c per litre. The reduction in excise has occurred because of the Government's promise—one of the few promises the Government has made that it is going to keep—to reduce excise duty, as the cost of providing the services to aircraft funded by that particular duty also falls.

The total reduction has come about because of the 1990 transfer of federally owned aerodromes to full local ownership, and the encouragement of aerodrome owners receiving federal funding to accept full financial responsibility for their aerodromes. So the Government is no longer responsible for the cost of maintaining and administering those aerodromes. It is also the result of savings achieved by the Civil Aviation Authority, following the removal of rescue and fire fighting services from secondary capital city airports. This move was supported both by the industry and by the Opposition.

In respect of the increase in the excise on tobacco and tobacco products announced in the 1992 Budget, it is intended to address, in part at least, some of the social costs to the community of people's smoking. The excise increase will be $5 per kilogram, increasing the price from $52.50 to $57.50 per kilogram. Concerned though any government ought to be regarding the social costs of smoking, an unfair burden should not be placed on smokers by inappropriately inflating the cost of such products. Both these excise duties—that is, on avgas and tobacco—as I understand it, took effect last year pursuant to excise tariff proposals Nos 1 and 2 of 1992. Notwithstanding the lapse, collection of duties continued at the rate specified earlier. Hence, this Bill proposes the validation of those collections.

Sadly, as far as light aircraft operators are concerned, what this Labor Government giveth with one hand it taketh away with the other. Unfortunately, the savings they will gain through reduced excise will be more than offset by the additional cost to general aviation engendered by the Government's proposed new airspace management system. Even more importantly, the new airspace system announced recently with great fanfare by the Civil Aviation Authority is fundamentally flawed and potentially dangerous. It is like no other system in the world.

The original plan, introduced by John Wright and his AMATS team, had the desirable aim of harmonising Australian airspace with the rest of the world, as well as reducing costs and allowing Australians to purchase proven air traffic control equipment. An

speech.para:
outline of this plan was published in a Civil Aviation Authority publication, entitled
Improving the Management of Australian Airspace
. The airspace system that the Civil Aviation Authority plans to introduce in Australia contains unique features which have never been tested anywhere else in the world and which are potentially dangerous.
Civil Aviation Authority board members do not appear to appreciate the high risk that they are allowing to be inflicted upon Australian aviation—a situation for which the board, the Department of Transport and Communications and the accident-prone Minister for Transport and Communications (Senate Collins) will have to accept responsibility. If one looks at the diagrams and comparison charts showing the Civil Aviation Authority—

talk.start.para: —What has this got to with an excise Bill?

—It has got a lot to do with the excise Bill. I made the point that on the one hand the Government is reducing some of the costs for general aviation but, on the other hand, as a result of these measures, it is going to increase them. That is why it has a lot to do with this particular Bill. When the Minister interrupted, I was referring to the diagrams and comparison charts shown in the Civil Aviation Authority booklet. I seek leave to have a copy of a chart incorporated in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

para.emphasis: [CHART OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 919]

talk.start.para: —I thank the Minister and I thank the Senate. If we look at the charts, it is clear that the original proposals put up for airspace had only minor differences, such as cloud separation requirements, from the International Civil Aviation Organisation's recommendations. Those proposals resulted in a simple, easy to learn, system. However, under the system now proposed by the Civil Aviation Authority the differences are major. These include unique and complicated radio procedures for visual flight rule aircraft in class E and class G airspace, thus negating the only reason for these classifications of International Civil Aviation Organisation airspace.

para.tab: There are more differences. First and most important, in the original plan an ATC service was to be provided to all instrument flight rule aircraft to ground level where traffic levels were high but would not justify a control tower. This is the system in both the United States and Canada, and the airspace is called class E. It is transparent to visual flight rule traffic and it is not as costly as the existing high level controllers providing the service, as the diagram shows.

Under the new proposals this air traffic control service will stop at 5,000 feet in radar airspace and 10,000 feet in all other airspace, which covers about 80 per cent of Australian airspace. No other country in the world has such a system. The Civil Aviation Authority has invented a mandatory traffic advisory frequency procedure in an attempt to compensate for the lowering of safety. Unfortunately, this is an unproven system and completely at odds with the existing mandatory traffic advisory frequency where all instrument flight rule traffic is provided with flight service traffic information.

This unique mandatory traffic advisory frequency procedure will be complicated and totally different to that applying in any country in the world, and effectively negates the whole reason for changing the airspace, which was to be harmonisation with best world practice. Australian pilots flying overseas and overseas pilots flying here will have to learn and adapt to totally different procedures. More importantly, the advanced Australian air traffic system equipment will now have to be designed for the unique Australian airspace system, resulting in potential huge cost blow-outs and delays in commissioning.

Another major difference is the mandatory transponder or radio requirement for aircraft above 5,000 feet in en route radar space. This is not an International Civil Aviation Organisation recommendation, and again no other country in the world has shown it can afford such a restrictive and expensive requirement. In the United States, that requirement is now 10,000 feet; in Canada it is 12 1/2 thousand feet. This unique Australian requirement will cost up to $6 million and only affects general aviation aircraft, as airline aircraft already have transponders. As I said earlier, what the Government gives in one hand in reducing this avgas excise, it is taking away with the other with the additional costs it is imposing on light aircraft operators. If radio is used instead of a transponder, the cost will be even higher as air traffic control sectors will have to be smaller and visual flight rule aircraft will have to be charged for the service.

No objective cost benefit study has been done for this transponder requirement, even though a comprehensive cost-benefit study has been done for closing down control towers, which, by strange coincidence, represents a cost saving to airline aircraft. Avgas powered aircraft pay the same whether there is a tower there or not—an across-the-board excise, as a result of this legislation, of a bit more than 25c per litre.

Some thought must be given to what this system would do to air traffic controllers who are, of course, a very professional group. They are losing responsibility for providing safety services to passenger carrying airline aircraft that need and can afford an air traffic control system while they will be given extra responsibilities for large numbers of visual flight rule aircraft operating above 5,000 feet without a transponder. Even flight service no longer provides a service for these aircraft.

The new system will place professional air traffic controllers in an almost impossible position, as they are to be given responsibility and therefore duty of care for visual flight rule aircraft, including gliders in class E airspace, without the internationally proven protection of the class D airspace procedures. One has to seriously question why we even bothered to move to the International Civil Aviation Organisation's separated instrument flight rule and visual flight rule cruising levels.

The total injustice of this system is obvious. The airlines claim that, because they pay over 80 per cent of the Civil Aviation Authority's income, they should have most of the say. They have used this clout to bring in procedures which reduce safety to airline passengers but save the airlines many millions of dollars, while forcing additional and onerous requirements and costs on general aviation. However, in the long run, the airlines will probably end up with less safety and higher costs as they will no longer have a thriving general aviation industry from which they can draw a pool of experienced pilots.

The board of the Civil Aviation Authority has failed to obtain independent, professional advice on these issues—for example, by speaking to North American experts—before making a final board decision on airspace design. Instead, it has accepted the recommendations of the Civil Aviation Authority management. Apparently, Civil Aviation Authority management regards the proposals as not a significant departure from internationally accepted practice. But no country in the world, including Australia, has ever put in place the proposed system of airline traffic, operating into airports such as at Yulara or Cooma, without a traffic separation or information service being provided on other instrument flight rule aircraft.

The Civil Aviation Authority management has wrongly claimed that this is the practice in Canada. That is clearly not the case, as Canada has yet to move to International Civil Aviation Organisation airspace. However, in its current airspace, which is similar to our proposed class G, airline traffic is provided with a traffic information service from remote VHF outlets and local flight service stations on frequency 126.7. This is completely different from what is being introduced in Australia.

The Civil Aviation Authority has also wrongly claimed that Canada has a similar system to our mandatory traffic advisory frequency. That is also not the case, as the Canadian system of mandatory frequency has a fundamental difference. It only has a mandatory radio requirement where there is a ground station with which to communicate. The reason a ground station must be present for mandatory frequency requirements is for fundamental safety reasons.

Civil Aviation Authority management claims that the North American system of class E airspace would cost up to $30 million per annum to implement in Australia. That is completely unjustified and incorrect as a claim, and shows a clear lack of understanding of the criteria used in the North American system. These criteria are based on objective traffic densities and risk modelling. If the same criteria were used in Australia it would mean only class E airspace to ground level at a small number of busy airports with airline traffic but with insufficient traffic density to justify a control tower. This is, of course, as was originally planned by John Wright's team. There would be a cost, but this could be fully justified under the application of objective safety criteria.

Under the proposed potentially dangerous system, airline traffic will be largely on its own below 5,000 feet in radar airspace and below 10,000 feet in other airspace. This means that large aircraft such 737s going into Yulara or the F28 jets that fly into Cooma—we need to remember that Cooma can be subject to bad weather conditions—will not be provided with traffic or separation services on all other instrument flight rule traffic. This is totally unacceptable, and it is unfortunate that we will probably have to wait for a serious incident or accident before the merit of fully adopting the proven international system is driven home.

Do not imagine that work force airline pilots and air traffic controllers are happy with the new proposals. It is my understanding that a number of the chief pilots of major regional airlines and a wide range of air traffic controllers are opposed to the proposed system which has now been accepted by the Civil Aviation Authority and which, as I understand it, is hurriedly being put in place for November of this year.

Under the original John Wright plan the International Civil Aviation Organisation airspace was not to have been introduced until July 1994. The Civil Aviation Authority claims to have industry support for its new airspace system. This may appear to be the case only because the Civil Aviation Authority has convinced industry that the proposed system is based on proven international practice. As I have just indicated, that is clearly not the case. Senior air traffic controllers who have been involved in the development of the airspace proposals and the chief pilots of a number of regional airlines are totally opposed to the parts of the proposals that are unique to Australia and that are as yet unproven.

Most people in the industry do not understand the proposals and genuinely accept the Civil Aviation Authority's October 1992 aviation bulletin which stated that it was moving to the International Civil Aviation Organisation airspace classifications and harmonising with the rest of the world. In the absence of any widely circulated publicity from the CAA about its changed position, most industry people have assumed that the original proposals remain in place, but nothing could be further from the truth.

It is hardly surprising that the Civil Aviation Authority board is getting questionable advice. The team that the Civil Aviation Authority has put together for the airspace system project is made up of pilots and Civil Aviation Authority management with no training in the complex job of objective risk analysis of airspace design. Designing an airspace system is just as complex and specialised a task as designing the aircraft that use the airspace—a task that no-one would contemplate leaving to pilots. No person who has an in-depth knowledge of the North American airspace system we are moving to and of the fundamentally different culture involved has been consulted.

As a consequence, the CAA has attempted to fit its old ideas and culture into the new International Civil Aviation Organisation international system. This is simply a recipe for disaster. While the original proposals appear to have been hijacked by a small group of airline people, we must get the system back on track and follow the safe, simple and proven International Civil Aviation Organisation recommended system, which is being adopted by New Zealand, the United States, Canada and Europe. I understand the CAA is already having difficulty in inventing the new procedures and is being forced into compromises. Let us hope that commonsense eventually does prevail and that we move back to the original proposals to harmonise with proven safety the international procedures so capably brought to us by John Wright and his original AMATS team.

The proposed system is fundamentally flawed and potentially dangerous. Therefore, the CAA board, the Department of Transport and Communications and the Minister are personally responsible if this system is introduced, because they have failed to obtain proper independent expert advice before accepting the proposals. Only yesterday we saw the Minister profess ignorance of all these matters in answer to a question I put to him during Senate Question Time. Again it is clear that Minister Collins is failing on too many fronts to exercise appropriate authority or control over his Department of Transport and Communications, and thereby allowing it to run its own agenda, whether that be pay television, aviation or whatever comes next. While passage should not be denied to this particular piece of legislation, the time has well and truly passed when this Minister should stand aside.

talk.start.para: —I rise to address briefly the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1993. The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to decrease the excise duty payable on gasoline for use in aircraft—known as avgas—and to increase the excise duty payable on tobacco and tobacco products.

para.tab: The price of avgas will fall by a total of 2.1c per litre as a consequence of this Bill. The reduction in the price of avgas can be separated into two separate components. First, there is a 2c per litre reduction which is attributable to the aerodrome cost recovery program. This program involves transferring Commonwealth owned aerodromes to full local ownership and encouraging aerodrome owners who are receiving funding under the aerodrome local ownership plan to accept full responsibility for their aerodromes.

Secondly, there is a 0.1c per litre reduction due to the Civil Aviation Authority `achieving cost savings in the provision of its rescue and firefighting services' to secondary capital city airports. This has been implemented after a comprehensive consultative process which was carried out with the aviation industry, local authorities and the Federal Airports Corporation. Nevertheless, the Australian Democrats wish to ensure that the results of this cost cutting measure are monitored so that the rescue and firefighting services are not diminished at these airports.

In addition, the Democrats wish to express concern, as Senator Chapman has, about the new airspace system which is to be introduced by the Civil Aviation Authority. Without going into the detail that Senator Chapman has put on record, the Australian Democrats would suggest to the Minister that it is appropriate to review the concerns that have been expressed by various people in the industry and put on the record in the Senate today and to respond in some detail on the concerns which have been expressed.

Turning to the excise on tobacco and tobacco products, this will increase by $5 per kilogram under this Bill, raising the price from $52.50 to $57.50 per kilogram. This was a measure announced by the Government in its 1992 Budget and is designed to address the social costs of smoking; that is, to improve the health of the Australian community. The Australian Democrats very strongly support this measure not just as a revenue raising measure but very much as a measure to address the social costs of smoking.

The Democrats have a long history of attempting to decrease the use of tobacco in the community in realisation of the tremendous health costs—billions of dollars that are being borne by the whole community, quite apart from the diminishing health of individuals. I refer to the private member's Bill initiated by Senator Powell prohibiting the print advertising of tobacco which was passed through both Houses, the first such Bill for a long time and certainly the first private member's Bill by a woman senator.

The Australian Democrats have continued that campaign, and in particular I refer to Senator Robert Bell's efforts to remove the cost of tobacco from the CPI so that the additional imposts that we as a matter of policy support do not affect the inflationary effects of increases in the CPI. It is a matter that the Australian Democrats will continue to pursue. The Democrats certainly give their support to this Bill.

talk.start.para: —I have been present in the chamber to hear most of the speech of Senator Chapman indicating support for these measures from the coalition, and I have heard now the remarks of Senator Spindler from the Australian Democrats likewise indicating support for these measures.

para.tab: The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1993 in one part deals with decreases from 7 May 1992 in the excise duty payable on gasoline for use in aircraft, and in another part deals with an increase in the excise duty payable on tobacco products. This Bill comes under the portfolio of the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, on the basis that he has the customs function within his portfolio. Excise on gasoline for aircraft is something that the Department of Transport and Communications has an interest in and excise on tobacco is something that the Treasury and the Department of Health have an interest in.

As is usual in a case in which there is heated agreement in this chamber between all of us that such Bills shall pass unanimously, the occasion of this debate has been used to some extent by some speakers to make points not related to this legislation. I note the references made by Senator Chapman about civil aviation management and the expression of his concerns about how those events are proceeding. I will draw his remarks to the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), and I have no doubt that Senator Collins at an appropriate time will make reference to them and reply to them. They are not germane to this legislation and I do not propose to use this occasion to speak to those matters.

I thank all honourable senators for their contributions to this debate, and trust the reflection of their support for this Bill will be carried through in the vote and that this Bill will pass unanimously.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debate.title: ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGES (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY) BILL 1993

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by
Senator Faulkner
:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para:
—On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I indicate that the Opposition will allow the passage of this Road Transport Charges (Australian Capital Territory) Bill 1993. The Bill is a result of the Inter-State Commission inquiry report, handed down in March 1990, entitled
Road use charges and vehicle registration: a national scheme
. The Inter-State Commission report was followed up at the Special Premiers Conference and culminated in a heads of government agreement establishing the National Road Transport Commission.

para.tab: The National Road Transport Commission was set up initially to make recommendations regarding uniform registration rates for heavy transport vehicles because, quite frankly, the situation was chaotic, with each State and Territory having its own regulations and charges, making the whole heavy transport industry a nightmare. In June and August 1992 all States except New South Wales and Western Australia accepted the determination of the National Road Transport Commission regarding the implementation of annual registration charges for vehicles rated over and above 4 1/2 tonnes as well as permit charges for vehicles operating above 125 tonnes. Victoria abstained from joining.

The outstanding issues, of course, will be the resolution with some States regarding potential compensation for loss of revenue where those States' existing registration collections would fall as a result of the National Road Transport Commission determination. The ACT Legislative Assembly has already passed parallel legislation which has been supported by Liberal colleagues in the ACT Opposition.
The ultimate purpose of this legislation is to put in place the Commonwealth's legislation as a model for other States to follow, and in the meantime outstanding problems are to be resolved.

The Liberal and National parties have long battled with this Government over the question of inefficiencies in the heavy transport road sector with respect to fuel and registration charges. So this legislation is at least a move in the right direction. The arrival of a consistent set of registration charges throughout all the States and Territories of Australia to overcome the flights of registration from States of ownership to States which have lower charges is a constructive point from which to move forward. The industry, as represented by the Road Transport Forum, supports the principles of this Bill and the charges in the Bill as proposed by the National Road Transport Commission.

Indeed, the industry has had effective input into this outcome. Hundreds of those involved at all levels of the industry came forward in discussions to put their strong view, and this was appreciated by the commission. The commission had a solid and dependable rapport with industry right across Australia. It is my belief that the entire process was a valuable exercise both for government and for industry groups. These measures represent much needed and long overdue reform for the heavy vehicle industry in Australia. For too long, inefficiencies with respect to road user charges have contributed to inefficiencies throughout the entire industry and throughout the entire country.

This legislation applies to the Australian Capital Territory alone. It does not affect any existing registration scheme in operation in the ACT other than to fix the charges to be collected when a vehicle covered by the Bill is registered. Registration exemptions or concessional charges will continue to be a matter for the ACT itself to determine. The charges do not include, nor does the schedule preclude, the fixing of fees for administration and other services provided by the ACT. In effect, this Bill pioneers national regulation of the road transport industry in Australia. It is but the first step in establishing necessary uniform regulation right across the country, including uniform loadings and general regulations.

It is interesting to note the variations which have applied to registration charges in the past, variations which of course will be removed by this legislation. For example, a six-axle semitrailer—that is, a prime mover with bogie drive and a tri-axle—is currently charged the following rates: in Queensland, $3,280; in New South Wales, $5,870 and in fact up to $8,000 in some circumstances; and in the Northern Territory, just $430. It is clearly ludicrous to have such massive variations in registration charges across this nation. Under the National Road Transport Commission proposals incorporated in this legislation a six-axle semitrailer would attract a registration charge of $4,000 anywhere in Australia.

As I have said, the legislation only applies to the ACT and will require complementary legislation from all of the other States so that we have the same inspection criteria for registration of vehicles, load limits, driver times and so on.
