There has been some controversy with regard to the introduction of these charges. That controversy was such that it was necessary for the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure—which, sadly, no longer exists in its own right as a result of this Government's determination to reduce adequate parliamentary scrutiny of issues and legislation but has been combined with the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and henceforward will be a very overworked committee—to take up a very detailed inquiry into the impact of uniform road user charges, particularly on rural and isolated areas of Australia. Of course, that inquiry confirmed what we all knew—that the road transport industry in Australia is the highest taxed industry in this country. Currently, a six-wheeler truck for each 120,000 kilometres that it travels is taxed in total at a rate of some $44,000.

We also need to recognise that a major cause of the excessive taxation on this industry is the dramatic increase in fuel excise that has occurred since this Government came to office in 1983. It has risen from 6c per litre to 26c per litre. This has taken total collection of fuel excise to some $7 billion—but, sadly, only $1.2 billion of that $7 billion goes back into road funding. That is a parlous situation for a country which is so heavily dependent on road transport for the production and distribution of its goods and for its wealth creation. When this Government came to office, about 80 per cent of fuel excise went into road funding; now it is down to something less than 25 per cent.

As I have said, all of the States, with the exception of Western Australia and New South Wales, have accepted the determination of the National Road Transport Commission for vehicles over 4 1/2 tonnes. That is a very great step forward. But the Government needs to go further. It needs to take initiatives which will reduce the costs of operation of road transport in this country.

During the election campaign we saw yet another part of the Government's dishonest attack on coalition's policies; that is, the suggestion that road transport would in fact be charged more under a coalition government, notwithstanding the fact that we had made a firm commitment to abolish fuel excise and completely get rid of that 26c a litre that is charged not only on road transport operators but on all vehicle operators, including motorists. That would have represented a substantial saving to road transport in this country. Our further commitment was that there would be no additional road user charges levied on the industry other than that being put in place by this legislation—the uniform road user charges that this Government had already introduced on the recommendation of the National Road Transport Commission.

Notwithstanding those two firm commitments from the coalition, we saw a massive and dishonest scare campaign embarked upon by various Labor Party candidates in the last election. They implied that there would be a new road user charge introduced by a coalition government when we had clearly said that there would be no new road user charge in the first term of that government and that the situation would be reviewed at the end of that first term to consider the equity of the scheme that was then in place. We also heard claims made by Labor Party candidates not only that there would be additional road user charges for the road transport industry but also that private motorists would be hit by increased registration charges initiated by State governments as a result of the loss of revenue from the fuel excise.

But of course the fact is that that revenue does not in any way provide the States with funds for roads. The funds provided for roads by the Commonwealth Government were fully covered in the coalition's policy package. The additional revenue which States put into roads is raised from their own sources; it would not have been affected in any way by the changes the coalition was proposing and, of course, there would not have been any increase in State registration charges as a result of the coalition's policy.

I just raise that matter to highlight again the dishonest way in which the Labor Party campaigned during the last election. It is absolutely essential that a review of the costs of these new charges be undertaken by the Federal Government, and in particular by the National Road Transport Commission, to ensure that there is equity in the impact of the charges—firstly to make sure that the road transport industry in toto does not continue to pay a much greater level of taxation than is paid by other industry sectors, and, secondly, to ensure that regional, isolated and rural areas are not paying more than their fair share of the costs of taxation on the road transport industry because of the additional cost to freight that these charges and levels of taxation cause.

They are the two areas of my concern, they are the two areas of major concern to my coalition colleagues, and it is essential that the National Road Transport Commission continue to monitor both of those areas and when the time for review of the present charges comes up, then certainly any discrepancies and unfairness ought to be removed in the next lot of road transport user charges introduced by this Government. With those remarks, I conclude and simply indicate the coalition's support for the legislation.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Chapman for indicating the Opposition's support for the Bill.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

talk.start.para: —by leave—In response to a return to order of the Senate to table documents by 12 o'clock today, I advise the Senate that those documents cannot be provided to the Senate today for this reason: the Pearce report, which was due to have been tabled in the Senate on Monday—that is, four days hence—as a result of urgent requests from all honourable senators to have it earlier, has in fact been produced and will be available to the Senate I hope within the next hour at the latest. The report has been completed and was printed this morning. I am simply waiting now for copies of the tabling statement to be printed with it. As soon as I have both of those documents, I will table the Pearce report. For that reason, I did ask officers of my department to concentrate on getting the Pearce report into this Parliament four days ahead of schedule—that is, today. I think they have done a herculean job. As we say, the impossible we do today, the miracles take a little longer.

para.tab: I just advise the Senate briefly what will be happening with the MDS papers. I am indebted to Senator Alston for narrowing the focus of these papers. As I indicated to the Senate last night, there were 113,000 pages of documentation broadly identified as being covered by the original request. I am now told that Senator Alston's motion has narrowed that down to hundreds, rather than thousands, of pages. Work is commencing on that. Mr Hutchinson of the department is preparing a report on the MDS papers, and in fact I am grateful to the ANU for allowing Professor Pearce some further time to work on this next week.

What will now happen is that the secretary to the department will receive Mr Hutchinson's report into the MDS tender process. I have now arranged for that report and the documentation to go to Professor Pearce and he has agreed to independently review that entire issue as well. I give an undertaking to the Senate—

talk.start.para: —What about the terms of reference?

—They are pretty simple in this case. I have, in fact, just indicated them. There will be a departmental report prepared by Mr Hutchinson of all the papers and Professor Pearce will conduct—it is wide open—his own independent review. He can use whatever discretion he likes and whatever terms of reference he wants. He will conduct an independent review of that report.

para.tab: I give an undertaking that the papers, the report and Professor Pearce's review of the report will be in the hands of the Senate before the Senate rises next week, but no later than Wednesday of next week. I will, as I have done on this occasion—I might add four days ahead of the promised delivery of the Pearce report—attempt to have it in the hands of the Senate at the earliest possible moment prior to Wednesday. But I have to say that Professor Pearce is concerned that, because his name will go on this thing—and academics, particularly legal academics are rather jealous of their reputations, I know—he is given at least a reasonable amount of time to carry out a competent examination and review of the report.

So I give an undertaking to the Senate that this review will be in the hands of the Senate no later than Wednesday of next week. I also give an undertaking, as I have delivered on the Pearce report, that it will be in the hands of the Senate at any earlier time before that if it can be done.

speech.speaker: Alston Sen R.K.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the statement.

speech.para: I apologise for not being here at the commencement of the remarks made by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), so to that extent I may be partly misinformed. Nonetheless, I am sure that the Minister will take every opportunity to correct me if I am misinformed.

para.tab: As I understand it, what the Minister has said is that he will be tabling the Pearce report shortly but that he is refusing to comply with the order of this chamber yesterday that he table documents by 12 noon.

talk.start.para: —Less than 24 hours.

—It has nothing to do with 24 hours. The Minister has had two weeks or more to get all this information together. When the motion was moved and debated yesterday, he did not in any way indicate that he would have difficulty in meeting that request. He rabbited on about 113,000 pieces of paper. As we both know, that was completely irrelevant because by that stage I had narrowed my request down to what I would have thought is probably going to be no more than half a dozen to a dozen documents.

para.tab: If there is voluminous advice—legal, technical and other—then I would have thought that the very least the Minister could have done was to have come in here today and said, `This is what we have identified'. Presumably people have been working on this for at least the last 24 hours.

talk.start.para: —We've got the Pearce report in four days ahead of schedule.

—I am not interested in that. I am talking about the Minister's attitude to a motion which he did not contest. He did not in any shape or form demur, let alone vote against that motion. In other words, the Minister accepted a solemn obligation to table all of those documents. He did not say that it was an impossible task. The very least he could have done was to have tabled a quantity of documents by the appointed hour. I am amazed to hear, as I think I am hearing, that there are so many bits of advice—
—It has always been the case—Senator Bolkus last year, Senator Collins.

—This is not accidental. As Senator Hill points out, this is deliberate. It is a strategy of delay and defer and filibuster and putting it all off as long as possible. It is pretending that somehow this is an incredibly difficult task, that we have got all these loyal and dedicated public servants working 24 hours a day—`They are absolutely swamped, cannot possibly comply with a motion to which Senator Collins took no objection'. This bloke has been sweating over this, or should have been, for the last two or three weeks at least and ought to be blindingly—
—I've been doing one or two other things as well.

—If the Minister has, he has not been concentrating on the main game, because I would have thought that this would be what it ought to be about for him. He ought to have been blindingly aware for the last three weeks that the allegations against him were that he personally did not seek or obtain the necessary advice—
—You are going to have the report in 30 minutes.

—Do not worry about that. We will come to that in a moment. It ought to have been achieved days ago, if not weeks ago. Senator Collins ought to have been acutely aware, because if he had any concept of how to administer his own office in his own interest he would have immediately said, `What documents did I get? What did I ask for? If they are blaming me, tell me; did I do everything reasonable in the circumstances? Do not let us just say, "Go away and find some scalps in the department". Tell me what I did and what I ought to have done'.

para.tab: It is preposterous for Senator Collins to come in here and now refuse to comply with the order of the Senate yesterday. I do not for a moment accept that there is any difficulty in his doing that, at least in part and, indeed, I would say in whole. There cannot be very many pieces of advice. His whole defence in this matter seems to have been, `Hell, why should I have thought of that? This is arcane legal nonsense', or, `There I was sitting up in Darwin on 19 January and staff were on leave and I did not think of doing this, that and the other'. I suspect that there was precious little advice that he got or asked for. Yet here he is having the cheek to say to the Senate that he really cannot comply at all with that request to which he did not object. That is treating the process with contempt. That is making it abundantly obvious that he is not fair dinkum about trying to face up to his own responsibilities.

He clearly knows where he failed and he simply will not acknowledge it. As I apprehend what he said before I arrived, there will only be a couple of documents. The Minister indicated earlier that if I am wrong he will quickly indicate that. Am I correct in assuming that when he does table the Pearce report it will be accompanied by only several documents—

talk.start.para: —Why don't you wait to see; you haven't got long to wait.
—I am just asking the Minister whether he has said how many documents, if any, will be tabled with the Pearce report. If he has not said anything on the subject I will not pursue it at this stage.
—Give me leave when you have finished. I am not going to interject across the chamber. Give me leave and I will respond.
—Why not?
—Senator Alston, you should be talking to the Chair and not to the Minister.

—Therefore, Madam Acting Deputy President, I can proceed only on the basis that, when the Minister does table the Pearce report, he will table precious few accompanying documents. I therefore remind him again of a solemn promise that he gave to the estimates committee to table every relevant piece of paper that was used by the inquirer.
—That is a nice little payback for being honest with you, Senator Hill.
—Order!

—Do not let us have this fatuous and disingenuous nonsense that the Minister does not interject across the chamber, particularly when he is invited to offer a helpful and constructive piece of information. The Minister chooses not to do so, and I am therefore simply pointing out that he told the estimates committee something like, `This is not just any old inquiry. I will ensure that every conceivable piece of paper used by the inquirer will be tabled in the Senate'. I have not got the transcript here. We will look at it a little later.

para.tab: I am putting the Minister on notice that when the Pearce report is tabled we expect him to comply with that undertaking, and that will include not only every document that Professor Pearce looked at but the transcript of the evidence of those who appeared before him.

talk.start.para: —Don't talk nonsense—the transcript is evidence.
—So we are simply to rely on, are we—
—The integrity of Professor Pearce.

—Not the integrity of Professor Pearce at all. It depends very much on the interpretation the Minister places on Professor Pearce's terms of reference, but I can tell the Minister right now that I do not accept that Professor Pearce has any jurisdiction to pass judgment on the Minister's failings. Professor Pearce is asked to address the problems in the department, and therefore there may well be a lot of material there that Professor Pearce does not refer to because it is extraneous, and particularly if the Minister did his usual trick and went along and no doubt tried to persuade Professor Pearce of how important and how accurate and how righteous he has been in the whole process.
—What?
—I do not know whether the Minister did. Did he? Has the Minister been along to give evidence to him?
—Smear me if you like, but leave Professor Pearce out of it.

—I am simply saying that if the Minister went along to see Professor Pearce and went to great lengths to tell the professor how good he had been, Professor Pearce may well take the view, and should, that any self-justification is irrelevant because his terms of reference confine him to passing judgment on the department. Therefore, it is outrageous for the Minister to suggest that his undertaking to the estimates committee does not require him to table every piece of paper, including the transcript. This process will be a farce—it is no fault of Professor Pearce—if the Minister chooses not to table the transcript. If the Minister chooses not to table every relevant piece of paper it will be his decision alone, taken for political purposes to cover his ample hide. It will certainly, I think, contaminate the whole process. It will bring Professor Pearce's name into needless controversy, and it will ensure that the Minister remains the focus, as he deserves to be.
—That is dead right.

—I am glad we agree on something. Let me simply say that the Minister has not provided any reason at all why he is deliberately and flagrantly disobeying the order of the Senate, to which he did not object yesterday. He has not in any shape or form tried to explain why he is not able to table at least some of the documents. I would not accept that that is sufficient. He ought at the very least to know how many documents there are and what they are. He ought to have been able to tell us that before midday. The Minister is deliberately refraining from cooperating with the expressed wish of the Senate. He is clearly wanting to be as protective of his own hide as possible. He is not wanting to provide the documents that will enable the Senate to pass judgment on his responsibility. Once again he is wanting to hide behind a report that he has commissioned and whose terms of reference are limited to the activities of bureaucrats. We know he has been desperate to try to blame the bureaucrats from day one, when he is not busy blaming the Opposition, the Senate, the media, or anyone else.

para.tab: His main game has been to try to shaft the bureaucracy. That is understandable when he is not prepared to face up to his own responsibilities, but it is outrageous for him to somehow pretend that the Pearce report, in the form in which it appears, without all the documentation, somehow addresses the issues of concern. It simply does not. The Minister will be hounded until he fully complies with the request.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: —I want to add a few words to those of my colleague Senator Alston because it seems to me that clearly two separate issues are being confused, I suspect deliberately, by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). Whatever the motive, they are clearly being confused. One issue is a course of action that the Minister has adopted in relation to both the satellite fiasco and the confusion over the MDS process, that is, the reports he is seeking independently from Professor Pearce. With regard to the one he sought in relation to the satellite process, he said that it would be tabled sometime today, and he has indicated to me that he expects two documents to be tabled with that. Also, we now understand a further report will be done in due course by Professor Pearce in relation to the other process, which report will be apparently a review of a review of the process that is going to be undertaken internally by Mr Hutchinson. No doubt they will be interesting documents, but whether they will go to the core of the problems is unclear.

para.tab: As my colleague Senator Alston said, the first Pearce inquiry that the Minister instituted seems to be quite limited in its terms of reference. That is one issue; that is the step that the Minister and the Government decided to take. He has said that those documents will be tabled, and that one will be tabled today. That is separate and distinct from the issue, which is the issue that this Senate should address as of midday today—the obligation that the Senate imposed upon the Minister to table certain documents before the Senate at midday of this day. That is part of our responsibility of accountability.

In the light of the total mess-up in the Minister's communications, it is part of our responsibility to seek to get to the bottom of the problem and to try to determine where there is blame. Is it properly directed at the bureaucrats, which has been the approach of the Minister to date, or is it properly directed at the Minister's staff, which seems to be the approach that he was taking yesterday? Or is it the Minister who should be properly accepting responsibility for the awful mess-up that has occurred in both these areas of satellite and microwave communication?

We want to get to the bottom of that. We have said to the Minister that to do so we require certain documents to be tabled. We have obtained an order of the Senate that he table them, and that he table them by midday of this day. As I understand from my colleague, Senator Alston, the Minister did not even object to that process yesterday.

When I look back upon experiences of recent times, for example, a similar order that we imposed on Senator Evans in relation to the Marshall Islands affair last year, there were all sorts of protests about how difficult it would be and so forth. But Senator Evans, to give him credit, tabled the documents. There were some parts that he preferred not to, and they were whited out. We had discussions and it was handled in a proper way because they were sensitive to individual interests and so forth.

I remember another case only a year or so ago involving Senator Bolkus under the administrative services portfolio in relation to a tendering process. We imposed an order upon him because we wanted to see whether matters had been handled properly or improperly. He was not at all happy with that; nevertheless, he accepted his obligation to comply with the order of the Senate, as all Ministers should be prepared to if we are going to have a decent system of accountability within our democratic structures. He complied with the order also. This Minister has failed to comply with the order of the Senate which was made yesterday:
That there be laid on the table at or before 12 noon on 20 May 1993 the following documents in relation to:
(a) The MDS licence tender process.
(b) The satellite licence tender process.
(i) Copies of any requests—or documents relating to such requests—made by the Minister or his office between 1 January 1993 and 18 May 1993 for technical, legal or other advice.

(ii) Copies of any legal, technical or other advice—or documents including briefing notes or minutes referring to such advice—received by the Minister or his office between 1 January 1993 and 18 May 1993.

speech.para: What I, as one senator, want to know is why the Minister is failing to comply with this order of the Senate. If he gets up—he is going to contribute further in this debate—and says, `I regret that I had insufficient time to put the MDS stuff together', that will be an argument that we will consider in good faith. I will be amazed if he has got the nerve to say, `I have had insufficient time to put the satellite material together', because clearly he and his department have been putting that stuff together now for weeks, and had to put it together for the purposes of the independent inquiry that he set up. In those circumstances, I ask that the question of the Pearce report be put to one side and that the Senate address why this Minister is deliberately breaching an order of the Senate that was passed yesterday.

talk.start.para: —I apologise to the Senate, but unfortunately I was in a meeting when the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) made his statement. To make a decision on this I would appreciate it if the Minister will tell us precisely what he is not prepared to table now, why he is not prepared to table it and when he does expect to table it.

speech.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —I apologise to Senator Bourne. I have covered these issues, but I will cover them again. I will say a few other things as well about something I am really fed up with. I will say a bit more about it when tabling the Pearce report because I really am sick and tired of the continuing misrepresentation by Senator Alston about—
—Forget the theatrics and get on with it.

—No, it is important to say this. In this perfect world that this pretend Minister creates one sits back and does nothing else except put documents together. I will tell honourable senators what actually happened. Senator Alston and the Australian Democrats know it. Senator Hill knows what I told him earlier—and I only told him because Senator Alston was not in the chamber. I asked him to tell Senator Alston about it, which he did.

para.tab: But I will put the record straight now. When the original request was made for MDS documents I told Senator Alston that because of the all-embracing nature of the request the department had identified potentially in excess of 113,000 pages of material. Senator Alston said, `Fine. I'll work on narrowing down that focus', which he did and I thanked him for it. Mr Hutchinson of the department has told me in broad terms that this has narrowed the focus down from thousands to potentially hundreds of pieces of paper, and that is helpful.

But Senator Alston has not told the Senate what happened after that was agreed. There has been absolute misrepresentative nonsense running here this morning. But you just separate the two things out—the Pearce report and the MDS documents. With regard to the Pearce report, Senator Alston said, `I am not interested in that'.

talk.start.para: —For the purposes of the Senate motion.

—This refers to what Senator Alston knows was his gross misrepresentation of undertakings that I gave to everybody about the Pearce report. I will tell the Senate what they were. A conversation took place in this chamber which Senator Alston knows was referred to me rather aggressively yesterday. It is not a matter that I was going to raise, but it is fair to say that I had a blue with Senator Alston yesterday about this and got off my bike—and I think rightly.

para.tab: I will tell you what the original agreement was, Madam Acting Deputy President. I thought it was a reasonable one. It has been a hell of a job, quite frankly, for all of these documents to be perused and for Professor Pearce to not only examine them but also examine officers, write a report and bring it down before the Senate gets up. I undertook that I would have the document in the hands of the Senate by the 25th of this month—next Tuesday. Senator Alston knows about this. I was told by my department, on advice from Professor Pearce, that that was the tightest time in which he thought he could do a responsible job.

Senator Alston and I had a discussion about tabling papers, and I said to Senator Alston—although he tried to deny it yesterday—that even though I was told it was going to be difficult, I would bring forward the Pearce report a full 24 hours to next Monday. I had 10 years in opposition. If one needs more than four days to do a job, then one should hand one's pay cheque back after a fortnight. But Senator Alston did not dispute that. I said, `That will give you Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday—four full days—to examine it'. I further gave an undertaking that it would be in the House at the beginning of the sitting on Monday—not at the end of it, or the night. For all Senator Alston's prevarication and nonsense, that was the agreement and he knew it.

I then got a number of urgent requests—which I did not think were unreasonable, frankly. It would have been tight enough to have got the Pearce report in here on Monday, but I was asked to have it here four days ahead of when I had promised it; that is, today. I said, `All right, I'll try'.

Judging by some comments I saw in the paper this morning, it seems to be impossible in certain quarters to get any fair and reasonable assessment of this. I refer to the little stunt Senator Alston pulled on yesterday afternoon about my alleged lack of communication with my departmental secretary. I will canvass that now, too. I had a meeting with Mr Evans in response to this request from the Australian Democrats and Senator Alston to get the Pearce report in the chamber four days ahead of when I had promised. I told the honourable senator all about this yesterday, and he knows it. I met with Mr Evans at about one o'clock yesterday afternoon and I said, `What I want you to do is to separate out your part of the report. I know you want to have it all tabled together but, sorry, you can't do it. You are going to have to table that separately. What I want you to do is go and see Professor Pearce and find out if we can get the report finished, printed and tabled in this Parliament today.' He said, `All right'. That was at one o'clock yesterday.

The people who actually commented on this in the newspapers I hope will listen to this, in terms of Senator Alston's little stunt yesterday afternoon. That is the undertaking that I gave and I have discharged it. Then I had the comment from Senator Alston, `Oh, well, you won't get it in till midnight then, will you, this evening?' I said, `Well, it might be pretty tight, actually. We might not be able to get it in until midnight but at least that will give you the full weekend to read the thing'.

So that was the conversation I had with my departmental secretary. At that point, despite comments to the contrary, he had not only not received the report but he had not read the report or even seen it. I said, `Go back to the department, crack the whip, get the report, make arrangements now in advance of even getting it for it to be printed quickly, because we need at least 200 copies printed, and you do your bit over the weekend and I will table it separately next week.'

I then spent the next half an hour or so—remember what was happening yesterday—preparing for Question Time. I needed a brief 30 minutes to do that. Have a look at the reports I am referring to and a couple of the opinion columns. These scenarios are outrageous, based on the fabrications of Senator Alston. It was one o'clock when I spoke to the secretary—at that time he did not have the report; had not seen it. I then spent about 45 minutes preparing for Question Time. I came into this chamber yesterday at two o'clock for Question Time. After Question Time I left the chamber and I had a blue with Senator Alston right outside that door, which lasted for about 15 minutes. I then went to get briefed on the Aboriginal—

talk.start.para: —I was there, too.

—I did not want to mention that. Do you understand I was deliberately leaving you out of this, and you jump up and call me a liar the minute I step off the path—and thank God you were there again. You mentioned it, Senator, not me. I was not going to.
—I was there.
—Yes, I know the honourable senator was there but I deliberately did not mention that. I left her out of this. I had a blue outside that door—
—I took you outside, remember?

—That is right. I reminded Senator Alston, and he had forgotten it, about the conversation we had over here. I pointed through the door and said, `You are crazy.' He had also forgotten that Senator Bourne was present at that meeting. I will tell you what: as I said yesterday, I have nothing to fear from this Senate because I have done nothing for the last three weeks except come in and tell the truth. But if you do not tell the truth, I will tell you the thing you have to have—a good memory to go with it. Senator Alston has not. That is his problem. After 15 minutes of argument I went to get briefed on the Aboriginal affairs Bills—just remember what I was doing yesterday afternoon—so I could take them through the Senate.

para.tab: In all this time, I had not gone back to my office—I did not have time to, did not have a chance to pick up a phone. In fact, I had staff running around with briefings on the Aboriginal affairs Bills that went through yesterday. I went back to my office. I did not get there. I was met in the corridor by the staffer who was sitting in this chamber, who said, `Senator Tambling is speaking. The debate is on now. Here are your papers. You have got to go back into the Senate'. I came back into the Senate and spent the rest of yesterday afternoon taking those two Bills through the Senate. I got back to my office at 6 o'clock, and the Pearce report was waiting there at 6 o'clock.

speech.para:
Senator Walters interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —You did not read these articles, Senator Walters, so you do not know what I am referring to, but Senator Alston does. I had not had a chance to speak to my departmental Secretary from one o'clock to six o'clock, for the reasons I have just laid out: because I never got back to my office, even though I tried, till 6 o'clock. The people penning these further outrageous calumnies about lack of communication should review what they wrote against the facts.

para.tab: I have not heard anyone jump up to say, `You are misrepresenting what happened, Senator Collins'. I know that I did not, because what I have said is exactly what happened yesterday afternoon. What Senator Alston has not bothered to tell the chamber is that I agreed to narrow the focus down to these documents on the understanding—which he tried to deny yesterday—that I had brought the Pearce report forward a full 24 hours and was going to table it on Monday. Yesterday afternoon people were saying, `Look, you have to get it in tomorrow'.

Senator Tate interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —I have to say that this is outrageous, Senator Tate. I said, `All right'. I said to the departmental officers, `Look, forget about the MDS stuff temporarily. Concentrate on the Pearce report. I want it in the House before Question Time today'—not midnight, but before Question Time today. They said, `Fine. It will be done'. That is what Senator Alston left out of this nonsense that he has delivered here this morning—as if nothing else had happened in this perfect world that this pretend Minister creates. I can tell him that for real Ministers it is a hard slog. It is a bit different from pretend Ministers. They are the facts about what happened yesterday. I did not get a chance after speaking to my departmental Secretary at 1 o'clock—
—You are not the only one who works hard.

—At that time he did not have the report and had not read it, and because I was in here for hours during the ATSIC debate yesterday afternoon—which those opposite seem to have forgotten—I did not get back to my office till 6 o'clock. I will tell the Senate what I have done in compliance with all those demands—
—You overworked fellow!
—That is something you will never be guilty of, Senator Walters.
—You poor overworked fellow!

—It is a hard-work portfolio, Senator Walters. I have the Pearce report. It is here today. I deliberately wanted it here before Question Time. Those opposite can do their worst with it then. All I am waiting for is the tabling paper to be prepared so that I may table the report. That will be in five minutes, hopefully.

para.tab:
I want to say a few words about Professor Pearce, because I can see where the focus is shifting now—and it is outrageous. Senator Alston should keep it on me. I will tell honourable senators something about Professor Pearce. I refer them to what Senator Michael Baume had to say in this chamber last week about Professor Pearce, and I will table a paper in relation to that. Senator Baume is not bad at throwing abuse, as I am, at the best of times, but Senator Baume gave one of the fairer versions. Senator Baume said—look in
Hansard
—that Professor Pearce is noted as the outstanding expert on administrative law in Australia. But the one concern that Senator Baume raised—and it was valid—was that he acts as a legal consultant, which he does, to a private firm which may have an interest in the contract matter. That is a serious issue, and I took it up immediately. I will table a letter to Jack Lake from the head of my department, who discussed this with Professor Pearce and pointed out the obvious. Frankly, when Senator Baume reads this letter I am sure he will accept it.

Professor Pearce said, `Yes, I do act as legal consultant to a private company but that is not relevant. There is no conflict of interest, because I am investigating'—as the report will clearly show in a minute—`a problem of a failure of process in the department which has nothing whatever to do with any commercial interests of any company'. I table this letter now. So if the one concern that Senator Baume had is removed we are left with Senator Baume's statement—and it is correct—that Professor Pearce is what everyone acknowledges him to be: one of the outstanding experts on administrative law in Australia. Senator Baume is right about that.
But I will tell another little story. A couple of weeks ago a backbencher in the House of Representatives, a former Minister, said to me, `Gee, you've appointed Pearce—

talk.start.para: —He said, `You're mucking this one up'.

—No—Senator Alston can read this in a minute. He said, `You've appointed Dennis Pearce'. I said, ` Well, I haven't. The secretary to the department has'. I said—and I told the Senate this a fortnight ago—`I told him what I wanted—somebody that had very high level experience in both legal and administration issues'. This particular member said to me, `Well, mate, you'd better know that when he was the Commonwealth Ombudsman he didn't hesitate to drop a bucket on the Government and criticise the Government when it was deserved'. I said, `Good'.
—`I deserve it'.

—There is going to be no fairness in this debate; I know that. But I would like to table an article from the
Canberra Times
of 11 May by Jack Waterford. I do not agree with everything that Mr Waterford says but I would commend it to Senator Alston for his reading because it actually talks about—and I had not read it at the time—Professor Pearce's record in criticising the Government while he was Commonwealth Ombudsman. I know there is going to be no fairness in this debate, as I have said, but Senator Alston should keep his focus on me.

para.tab:
The one thing I said to this former Minister who is a lawyer and now a backbencher was, `One of the main reasons I was delighted with Professor Pearce's appointment is that he is an outstanding legal academic—and the one thing I do know about academics of all kinds, but legal academics, is that they are very jealous of their reputations. And I do know that there is no way he will put his name on a report which is not a scrupulous representation of the facts'. That is what I said to this backbencher, and I will table this article from the
Canberra Times
, which I had not read at the time, that confirms it.

So I think people are entitled to accept that Professor Pearce is a person of integrity—a lawyer of great note, who can be expected to have carried out a scrupulous examination of the facts before he put his name on anything.

talk.start.para: —Why don't you just table the documents and get back onto the topic?

—I would if it were not for this nonsense. So I conclude on this tabling statement nonsense by saying this: what has been put before the Senate this afternoon by Senator Alston once again is a total fabrication, and that is not a strong enough word—a total fabrication.

para.tab: Senator Alston knows that I gave a commitment to table the Pearce report on Monday when I agreed to bring the MDS documents in here. And he knows that since then, in response to pressure from the Democrats and the Opposition, I have brought the report forward four days. So I concentrated on that and advised people I was doing it.

I do not know how much unfairer this debate is going to get. But it is about time that at least the misrepresentation from Senator Alston stopped. He has not distinguished himself at all in the last three weeks in this area. It is about time people started realising that.

I have endeavoured to comply reasonably with every request of me. The Pearce report is available—I will get the copies in now. Also, the tabling report, which I will table now, will be brought in here, as I asked for, before Question Time. I cannot do much better than that. I said, `Make sure it is before Question Time, so they'll be able to have a go at Question Time on anything in the report'.

I will finish on the one point of what I said to Senator Hill. What did I say to Senator Hill to tell Senator Alston about the two documents tabled? He should read the report first before he leaps to judgment. As he will see, in the body of the report is a statement from Professor Pearce that he examined all of the relevant documents. There was no let or hindrance to him—he saw the lot. The reason that he has brought in only two, so he is not going to bury us with paper, is that in his judgment—and I will defer to it—those two papers, the two documents, are the only documents that he considers, having looked at all the rest, are relevant.

Why are they relevant? I will tell the Senate why because I will tell it what they show. For three weeks now I have been telling the Senate that I saw only two documents describing the process to me—two only! I did not know what was over in the department. As I said two weeks ago, even a telephone call generates a file note. Professor Pearce saw the lot. But I knew what I had seen: only two documents. Professor Pearce has now discovered that the two documents only that I had been telling the Senate for three weeks I saw are the only two documents that exist.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President—
—You do not want the truth.

—I am conscious of the fact that it is almost a quarter to one. I thought that Senator Bourne had invited Senator Collins to explain why he has not complied with the resolution of the Senate yesterday. I hope he is not suggesting that in any way any discussions in relation to Pearce absolve him from complying with the motion. The point of order is one of relevance—that the Minister has not complied with the request from Senator Bourne, and I invite you to direct him to do so.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)
—There is no point of order.

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, the reason I made the last point, and I know Senator Alston did not like it—was to correct—
—Are you raising a point of order, Minister? It is 12.45 p.m., and at this time it is normal practice to bring on matters of public interest.
—I think this is a matter of public interest. I seek leave to continue the debate.

para.tab: Debate—by leave—continued.

talk.start.para: —The tabling statement has just arrived. The reason I made the last point was because of the further misrepresentation I just heard from Senator Alston about the lack of documents attached to this report. I told Senator Hill precisely what I have just told the Senate: that there is a statement in the Pearce report which attests to the fact that he has seen every document.

—The only reason—and I know Senator Alston does not want to hear this, because it does not support his fanciful conspiracy theories, or untruthful theories—is that the two documents, which I have been telling the Senate for three weeks were the only documents I saw, are the only two documents that exist in terms of advice to me. I answered that, I think, at length.
—Why won't you comply with the order of the Senate?
—It is all here—the tabling statement and the Pearce report—and I would like to go ahead with it.
—Why won't you comply with the order?
—Order!
—I will say it again, Senator. I thought I said it at tedious length. The reason that I cannot—not will not—comply with the order today is that since the order was agreed to—
—This is outrageous.

—I know that the honourable senator tried to misrepresent this yesterday. I agreed yesterday to bring the Pearce report forward a full four days and I have got it in here now, with the tabling statement—not only four days before I said I would bring it in, but before Question Time today. I cannot do better than this. Senator Alston can do his worst with it, but that is the reason; not the continual fabrication and misrepresentation that he has been engaged in for the last three weeks, up to and including yesterday.

—by leave—I want to comment on the difficulty that we have seen in this debate. I think it is very difficult for people to make decisions based on second-hand versions of who said what to whom when and who recollects what about what was said. This is a very unsatisfactory way to conduct a very important debate. I think we should revert to being much more disciplined about putting things in writing and making statements on the record in this chamber. I think that would make the debate on this very important matter much more helpful.

—by leave—I respond briefly to the very valid point made by Senator Kernot by saying that the central proposition is this: the Senate, without demur, resolved that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) be required to table documents. It seems to me, from what has been said today, that Senator Collins's purpose in taking us outside the chamber was to somehow override that clear order of the Senate. What he said today is that, in his view, because of the exigencies of Pearce, he is somehow absolved from complying with a solemn order of the Senate.
—I think you've got the order of events wrong. I don't think you had moved your motion prior to that conversation.
—I had moved it prior to—
—Senator Kernot is saying you hadn't moved the motion prior to the conversation.
—I thought I had. But irrespective of that, can I simply say that Senator Kernot—
—We hadn't taken a vote on it. It illustrates how difficult this is.
—Precisely, and that is why one cannot simply disregard an order of the Senate.
—I am not.

—No, not Senator Kernot. The Senate solemnly resolved—the Minister did not object—that he was required to table documents and somehow his excuse for not even addressing that issue was, `I am busy dealing with Pearce'. At the time, if he had wanted to say to the Senate, `I am not going to be able to comply with that order because I am busy doing other things', he could have got up and argued the toss, voted against it or harangued us in the usual manner. He did none of those things.

para.tab: But even more importantly, he could have come into the Senate at any time prior to 12 noon today and said, `I am not in a position to comply with that order to which I consented yesterday, for the following reasons'. What he has done and what he continues to do is to flagrantly ignore an order of the Senate because it does not suit his convenience.

talk.start.para: —I have been in here all morning.

—Precisely. The Minister has been in here all morning, and has had every opportunity to say to the Senate, `Because I reckon I am too busy with Pearce, I am not going to be able to comply with the order of the Senate'. That is precisely the point. He agrees to table documents, then, for his own purposes, for other reasons—he says Pearce—he does not comply. The Minister has not advanced one reason why he is unable to comply with that request. The only mention he made of it was that the department tells him it has narrowed down that request to hundreds of pages. He has made no attempt to table any of those pages, and no attempt to argue that somehow it has been too difficult for him to comply. He has simply ignored that order of the Senate. He has flouted the requirement. He ought to give the game away.

speech.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I table the Pearce report and attached explanatory tabling statement, and I seek leave to move a motion in relation to it.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I say for the benefit of the House that I did have the courtesy to speak to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) about this, and indicated what I thought was a manageable way of handling the debate, now that I have got it in here before Question Time. It was that I would speak on it as soon as I could and table it; that someone would adjourn the debate, which would give the Opposition the chance to read it; and that negotiations, as they normally do, would take place between the Manager of Government Business in the Senate and the Manager of Opposition Business about bringing the debate on at whatever time is convenient to both the Opposition and the Government.

para.tab: The written statement touches upon the key issues in this matter. I have just explained, again, what I explained to Senator Hill half an hour ago, in full: that I will table the report; that I will make a statement on it; that it would be reasonable for someone then to adjourn the debate, having spoken to my motion to take note of the report; and then the Opposition can bring the debate on later, whenever it wants to—today, if it wants to—having read the report. That is not an unreasonable process. I have now tabled it.

Honourable senators will note from the report that Professor Pearce says that he is not going to, and does not need to, canvass the issue of this definition of ministerial responsibility. There is a good reason for that: there are thousands of definitions. I wish to give the Senate, because this is the nub of the matter—

talk.start.para: —It depends on the Minister, doesn't it?

—No, it does not. I quoted from some conservative Ministers in previous years, and from one in particular. I think that the three areas in the modern parliamentary system that Ministers actually do resign over—

—Mr Deputy President, can I suggest an alternative process? The Minister has suggested that he wanted the matter adjourned after he has put down his tabling statement. We think that is sensible, because we have not read the report. Could I suggest that he seek leave to incorporate his tabling statement? Then we can all take the documents away—the report and the statement—and come back and debate the matter later in the day.
—No, I do not want to do that. I explained to—
—You want to spend as much time as possible—
—That is why I say that one can get no agreement on fairness in this. This has been the central issue of these sittings every day and night for three weeks. I have the report.

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —I will say it now, and for this reason.
—Order! The Minister has the call.
—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: what is the effect of the sessional order that required us to go on to other business at a quarter to one?
—At a quarter to one leave was granted for this debate to be carried on.
—Leave was granted for the Minister to table a report.
—And to table his tabling speech.
—Order!

—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: leave was granted for the previous matter to go past 12.45 p.m., the time at which matters of public interest are called on. After the conclusion of that matter, on the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition for the adjournment of the debate, leave was granted by the chamber for the Minister, Senator Collins, to table the Pearce report and make a tabling statement.
—That is correct. The Minister is in order.

—Mr Deputy President, could I just explain why I think this is the best way of handling it? I am happy to make my statement now, for obvious reasons, because when Opposition senators have as many hours as they like—

—No, I do not need to do it afterwards. When Opposition senators have as many hours as they like to consider everything, they can not only consider the report—they have got the
Hansard
—but they can consider what I have to say about it. I think that that is fair, so I will continue.

para.tab: I was just getting to the point of saying that the key element here—at least, it has been every day and night for the last three weeks—is ministerial responsibility. Let us get right down to the bottom line: whether Ministers should resign and under what circumstances. I have had calls for the last three weeks that I should do so. I will tell honourable senators what I think Ministers should, and do, resign over. There are three grounds.

talk.start.para: —Speak to the Pearce report.

—This is exactly the point of this matter, as the honourable senator knows. I quoted Sir Victor Garland, a former Liberal Minister, who said that a Minister should only resign if the Prime Minister believes it is for the good of the government. But I think there are two other grounds. There are three grounds, I think, that should cause Ministers to resign and, indeed, that the record shows Ministers do resign over. The first is when the Minister loses the confidence—
—Mr Deputy President, could I raise a point of order regarding the relevance of this? What have ministerial responsibility and reasons for resigning got to do with the tabling of the Pearce report?
—The Minister is in order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I am glad this is all going into the
Hansard
. Has anybody been listening to the calls from those opposite for the last three weeks? This report is to determine, independently, whether I should resign or not. For Senator Macdonald to pretend that that is not the case on some obscure—

para.tab:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —I will continue, Mr Deputy President, regarding this specious point of order. There are three grounds on which Ministers should resign.
—The Minister should ignore the interjections.

—I will. The first is if the Minister has lost the confidence of the Prime Minister and—in my case, I will extend that net a bit further—his senior colleagues. I do not think they will be embarrassed if I name them. There are five Ministers in this Government whom I have known for something like 15 years and to whom I regularly go to seek advice on political issues. They proffer it to me unasked very often. Those Ministers are: the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, Senator Ray, Senator Richardson, Mr Beazley and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I lived in Arnhem Land, as honourable senators know, for four years.
—Is this relevant?

—Yes, very relevant. Twice in my life I have witnessed people being sung to death, which is what has been happening to me for the last three weeks. People refer to it as pointing the bone. That is only done in Central Australia, but the mob I lived with for four years, whose language I still speak and whose ceremonies I—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Apart from its lack of relevance, I think this is highly offensive. I find it offensive that our right to expect proper accountability of a Minister is being spoken of in terms of somebody being `sung to death', to use the Minister's expression. He has sought leave to table a report and a statement. If he would table the statement we could get on to the business that the Senate is assigned to undertake at a quarter to one each Thursday and we could come back to the debate later in the afternoon when we have all had a chance to read both the report and the statement. The Minister seems to be distracted, if I might say so, with respect.
—The Minister is speaking to the motion, which he had leave to move.

—I will finish in no more than two minutes. I will conclude my speech by stating what I think are the three grounds on which Ministers should resign. In my view, the first is that a Minister has lost the confidence of the Prime Minister and, in my case, a number of senior colleagues. The second is that a Minister has committed some gross personal impropriety, either inside or outside Parliament. I talked to Senator Michael Baume about this the other day. He would agree that history seems to indicate that that is either corporate or sexual impropriety. It would include such things as a Minister sleeping with a Russian spy—or perhaps kissing Senator Bishop on national television. The third ground, which is very important, is that a Minister has misled the Parliament. In my view, if he has misled the Parliament, he should resign instantly.

para.tab: I say that the Pearce report indicates, firstly, as honourable senators will see, that I certainly know that I have the full support of the Prime Minister on this issue and that of my senior colleagues whom I have mentioned. Secondly, it indicates that I have committed no personal impropriety either inside or outside the Parliament. Thirdly, the Pearce report will indicate that for the last three weeks I have told the Senate nothing but the truth.

talk.start.para: —Order! The Senate will move to matters of public interest.

debate.sub2.title: Anton Breinl Centre for Tropical Health and Medicine

speech.speaker: Macdonald Sen I.D.

talk.start.para: —The Battle of the Coral Sea was a significant turning point in the Second World War. It constituted Japan's first major setback after Pearl Harbour, it saved Port Moresby from a combined land and sea attack, and it ensured the safety of Australia from potential invasion. It also paved the way for the subsequent decisive Allied victory in the Battle of Midway.

para.tab: Last year, on the 50th anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea, celebrations were conducted all over Australia, and major celebrations were held in Townsville and Cairns in North Queensland. In the delightful little seaside town of Cardwell, situated approximately halfway between Townsville and Cairns, the townsfolk many years ago decided to establish a lasting memorial to those who participated in the Coral Sea Battle. Cardwell is situated on the shores of Rockingham Bay, where the Coral Sea touches mainland Australia. It was approximately 500 miles due east of Cardwell that the Battle of the Coral Sea took place in 1942.

The Coral Sea Memorial Committee in Cardwell decided to turn a 16-acre shorefront reserve into a lasting memorial, and the then Queensland Governor, Sir James Ramsay, initiated the project back in 1984. Last year, on the 50th anniversary of the battle, the park was dedicated by Rear Admiral Guy Griffiths, retired, and Mrs Jean Farcombe, the widow of the captain of HMAS
Australia
at the time of the Coral Sea engagement.

I have been privileged to be part of this memorial, some years ago meeting on the site before any work had been commenced, when the site was simply virgin bush above the high-water ridge overlooking Rockingham Bay. I was also privileged to be part of the dedication ceremony on the 50th anniversary last year. The park has been designed so that palm trees are planted throughout the park and sponsored by various groups and individuals.

This year I was able to unveil a plaque dedicated by Liberal senators in Queensland—Senator MacGibbon, Senator Parer, Senator Herron and myself. Our plaque sits alongside those from many other groups and individuals as a lasting memorial to those who served in the Battle of the Coral Sea.

This year I was also privileged to read a message on behalf of John Hewson, who had been officially invited to the ceremony. In his message John Hewson made specific reference to the significance of the Battle of the Coral Sea and of the continuing United States-Australian defence relationships which were initially formed in that battle 51 years ago. Dr Hewson congratulated those in the Cardwell community who have worked so hard to ensure a continuing commemorative park.

I wish to place on record my congratulations to the chairman of the committee, Albert Ebert; vice-chairman, Bill Phillips; secretary, Sue Lang; Les Kirk; Len Brown; Councillor Flegler; Councillor Mealing; Bob Mutton; Bob Braid; Vince Griffiths; Stella Gibbs; Bob Carroll; Rob Lang; Stan Flegler; Peter Jones; Shelley Bates; and John Sutherland. As well, the Cardwell Shire Council and its chairman, Councillor Tip Byrne, have tangibly assisted in the project. Albert Ebert and his committee are just ordinary Australians but typify those in our country who are proud of our flag and of our heritage and of those who gave their lives to protect our way of life and freedom.

There was a particularly large contingent from Her Majesty's Australian Cruises Association. There was a particularly large complement of veterans who served on board HMAS
Australia
and HMAS
Hobart
. The Navy was represented by Commander Simon Hart, who gave the principal address. HMAS
Tarakan
, under the command of Lieutenant Mark Burling, was moored offshore from the park and the crew of the ship took a special part in the parade.

The member for the federal electorate of Kennedy, Mr Katter, and the member for the State electorate of Hinchinbrook, Mr Rowell, were also present. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs had been invited and was, I thought, rather unusually, represented by an officer of the veterans' affairs department. With no disrespect to that officer, who represented the Minister admirably, it did seem somewhat a shame that the Minister could not find a parliamentary colleague who could represent him at such an important function.

Like any other community in Australia, Cardwell is made up of a good cross-section of genuine Australians, with the occasional character who stands out. I was privileged to meet one of those characters, a 90-plus veteran, Vince Raleigh, who served in the Merchant Marine at the time of the First World War and actually delivered ammunition to Anzac Cove at Gallipoli. I also met a Mr Jack Gillen, a 93-year-old veteran of the First World War.

I have the greatest admiration for the people of Cardwell and the hardworking committee for their efforts in creating this lasting memorial to the Battle of the Coral Sea. It should be compulsory for all honourable senators to visit North Queensland regularly, as it is without doubt the best part of Australia. If honourable senators ever do have the privilege and opportunity of visiting the north, they should make the effort to drive to Cardwell and inspect the Coral Sea Memorial Park, to pay their respects and to get an appreciation of what ordinary patriotic Australians do for their country.

I have a few minutes left so I will raise another matter of public interest that I think that this Parliament should be aware of. I hope Senator Richardson might take note of what I am going to say. I see Senator Reynolds is on the speakers list to follow me today; hopefully, Senator Reynolds may make some comment on this matter as well. It relates to the Anton Breinl centre at James Cook University.

I am concerned at reports that the Federal Government is about to scale back the role of the Anton Breinl Centre for Tropical Health and Medicine, which is based at James Cook University in Townsville. Some $500,000 in general funding for research into tropical disease and training of people in public health may now be withdrawn from the centre in favour of a planned expansion of facilities in Brisbane. The director of the centre has said that such a funding cutback would mean a serious down scaling in research and a 50 per cent reduction in staff numbers.

A working party on public health development established by the Government has apparently recommended that major public health research and education facilities be limited to one per State and, further, that a national centre for international and tropical health, incorporating Aboriginal health, be established. The working party has recommended that this national centre be located in Brisbane. The recommendations largely ignored the contributions and existing facility of the Anton Breinl centre. The Anton Breinl centre's role may be greatly eroded under this proposed plan.

It will come as no surprise to those of us from the north to learn that the working party included no-one from northern Australia. The two people on it came from the University of Queensland in Brisbane. The working party was clearly unrepresentative and has resulted in decisions which do not consider the special needs of health in northern Australia.
I am very concerned at this example of the north again being ignored. The Anton Breinl centre is a very important facility which should be supported by the Government. It is at the coalface of research into some of the very important diseases in northern Australia, many of which are not understood by people outside the north.

Only this week we had the Queensland Health Minister, Mr Hayward, displaying quite incredible ignorance of how widespread and important is the terrible tropical disease, dengue fever. Meliodosis, another example, is a lethal and little understood tropical disease which, in the last proper wet season, claimed a number of lives in North and Far North Queensland. The disease is particularly savage, claiming its victims with little warning—in a matter of days. This disease, the bacteria of which reside in the soil, is most dangerous during wet weather. It is only thanks to the drought that this disease has not caused more deaths over the last two years. Ross River fever is another debilitating tropical disease which needs much more research. The Anton Breinl centre has been heavily involved in vital work on all of these diseases.

In the field of education the centre plays a very important role through its courses for over 100 graduate students in public health and tropical medicine at diploma, masters and PhD levels. I am advised by the centre that some 20 per cent of the students at the college are from Aboriginal and Islander communities, and that there is a special focus on Aboriginal health, which I think is very important. Block courses are conducted across northern Australia in Nhulunbuy in the Northern Territory and Broome in Western Australia.

I am somewhat surprised that the Labor member for Herbert, Mr Lindsay, has not lifted a finger in the last week since the prospect of funding cutbacks has been raised. I would have thought that Mr Lindsay, as the member for one of the northern seats, would, like me, be getting behind the Anton Breinl centre. In 1991, Mr Lindsay told Parliament:

speech.para: Unquestionably, the Anton Breinl Centre is making a significant contribution to public health education and training in Northern Australia . . . the centre has shown an outstanding ability to respond to the needs of public health education and research in North Queensland.

So I have been very surprised that Mr Lindsay has been silent in response to the concerns expressed by the Anton Breinl centre. I understand that the Anton Breinl centre is today delivering a submission to the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, in the hope that cutbacks in funding and an erosion of the role of the centre can be averted. The submission seeks an expansion in support from the Commonwealth from 1995, when the current funding contract expires, which would include work at the Menzies School of Health Research in Darwin. I know Senator Richardson has met in recent days with the director of the centre, Professor Wronski, and I would urge Senator Richardson to reconsider the recommendations of the working party, to ensure that the role of the Anton Breinl centre is expanded rather than scaled back, and to make sure that the special needs of northern Australia are not overlooked, yet again, by this Government.

speech.speaker: Kemp Sen C.R.

talk.start.para: —As honourable senators will be aware, there have been many issues regarding pay TV which have been extensively canvassed in this chamber over the last two weeks or so—indeed, over the last two or three hours. I will not traverse the ground which has already been covered. However, an issue has emerged which, I believe, is of great interest to Victorians. Specifically, when all these matters are finally resolved, where will the ABC pay TV headquarters be located? This is no trivial issue; some 240 jobs are at stake.

para.tab: Indeed, the acting Managing Director of the ABC, Mr Conroy, advised the Senate estimates committee hearing last week that it was estimated there might be 100 jobs on a pay TV news channel, and up to 140 jobs on a second channel which would be a children's channel with an arts component and a documentary component. In addition, Mr Conroy emphasised the stimulatory effect which pay TV will have and its potential for providing significant knock-on effects to other sectors of the industry. Indeed, I believe these knock-on effects will lead to a multiplier impact and will result in a very significant boost in jobs for people such as actors and producers, and production houses and industries generally affiliated with the television industry. It will provide major career opportunities for the media in Melbourne, particularly the men and women employed by the ABC who, very sensibly, prefer to live in Melbourne.

The location of the ABC's pay TV headquarters and production facilities is currently under consideration by the management and board of the ABC. It appears that the two locations being actively considered are Melbourne and Sydney. There is no technical reason why ABC pay TV should not be based in Melbourne. At a Senate estimates hearing, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, perhaps reflecting the interests of the Northern Territory, said:

speech.para: With the technology available these days I am sure it—
and he meant pay TV—
could effectively operate from the top of Ayers Rock.

I do not believe that there is any economic reason why Sydney should be preferred to Melbourne for the location of this very important facility.
However, the decision that is made will touch on the more fundamental issue of whether the ABC is truly a national broadcaster or whether it is simply the Sydney broadcasting corporation masquerading as a national broadcaster.

para.tab: The ABC TV budget totals some $360 million. It is collected, as honourable senators will be aware, from taxpayers all around Australia. The ABC spends some 70 per cent of this TV budget in New South Wales, yet only 34 per cent of the population of Australia live in that State. I simply do not believe that this concentration of ABC activities in one capital city can be justified. Whatever the historical reasons for concentrating activities in Sydney, modern technology has opened up the opportunity for a major decentralisation of ABC activity. It is also worth noting that the other public broadcaster—the Special Broadcasting Service—has also concentrated its activities in Sydney. Melbourne has excellent facilities and staff resources on which to base this major new ABC venture. I urge the ABC board to take this opportunity to demonstrate that the excessive concentration of ABC activity in Sydney is coming to an end.

talk.start.para:
—I want to bring to the Senate's attention the question of the immigration to Australia many years ago of a person who was subsequently granted citizenship and who, allegedly, was involved with the Hungarian secret police. He was gaoled for his maltreatment of prisoners in Hungary during the Stalinist period. Honourable senators may have noted this story which first became public, to my knowledge, in an extraordinary report—which I understand is authentic—in the
Sydney Morning Herald
of 27 March.

para.tab: The article tells an extraordinary story of events regarding the immigration to Australia of a person who was allegedly involved in the imprisonment, and possibly later death, of a Mr Istvan Somogyi in Hungary in the mid-1950s. Istvan Somogyi's wife—now Mrs Magda Bardy—migrated to Australia with her son in the second half of the 1950s. She and her first husband, Istvan Somogyi, had been imprisoned in Kistarcsa in 1951 during the Stalinist period by the Hungarian secret police, the AVH. Mrs Bardy served 2 1/2 years in gaol. On her release, she found that her husband had died in prison as a result of torture.

Since the collapse of the communist regime in Hungary in 1989 Mrs Bardy has been searching Hungarian records to track the fate of her first husband. Through her investigations she has learned that the person who signed the orders for her internment and the internment of her husband probably migrated to Australia, and has been living in Sydney since 1957, just a few kilometres from where Mrs Bardy lives. She found her husband's arrest document was signed by a person called Tibor Vajda by order of the head of the secret service. His crime was that her husband `was aware of smuggling of people and goods and provided a hand in these', and his internment was `for state security reasons'.

The same Tibor Vajda was one of the many post-war communist hardliners who were arrested in the power struggles following Stalin's death. In January 1953 he was convicted by the military court of Budapest and sentenced to six years gaol for maltreating prisoners and preparing false statements. In October 1956 came that short-lived revolution, the surge towards freedom in Hungary, which was so ruthlessly crushed. Vajda was one of the thousands of AVH agents who fled Hungary at this time.

Through her investigations, Mrs Bardy found that the Tibor Vajda who arrested her and her husband was a dental technician who had joined the Hungarian secret police in 1946. He was a senior investigator, the leader of his party sub-branch. It was also revealed that Vajda had studied for a year in 1950 at the KGB Dzerzhinsky Academy in Moscow.

Mrs Bardy has also found that a Tibor Vajda and his family had migrated to Australia in February 1957 on an Italian ship, the
Flaminia
. She has discovered many coincidences which have led her to believe that the Tibor Vajda who has lived in Sydney for many years and practices there as a dentist is the same person who interned her husband, who tortured her in gaol, and who may possibly have been involved in the torture of her husband leading to his death.

The coincidences include the fact that the birth dates of both Tibor Vajda and his wife corresponded to the birth dates of Tibor and Eva Vajda as recorded in government documents from the archives of the Hungarian Government. Vajda's personal details in the New South Wales Dental Board records also matched. Information contained in Vajda's curriculum vitae, signed by him on 12 January 1952, corresponded to the general report of him being a dental technician in Hungary. From a search of his company records Mrs Bardy found that Vajda's signature corresponded with the signature on her husband's arrest papers. A forensic expert believes that the signatures were `very probably' written by the same Vajda.

Mrs Bardy believes that Tibor Vajda has provided false information to the Australian Government. He claimed that he graduated from Budapest University as a dentist in July 1949. However, this is at odds with information that Mrs Bardy has received which says that the Budapest University had no record of a graduate by the name of Tibor Vajda born in 1924.

Mrs Bardy has lived in Sydney for most if not all of the period since she came to Australia in the late 1950s, and in 1984 she was awarded an Order of Australia for work in a Darlinghurst sheltered workshop. She is a constituent of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, and Dr Hewson has written to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) asking him to investigate the matters raised by Mrs Bardy following her taking it up with her local member.

All the points that I have made today are based on the report in the
Sydney Morning Herald
of 27 March. As I understand it, the allegations in that report have not been refuted. On the basis of that report, the Minister has been asked to investigate the matters raised by Mrs Bardy. The representations were made to the Minister on 28 April. I hope the Minister will report urgently on this matter. In particular, I hope he will find out when Mr Vajda and his family migrated to Australia, when they were granted citizenship, and what documentation they were required to provide.

It is also worth noting that in 1960 Mr Vajda made his first application to practise as a dentist in Australia and that that application was refused, although that decision was overturned the following year after intervention by his then local member of parliament. I hope that when the Minister is investigating these matters he will also report on the details of the initial refusal of the application. I also hope that the Minister will report—depending on the circumstances and the facts, of course—on whether it is within his powers to revoke the citizenship of Australians who have knowingly provided false information to the Australian Government.

I raise this matter because I think it is a compelling story which shows great fortitude on the part of a woman and her son who suffered depravation in the early 1950s, and who have now been good citizens of Australia for more than 30 years. In the interests of all concerned—and not least Mr Vajda—it is a matter that requires the attention of the Minister. It is a matter that probably affects us all in some way. It is for those reasons that I hope the Minister will respond properly to the approaches that have been made to him.

debate.sub1.title: Lake Eyre Region: World Heritage Listing

talk.start.para: —I take the opportunity provided by the matters of public interest debate to refer to a meeting of the Lake Eyre catchment group that occurred yesterday. That meeting passed a resolution opposing the World Heritage listing of that area. I have had an interest in the matter of the World Heritage listing of the Nullarbor for a long time, and it is a matter which I have raised from time to time in this chamber.

para.tab: I am very pleased to report to the Senate—and I think it is the first time this has been reported—that the World Heritage listing of the Nullarbor will not proceed unless this Government breaks its word. The Government has promised that the listing will not proceed unless all of the governments—that is, the Western Australian Government, the South Australian Government and, of course, the Federal Government—proceed unanimously with the nomination of the Nullarbor region.

I know that Premier Richard Court, who accompanied me to the Nullarbor nearly two years ago, has a personal interest in this issue. Given Mr Court's interest, I know that the Western Australian Government will not be recommending the Nullarbor for World Heritage listing for many good reasons which I have already outlined on a number of occasions in the Senate and in other places. So the Nullarbor has been saved.
