para.tab: No. 11—Australian Wool Realisation Commission Amendment Bill 1993;
(3) That this order have effect till 2 p.m. this day.

Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by
Senator Faulkner
:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

talk.start.para: —The Dairy Produce Amendment Bill will give the Australian Dairy Corporation more commercial flexibility in financing its arrangements, a move welcomed and supported by the Federal coalition. Under this legislation, the corporation will be free to undertake futures dealings with banks, although this will be restricted to hedging.

para.tab: The intention is to remove uncertainty surrounding the ability of the corporation to secure exchange rates and cover the financial risks involved in international trade. The powers are similar to those previously given to other marketing authorities such as the Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wheat Board.

The legislation is significant because the dairy industry is the largest food processing industry in Australia as well as our largest value-adding agricultural industry. Export income from dairy products this financial year is expected to exceed $900 million, up from $761 million last financial year. This year, Australia's production of milk is expected to exceed 7,000 million litres of milk, the highest level of production for 20 years. It is interesting to note that these high levels of production have not resulted in calls for cuts in production, but have been welcomed by the industry.
The only product still causing concern is butter.

The dairy industry has been through a period of dramatic rationalisation over the last 20 years and is now enjoying a period of stability, as well as relatively high returns for farmers. Some 20 years ago, there were 47,000 dairy farmers in this country. Today there are only about 8,000 dairy farmers and they are producing as much milk, if not more, than was produced by the 47,000 farmers 20 years ago.

Our dairy farmers are certainly among the most efficient in the world. In just 10 years, they have achieved a 25 per cent increase in the annual amount of milk produced per cow through better breeding, concentration on nutrition, and so on. Ten years ago the milk per cow was about 3,000 litres; this year it will top 4,000 litres.

Over the last decade, the average herd size has more than doubled, as a result of the rationalisation of the number of farmers, while sales of milk have continued to increase. In 1991-92, for example, sales went up by 32 million litres to a total of 1.8 billion litres.

Even so, Australia's per capita consumption of liquid milk, at 102.9 kilograms per annum, is a long way behind many other comparable countries. The Irish consume 184 kilograms of milk per year per head of population; the Finns, 172 kilograms per year per head; the Scandinavians, around 156 kilograms; and New Zealanders, 134 kilograms. The Danes, the Swiss and the Americans also consume more milk per head than we do, so there is definitely room for expansion. I am confident that the dairy industry, which is capable of innovation and clever marketing, will capitalise on that obvious potential in the domestic market.
My colleague in the other place, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), sounded a warning last week when he said that there was no room for complacency in the dairy industry. He stated:
The dairy industry, although it has more confidence than it has had for a long time, still feels very exposed and vulnerable to sudden shifts on the international trading scene.

speech.para: Then in a reference to New Zealand, he added:

Dairy farmers have learnt for a very long time to compete in the international market place without government assistance. They have to cope now with imports from New Zealand under closer economic relations, but they cannot do it while they have a fixed structure of costs that is many times more oppressive than that which their New Zealand counterparts have.

On international trade, may I remind honourable senators, the European Community is still heavily subsidising a range of products, including dairy products. Our dairy farmers have traded into these highly corrupted markets for years without government assistance. They have also competed against them in the domestic market without tariff protection, apart from an EC tariff quota arrangement. This arrangement means that, after the European Community has shipped 11,000 tonnes of cheese into Australia, we are entitled to add an import duty which is equivalent to the amount of export subsidy paid by the EC to its exporters. Meanwhile, Australia is only permitted to export 3,000 tonnes into the EC and must pay a tariff of more than 20 per cent.

para.tab: Regrettably, many people in Europe do not realise how much it costs them as taxpayers to keep the EC dairy industry going. Last March, the EC cut some of its huge subsidies and I understand that this move has the potential to lift returns to the Australian dairy industry by $30 million. Yet, despite the recent cut in payments to exporters, the EC still pays them rates up to about 240 per cent over the world price.

When the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), spoke on this Bill in the other place, he expressed grave concerns about the operation of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. `Our dairy exporters', he said, `would be considerably helped if the Government let the industry become more responsible for its own quality control and forced the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to be more efficient'.

AQIS currently charges the dairy industry about $2 million a year, 70 per cent of which is for overheads, while 30 per cent is for the cost of inspection. Like my shadow Ministry colleague, I believe those figures should be reversed, thereby giving the dairy industry a 50 per cent reduction in the cost of export inspection.

The dairy industry is highly sophisticated. It is adopting world best practice quality management techniques at a faster rate than any other commodity group, and is understandably keen to deregulate exports. The Federal coalition supports these aims and believes that AQIS should wind back rather than expand its involvement in the dairy industry.

Currently, milk designed for manufacture must be passed by the State milk authority and then AQIS, making the dairy industry unique in the processed food industry and unlike other sectors such as biscuit and confectionery manufacture. Surely, if the milk meets the standard of the State milk authorities and is fit for us to drink then it is also fit for manufacture into dairy products. Instead, we have a system so ridiculous that if a dairy is being modified for a dairy company which produces for both domestic and export markets, the building must be approved by both State and Federal bodies. It is time the Federal Government cut the red tape and seriously considered viable alternatives such as State accreditation.

As the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) pointed out, the cost of doing business in this country is too high, and the Federal Government must create a better economic environment for our export industries. So far, the dairy industry has led the way with value added product, but its expansion is constantly hampered by high costs and closed markets. Currently, milk tankers are subject to a wholesale sales tax of 20 per cent. There are 18 tyres on a milk tanker, and the tax on each tyre is $90. Excise on fuel is about 27c a litre, and transport costs are about double those faced by many of our international competitors.

The Federal Government has also neglected bilateral agreements which could open up many of the currently closed markets in Asia for packaged dairy products. Clearly the Federal Government has much to do for and on behalf of the dairy industry. The Federal coalition supports this legislation.

talk.start.para: —I need to make a few comments about the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill. I go back to my maiden speech—a fair while ago, now—in which I discussed at some length the dairy industry in my own State. In those days the industry was virtually down and out, and I am particularly pleased that from that position it has made a most extraordinary recovery—a recovery that is an example to any of the other industries that have been on hard times.

para.tab: This legislation is supported by the coalition. It was instigated by the industry which, in an effort to improve its own flexibility and its own marketing arrangements, wanted an extended range of financial management which the previous Act did not cover. That is really all the legislation is about. Having said that, it is well worth while to have a look at just what has happened and is happening on an Australia-wide basis.

I, too, would like to mention the question of costs. It is absolutely ridiculous for Australia to be trying to compete on international markets when we do not allow our industries to compete on international terms. We must allow this to come about. It is not only a matter of allowing it; we must make it come about. We cannot expect our producers to compete on this ridiculous pattern in which we have all the costs at our end and all sorts of obstacles at the other end as well. We do not put obstacles of any magnitude on the product coming in, we only put them on the product going out. The industry has been trying to cope with this for a long time.

This particularly applies to our situation with New Zealand. We meet New Zealand on international markets in which its costs, overheads and government imposts are nothing like ours. It is a crazy situation. We have the opportunity to produce more product into an international field where there is a market for the things that we are now producing, and we do not do it.

I, too, have been known to make comments about the operation of AQIS, and I think this is another opportunity for me to do exactly that. There is no reason why it cannot be arranged that producers accept responsibility for the quality of their own product and pay penalties if it is not good enough. But they are being obstructed by enormous costs. I recently had a case where two AQIS officers were appointed and moved to King Island but there were no houses for them. This went on for some months until we were able to arrange that accommodation. I question whether having two more officers on King Island was necessary, because the work could have been done by the meatworks and the dairy organisation.

I think it is most impressive that, 40,000-odd dairy farmers having now been reduced to about 14,000, production has gone up to the extent that it has. I give great credit to people like John Bennett and Pat Rowley for the enormous amount of leadership they have demonstrated and for the way in which they have been able to hold a very fragmented industry together and, in very difficult times, to keep farmers moving in a forward direction so that not only are they able to survive but they can survive with dignity and with profit.

There is still a big future for the industry. The real difficulty in my area is that there is only a certain amount of land suitable for dairy farming. It just so happens that most of that land is also suitable for growing cash crops. So there is now very stiff competition between what can be made from dairying and what can be made from other products. I hope that it works out to the advantage of the farmers and that they may be able to get a better price by being under competition for the use of their land.

The industry was all but gone in 1976-77. It is now able to recover and is looking to increase its productivity from three per cent per annum to five per cent per annum. I believe that it will. In Tasmania alone, this would be worth an extra $20 million to our economy. I am amazed at the new range of products that have come into the area. We have one factory producing UHT products, everything from custards to cat food. We now have new factories being built for specialist forms of cheese. We have whey powders of pharmaceutical grades being prepared for baby food and so on. In cheeses, yoghurts and all sorts of products the progress has been quite outstanding. I look forward to seeing those products continue to expand in the years ahead. As time is running out, I announce that I support the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

question.speaker: Calvert Sen P.H.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. On Wednesday last—12 May—I asked the Minister a specific question as to whether he was aware of internal investigations by AOTC regarding alleged travelling rorts. The Minister replied:

question.para: No, I have no advice on that specific issue which, I must say, I am not surprised about.

I draw the Minister's attention to a letter signed by him of 1 September 1992 addressed to my colleague the honourable member for Cowper, Mr Garry Nehl, regarding this matter in which he not only refers to claims of alleged rorts in Telecom but also indicates that he has requested a report on the matter. I ask: did the Minister mislead the Senate in his answer on Wednesday, 12 May, when I have in my hand a letter which he himself signed and which clearly shows that he did have knowledge of this matter? Did the Minister in fact read the letter of 1 September 1992 or does he make a habit of signing letters without reading them? Will the Minister make available the report from AOTC on alleged travel rorts in Telecom?

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable senator's time has elapsed.

—No, I did not mislead the Senate, as I never do. Honourable senators will recall what I said to Senator Calvert. Having had this question directed to me, I examined the question brief on telecommunications and Telecom that was in front of me in the chamber and said, accurately and honestly, that I did not have a brief on it. I cannot honestly recall the letter that I signed about this in January or whenever it was, but what I told the honourable senator was the truth. I looked in the brief. There was no specific information in the question brief which, as I said, did not surprise me because it was a matter of some detail and that kind of detail is not normally found in question briefs for questions without notice.

para.tab: What I then did—and I will check with my office and if there is any further advice I will ask it to send it down now—was say I would pursue the issue, and I have. I asked my office to get an answer for the Senate as soon as possible. I have no doubt that that is being done; and, if it is available now, I will provide it now.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Is the Minister aware of the statement made on 18 May by the Council of Australian Museum Associations on relationships between museums and Australia's indigenous peoples? What is the Government's position on the protection of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural property held in public collections and the return of significant items of cultural property to their rightful owners?

—Yes, I certainly am aware of that statement, which I very much welcome. It was appropriately made on International Museums Day and concerned the relationship between Australian museums and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It is very important to note that the statement was developed in consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and provides for a stronger role for indigenous people in policy making, management and care of their cultural property in public collecting institutions. It indicates that museums will undertake to provide information to communities in an accessible form so that rightful owners may request the return of objects, and museums will extend their programs to assist communities to care for cultural property in their own keeping places and in community museums.

para.tab:
This is very consistent with the Government's election policy statement in
Distinctly Australian
, where we renewed our commitment to support Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural heritage, particularly the return of significant cultural property to rightful owners. In that area, we will be giving—as I think most people would agree is appropriate—a priority to the return of skeletal remains. I am talking to my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs about the priority framework for implementing those commitments.

There is recognition of the importance of these issues and the primary rights of indigenous people to ownership of their cultural property, et cetera. On the basis of those commitments and that history, I was a little surprised by announcements by the Victorian Government that there was going to be developed in Melbourne a federally funded museum of Aboriginal culture. Let me say quite clearly that, contrary to any impression given in media reports today, the Commonwealth has provided no commitment whatsoever to the Victorian Government to assist in funding the development of a museum of Aboriginal culture in Victoria.

talk.start.para: —Has Kennett got it wrong?

—It is obvious that we would not do that because, with the Commonwealth's general priority in this area and through the development of the National Museum of Australia, this Parliament has given us a specific statutory responsibility for the representation and interpretation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture. That must be our priority in this area and it will be our first priority in this area. We can develop the gallery of Aboriginal Australia within it for much less than $70 million.

para.tab: If we were—as we might be—prepared to consider cooperation with the States in developing proposals in conjunction with the National Museum of Australia, we would of course consider any claim by Victoria. But I am well aware that there are other States which have interesting proposals and programs and significant important collections in this area. They would wish to be involved in any discussion about where the Commonwealth would assist with further funding of museums with regard to the history of our indigenous Australians.

There is no commitment by the Commonwealth to the Victorian Government in this area. Our first priority is and will remain to the National Museum of Australia. If we are to go beyond that, or to develop further proposals in conjunction with the States, Victoria's claim will be considered but only in conjunction with those very legitimate claims of several other States which have already been raised with us.

question.block.title: Aviation: Centre for Air Traffic Services

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Why was merit abandoned as the criterion for job selection for students from the Centre for Air Traffic Services?

—I am not aware that merit has ever been abandoned in that sense. In terms of training of air traffic controllers, there is an important issue which, of course, concerns those honourable senators who come from Tasmania, and it is a position which the Civil Aviation Authority has adopted and which I fully support.

para.tab: For some years, training of air traffic controllers has been conducted in a tertiary institution in Tasmania. For some time, the CAA has expressed its concern about the high failure rate, if you like, of the graduates from that institution to actually make it on the job. The change results from that concern and the decision of the CAA to establish a national system of air traffic control which involves the establishment of two complete backup air traffic control systems in Brisbane and Melbourne—that is, complete duplications of the air traffic control system that can be used in the case of a failure. Those backup systems are absolutely ideal for training air traffic controllers on the job.

I gave this matter a great deal of consideration when I was the then Minister, and it was felt by the CAA—and, I might add, in accordance with practice around the world—that it would get a far greater degree of rigorous control, and of course the control has to be very rigorous in training these officers, if they were trained on the job rather than having them trained in a separate institution in a simulated air traffic control situation. Having seen it work, let me explain how it works. The backup systems are in a position to actually replicate the real life situation that is going on in the control room next door. In other words, what is actually happening in the air can be brought up on those screens at the same time, with of course the satisfaction that, if the trainee controllers do not do it properly, two aircraft do not actually collide with each other while the trainees are training.

With the establishment of what is going to be very sophisticated and expensive backup equipment it made far more sense to utilise that backup equipment for the training of air traffic controllers, rather than continuing it in Launceston. I conclude by saying that merit and expertise remain the primary criteria for the training of air traffic officers.

question.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. I inform the Minister of a letter from the Civil Aviation Authority dated 6 January 1993 which says, in part:

question.para: The ballot for places occurred in Canberra on Tuesday, 5 January 1993.
Is the Minister really telling us that a raffle is better than merit when it comes to employing air traffic controllers?

talk.start.para: —No, it is not reasonable to place that interpretation on my answer.
—What is it?

—I will explain precisely what is going to happen with the training of air traffic controllers. I have said that I strongly support the decision of the Civil Aviation Authority. Air traffic controllers in future will be trained by CAA controllers in the backup systems that will operate as part of the national air traffic control system in Brisbane and Melbourne.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Given the importance to the Australian economy of improving our performance in manufactured exports, is the Minister able to provide information on the success to date of the export access program? Is he able to advise on potential opportunities through the program and plans to realise that potential?
—I am able to report to the Senate—
—Why don't you make a statement after Question Time?

—I know that honourable senators opposite—like Senator Kemp, who has no interest in small business—will be disappointed about the success of the Government's export access program. The program started in 1991 with a $4 million grant from the Australian Government. It became very quickly a model for cooperation between government and small business. The program arose from discussions at the National Small Business Forum, an organisation representative of the small business organisations in Australia that was started by Minister Beddall when he was Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs.

para.tab: Such was the success of the organisation that in a very short time, in the One Nation statement of early last year, the $4 million funding to the export access program was increased by a further $8 million to expand the program, because small business was taking up and becoming involved in the program at a very rapid rate.

One of the great advantages of the export access program is that it brings together small business and industry associations in a whole multitude of areas and encourages them and their members to be involved in the program. They manage the program. The funding is provided by the Federal Government, but it is managed by the business and industry associations themselves. That is proving, in my view, to be one of the major successes of the program.
Already we have had some startling successes. I know that honourable senators opposite might not like to hear some of the statistics.

talk.start.para: —What about your own members; wouldn't they like to hear it?
—They are listening quietly, Senator Macdonald. Senator Macdonald does not want to listen to anything sensible about small business.
—Tell us about your background in this matter.
—Government senators are listening and it would do Senator Macdonald the world of good if he listened, as he should have listened to local government during the last election campaign.
—Order! Senator Macdonald will cease injecting and Senator Schacht will address the Chair and not the interjectors.

—Mr President, I certainly accept the advice to ignore Senator Macdonald. The figures for export access already show a very successful uptake rate. Up to the end of April this year, which was only 15 months after the program started, some 493 firms had applied and 182 applications had been approved and had entered the scheme. Overwhelmingly, the applicants were firms with turnovers of less than $5 million and with less than 50 employees—clearly small businesses.

para.tab: As of 31 March this year, 17 clients had export orders confirmed of over $876,000 and 35 clients of the export access program had confirmed orders worth $2.5 million approximately. The projected first year sales of 44 clients—this is the projection for the next 12 months—was $9.7 million for exports. That was at 31 January this year. By 30 April this year, that projected figure had already grown to $15 million.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. To get the public record straight, will the Minister explain why and when he asked Professor Dennis Pearce to review the abrogation of the MDS licence tendering process, which was announced by him last Monday? Will he table today correspondence and any terms of reference establishing a review, as he did with the Pearce inquiry into the satellite licence tender process?

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —Yes, I will.
—Today?

—I am happy to do it now. As the Opposition and the Democrats know, in terms of the bundle of documents that I provided to both the Opposition and the Democrats a few days ago, which were all the documents that were tabled in the Federal Court, I have attempted as quickly as physically possible to provide honourable senators with all the information available.

para.tab: The MDS matter is a matter absolutely of legal construction and advice. I just took the opportunity, which I thought was a reasonable one. I can think of nobody better to provide an independent review than the Dean of the Faculty of Law at the ANU. I am grateful that the university, which I am told was not all that pleased about it, has given him additional time off to investigate it.

In answer to Senator Kernot's other questions, I think they are all answered in the correspondence, which I will now table. This provides the advice given to Professor Pearce about what was required by the secretary to the department and the terms of reference. I was advised just 10 minutes ago that Professor Pearce has agreed that the terms of reference are appropriate. I will table both documents.

In conclusion—I have only just had this matter brought to my attention a few minutes ago—in terms of all this huffing and puffing and obfuscation that is going on on the other side, the person whom the industry would probably say is most rightly aggrieved by the problem with MDS is Mr Stokes. It is well known in the industry that he is one of the big bidders for these licences. I said yesterday in the Senate—and I have only just had this brought to my attention; I have never met Mr Stokes but I am about to redress that because I want to follow up what he said today—that I had given Mr Stokes, happily, something which people who are contesting a court action do not often get; that is, I had provided him with all the legal advice in advance from Attorney-General's and from Mr Gyles QC which canvassed all of the arguments that are to be tested in the Federal Court. I speculated—and it was only speculation yesterday—that I felt that the comments made by Mr Stokes were probably made before he had an opportunity to read that advice. I have just had pointed out to me the statement made by Mr Stokes which appeared in the
Canberra Times
today. Just to put a little bit of balance back into this debate, I will read the statement of the person most aggrieved, I would have thought. The article said:

answer.para:
Mr Stokes told the
Canberra Times
later that he had made his criticisms before he had looked at the Government's legal advice and that he was now satisfied that the attempt to abort the process was `not a personal vendetta or a nefarious conspiracy'.
On the advice I have, our case is stronger than theirs.
If it is, good. He then went on to say:
I am appreciative of the fact that the Minister has gone so far as to send us the legal arguments that have been presented to him.

talk.start.para: —My question, which is to the Minister for Family Services, relates to the Government's support for voluntary agencies' Christmas appeals. Would the Minister please clarify the nature of the Government's commitment, the offers made to eligible agencies and the amounts expended by the Government to meet this undertaking?

answer.speaker: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

talk.start.para:
—I thank Senator Reynolds for her question because it allows me to completely refute the mischievous and very wrong proposals put in this place by Senator Patterson yesterday. I want to clarify at the outset exactly the terms on which the Commonwealth offered matching funds for Christmas appeals. This was a one-off program of support for people in need over Christmas. It was using the voluntary agencies as conduits for getting help to those in need. We promised to match money raised and spent, and we did. On 6 December, the Prime Minister announced the initiative. John Dalziell, Communications Director of the Salvation Army, said on
PM
last night:

answer.para: When the Prime Minister made his announcement we immediately sought clarification . . . which we got very quickly . . . it was going to be geared to what we distributed not just to what we received.

On 12 December an advertisement appeared in the press inviting expressions of interest, and it stated quite clearly that operational funds would not be eligible for matching funds. On 14 December the department started sending out application forms to agencies. Those forms set out the terms for the matching grants. They included the relevant time limits for fund raising and for expenditure, and the type of expenditure which would receive matching funds for their Christmas appeals.

talk.start.para: —Don't you know you are supposed to do it all the time, not just prior to an election?

—I think it is Senator Patterson who needs to listen. In particular, eligible funds were defined as those raised between 1 November and 31 December. The eligible time period for those funds to be spent was defined as between 1 December and 31 January. Material assistance was defined as food hampers and cash relief—immediate relief for people in need during that Christmas period.

para.tab: On 21 December letters were sent out by the department offering funds to successful applicants. Once again, those terms of money raised and money spent were made quite clear to all of the applicants. It is quite clear that any agency participating in the Christmas appeals knew and was fully aware of exactly what the terms of that offer were. It is an absolute nonsense to suggest that the Government had reneged on its undertaking or somehow misled the agencies with regard to its support.

I come now to another very important point—the claim by Senator Patterson that the goalposts were shifted. What is important to know is that on 31 January, as the time for expending the relief had come, a number of the agencies contacted the Government and said they had not had time to complete the expenditure. So the Government, with a fair amount of generosity, extended the time for that money to be spent until 31 March, giving all the agencies another two months in which to continue to expend the money which they were having matched by the Government.

To date, the Government has actually provided $8.74 million for eligible agencies. It is estimated that a further $3.8 million will be paid out to finalise this program. It was nothing to do with the election. The program was announced in December. The extension of the time to 31 March was decided in response to requests from the agencies at the end of January. It was never in any doubt to the agencies. I am sorry that Senator Patterson has got it so wrong.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. What will be the first full year cost of the Government's home child-care allowance, and will it start on 1 July?
—In this place, I think on Tuesday morning, we introduced legislation to amend the child-care provisions. The question was about the home child-care allowance, Senator?
—Yes.

—Thank you. I just needed to get that clear. The home child-care allowance is an election commitment made by the Prime Minister. It is very important that this election commitment be implemented sensibly, and we are looking at the implementation details of that process. As the Treasurer has said, we are going to be looking at them within the Budget context. The honourable senator has got it wrong in addressing that question to me; it properly belongs to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It seems that the Minister for Family Services does not know much about families where both parents are not in the work force. The Minister is clearly not aware of the fact that when the Prime Minister made this promise he said, `It is time to redirect this assistance'. Does the fact that the Minister is not prepared to answer this question really mean that it is not time after all, and that Australian families are going to have to take a raincheck on this promise for a full financial year? Is this not simply yet another of the Government's broken promises? How many more are we going to have?

—To the extent that the honourable senator, having been directed to the right Minister, insists on putting that question back to me, I will reiterate that the Government is not walking away from any of its election commitments but intends to implement them sensibly. The Treasurer has said that we will be looking at those commitments in the Budget context. I suggest that the honourable senator direct her question to the right Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Is the Minister in a position to outline the purpose of the current Medicare television campaign, its target audience and objectives? Why was the campaign interrupted, why has it been restarted and what is it aimed at achieving?
—To waste money.
—No, it is not a waste of money. I thank Senator Loosley for the question.
—It has been going on for 10 years.
—Remain calm. I think all honourable senators would be aware that the Medicare advertising campaign was in fact—
—I am always calm.

—This stuff is pretty devastating. The Medicare advertising campaign was stopped during the early part of the election campaign. It was stopped because a number of people took the view that the ads were political. I did not share the view that those ads were political. I do not now believe those ads to be political. But the Government, being the kind of government that it has always been—anxious to do everything that is right and proper and appear to be so—pulled those ads off.

para.tab: Given that there is no election campaign now that the Government has been re-elected, and it will be here for some time to come, we can get back to business. Some weeks ago I instructed the department to restart the campaign. I think that the first ad appeared on 1 May.

The Government has a right to explain to the citizens of Australia the kind of health care system that they have and all that they are entitled to. They have been subjected to some pretty ordinary scare campaigns in recent times, both by the Opposition and by some of the private health funds, about the kind of care they can expect to get. While it is accepted by everyone, except some people in the Opposition and a handful of doctors, that the Australian health system is not in crisis, nonetheless that is a perception that some people have tried to put over. In researching that problem—research that the Government conducted some time ago—there were a number of alarming statistics that needed to be addressed.

Very large numbers of people believed incorrectly that they would be forced to pay extra charges not covered by Medicare if they went to a public hospital; about one-fifth of Australians thought they would have to pay bed fees; over one-third thought they might be liable for an anaesthetist or a surgeon; over one-third thought they would have to pay for medication; a large number thought they would have to pay for intensive care fees. All of those things were wrong, but they were all perceptions that in the Government's view needed to be corrected. So we set about organising a campaign which would explain to Australians the kind of health care they could expect in the public system, and we proceeded to make sure they knew all about it.

talk.start.para: —They find out when they get there.
—As long as they can get access.

—What Senator Herron, Senator Crichton-Browne and others have to acknowledge is that the Opposition fought a long, hard fight against Medicare and lost it. In the 1990 and 1993 elections, health was a very big issue, and the Opposition got slaughtered on it. The mob does not believe the Opposition; it just does not win the argument.
—You ask for an appointment at the Royal Brisbane hospital and you are told that it is two years to wait for an operation.

—I would have thought that the more intelligent among the Opposition—and there must be some—would have worked out by now that the interests of Australians come before the interests of the Opposition and that we should all be considering where we can improve the system and doing it. We certainly should not be trying to scare Australians into believing that in some way we have a system in crisis. We have not. Ninety-seven per cent of those who turn up for care in public hospitals get dealt with quickly and adequately.

—My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Does the Minister now accept that the doctrine of ministerial responsibility was not within the terms of reference of Professor Pearce? Does he accept that the Pearce report regards the deposit issue as being of sufficient importance for the Minister to have been given a fuller briefing? In view of the fact that Professor Pearce found that at the date of the pay television determination the Minister was familiar with the MDS and AM-FM conversion procedures, both of which required payments of deposits of differing kinds, why did the Minister not ask for a briefing and why did his staff not arrange or provide it as a matter of course?

—I suggest Senator Alston read the report and debate it later today rather than wasting any more time in Question Time on the report. I understand there will be a debate later today, and I am looking forward to it. I expanded on the question of ministerial responsibility earlier to the point where I was getting screams of protest and howls of outrage from the Opposition that I should not be saying anything at all. Senator Alston, who has changed his position on this issue more times than a white ball in a snooker game, has said, `I don't care about the Pearce report; I've got no interest in that'. Have a look at the
Hansard
. The Pearce report has been at the forefront of this debate every day and every night for three weeks, and I have sat here in this Senate listening to the most outrageous, defamatory and disorderly accusations levelled at me that I have ever heard delivered at any Minister in the 16 years I have been in this business.

para.tab:
Opposition senators
—Oh!

talk.start.para:
—Have a look at them. I do not mind everyone having some fun with this because there is a lot of fun to be had with it. I am not protesting about that. I do not mind the cartoons. In fact, I think the cartoons have been great. If I might put in a plug for my home town cartoonist who has parodied me in my own backyard, I think Colin Wicking in the
Northern Territory News
has done the best one of all. I do not object to any of that. But have a look at the
Hansard
record. I have sat here for three weeks being accused of lying, misleading the Senate, Senator Alston—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This cry and plea for sympathy are totally irrelevant to the question. I ask that the Minister address the question that has been put to him.
—I am answering the question.
—I think the Minister was digressing in that answer and I think he should be relevant.
—Thank you, Mr President—and, I might add, the most outrageous accusation of all—
—Mr President, you clearly directed that the Minister was out of order. He is totally disregarding your ruling and carrying on as though you had not spoken. That is a gross contempt of the chamber.
—Order! Senator Collins has only said a few words. It is very hard, then, to rule again on relevance, but I ask him to be relevant.
—The most outrageous accusation of all, Mr President, made by Senator Alston and Senator O'Chee—

—Mr President, I suggest that the Minister has now given you sufficient information for you to realise that he is not going back to answering the question at all but continuing down the same path upon which you have already ruled. Therefore, I ask you definitely to bring him to order.
—On the point of order, Mr President: I would submit to you that Senator Collins has not even completed either of the two sentences he has attempted.
—I will listen carefully to the Minister's answer but I ask him for the third time to be relevant.

—To complete the last sentence two minutes ahead of time: the most appalling accusation of all—and I did not protest or ask for anything to be withdrawn—was of my perjuring myself in the Federal Court in a case that has not yet been determined.
—It was a disgusting—
—It was disgusting, Senator O'Chee. Mr President, all I can say is the Pearce report has cleared me comprehensively of all of those charges.

—Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Can the Minister inform the Senate of what actions the Defence Science and Technology Organisation is taking to support the Government's policy of strengthening relationships in the South East Asian region as a means of promoting regional security?

answer.ministerial: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL
answer.speaker: Faulkner Sen J.P.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I thank Senator Maguire for his interest in this particular matter. The DSTO is actively engaged in establishing and maintaining defence science links with our South East Asian neighbours and expects to strengthen these still further over the next period of time.

para.tab: In March 1993, the Secretary to the Department of Defence and the Permanent Secretary for Defence Development from the Republic of Singapore signed a memorandum of understanding covering defence science cooperation. Under the auspices of the memorandum of understanding, a joint project in the area of defence communications has commenced. Another joint project on jet engine modelling is being planned. Both of these projects will involve exchange of technical information and the posting of Singaporean engineers into DSTO laboratories. DSTO also expects to provide Singapore with scientific support on a fee for service basis.

DSTO has a joint project in place with Malaysia to measure ship magnetism. The project so far has involved the attachment of a Malaysian scientist to DSTO for a period of three months, and the joint development of computer models. DSTO has, for many years, supported Malaysia through the posting of a defence science adviser to work with the Malaysian Ministry of Defence in Kuala Lumpur.

DSTO interaction with Thailand has recently been quite extensive. Last year DSTO accepted an invitation to attend a defence research and development planning seminar in Bangkok. Earlier this year Australia hosted a follow-up seminar with key Thai defence officials who spent two weeks with DSTO discussing top down planning issues in defence and also defence science.

A joint trial to investigate the effects of upper atmosphere changes on long-range radio transmissions is also planned for later in the year. DSTO has a defence scientific adviser posted to Bangkok to work directly with the Thai Ministry of Defence. Defence research links with Indonesia are at an early stage. DSTO participated last year in a major seminar on aerospace and shipbuilding activities in Indonesia.

With Japan there are regular exchanges of unclassified defence science information. This link has developed over the past 12 months, but the Japanese constitution inhibits further defence science cooperation at this stage. DSTO is also planning a joint project with India on research into long-range adaptive radio systems.

The Government views these examples of scientific cooperation as being a very important aspect of the developing partnership between Australia and our region. A cooperative yet measured exchange of science and technology by Australia with the countries in our region builds a clearer understanding of each country's ability to support its defence with advanced technology. I can assure Senator Maguire and other honourable senators that in doing so we are furthering a positive security environment in our region.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray. I refer to the advertised sale on 22 May of 36 RAAF CT4 basic training aircraft. Why are the 36 aircraft being sold at one time when no-one is buying aircraft in Australia, let alone specialised military training aircraft which cannot be placed on the ordinary civil register, and why is there no reserve?

—The Department of Defence is following the normal procedures as laid down by the Department of Finance in this case. We judge that there will be some interest in the sale of these planes because of the people who are already doing flight training around the country. We cannot presume a particular price in advance, because it is really up to market forces, and that is why there is not a reserve.

—As a supplementary question, I ask: given that if these 36 aircraft were properly marketed they would raise at least some $2 million, as against only approximately a third of that at the proposed dumped price—that is, a loss of $1 million of taxpayers' money—why does the RAAF not upgrade them for sale, and how does the Minister condone the loss of $1 million of taxpayers' money?

—I do not accept as necessarily correct any of the propositions that Senator Brownhill has put, nor do I accept the sums that he has produced here today. The fact is that if we look at some of the previous disposals, going back to the Liberal Government's disposal of the Hercules in the 1970s, we will find that the term `properly marketed' can have many meanings, and in the end far more money can be absorbed in the marketing of these things than we will ever get back. We have to obey the various guidelines put down by the Department of Finance on disposal of surplus equipment. We are doing that in this particular case. We recognise that there is not a widespread market for these planes. They are surplus to requirement, and they are being disposed of at auction as per the guidelines.

—My question is directed to Senator Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister aware of a recent statistic which showed that 45 per cent of South Australians subsist on an annual income of less than $12,000? Is the Minister also aware that the salary now being paid to the new head of the MFP in South Australia is $370,000 per year, or well over 30 times the income of almost half the population in the State? Noting that it is not private sources but his Government that is paying this very high salary to the head of the MFP, how does the Government defend this enormous disparity in income? Does the Minister consider this disparity morally defensible? If the Minister seeks to excuse the disparity by invoking market forces, do outcomes such as this—arising from the unfettered operation of the market—not point to the urgent need for governments to intervene in the operation of markets?

—With the utmost respect to Senator Coulter, his distance from the real world has been amply demonstrated recently by the outcome of the ballot within the Democrats on the leadership issue. The truth of the matter is that there are market forces at work that determine the kinds of salaries that have to be paid to chief executives of significant organisations in this country that have a particular responsibility to work with the private sector and to encourage large-scale private sector investment, which is of course what we are chasing in the context of the MFP exercise.

para.tab: The MFP is not a South Australian project; it is a national one. But if it does succeed, as we all hope it will, it will benefit, obviously on a very significant scale, the citizens of South Australia, including those who are presently unemployed, and we can expect very significant benefits to be generated for the whole Australian economy. Against that background, in those circumstances, while I am not aware of the precise considerations that determined this salary on this occasion, I believe the amount that has been determined by the board appears, on the face of it, defensible.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the Minister of his Government's specific election commitments to remove aged pensioners from the taxation system by 1995; to create a separate department of regional development; to establish a national investment council; to purchase private hospital beds for public patients; and to provide free dental care for low income earners from 1 July 1993. Is it a fact that all these commitments have been broken, either in part or full, since the election on 13 March? Is it also a fact that the Government made approximately 40 other new spending commitments in the lead-up to the election? Will the Minister please advise the Senate which of these election promises the Government intends to dump as well?

—There is no foundation for any suggestion that the Government is walking away from commitments it made in the pre-election process. So far as the dental situation is concerned, that has been amply explained by Senator Richardson. The Government is wholly committed to implementing that program. The start-up date will certainly be no later than 1 January next year and, with a bit of luck, it may well still be earlier than that; but that is contingent upon Cabinet decisions and the making available of the appropriations that are necessary to sustain that.

para.tab: So far as the department of regional development is concerned, that has of course been embraced within the Department of Industry and Regional Development as it has now been established. Nobody can make any serious suggestion that the Government is other than wholly committed to developing very specific regional development strategies of the kind that were foreshadowed during this particular campaign.

The Government was elected on the basis of the confidence the Australian people had in the kind of capacity we had to implement promises we have made, as we have been doing throughout the whole of the last 10 years, and as we will continue to do for the rest of this decade.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Government does propose to honour all of those undertakings, how does it propose to fund these promises and at the same time meet its commitment to reduce the Budget deficit to one per cent of GDP by 1996-97?
—By exactly the processes we have been using with a great deal of responsibility and effectiveness throughout the last decade.
—Your Budget is blowing out.

—It has not been as a function of any blow-out in the kinds of structural outlays of the Budget, as Senator Short perfectly well knows. The particular programs that are separate and distinct from the implications of the economic cycle and the payouts that are involved for unemployment benefit and so on—in other words, the structural component of the Budget—have been kept under rigorous discipline throughout the last few years, as Senator Short well knows, and these programs will continue to be kept under that discipline in the future.

para.tab: As I said yesterday, what is involved, of course, is the necessity for there to be a medium-term fiscal strategy to take us through to the 1995-96 target. That strategy will be articulated in detail in the Budget. Until then, I have nothing further to say on the specifics of that budgetary process.

talk.start.para: —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the Senate on the status of proposals for further improvements to the Tod Highway in South Australia?

—I appreciate the continued interest of South Australian senators in this issue. I am glad to report to the Senate that the news for South Australia is good. The South Australian Department of Road Transport sought from me federal approval and funding to enlarge the Tod Highway project between Karkoo and Wanilla. As those honourable senators from South Australia in particular would be aware, the Tod Highway provides a vital connection between towns in the central Eyre region and Port Lincoln, the regional centre of the Eyre Peninsula. The highway is important in the transportation of the wheat and wool produced in this area. I am also reliably informed that it is an extremely scenic part of Australia.
—Indeed.

—Senator Maguire agrees with that. The further works of $2.3 million, which I have just approved, will take the total approved federal funding for this project to $11 million. These improvements to the highway will directly benefit the important rural and tourism industries of the Eyre Peninsula.

para.tab: Work on the Tod Highway project to date has involved reconstruction of crests and horizontal curves to provide adequate stopping sight distances and reconstruction of the road on its present alignment. The latest project approval is a further demonstration of the overall commitment by this Government toward land transport in Australia. In the case of South Australia, through the national highway, One Nation, black spot and other road and urban public transport project expenditures, the Federal Government's commitment for the 1992-93 year is estimated to be in excess of $120 million.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Could the Minister inform the Senate what impact the affirmative action legislation has had on the percentage of women above senior lecturer level in higher education?

—I think one of the great flagships of this Government has been the affirmative action legislation and the way that legislation has focused the industries and the educational institutions of this country on particularly the structural barriers to the advancement of women in those areas. Industries which employ 100 people or more and our academic institutions are required to report annually on the effects of the affirmative action program. In particular, they have had to select an affirmative action person and, in consultation with the people involved, come up with a program that addresses the particular difficulties that women have had in gaining advancement.

para.tab: We know that in both industry and universities women are largely clustered in the lower paid areas of employment. That is a major concern for government and one which the affirmative action legislation intends to address. The universities have all been making their reports over the years that the Affirmative Action Agency and the affirmative action legislation have been in place. It has been very interesting to see how universities have actually had to address the fact that women in universities are still largely appointed to the lower positions; they are much more present in non-tenured positions and in tutorships.

It is also true that over the last few years we have seen a slow increase in the number of women professors and the number of women in senior lecturer positions. I can certainly get the exact details of those and I will provide them to Senator Knowles as soon as I can.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I find the Minister's speech—a non-answer—quite interesting, but it really did not answer anything to do with the question. It is very interesting for the Minister to actually talk about the universities making reports and the universities actually having to address this matter. But the question—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator has taken 35 seconds to get to the beginning of her question. That is just unacceptable, and I suggest that you rule her out of order and sit her down.
—Now you're trying to take up my time.
—Order! The point raised by Senator Evans is relevant. However, this is one of the by-products that are developing from having a minute for a supplementary question.
—The Minister is obviously unaware that the answer to the question appears to be that there has been a 30 per cent drop in the number of women at the higher academic levels.
—If you knew that, why did you ask the question, you numbskull?
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—Why has the Minister not known that the rate has fallen, why has she not known the effect of the affirmative action legislation, and what is the effect of the affirmative action legislation? That is the question.

—I have already made it clear that it is the Government's recognition of the difficulties facing women in universities that has led to this legislation and has established those processes. I have also said to Senator Knowles that I will provide for her the exact details of the figures in universities. It is curious that Senator Knowles says that, because there is certainly an increasing number of women in senior positions. I know that there is an increasing number of women professors, vice-chancellors and lecturers in universities. As I have already said, I will seek the exact details and provide that information for Senator Knowles.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. I refer to recent reports about Australian tourists travelling overseas where they sexually abuse young children particularly vulnerable because of their poverty. Quite often there is an element of racism involved as well. Can the Minister confirm whether the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence is compiling information on the activity of Australian paedophiles both domestically and overseas? Are any steps being taken either legislatively or administratively to help curtail this terrible practice?

—I thank Senator Tate for his question—and a good one it is too. I do not have direct information from the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, but I will seek that. I do, however, have information on other aspects of government and our response to the particular issue that Senator Tate raises.

para.tab: We do of course take seriously the issue of child sexual exploitation and paedophile activities. Our responses are targeted both on the domestic as well as the international level. For instance, we encourage those countries concerned to deal with the underlying problems causing child prostitution. To this effect, Mr Howe, the Deputy Prime Minister, discussed this issue last year with the Thai Prime Minister.

Domestically, the Australian Federal Police is presently monitoring the nature and extent of paedophile activity overseas. Liaison officers are working together with local law enforcement agencies and are collecting intelligence on paedophile groups. We must remember that Australia is a party to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. This means that our domestic law and practice have to be and are in fact in accordance with the obligation set out in article 34 of the convention. That article obliges Australia to protect children from sexual exploitation and abuse involving both prostitution and, of course, pornography. We are obliged to respond by taking measures on national, bilateral and multilateral levels.

There is one aspect of this response that has achieved some publicity in recent days and that is the circumstances in which Australia would assert jurisdiction over conduct by persons outside Australia; persons who are present in the country but who may commit offences outside this country. To date, our jurisdiction extension has only gone as far as matters such as war crimes, hijacking and torture. Then, in those circumstance, we have extended it that far if there has been considerable international support for such extension.

When one looks at this particular area, there is another complication, that is, that the activities we talk about are not always regarded as criminal activity in the countries in which they occur. We do, of course, support the criminalisation and prosecution of such conduct in those countries.

The matter has been receiving close attention by the Minister for Justice. As a result of an options paper put to him by the Attorney-General's Department, he has instructed the department to prepare detailed advice on the possibility of developing legislation to create an offence of sexual exploitation of children by Australian citizens overseas, and laws to punish those who organise, advertise or otherwise profit from child sexual exploitation. The department is also looking at law enforcement strategies to improve links with countries where these practices are most prevalent.

In closing, I also add that the Minister has asked for the matter to be placed on the agenda of the Australasian Police Ministers Council meeting to be held in Christchurch on 28 May, and the issue is also on the agenda for the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General which will meet in Darwin on 24 June.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the current sales tax legislation which, when introduced, the Government stated, would not increase costs to sales tax exempt primary producers. Is the Minister aware of the anomaly in this legislation which means that farm machinery dealers are required to pay sales tax on spare parts bought to recondition farm machinery to be sold to primary producers, but spare parts sold directly to primary producers are sales tax exempt? Is the Minister also aware that, because of the anomaly, farm machinery dealers will pay an extra $10 million in sales tax, which will be passed on to primary producers who are increasingly being forced by the rural recession to buy second-hand machinery? How can the Government justify this extra burden on a rural community in deep crisis?

—During the development of the sales tax legislation and its implementation phase I heard a very large number of expressions of concern and apprehension about crises which were going to occur, some of which were to do with problems for farm machinery dealers. The matter that Senator Ferguson raised was not one of those. All those others which were raised turned out after the implementation to be ill-founded.
—No, you didn't change your procedures.
—This one is not.

—It is all very well for honourable senators to leap to conclusions. Let me just answer the question. Those fears did not turn out to be well-founded. That does not mean that the matter that Senator Ferguson raises does not have any substance. It has not been raised with me before. Of course, I am no longer directly responsible for these matters. There were some similar matters raised, but I do not think the one that Senator Ferguson raised was among them, or at least not that I can recall.

para.tab: Those other matters were not well-founded. This may well be, but I do not know. I will refer the question to the Treasurer and get an answer for Senator Ferguson as soon as I can.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. Taking into account the Minister's answer to my question, what I would really like to know is: was it the Government's deliberate intention that this extra sales tax burden should be placed on the rural community or was it an unintended consequence of the legislation?
—We have not yet determined that it has fallen, so let us discuss the cause after we have worked out whether the outcome has actually occurred.

—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
.

debate.sub1.title: Aviation: Centre for Air Traffic Services

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Reid this day, relating to the employment and training criteria used by the Civil Aviation Authority.

speech.para: There are three aspects of the matter that need to be dealt with arising from the question and the Minister's answer: firstly, the question of the balloting of the students for employment; secondly, the nature of the employment in the first place; and, thirdly, that part of the Minister's answer which in fact dealt with the motion I moved yesterday dealing with the location of the school in Launceston.

para.tab: I will not go over speeches that I have made previously which dealt with the fact that the school should never have been placed in Launceston and clearly should have been in the national capital in the first place. It was placed in Launceston for political reasons. The folly of that decision has now been proved by the Minister's statement today about and endorsing shifting it from Launceston, the cost to taxpayers all-up being about $40 million. Goodness knows what it will cost to relocate the facilities in Melbourne and Brisbane, as is presently planned.

But that at least is one aspect of the argument. My notice of motion yesterday asked the Minister to make a statement to the Senate about why this is happening and the costs. At least from his answer today we know that he approves of it.

But the course has been operating in Launceston. I wish to refer in particular to the students who did the course during 1991 and 1992. They responded to an advertisement in the
Weekend Australian
of 6 and 7 October 1990, which advertisement said in part:

speech.para: Graduates will be eligible for employment as air traffic controllers or flight service officers with the Civil Aviation Authority following successful completion of final field training. Persons embarking on a career with the CAA will find it challenging and rewarding.
I am sure they would if they could actually get jobs. At the bottom of the advertisement, it states:
Course numbers are structured to meet the needs of the CAA and employment opportunities are excellent.

If we examine the facts, we could only come to the conclusion that that advertisement was misleading. Thirty-three students completed the course in 1992, having started their course at the beginning of January 1991.

para.tab: It transpires that within six months the CAA knew that the students would not get jobs but it did not tell them. They found that out near the end of their course, in November 1992. Having completed the course, and graduated in the order of numbers from one to 33, they then found out that they would not be employed in order of merit. A ballot was to be held for the positions that they would be offered. I do not know whether any of them have actually been offered jobs, but many of them would have taken up other courses had they known that this advertisement was false.

On 5 January 1993 the ballot took place in Canberra, none of the students being present, so far as I know. It is confirmed in correspondence that the Civil Aviation Authority came to the conclusion that balloting, raffling, its students was the way to offer opportunities for employment, not merit in the order in which they had passed their exams.

I ask the Minister to deal with the Civil Aviation Authority, and require that authority to deal with those students in the way that the Public Service now deals with promotions, that is in the order of merit. I seek leave to incorporate in
Hansard
a letter from the Authority, dated 6 January 1993, which confirms that the ballot took place on 5 January, and also to incorporate in
Hansard
the list of names of students, one to 33 under the heading `Ballot held in Canberra on Tuesday 5 January 1993'.
Leave granted.
