talk.start.para: —Mr President—
—Is this on the same issue?

—
It relates to the issue, in a general way, that my colleague Senate Reid mentioned and I support what she said. While it is relevant to the issue of training by the CAA, and training for young people learning to fly, it also relates to the question that Senator Brownhill asked of Senator Ray. I am desirous of an answer from either Senator Collins or Senator Ray, so I thought it would be appropriate to raise it at this time.
—It is really a different issue. I will give the honourable senator the call but really I should put the motion that the Senate take note of the answer.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Macdonald Sen I.D.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Brownhill this day, relating to the certification by the Civil Aviation Authority of aircraft being sold by the RAAF.

speech.para: The matter possibly involves Senator Collins as well. The question relates to the aircraft that are being sold. I have been contacted by the Broadmeadows College of Technical and Further Education about the sale of those aircraft. The college, or someone associated with it, is interested in looking at them. I understand that it is being suggested that an amount of $40,000 will need to be spent on those aircraft to bring them up to a standard that will allow them to be registered, so that they can be flown in civilian air space. The RAAF has in the past been flying them in civilian air space. The query is raised as to why they should now require these modifications to enable them to fly in the same air space.

para.tab: There is a suggestion, from the CAA to the air training corps, that a waiver is not possible for use by cadets of these aircraft in a flying-training role. I ask either Senator Ray or Senator Collins to indicate whether they would be prepared to consider an exemption for air training corps from the CAA requiring these qualifications so that the aircraft can be used by cadets for flying training purposes only. The matter is a fraction urgent because the auction is on at the end of this week, I understand, and these people are interested in some response to this before they consider their position in bidding at the auction.

talk.start.para: —On this matter I probably cannot be as helpful as the Minister representing the CAA. Even Senator Macdonald might think that the Minister would like to concentrate on another couple of matters for the next few minutes. I will give a general answer to supplement the answer I gave Senator Brownhill. In fact, 51 aircraft have been acquired since 1975. Forty-seven of these are now available for disposal. There have been a number of requests indicating an interest in purchasing the aircraft—and I suppose there have been some people wanting them for nothing, as always happens with military equipment.

para.tab: I am informed that in their present configuration the aircraft would not be immediately eligible for registration on the CAA civil register, which is the same information as the senator has. All the aircraft require a number of modifications to bring them to the standard which the CAA has accepted for certification of a number of the CT4B aircraft operated by British Aerospace and Ansett Technologies at Tamworth, New South Wales, for pilot training and flight screening.

I understand the costs are, as has been quoted here, about $40,000. As to why there is this dichotomy between the standard for a military aircraft and that for a civilian aircraft, I have not gone back into the mists of time to find out what the circumstances are. It has been known for quite some time, though, that these planes were up for disposal. I think I signed off this particular matter in January 1993. I think those opposite would concede it would be most unreasonable if we spent $40,000 per aircraft in Defence to upgrade them. We sell them as is. They can be used for a number of different purposes but, if they are to be used for the purpose of carrying the general public, then they will need the $40,000 spent on them.

The crux of the matter raised is whether a distinction can be made if the aircraft are used for CAA training. I will pass that on as quickly as I can to my colleague to try to get a response before the weekend. I simply do not know whether I can or cannot. Clearly, if I cannot, I hope that the matter continues to be negotiable. If those at Broadmeadows, or wherever it is, decide to put in a purchase order, maybe negotiations on the matter can ensue. It is really the first time this matter has been directly put to me in this way. I have known that it was going to cost $40,000 to upgrade the planes for CAA. I did not know of this other function that they could be used for—nor should I. I really prefer not to know who the potential tenderers and auctioneers are. I usually like to be informed after the event.

talk.start.para: —I was disappointed that Senator Ray resorted to the Collins defence of blaming the Department of Finance for the tendering process. If that is the advice from the Department of Finance, then the department ought to reconsider its position. Hardly any aircraft at all have been sold in Australia. To dump 36 aircraft in one block, irrespective of whether they meet registration standards or not, just kills the market: it cannot be done. There is no loss for the Commonwealth in holding these aircraft and selling them in smaller units over a six-month or 12-month period at a rate which the market could absorb. I believe we are going to lose quite a lot of money under the procedures proposed by the Department of Finance. I would seriously suggest to Senator Ray that the department ought to talk to some people in the industry if it is faced with similar situations in the future.

talker.name: Senator BROWNHILL
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —I thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). He is usually across his department, but today I do not think he is quite across it as well as he could be. Maybe that is because the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) might be taking a part in this matter as well. I want to take Senator Ray up on a couple of points he made regarding selling to the highest bidder and regarding market demand. Surely, the Minister, if he were fully responsible for the Defence Department, would be making sure of business best practice, which would mean that he would be trying to do the best for his department to get the best value from it.

para.tab: Two other matters were overlooked and I bring them to the attention of the Minister. The first is the safety angle of the airplanes which, as the Minister alluded to, have been quite willingly flying in airspace and which now have to be upgraded if they are to be used in the same airspace under a different category. That is rather disturbing. The second point is that the Minister said that the upgrading would cost $40,000, which is quite correct, but if there are 800 engineers in the RAAF, surely they could have helped with the upgrading of those planes.
With respect to the auction, there are some 36 aircraft—although we are now told there are 51—which, if they are sold at an estimated—

talk.start.para: —No, 36 for sale; 51 overall.

—If the 36 were sold at, say, $25,000, that brings in about $900,000. If they were sold separately over a period, as Senator MacGibbon suggested, then that would bring in something like 36 multiplied by $35,000 or more. The extra money would be good for the department and it would be a fairer sale. On the basis of the figures presented earlier, something like an extra $1 million-plus would be coming into the department. That represents quite a difference. Being taxpayers' money, I would imagine that in his ministerial capacity, and being a frugal person, the Minister would be more interested in making sure that the taxpayers were as well looked after as any other interested parties.

para.tab: I express to the Minister my disappointment that the safety angle has not been discussed in regard to the fact that airplanes that had previously been able to fly in an airspace now have to be upgraded to fly in the same airspace. Surely that can be looked at in the future. The Minister can look at using the resources of his department to ensure it obtains the best value for its dollar.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Newman this day, relating to home childcare allowances.

talk.start.para: —As honourable senators will recall, my question was related to the home child-care allowance, which was an election promise targeted at Australian families where a parent is providing for their own child care. It is going to involve a cashing out of the dependent spouse rebate for families with children. It was also a recommendation of the bipartisan Lavarch committee inquiring into the status of women. It has been part of the national debate in this country for a long time. Those working in the home, providing for their own child care, have been calling for this allowance for ages. Yet the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley)—I emphasise that it is family services—firstly tried to answer some other question altogether. She got the wrong end of the stick about what sort of child care I was talking about, and then she tried to duck the question entirely by saying that I was asking the question of the wrong Minister.

para.tab: It is clear that it was the wrong Minister. This Minister does not seem to know much about families at all. Any time she is asked anything she gets the wrong end of the stick. This issue was important enough to Australian families for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to regard it as an extremely important promise and to include it in his election policy speech.

The Prime Minister said, `It's time'. Clearly, from the Minister's evasion, the time is not yet ripe. The measure needs to be introduced at the beginning of the financial year because it relates to an annual tax rebate which is to be cashed out, presumably through the Department of Social Security. If it is not done on 1 July this year, it presumably will have to be delayed until 1 July 1994 at the earliest.

That is hardly an indication of the urgency with which the Prime Minister seemed to attend to it in his policy speech. The reality is what the dogs are barking all over Canberra: the Expenditure Review Committee is not going to pass the Government's election promises—avoiding and delaying any it can get away with. We have already seen it welshing on the removing of the pensioners from the tax system; we have seen it welshing on buying hospital beds in the private sector; we have seen it welshing on starting up the emergency dental health program, and now the Government is clearly getting Australian families to take a raincheck on the home child-care allowance. It was always a pretty deceitful promise anyway. It was a pea and thimble sort of trick. It was sold as $30 a week for families who provided their own child-care; yet in reality it was a transfer from the father's wallet to the mother's purse, plus $2.80 in tips. It is nice to have that extra $2.80, until we remember that that $2.80 is coming out of that same family's pocket by way of the taxes it has to pay.

That did not bother the Government all that much because it was pretty good for a headline on the evening news. At that stage of the election, if honourable members can recall, that was all that was worrying the Government at the time. It did not really expect to be in government, and it spewed out promises willy-nilly, never really thinking about either the cost or the implementation. It has been pretty clear in the answers that we have been getting from the Ministers just lately that implementation and cost really were ignored. We saw Senator Richardson yesterday trying to bluff his way through the election promise about the dental health system, and then being forced to admit later that the Government was breaking a promise by putting back its emergency dental health program.

We have seen the reduction of the Government's commitment to match the funding of the major welfare organisations, and we have seen the Minister fudge the issue of the home child-care allowance by simply saying it was being considered in the Budget process. If it is being considered in the Budget process, it is being delayed substantially, and yet on 24 February the Prime Minister said, `Labor believes it's time to redirect this assistance and convert the tax rebate to a cash benefit paid directly to the spouse at home caring for the children'. That promise was going to cost $326 million over four years.

What we have to ask in this chamber is: which four years are we talking about—the next four years? Or are we talking about starting up the implementation of this program in maybe the year 2000? Maybe this is all part of
Towards 2000
. Certainly the Australian voters at the election thought these promises were being introduced straightaway. No fine print was delivered to the voters when they signed on the dotted line for this Government. At the next election I guess they are going to want to see every t crossed and every i dotted because this Government cannot be trusted with promises, just like it cannot be trusted to run the country. This is just the latest in a long line of examples of the inability of this Government to commit itself honestly to what it is promising the Australian people.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

qwn.title: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

talk.start.para: —I table the answer to Senator Calvert's question.

speech.speaker: Calvert Sen P.H.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I thank the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) for making that answer available. I would like to point out that twice now he has said that he had no advice on the matter. I understand that he has had a lot of other things on his mind in the last few days, but this letter that I quoted today was written on 1 September last year. It states:

speech.para: However, in this case I did request a report from AOTC regarding the matters you raised, and I am satisfied that the management has acted in accordance with accepted commercial and management practices.

I would have thought that any Minister—my memory is not all that bright—who asked a question of the biggest corporation in this country, AOTC, would have had some memory of signing a letter. The letter was dated 1 September last year. I would have thought that a responsible Minister whose signature is on this letter—he has now given me an answer, though—inquiring into a corporation the size of AOTC would have remembered signing that letter. I think it is another example of the department running the Minister.

speech.speaker: Knowles Sen S.C.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Knowles this day, relating to the employment of women in higher education institutions.

speech.para:
The question I asked today was about the impact of the affirmative action legislation on the percentage of women above the senior lecturer level in higher education. I was absolutely fascinated to hear the Minister's non-answer because she did not go into any of the areas of the specific request that I had made. She launched a book called
Women in Australia
only a couple of weeks ago. I was quite happy to be associated with the launch, but I am surprised to notice that she has not actually read the book. The fact is that the percentage of women above senior lecturer level in higher education has actually fallen. The book states:

Women's representation among academic staff declined with level, from over 50 per cent of staff below lecturer level to less than 10 per cent of staff above senior lecturer level in 1991. Women's representation at above senior lecturer level declined from 13 per cent in 1988 to 10 per cent in 1991—
which is an overall 30 per cent reduction in the number of women. The book continues:
. . . but increased in all the other categories of academic staff.

Senator Crowley today went on to say that there had been general increases across the board and that the affirmative action legislation was working particularly well. Why is it that a government, through the Minister, continues to tell the people of Australia that this legislation is working particularly effectively when in fact in education, in the Public Service and in various other areas under the Government's control the legislation has clearly failed?

para.tab: I suggest that the Minister familiarise herself with the very book that she launched and come into the Senate and give us a straight answer as to the situation in this particular area. As I say, she launched the book, and what we need to know in the Senate is why is the affirmative action legislation not being trumpeted by her and her Government consistently.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Reynolds this day, relating to Government support for charitable organisations.

speech.para: Today on the Pru Goward show Senator Crowley said that she was appalled at the beat-up of the Opposition on the issue of grants to organisations in the Christmas appeal. She said that some of the charitable organisations are quite distressed that this kind of misrepresentation has emerged. There was no misrepresentation, and I have had no representation from any of those organisations that they were distressed. Of course, they are grateful for the money they receive from the Government, but I am distressed at the way they were given that money. She said:

It does no good at all to have gotten it as wrong as this and I hope the Opposition will be able to make an apology, because they have very, very unfairly misrepresented what was promised and what was delivered.
I want to know, and I want Senator Crowley to tell me, how I and the Opposition misrepresented the situation. On 6 December the Prime Minister in a press release said:
I am pleased to announce today that the Government will match dollar for dollar cash donations by the Australian public to major voluntary agencies for their Christmas appeals.

That is what he said on 6 December. On the
Sunday
program on 6 December—on the same day—he said to Laurie Oakes:

So let me say to you, Laurie, that for every dollar that the voluntary agencies like the St Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family, the Salvation Army collect for material assistance, the Commonwealth will match for the Christmas Appeals.
There he is again saying, `for every dollar that they collect'. On 11 December, again in a press release, the Prime Minister said:
I announced on 6 December 1992 that the Government will match dollar for dollar cash donations by the Australian public to major voluntary agencies for their Christmas appeals.

He went on in great detail in that press release about the conditions surrounding the Government's funding. He talked about the organisations that would be eligible, and stated that they must have a sound record in material aid, et cetera. But nowhere did the Prime Minister say that the Government's funding would involve only the dollars spent by the agencies over a specific period.

para.tab:
I did not misrepresent the situation. I came into the chamber yesterday and said that the goalposts had changed. For a week the agencies believed those press releases. On the basis of those press releases the agencies actually started to look at how they would organise their spending patterns. The Prime Minister has the habit of legislating by press release, so I suppose the agencies were to be excused for thinking that this was no different. In today's
Canberra Times
, a spokesman for Senator Crowley—and maybe this is wrong; Senator Crowley can advise us—said the following:

speech.para: . . . the contract signed by the major welfare groups on December 11 said "matching funds means grants equivalent to amounts of Christmas appeals donations received or expected to be raised between November 1 and December 30, 1992, and expended between December 1 and January 30, 1993".

That is the first the public knew about it—except for the advertisements that appeared on 12 December. We have not been able to get a copy of those advertisements. Maybe the public was told then. In an interview with Senator Crowley, Pru Goward said:
Well, the Prime Minister's Press Release actually said

the Government will match dollar-for-dollar cash donations by the Australian public, which a reasonable man, I'd have thought would take that to mean the money raised, and according to the charities it was only later that the Government decided what they really meant was the money spent.

Pru Goward thought that; the public obviously thought that. Then, in an editorial appearing in the
Sun-Herald
on 13 December, it is obvious that the editor thought that:
Prime Minister Keating's promise of matching dollar for dollar the money raised by some organisations in the lead up to Christmas will help some but not all families.
On 19 December, Mr Wilson, the chief administrative officer of St Vincent de Paul, is reported as saying:
Then we've got Prime Minister Keating's promise of a dollar for dollar raised by us. That will help take the pressure off.

The community believed that, and that is what the donors believed. The Government has duped the donors of Australia. I have had phone calls to my office by people saying that they gave money on that understanding. They have been duped. That is the issue. The Australian public was told by the Prime Minister that the Government would match dollar for dollar the money that was raised by those organisations. That is what people believed when they gave donations to those organisations. That is the great untruth; that is the great misrepresentation. For Senator Crowley to say that I created mischief is very poor indeed.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Herron Sen J.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Loosley this day, relating to the advertising of entitlements under Medicare.

speech.para: Senator Richardson missed the whole point of my interjection and the objection of the health agencies to the expenditure of nearly $3 million to inform people of their entitlements under Medicare. Medicare has been in existence for 10 years. People do not choose to be ill; they get ill, and then they seek access to health care providers. Advertising their entitlements under Medicare is a total waste of taxpayers' funds because of that very point. That is the point that has completely escaped the bureaucracy and Senator Richardson.

para.tab: The problem with Medicare has not gone away because of the election, and it was not a point scoring exercise. There is enormous difficulty of access in relation to the public hospital system. The money spent on advertising the virtues of Medicare should well be spent, as Senator Richardson has acknowledged, on advising people to get private insurance because then they would get access to the hospital system.

It has been noted that the waiting times in the public hospital system, certainly in Queensland, vary by anything from seven months to get an orthopaedic appointment or to get into an ENT outpatients ward, to 18 months once one is advised to have surgery. I have a letter before me from a patient in Nambour who has been waiting three years to have a tonsillectomy. I would suggest that some of that money should be spent on the Nambour hospital so this lady can have her tonsillectomy instead of currently having to go to her local general practitioner to get antibiotics to stave off the symptoms. I am happy to notify the Minister of the name of that patient if he so desires it.
But it is absolute rubbish to spend this money on advertising the availability of Medicare when people cannot get into hospital. I suggest the Minister is suffering from mythomania.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, on at least two occasions in one interview.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—On Pru Goward's program this morning, the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, claimed that my efforts to expose the Government's deception in regard to its Christmas promise to charities were, and I quote:

speech.para: . . . the beat-up by the Opposition on this.
In an even more outrageous and distasteful claim, Senator Crowley said, in relation to my efforts, that:
Their great good work on behalf of needy Australians is now being called into question.
In regard to the `beat-up', I simply quote the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 6 December 1992. He said:

. . . every dollar that the voluntary agencies like the St Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family, the Salvation Army collect for material assistance, the Commonwealth will match for the Christmas Appeals.

In regard to the second claim, may I say that I have not and will not in any way question the great work of these charities. It is an absolute disgrace for Senator Crowley to imply this. On the contrary, my efforts have been aimed solely at exposing the fact that the Government has duped these charities and a generous Australian public by reneging on its promise to match, dollar for dollar, money raised in these Christmas appeals.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

talk.start.para:
—I table the Government's response to the President's report on outstanding government responses to parliamentary committee reports and seek leave to incorporate that document in
Hansard
and to move a motion in relation to it.

para.tab: Leave granted.

para.emphasis: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORTS
RESPONSE TO THE LIST TABLED IN THE SENATE BY THE PRESIDENT ON 17 DECEMBER 1992

speech.para: Possible improper interference with a witness and possible misleading evidence before the National Crime Authority Committee (recommendation 2)
Recommendation 2 by the Committee was that appropriate steps be taken to clarify matters of concern in relation to sections 51 and 55 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984.

As the Government had foreshadowed in its response to the PJC report "Who is to Guard the Guards?", the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill (No.2) 1992 was introduced in November 1992. The Bill was amended in the Senate in a manner unacceptable to the Government, and was subsequently not pursued in the House of Representatives in December. The Government is now considering what further action it might take.
Alleged intimidation of witnesses—implementation of pharmaceutical restructuring measures inquiry

The Government has noted the Committee's Report. The Committee recommended the matter be referred by the Senate to the Committee of Privileges. As there were no other recommendations in the report no further Government response is necessary.
Employment of people with disabilities
Presented to the President of the Senate on 4 February 1993.
Feasibility of a National ID Scheme: The Tax File Number
The response is still under consideration and will be provided in due course.
A National Drought Policy—First Report
No response required.
A National Drought Policy—Final Report
The Government is working to implement the recommendations of the report and will provide a full response to the Senate in the Autumn 1993 sitting.
Kangaroos
Final response tabled 6 May 1993.

para.emphasis: COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING TELECOMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGIES—SELECT

speech.para: Final Report
The Government intends to respond to this report during the 1993 Budget sitting.
Final Report

The Government response to this report was reflected in the Second Reading Speech for the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill 1992 delivered by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator the Hon. Bob Collins, on 4 November 1992.
The Conduct of Elections: new boundaries for cooperation
The response is to be tabled during the 1993 Budget sitting.
Australia's refugee and humanitarian system: Achieving a balance between refuge and control.

The Government's response has been delayed due to the need to consider the important issues raised by the report relating to the humanitarian claims of PRC nationals in Australia within the overall context of refugee determination. Gungahlin's Transport Links

Legal casinos and organised criminal activities

The Government notes that, at this stage, the Parliamentary Joint Committee (PJC) has decided not to pursue its inquiry into legal casinos and organised criminal activity, and that the PJC will review its decision early in these sittings.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the General Business order of the day relating to a statement by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) concerning the order of the Senate of 19 May 1993 for production of documents be called on immediately and have precedence over all other business till determined.
Debate resumed.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.M.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Mr Deputy President, as you would be aware, yesterday the Senate passed an order by consent, in effect—there was no government objection to it—that certain documents be tabled by midday today. Those documents concerning the satellite tender and the MDS process were to be tabled in the Senate by 12 o'clock today.

para.tab: At 12 o'clock today, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) came into the chamber. We thought that we were either going to get the documents or an explanation as to why the documents could not be tabled. Approximately an hour later we had achieved neither. We still do not know whether the Government had any real explanation of why it was unable to table the documents, and we certainly do not have the documents.

At that stage debate on the matter was adjourned until later in the day so that the Minister might consider his position and so that, hopefully, we would get the documents in accordance with the order of the Senate or, alternatively, hear from the Minister as to why he was unable to comply. This debate has now been reopened, for which I thank the Senate. I think we are at the stage where what we are really doing is giving the Minister a further opportunity to act in accordance with the order, or to make some satisfactory explanation.

I will put this matter a little more into context. I said that the order was made yesterday by consent. Yesterday certainly no indication was given by the Minister that he would be unable to comply with such an order. I guess that that is not surprising, because we have been hearing for some weeks that there is no difficulty in the Minister tabling documents in relation to these two matters and, in fact, that they would be tabled.

Mr Deputy President, I do not want to take much more of the Senate's time, but I take you back to 6 May. In answer to questions from my colleague Senator Alston, who asked that a whole range of documents in relation to the satellite pay television licences be tabled, Senator Collins said:

speech.para: I will table the documents which apply to Senator Alston's question. As I said yesterday, I have asked my departmental secretary to start the process of getting those documents together now.

Senator Collins said that on 6 May. Those documents included advices, notes of telephone conversations—all relevant material, in effect, to the satellite process. On 13 May the Minister also said, in effect addressing Senator Alston:
This I can guarantee: the maximum number of papers will be lodged on Tuesday. If any are left out, I imagine that it will not be long after that that they will be tabled.
Then yesterday Senator Collins, in relation to Professor Pearce, said:

Professor Pearce has been examining all of the papers connected with this matter. He has had access to whatever officers of the department he wished to speak to about it. His report, together with the papers that he has examined, will be tabled in this Parliament.

We have got to this stage, and certainly Senator Collins has now tabled Professor Pearce's report and two documents—but he has certainly not tabled all the documents that Professor Pearce has examined. Certainly Senator Collins has not complied with the order of yesterday.

para.tab: Yesterday's order was very carefully drawn to try to reduce the number of documents that we would require, because we understand that there is a certain management difficulty in dealing with a lot of paper. We were at pains to try to be more specific—more specific than those that the Minister had indicated earlier that he would be able to provide to the Senate. So we were not even keeping him to his earlier undertakings. We tried to be helpful by reducing the number and focusing on the documents that were particularly relevant to the questions that we were seeking to have answered, and the order was in that form.

So Senator Collins has not complied with the order. He has not complied with any of the undertakings that were given on any of these days. He has not complied even with the statement that he made yesterday that he would table all the documents that Professor Pearce considered. We of course, not surprisingly, find that just a totally unsatisfactory situation.
There is one document that immediately struck me as being relevant. It was referred to on page 5 of Professor Pearce's report and is a draft determination that was floating around, which said:

speech.para: This document includes the statement that tenderers for a pay-TV licence `are not required to pay a deposit to enter the process'.

I would have thought that that was a vitally important document for us to have to make our determination whether this Minister has met the standard of performance of a Minister that we think is necessary.

para.tab: It is one thing to argue that Professor Pearce has made certain assessments, but that does not absolve us of our responsibilities. We have responsibilities to make certain assessments, and we can only do that if we have access to the necessary documents. We have had undertakings to produce those documents time and again, and they have not been produced. That forced us to the stage yesterday of seeking an order of the Senate that they be produced. Obviously we do not go down that path unnecessarily, but they were not being introduced. We sought the order, and the Minister said he consented to the order. The order was made. The documents have not been tabled and we still have no satisfactory explanation why that has not occurred.

So I raise the matter again and invite the Minister to either comply with the order or put to the Senate an explanation that we can consider. If the Minister is not prepared to do that, then we obviously have no alternative than to take other actions that are open to us because, as much as Ministers might not like being called to account by the Senate, it is our responsibility that they are and we are not going to let them avoid their responsibilities so easily by simply snubbing their nose at the Senate in the way that Senator Collins has done today.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I think, having now had a detailed discussion with Senator Collins and having had some opportunity to brief myself on the course of events in this very complex matter, I may be in a position to assist Senator Hill and the Senate in the, hopefully, amicable resolution of this matter. As I understand it, the situation is that Senator Collins did consent to this order yesterday. He indicated at the time of doing so in the Parliament that he had not yet had the opportunity to look at the details of the motion before him, but clearly what he understood to be involved in the motion was an order for the production of documents which was very much more limited in its scope than that which had previously been the subject of Opposition attention.

para.tab: In fact, as Senator Collins said yesterday, the original scope of opposition requests—on the MDS side of the equation alone—could have extended to something like 113,000 pages of material. What Senator Alston was now proposing was something much more limited. So Senator Collins accepted it on the basis that it was a much more confined task confronting him. Senator Collins also accepted the order yesterday without demur on the basis that, at that stage, he understood that the Pearce report—which has in fact now been tabled today—would not be required or expected to be tabled until next Monday. So it was on the assumption that the Pearce report would have that many more days of gestation that Senator Collins agreed yesterday to bringing forward his obligation to table this batch of papers.

As I understand it, what then happened yesterday afternoon was that further discussions were held outside this chamber—so they are not documented and inevitably recollections will vary about what occurred—and Senator Collins was requested to bring forward the tabling of the Pearce report from Monday to today. Senator Collins acceded to that request in the knowledge of and with the implication that, by doing so, the time and attention of his office and the relevant departmental officers involved would thereby be totally preoccupied with the bringing forward of the Pearce report, preparing the details of its presentation, being prepared to answer questions and so on.
Whether or not it was practicable at the time of agreement yesterday to meet this order, it certainly became hopelessly impracticable to do so in the circumstances as they evolved yesterday afternoon. That really is the reason why it just has not been possible to do the work necessary to bring the papers forward today.

What matters less, I would hope, than what has happened in the past is what should happen now. It is perfectly reasonable for the Senate, having passed an order and not having it complied with, to seek an explanation and to seek an indication of what response is now contemplated. The response that we propose to make, having had an opportunity to look at the scale of the task that is yet to be performed is this: we would propose—and we will make this the subject of explicit undertakings by Senator Collins in a moment—that we look at the order in two parts, the first part being documents relating to the satellite licence tender process, namely, the report that has been already put down now by Pearce. Let us call it Pearce report No. 1. The documents that are sought in relation to that are those here identified in the motion: copies of any requests, copies of any legal, technical or other advice. They are further described in the text of the motion.

Secondly, let us look at, as a separate exercise, the similar kinds of documents related to the MDS licence tender process which is to be the subject of Pearce report No. 2—if we might so describe it—which report will be tabled in this Parliament next Wednesday.

So far as the second category of documents is concerned, namely, requests for advice and copies of any legal, technical or other advice relating to the MDS process relating to Pearce report No. 2, we are proposing that those documents be tabled in the Parliament no later than next Wednesday. Indeed, if it is possible to table them any earlier than next Wednesday, if it is possible to table Pearce report No. 2 any earlier than next Wednesday, we will do so, and Senator Collins will give that undertaking. Present indications are, given the scale of the task, that that is not likely to be achievable any earlier than next Wednesday. But that is certainly our objective and that is the undertaking that Senator Collins is prepared to give.

So far as the other category of documents is concerned relating to Pearce report No. 1, or the satellite process, the undertaking that we are prepared to give in relation to this category is as follows: Senator Collins will table these documents as soon as he is able to do so and, in any event, no later than next Monday, when Parliament resumes. If it is possible to complete the task today, tonight, before Parliament rises, then Senator Collins will come into the Parliament and make the documents available. If the task is completed, as seems likely, not by tonight but some time tomorrow or Saturday or even Sunday, then Senator Collins will undertake to make the documents thus prepared available to the Opposition spokesman and the Democrats spokesperson as soon as those documents are ready and as soon as they can be couriered to whatever location they are—as has happened, I understand, with other documents.

The reason why some more time is required to prepare all these documents for presentation should, I hope, be obvious to honourable senators, but let me just spell it out in case it is not. Time until now has been totally preoccupied, for all the relevant officers and advisers, in going through the other steps that have been involved in leading up to producing and tabling today the Pearce report and dealing with the ongoing saga of the MDS licences.

Even though the scope of the request has now been much confined, which we appreciate, it is not just a matter obviously of retrieving and putting into a single pile all the documents that satisfy this description. It is a matter, in accordance with the time-honoured procedures and practices of this place on which I have had occasion to rely on various occasions, perfectly understood and accepted that there are legitimate grounds for non-disclosure. I do not seek to identify now all possible grounds that might be relied upon or might be relevant to these particular documents, but there are manifestly at least three: Cabinet-in-confidence, commercial-in-confidence, and documents, the nature of which or the nature of parts of which may adversely impact on the conduct of legal proceedings, or prejudice any party to legal proceedings.

There are legal proceedings currently extant in relation to the MDS side of the process—not, I verily believe, so far as the satellite part of it is concerned, but there is a sense in which these issues are intertwined; for example, the consideration of tender processes, practices and procedures and so on. There is a sense in which it may be that some of the documents that relate to the satellite side of it could impact on legal proceedings extant elsewhere. Obviously the documents have to be looked at very carefully against these criteria.

That will take more time than people have had until now. It may not take more time than this evening, before Parliament gets up. If it does, it will not take any more time than next Monday afternoon, when we resume; and I repeat that Senator Collins is prepared to give the undertaking, whenever the documents are prepared, to make them available to Senator Bourne so that she has maximum time to prepare whatever response she wants to make to them. That is the situation, as I understand it.

talk.start.para: —Don't call the defence.

—I call Senator Collins in order only, Your Honour, to rise and to give an undertaking that he will in fact directly and personally, on the record, give the undertakings I have described—but he will not redescribe them.

—by leave—The Australian Democrats do see this motion of the Senate as an extremely serious matter. It has been explained to us that its scope is much smaller than the original scope, and we accept that. It has also been explained to us by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) that the Pearce report on satellite tendering was originally going to come down on Tuesday. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) brought it forward to Monday—at our request and the request of the Opposition, I must say—and I do accept that I was one of the people who went to Senator Collins yesterday and said that it would be very good if the report came in today so we could look at it over the weekend.

para.tab: What I am hearing now is that Senator Collins then went and asked for things to be speeded up, and that that took personnel away from getting these other documents together. I did not realise at the time that that would be one of the consequences, and I apologise to the Senate if I am in any way responsible for that consequence. I must say, though, that the Minister's office should have realised that that could have been one of the consequences, and perhaps something should have been done there. But I concede that the Minister was in the Senate with Senator Kernot almost all day yesterday, so for his part getting those documents together would have been very difficult.

I accept that the MDS information should come down next week, after we have seen the results of the second Pearce inquiry. We are being told now that Wednesday, at the latest, is the day for the presentation of the report of the second Pearce inquiry. Given that we are going to have valedictories on Thursday, which may take up half a day, and I imagine we will be very busy on Thursday morning, I would really like to have set aside an entire day in the Senate if necessary to discuss the second Pearce report. I would like to see the documents, if not the second Pearce report, on Tuesday night at the very latest. That would give us that night to look through them and we would want to have a look at the Pearce report by the next morning, at the very latest.

As far as the documents relating to the satellite tender are concerned, I can accept what the Minister says: that they would come over this evening or be couriered to me and to the Opposition spokesperson. I must say that it was only yesterday or the day before that I spoke to the Minister about the Pearce report getting in before the weekend, so I would expect it not to take much more than a day and I would hope to get these documents within a day. If we can get them tonight, and tabled tonight, that would be excellent; but I would really like to see them on Friday at the very latest.

We do see this as a very serious matter, but we are trying to be reasonable. May I suggest to the Minister that he goes back to his office and tells his officers to please keep track of this sort of thing—because somebody should have got back to the department, if the department was not aware of it, obviously a lot sooner than that happened.

speech.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para:
—by leave—Very briefly, I wish to confirm the advice that Senator Evans has provided. He has a reputation for getting across a brief very quickly. Considering that he came cold to this about 10 minutes ago, he has done very well.
There is one additional issue I wish to touch on which is important—

para.tab:
Senator Walters interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —At least I have got a mind to cast. If I am not interrupted, I will take one minute. I want to touch on an important issue and table the letter that provided this advice to both Senator Alston and to Senator Bourne in respect of the MDS matter. I will table Senator Alston's copy. Senator Evans touched on an extremely important issue about legal scrutiny. There are two MDS court cases currently on foot and very active, one in the Federal Court in Sydney and one in the Federal Court in Perth. I was obliged to provide a caution in the letter that I sent to Senator Alston and to Senator Bourne, at the very solid request of senior legal counsel. I will read out the relevant section of the advice from senior legal counsel to me in respect to all documents relating to MDS:

speech.para: I have been cautioned by my legal advisers in the court proceedings to:
refrain from making any comment about the conclusions that should be drawn from the papers—
that is relating to MDS—
and
caution other Senators to have proper regard to the court proceedings in any use of the documents or publications of their contents.

This letter was provided to Senator Alston and to Senator Bourne on 18 May—two days ago. Although this letter specifically relates to the documents I freely provided them with in the Federal Court proceedings in Sydney, it also applies to all of the MDS documents in both court actions that are currently on foot. I table the letter.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Basically, the offers—as I refer to them—are unsatisfactory. There is no doubt about that. If the work had been done in accordance with the previous undertakings of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), the documents would have been tabled today—could have been tabled today—in accordance with the order that the Senate made yesterday. It is clear that that work was not done. One can only draw the conclusion, regrettably, that the Minister had no intention of meeting any of these earlier undertakings that he had given. It is the only interpretation that can be given; otherwise we would have seen the documents. It was our frustration in being constantly given undertakings that were not met that led us to seek the order of the Senate yesterday.

para.tab: It now seems that after the order of the Senate yesterday nothing was done to start preparation of the documents in any event. I know the Minister has been under a lot of pressure, and his department is under pressure, but I regard this matter as totally unsatisfactory. We are after the documents. Senator Evans has given certain undertakings on the basis that preparation will now commence. He has put to us a timetable that would enable the documents to be presented to the Senate on the basis that the preparation of those documents and the necessary checks be made from now. I do not think we have much alternative other than to accept that.
In doing that, we express our grave concern. When Ministers give undertakings in this place we have a right to expect that they will stand by those undertakings. The effect otherwise is—

talk.start.para: —The consent order.

—The consent order was only as a result of the Minister's failure to comply with his undertakings. It should have been unnecessary. The only time that we have sought orders in the past has been when a Minister has refused to give documents or agree to give documents. But day after day this Minister has given the undertaking, `Yes, the documents are coming; they are being gathered; they are being prepared'. It seems that was not the case at all and I find that very regrettable.
—The bulk of them were to be delivered on Tuesday, and the rest on Wednesday. Here we are; it is Thursday.

—That is correct. Even going beyond the documents that were specifically sought by yesterday's order, what about the documents that the Minister undertook to table in the Senate—that is, all documents that were provided to Professor Pearce for his assessment. Obviously, they are in a form in which they can be presented because they had to be first presented to Professor Pearce some week or so ago.

para.tab: I ask Senator Evans whether, in addition to the timetable that he has now put to the Senate for meeting yesterday's order of the Senate, the Minister will comply with his earlier undertaking—that he would table all documents that were produced to Professor Pearce, and upon which Professor Pearce considered and made his report—or is he intending to renege on that undertaking. We need to know whether or not we should seek an order to produce those documents as well. That process should not be necessary but unfortunately, in view of the history of this matter, it now seems to be necessary. So I would like to know whether we should regard as genuine the undertaking given by the Minister yesterday that those documents would be tabled and whether there is any reason why they cannot be tabled today.

speech.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I would like to respond to the last part of Senator Hill's request. I did in fact also give the explanation for this during the luncheon session but I will give it again now. The undertaking to table all the documents that Professor Pearce examined in relation to this report was given in good faith and what subsequently happened simply gives an indication of just how independent Professor Pearce's handling of this matter has been. And I am still happy to discharge the obligation, Senator Hill. Outside of his formal examination of me, with his assistant Dr whoever it was, I have had no contact with Professor Pearce. I gave this explanation. I will read the relevant section of the report. In the introduction to the report, at the bottom of the page, Professor Pearce said:

speech.para: I have been provided with access to what appear to be all relevant documents of the department.

For Senator Hill's benefit, I will say again what I said at lunchtime. I had made an assumption—not an unreasonable one—that all the documents would probably be given to Parliament. The explanation I have been given, and it makes sense, is that Professor Pearce, having examined all the documents—and he says he did, so I do not dispute he did—determined that the only documents that were really relevant to the central issue of this matter, which is what has been debated in here every day for three weeks, namely, my responsibility, were two documents. I said this at lunchtime.

talk.start.para: —The two documents which are attached to the report.

—Correct—the two documents which are attached to the report. I have been telling the Senate for three weeks that I only got two documents containing advice to me about the process. Professor Pearce has examined all of the documents available in the department and has found no more. I said this at lunchtime. So Professor Pearce has confirmed that the only two documents that relate to direct advice given to me about the process were the two documents that I received in my office.

para.tab: There was no attempt to mislead the Senate or give undertakings I was not prepared to discharge when I said that all the documents would be tabled with the report, because the original reporting date, as Senator Bourne has confirmed, was going to be Monday. I will give the undertaking again. Professor Pearce says in the introduction that he has not found any documents other than the ones I have been talking about for three weeks, and he has therefore attached only those. But I will again undertake to provide to the Senate the documents that Professor Pearce has examined, providing the same three normal conditions are attached to those documents as Senator Evans has just outlined: that they are cleared for Cabinet confidentiality, for commercial-in-confidence and—

talk.start.para: —How many are there?

—I do not know. I said to the Senate earlier today and about two weeks ago—look in
Hansard
—that two large boxes had been delivered to Professor Pearce. That is the extent of my knowledge. Once again we are in the same roundabout where you get dammed if you get involved and dammed if you don't. I have scrupulously kept away from his inquiry ever since. I assumed that all the documents would be tabled. Professor Pearce has decided that the only two documents tabled today are the ones that he thought were relevant, and they are the only ones he has been able to find relating to direct advice to me. Now that I have the report I reiterate the undertaking, notwithstanding Professor Pearce's decision, that I will table in the Senate the papers that Professor Pearce has examined, after they have been cleared for Cabinet-in-confidence, commercial-in-confidence and any legal examination.
—by leave—I take it that that undertaking has been given according to the deadline timetable of next Monday as well.

—by leave—Yes. I said I was not going to add to anything Senator Evans said. But as Senator Evans said earlier—and I have confirmed the undertaking—the documents relating to the satellite, not MDS, will be tabled on Monday. This is getting very boring, but that was the original undertaking—Monday. I reconfirm it. The answer is yes.

—by leave—Let me clarify this so that we do not have another argument later on. The terms of the motion that we have been arguing about, and in respect of which I gave the undertakings, are really quite narrow. The motion concerns copies of requests and documents relating to such requests made by the Minister or his office between January and May for technical, legal or other advice, and copies of legal, technical or other advice rendered to the Minister or his office during the same time frame. That is a very narrowly cast request, and it may well be that, construed narrowly, there are no more than two documents that satisfy that description. I was assuming that the field was wider than that in relation to satellite. A further question has been raised which is not directly subsumed by the terms of this motion, and that concerns all the documents that Professor Pearce may have looked at. Do I understand it that Senator Collins is said to have made some undertaking on some previous occasion or now in relation to all the documents that Professor Pearce looked at?
—Yes, and he acknowledged that.

—Let me now clarify that. Subject to the normal scrutiny that will have to be given to any document, the kinds of grounds that Senator Collins has mentioned—and they are not exhaustive, despite what my learned friend has said; there may be others as well, I make that clear for the record—all the documents that Professor Pearce looked at will then be tabled or presented in accordance with the timetable and undertakings that I laid out before. Is that absolutely clear?

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the Government Business order of the day relating to the Independent Inquiry into the Circumstances Surrounding the Non-requirement of a Deposit for Satellite Pay-TV Licences be called on immediately and have precedence over all other business till determined.
Debate resumed.

speech.speaker: Alston Sen R.K.R.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the documents.

speech.para: I want to make it clear from the outset that we have no quarrel with the authorship of the report that has been tabled in the Senate today. Professor Pearce is eminently qualified to deal with the matter and he has clearly done the job that he was asked to do. In no way are we impugning his integrity or seeking to make any personal attacks. I simply put that on the record at the outset because I apprehend that when I do move to some criticisms of the reports inevitably the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, will say that it is an ad hominem attack. I want that to be perfectly clear. The first thing to be said is that the terms of reference of Professor Pearce were narrow, and he conceded that explicitly. He said:

I did not seek an amendment to the Terms of Reference, noting their narrow compass and the short period for completion of the inquiry (it should be observed that the Terms of Reference do not require me to comment on issues arising from the doctrine of ministerial responsibility).
In other words, there is nothing at all in this document that can exonerate Senator Collins from any allegations that might be made in terms of ministerial responsibility.

talk.start.para: —What about page 16?

—I am simply pointing out that whatever might be said by way of gratuitous obiter dicta is utterly irrelevant to the terms of reference. All I can say is that page iii, for example, where it talks about no systemic deficiency, which just happens to coincide with the form of words that Senator Collins has chosen to use in defining ministerial responsibility, again can in no way be regarded as passing judgment on Senator Collins' actions. It will be our contention that the only appropriate place for that matter is in the Senate. At the end of the Minister's tabling statement, he said, `I'd rather be found accused of an error of judgment than to stand here today accused of a rush to judgment'. That seems to imply that, because the report talks in terms of an error of judgment, Senator Collins is accepting responsibility for that at worst. If that is the case, that is a significant advance because for the first time he seems to be prepared to accept responsibility for the actions of his subordinates and not simply to bag them as he has done for the last three weeks.

para.tab:
There is a very important point to be made about all this, although it is conceded on all fronts that something serious went wrong. For example, I note that Senator Bourne was saying on
PM
recently:

speech.para: Now obviously someone is to blame for this mess. The question is: is Senator Collins the one with the ultimate responsibility in this situation?
I would have thought it was obvious that someone was to blame for this mess, yet this report manages not to point the finger at anyone. Indeed, what it does—

talk.start.para: —I knew you were going to say that, whatever it said.

—I am just making the obvious statement. It does not deal with Senator Collins—we will do that. It does say that this was an error of judgment. An error of judgment is an alternative expression to negligence, and it really means that no-one is to blame.
—You call yourself a lawyer. Words are important, Senator Alston. Lawyers choose them carefully.

—I did not mean to say it is another description of negligence; I meant to say it is the opposite to negligence. It is saying that there is no negligence involved; it is merely an error of judgment. The fact is that quite obviously a lot went wrong, yet the final conclusion is:

speech.para: I do not consider that my inquiry has revealed any systemic deficiency in the Department's practices,—
and that is not surprising because Professor Pearce is only dealing with one episode—
nor has it revealed a general want of capability in any officers of the Department.

That seems quite a surprising conclusion to reach when one accepts that Professor Pearce says that it was desirable that matters were brought to the attention of the Minister. One would have expected officers of the department to have addressed this issue and, in various ways, Professor Pearce makes it clear that he thinks the issue of a deposit would have been discussed. I find it surprising when it is suggested a deposit was not discussed. He goes on to make it clear that he believes these matters should have been brought to the attention of the Minister.

para.tab: That is quite a separate question to what actions the Minister himself should have taken, and I will deal with that briefly. It is quite clear that this is not a Minister without any experience at all; this is a Minister who had been the Minister for Communications for some nine months as at January of this year—a Minister who was clearly aware of pre-existing approaches to tender, and particularly in this area. If one looks at paragraph 46, one sees:

speech.para: At the date of the pay-TV determination he—
the Minister—
was familiar with the MDS and AM-FM conversion procedures, both of which required payment of deposits (of differing kinds).

It follows from that that this was not a Minister acting in ignorance; this was not a Minister who knew nothing about communications; this was a Minister who was familiar with the procedures that had been adopted in other instances and who, therefore, ought to have immediately turned his mind to what procedures were being followed in this instance.

para.tab: Let us look at what Senator Collins has previously said. He said that he had read the determination of 19 January before he signed it. He said that he checked it for completeness. Professor Pearce says of Senator Collins:

speech.para: The Minister thinks that he read the minute sometime in the period before his return to Canberra on 18 January. . .

He is there talking about a draft determination dated 4 January which is attached as appendix 3. It is perfectly clear that Professor Pearce is expressing grave concern about the procedures in the Minister's office. The minute which was hand delivered to the Minister's office was not logged in in the normal fashion. Presumably the only reason why Professor Pearce does not reach any conclusion at the end in that regard is that, again, he accepts that he is only examining the failings of the bureaucracy.

para.tab: It is clear that that document was read by the Minister sometime between 4 and 19 January. Indeed, as I understand it, he also read the actual determination before he signed it. So on two separate occasions the Minister's attention was drawn to the requirement for only a $500 application fee; therefore, there is no excuse whatsoever for the Minister not to have turned his mind to the subject and sought advice.
Professor Pearce, in the Opposition's view, makes some very charitable interpretations of the way in which a lot of these issues were handled.

talk.start.para: —You started off by saying you were not going to impugn his report.
—Let us just examine some of the propositions. Professor Pearce stated in his report:

speech.para: In a perfect world the Minister's advisers would have gone through the minutes and Determination and alerted the Minister to the absence of deposit requirements.
I would not have thought a perfect world was needed to have that happen. That ought to happen as a matter of course. Not only that, he says:
This was a matter of process. . .

It is not a matter of process, and that is demonstrated by the fact that we have recently passed through this Parliament a Bill amending the Broadcasting Act to provide and require a deposit to be paid. It is clearly a matter of high policy.

talk.start.para: —Did you support it?
—Of course we did not.
—You opposed it.

—Yes, of course, we opposed it. But I am saying that it was a matter of policy, not a matter of process. The Minister should pay attention to the argument. It is not a matter of process; it is a matter of policy. He then goes on:

speech.para: In this case . . . the Minister's office was short-staffed with most members taking annual leave, a fact of which the Department was or should have been aware.

Again, it is absolutely no excuse to say that somehow because people had had a long and tiring parliamentary session, that it was over the Christmas vacation and that some people were on leave, the Minister was absolved from any responsibility to make his own inquiries and to call up staff if they were on holidays. None of that happened.

talk.start.para: —I said that. Mea culpa.

—Mea culpa, that is right. So it is very clear therefore that the Minister was in a position to have pursued these matters and to have obtained policy advice and manifestly failed to do so. The other excuses—the paperwork flow, having to sign a large number of documents of different kinds, not being expected to peruse each of these closely—were all trotted out in here numerous times. No doubt those excuses were trotted out again to Professor Pearce.

para.tab: But by no stretch of the imagination could one regard this document as just another one of a large number of documents. This was a crucial document. This was actually the document that started the whole satellite licence process—arguably the most important document in the history of pay TV in Australia. And here is the Minister telling Professor Pearce that it is basically just another piece of paper.

talk.start.para: —Where does it say that?
—It says:

speech.para: The Minister signs a large number of documents of different kinds. He cannot be expected to peruse each of these closely.

talk.start.para: —He didn't—you just made up that part.
—Like you make everything up, Senator Alston.

—If Senator Collins wants to get up and say, `I have said that in the chamber on a number of times but I did not say it to Professor Pearce', then I will be amazed. Professor Pearce either heard it from Senator Collins or he read the
Hansard
. Let us not get into how he got there; he got there. He puts forward this proposition:

speech.para: The Minister . . . cannot be expected to peruse each of these closely.

I am simply saying that in no way describes this document. It is not one of a large number and no-one expects him to read every one of a large number of documents very closely, but one expects a Minister to read a document of the seriousness of this document.

para.tab: There is also a statement in there that the Minister may not have had this important document brought to his attention. I do not know why that statement is made at all because the Minister acknowledges that he did and told Professor Pearce that in relation to the fourth that he thought he had.

talk.start.para: —There is no record of it.
—What is the point of volunteering that?
—Resign if you are mea culpa.
—Because I didn't put on another staff member in January?

—That is precisely the point—the Minister is condemned out of his own mouth. He should have put on a staff member over January. He should have sought advice from those who were already on his staff and could have been brought back. He should have sought advice from a whole range of people because he should have recognised the importance of this document and that provision, and manifestly he did not.

para.tab: This report, as Professor Pearce says, is of very narrow compass. There are very generous conclusions. It ultimately does not find anyone responsible. Having identified a whole series of administrative and bureaucratic—

talk.start.para: —Blame the umpire.
—I am not blaming the umpire.
—Of course you are.

—That is why I said at the outset that this would happen—that whatever we said those opposite would say we were bagging the umpire. That is why I made the point at the outset of saying we were not—and we are not.
—But you just did—three times.
—Just a minute. Persons of good faith can disagree about judgments, I would have thought.
—I agree with that.

—Good. Therefore, there is nothing wrong or improper or `kicking the umpire' to say that some of Professor Pearce's conclusions seem strange, are hard to accept and, indeed, in some instances are conflicting. He identifies a number of examples of where the process went horribly wrong. They found that document, but they do not know how it originated. No-one seems to take responsibility for knowing how the subject came up.
—I do.
—You do?
—Yes, two weeks ago.
—You accept responsibility for all that went on in your department, do you?
—A fortnight ago I accepted responsibility for what happened in my office in January, yes.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)
—Order! At the risk of being relevant, I wonder if I might be involved in this debate as well.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the point is that what went on in the department was clearly a succession of administrative failings. Yet the disappointment about this whole report is that at the end of the day no-one is responsible. Indeed, there is not even negligence, merely errors of judgment. That is clearly nowhere near good enough if one wants to get to the bottom of this fiasco, let alone to make sure it does not happen again. The only appropriate way that can be achieved is by establishing a select committee and ensuring that the proper processes are followed, that the failings are properly identified and that the system starts to work. But all we have here is pointing to a whole range of things that went wrong but then saying, `Well, it's no-one's fault in particular; indeed, it's no-one's fault'. That, I would have thought, is a contradiction in terms.

para.tab: In no way does this report absolve or exonerate the Minister. It quite clearly was outside Professor Pearce's terms of reference, as we always said it was. Senator Collins, of course, always wanted to maintain that somehow this document would clear him. It does nothing of the sort. In fact, it seems to clear the department, even though it identifies a number of problems. But it certainly does not get Senator Collins off the hook. In view of what Senator Collins has said today, I would have thought he has made a number of major concessions about his responsibilities—

talk.start.para:
—Just what I said two weeks ago. Look at the
Hansard
.

—No, I do not think it is. I think Senator Collins is all about how he should not be blamed for anything that did not actually come to him; that if it was just Mr Meagher finding out about something that is not the same as it coming to his attention.
—Hey!
—That is what Senator Collins said in relation to the MDS process.
—Have a look at what Mr Meagher said about the role of ministerial advisers.

—That is what Senator Collins said in relation to the MDS process, as I understand it. If he is now saying that something brought to the attention of Bruce Meagher should be treated as coming to his attention, that again is a very significant concession. The catastrophic failing is that he chose—

para.tab:
Government members interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order!

—Senator Collins ought to have known the importance of this document. He clearly did not bother. He was sitting up in Darwin not bothering to check with his office, not bothering to talk to any professionals. There are, I think, still a number of documents that need to be examined before one can again pass judgment. But the fact remains that this report does not go very far indeed in terms of remedying any administrative deficiencies. It certainly does not go anywhere near getting Senator Collins off the hook. It makes it clear that in a number of respects there were very significant failings. This was a very important document; Professor Pearce, I think, also makes that clear. On that basis, of course, Senator Collins should have realised it.

para.tab: Senator Collins also made another significant concession today. In the course of telling us how my memory was poor, he told us that he had a very good memory and that that was one of his great attributes. If he had a very good memory, clearly when he looked at that draft determination in the first instance—

talk.start.para: —Never forgive, never forget, senator.
—Does he not now have a very good memory?
—Never forgive and never forget, senator.
—What? A water buffalo never forgets?
—No, it is an old quote from Neville Wran.
—Well, I do not think he is a witness.
—Senator Bishop recognised the quote.
—Neville walked when he got caught out.

—That is right; he knew when to tap the mat. The point is that this very proposition about having a good memory is highly relevant. What it means is that when Senator Collins signed that determination, when he read the draft two weeks before, he must not only have been aware, by virtue of the collective memory, of those other two relevant episodes, but he also ought to have called them to mind in this context and asked himself whether this same procedure was being followed in this instance, and he clearly did not.
—That is all covered in here. Read it. You have not read it.
—Tell me where it says that.
—Bottom of page 10.

—It says nothing of the sort. What it does say, at paragraph 46, is that the Minister `was familiar with the MDS and AM-FM conversion procedures'. Therefore, the Minister should immediately have recognised that this document did not go down the same path.
—Bottom of page 10, `expressio unius est exclusio alterius'. You are the embodiment of `expressio stupidus'.
—The Minister thinks expressio unius is going to help him get out of this one. Over the page the document states:

speech.para: But in recent years it has been described as a weak aid to interpretation because it implies an intention on the part of the legislator that may not have been held.

Senator Collins would have us believe that because it mentions a $500 deposit fee, that ought to automatically—we are alleging—make him aware of the rest of the context. Of course, it should. The Minister should have been acutely aware of the procedure that was being followed in this instance. The Minister is paid handsomely to be a policy expert. He is supposed to draw on his accumulated experience. He is supposed to know what the process is all about. He is the one who is passing ultimate judgment on it when he initiates the procedure by signing the determination. Yet, for reasons never explained, the Minister did nothing.

talk.start.para: —He used to be chairman of the regulations and ordinances committee. He knows how detailed they are.

—It is unbelievable. The Minister chose to do nothing; not to seek advice, not to call up any staff, not to disturb them on holiday, not to even—he would say—recognise what should have been staring him in the face. If that is not a gross dereliction of duty, I do not know what is.
—Six months without a day off, my staff have had.

—Big deal. Professor Pearce does not say that all of the Minister's staff were on holiday and I do not think the Minister does either. A staffer was away on holiday, as I recall it. Professor Pearce says that they were on holiday sequentially, which I took to mean that they were not all on leave at the same time.
—Read what he said about the role of ministerial advisers.

—Again, I find it extraordinary that he makes a statement about ministerial advisers being a comparatively recent phenomenon. It has been a hallmark of this Government. This Government has been here 10 years, and the Ministers rely constantly on ministerial advisers. If they are not paid party hacks acutely attuned to all the politics of the issue, they are presumably policy advisers. In other words, they are there.
—Look at what he said about their role.
—In his concluding remarks, Professor Pearce states:

speech.para: The comparatively recent phenomenon of Ministers having advisers. . . does not remove this obligation from a Department. Advisers are also much more likely to be concerned with political/policy issues than process.

I have made the point several times that this is not a process issue, this is a policy issue; advisers are there to advise. If the Minister has an office full of people who do not have any idea or recollection of the history of tender processes in communication, what is the point? He might as well just close his eyes and sign every piece of paper that comes along. Quite clearly, advisers are critical of the process and if they are not, they might as well all be on leave permanently. The fact is that the Minister had an adviser—
