talk.start.para: —I will tell you what, Senator Alston; come into my office and I will let you be Minister for a day.
—If it is getting to the Minister like that, I think he needs more than a day's break.
—It is not. I am coping very well after this garbage.

—That is not the view of others, I would not have thought. Suffice it to say that this report does not take us very far down the track in terms of identifying who is responsible within the bureaucracy. It certainly does not provide any guidance or comfort in terms of ensuring that these problems do not recur. Finally, it does absolutely nothing to get Senator Collins off the hook.

—Professor Pearce has concluded in this inquiry that the failure of departmental officers to advise the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) that a substantial deposit was not required in the determination was an error of judgment on their part. In fact, he considers it to be an error of judgment, and just that. I think, considering the consequences, we can consider it to be quite a large error of judgment.

para.tab: The reasons for not including a deposit requirement were: it might deter new media players; the provision in the Broadcasting Services Act for ABA and TPC scrutiny of successful bidders; the winning bidders only won the right to be considered and would not automatically obtain a licence, and they would have to pay the full amount within a relatively short time frame of 30 days. Clearly, the department did not foresee the consequences. Very obviously, it did not foresee the consequences.

talk.start.para: —That is right.
—It did not draw the consequences specifically to the Minister's attention and, in hindsight—which of course we all have very clearly—it is clear that it should have.

para.tab: The Democrats have no reason to doubt Professor Pearce's interpretation of the facts before him or indeed any of Professor Pearce's reasoning in this report. He appears to have had full access to witnesses and documents. However, we are looking forward to the relevant documents being tabled. Let me reiterate that the Senate has its own time pressures and hence our insistence that with or without the second Pearce review, all the documents related to MDS tender and satellite tender under the Senate's order should be tabled no later than next Tuesday night.

The debate about this issue has become focused almost exclusively on whether the Minister should be sacked. This is obviously a very important question. As I said last Tuesday during the discussion of a matter of public importance relating to this matter, the Democrats we believe that any Minister should resign if he makes a serious error which he had sufficient information to avoid making. On the evidence in this report the Democrats do not believe that the Minister's resignation is warranted. On balance, the error appears to lie with the department. The doctrine of ministerial responsibility, as we defined it, demands that the Minister get on with cleaning up this mess.

In all this debate, there has been far too little focus on what course of action will deliver the best pay TV system, the best prospect for Australian news and drama, Australian culture, and the maximum potential for Australian jobs and Australian exports. We have to acknowledge that—and this is very ironic—despite the magnitude of this error of judgment, the result was to err in favour of media diversity, rather than privileging existing media players.

talk.start.para: —Yes, it is a bit of irony for DTAC.

—As Senator Kernot says, this is quite an irony for DTAC. Given consistent criticism that the Government was privileging existing players, it is perhaps preferable that that error was made in the other direction. However, given the findings in this report the Democrats believe that the objectives I have stated would be best served by ministerial continuity. Senator Collins now intimately knows, I should imagine, the pitfalls in his portfolio and will therefore hopefully be much more skilled in avoiding them. A new Minister would have to start from scratch.

para.tab: What this report reveals is that the Minister will have to improve the running of his office, and if we have a look at page 15 we will find that out. The Democrats remain convinced that the Minister must take a much harder look at the policies pursued by his department which we believe have been significantly at odds with the Government's policy and with the wishes of this Parliament. In saying that, I confine my criticism to the Department's handling of communications policy.

The Democrats will continue to pursue this matter to ensure that the department understands that it is a servant of the political process and not its master. We will make sure the Minister ensures that he firmly establishes that relationship and we expect to see a large swag of documents in this chamber by next Tuesday night. We look forward to examining them very carefully.

speech.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —Before lunch the Minster for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, suggested to the Senate that this document was a report which was put together to determine whether he should resign. That is an extraordinary statement for Senator Collins to make. He obviously did not even get as far as page 1, or maybe he got as far as page 1 but his memory became rather selective. On page 1 of his report, Professor Pearce says:

speech.para: . . . (it should be observed that the terms of reference do not require me to comment on issues arising from the doctrine of ministerial responsibility).

That clearly establishes that this document cannot, in any sense of the word, be seen to be an excuse for, or a vindication of, the Minister's own incompetence. Nor does it allow Senator Collins to escape the consequences of his responsibility as a Minister. His responsibility as a Minister is to oversee his department and to answer to this Parliament. It is our responsibility in this Parliament to see that he answers to us, and to see that he is held accountable for what happens within his department.

para.tab: No doubt we are going to hear from Senator Collins at length. No doubt we are going to hear every single story he can possibly come up with. He may even tell us about sitting under a tree in Maningrida. Senator Collins has left us all sitting under a tree at Maningrida because they do not have pay TV there and nor do we. It is going to take us a hell of a lot longer to get pay TV because of the mess-up that Senator Collins has made of this issue. Senator Collins is beyond useless. He does not even have a purpose. He is purposeless.

Let us go through this report and see how it, in itself, raises issues that go right to the heart of Senator Collins's ability as a Minister, and his ability to discharge his obligations not just in regard to his department, but here—to answer for that department in this chamber. One of the interesting things about this report is that it highlights the fact that the advice, the minute, that was given to the Minister sat in his office for 14 days. I am not saying that every bit of correspondence that comes into the office of a senator gets turned around within 14 days. It would be grossly untrue to say that. However, when one gets the single most important piece of paper that is likely to cross one's desk, at least in the space of that month, if not perhaps in the space of the first six months of that year, one might want to have a look.

We might even give Senator Collins the benefit of the doubt and say that if it was sitting on his desk for 14 days maybe he was actually considering it. That is the most charitable thing we can say about Senator Collins. But I do not think he was considering it. The document in question, which is attached to this report as appendix 3, says some interesting things. At the bottom of the first page of the document, it says:

speech.para: The draft determination makes it clear that the allocation process is to be a tender procedure with the highest price tendered being the sole criteria if the other considerations are met.
The minute then goes on to outline the other considerations:

These other considerations are the submission of an adequate industry plan (with the possibility of a plan being imposed as a licence condition if the submitted plan is inadequate), approval from the Trade Practices Commission as required by the Act and possible ABA consideration of the suitability of the applicant.
The next paragraph says:
The draft determination requires the tenderers to provide a $500 application fee that will make a small contribution to the costs of the process—
and given the mix-up we have had with this process, that will make a very small contribution—
and help discourage frivolous tenders.

There is absolutely no reference at all to a deposit. It makes it very clear that it is price and price alone, subject to those other considerations and to no other considerations. It is very clear from that, that if Senator Collins had read this minute, and it is only a two-page minute, he might have had cause—a reasonable person might have had cause—to say, `Maybe I should ask about the possibility of a deposit. We have done it with the others. Maybe I should ask about it here'. But no, this minute sat there for 14 days and Senator Collins did not even think to ask. I remember once asking a colleague of mine in the Queensland State Parliament, a very successful Minister—

talk.start.para: —You have got a few colleagues, have you?

—I have got a few colleagues who have a little bit more confidence in me than Senator Collins has. The truth of the matter is that some of the Minister's backbench colleagues who have some integrity, some who have decided not to come into the chamber today because they cannot stand behind him and back him all the way, do not have confidence in his ability to discharge his job. It is interesting that, even a couple of weeks ago, before all of the other damning evidence came out against the Minister, one of his colleagues said to me that, frankly, he did not want to defend the Minister because the Minister had stuffed up and he could not, in good conscience, defend him. That is the truth. The Minister does not even have the confidence of some of his own backbench.

para.tab: No doubt he has got the confidence of Senator Cooney, who is well-known as one of the most charitable people in this chamber. Senator Cooney's confidence has always been available when it has been required. Frankly, Senator Collins might need the confidence of more than just Senator Cooney and Senator Carr on the other side of the chamber. I think the absence of his other colleagues is a clear indication that he does not have their confidence.

I asked my colleague, to whom I referred, this question: what makes a good Minister and what makes a bad Minister? What is the difference between a Minister who is successful and a Minister who is a failure? He said, `A good Minister is able to stand up to his department. A good Minister requires his department to perform. A good Minister always keeps his department under scrutiny'. Senator Collins's explanation for this matter, as honourable senators will be well aware by now, is that he had a lot of other documents crossing his desk. When Senator Alston was discussing Senator Collins's manifest failures, the interjection came, `Look, you come and see the paperwork in my office and I'll make you Minister for a day'.

It is not as though the determination that Senator Collins signed was any one of a number of determinations; it is not as though it was one of a whole heap of letters he may have signed to new enrollees in his electorate. This letter was the determination for the pay TV system that was supposed to be the shining star of his period as Minister in this department. It was not one of a number of documents; it was one of the most important documents that Senator Collins would sign.

Even if it were just one of the other documents, it is interesting to note that Senator Collins has for a long time in this chamber, and outside this chamber, prided himself on the job that he did as Chairman of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. He did a very good job. One of the reasons why he did a very good job was that he ensured that the delegated instruments were properly made. He ensured that the delegated legislation that was made was absolutely and thoroughly put together. He had a hallmark for being a person very attentive to the documents. Yet, when he deals with the most important document that will cross his desk as a Minister, what does he do? He just signs it and does not even think to ask what has happened to the deposit.

Senator Collins is going to speak in a few minutes and tell us a story grand. He is going to tell us a marvellous story about officers of his department being overworked. He is going to tell us how his personal staff were on holidays—

talk.start.para: —How he only had one day off in six months.

—How he only had one day off in six months, as though some of us do not have similar work pressures. He is going to tell us every story imaginable. He might even bring in the Man from Snowy River or he might bring in Saltbush Bill from the Barcoo to stand in his defence. But what we are not going to hear from Senator Collins is the truth: that Senator Collins, as the Minister, bears the responsibility for this failure; that Senator Collins, as the Minister, does not have the integrity to say, `Yes, I am responsible for this stuff-up and a series of stuff-ups'.

para.tab: Senator Bourne said that, in her opinion, we need some ministerial continuity. That assumes that the Minister's track record to date has been one that obliges some degree of confidence in his ability to continue to perform the job. In looking at Senator Collins's degree of competence and at how well his track record stands up to scrutiny, we should remember that his big boast when he became a Minister was, `If I can't get waterfront reform right in the space of 12 months, I will resign'. On national television he said, `I'll resign if I can't fix the waterfront in 12 months'. Just this week we received a report showing that the cost of loading a 20-foot container in Melbourne has fallen just $4.24 in the space of the two-plus years that Senator Collins had to fix the waterfront. So his track record on the waterfront has not been that good.

Then there are the other manifest failures in Senator Collins's period as Minister. Of course, we had the TAATS contract. We had evidence that the TAATS contract was not going as it should and that it ought to be reviewed. As honourable senators would know, Senator Collins stuck his head in the sand—

talk.start.para: —That would be a better place than where you have your head stuck.

—Irrespective of where Senator Collins has his head stuck, it is always in the dark. He never opens his eyes to look at what is going on around him. It is quite clear that he did not open his eyes when this minute was presented to him. So we had Senator Collins's manifest failure on the TAATS contract, when he insisted time in and time out that there was absolutely nothing wrong with the TAATS process at all. Now we have this situation.

para.tab:
It is fine to talk about ministerial continuity but we must remember that we are going to have a Minister of continuing incompetence. In fact, we will have a Minister who is like the
Hindenburg
—full of hot air, lurching from one disaster to the next. I think that is an adequate summation of the way in which Senator Collins has discharged his duties.

Senator Collins can get up and say whatever he likes, but the truth is that he is a failure. The truth is that he is beyond useless; he is purposeless. That is why Senator Collins ought to have the decency to stand down.

speech.speaker: Cooney Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —That was a great speech by Senator O'Chee and—
—You are very charitable.
—Senator O'Chee made quite clear what he wanted to do, and that was to deliver a polemic against Senator Collins, and it was well delivered.
—Hang him, actually.
—That is right—that is exactly what Senator Alston wants to do, too.
—That is not fair.
—Yes it is, because Senator Alston said the other day that one offence was sufficient for a hanging, or words to that effect.
—This is an Oakes job.

—Senator Archer says that this is an Oakes job but the fact of the matter is that the speech we have just heard was very much a polemic. Senator O'Chee said, `Senator Collins should leave. He should do this and he should do that'. But that is not based on the evidence. Senator O'Chee did not purport to base his speech on the evidence. He made that quite clear when he said, `What we are not going to hear from Senator Collins is the truth'. This was said before Senator Collins had spoken. Had Senator O'Chee said, `I have heard Senator Collins and he has not told us the truth', that would be a different matter. But in effect, he has said, `What we are going to hear from Senator Collins will not be the truth'.

para.tab: We have a lot of work to get through in this chamber and we must resolve how we give priority to it. If the priority is to sit here—as we will no doubt do for the next few days—to see whether Senator Collins can be brought down by fair means or foul, then so be it. There is not much we can do about that.

talk.start.para: —No, fair.

—Is it fair when Senator Alston says that this report in no way exonerates the Minister or that it certainly does not let him off the hook? If those opposite say this matter is to be handled fairly, why do not come to it with a dispassionate mind? The language used against Senator Collins is hardly consistent with dealing with this matter fairly. The volume of rhetoric that comes from those opposite is not consistent with treating Senator Collins fairly.
—Which term of reference?

—The big problem—we would have it on this side if somebody opposite were in the firing line—is that we cannot come at this matter with a lack of bias. The problem with this report from the point of view of those opposite is that it puts Senator Collins's position in a good light.
—Do you know Professor Pearce?

—Yes, I know Professor Pearce well. He is certainly a man of great honour and integrity and his report is a good one. Since it is good and it helps Senator Collins's position, it has to be overcome by the Opposition. That is why it is subject to attack from those opposite. The Opposition has not looked at the integrity of the report; it has looked at its conclusions. Opposition senators have said, `Those conclusions are not consistent with the sort of charge that we want to bring home against Senator Collins, and therefore this report has to go'.

para.tab: Senator Alston made a great statement, in the old terms of wanting to wound but being afraid to strike, when he said, `We think Dennis Pearce is a great man'. I have not heard anybody here today say that he is not. But having said that, Opposition senators then tackled the task of trying to undo his report. First of all, they said that it does not talk about what is required for ministerial responsibility. Of course it does not because Professor Pearce was not asked to deal with that topic.

The Opposition then said, `The terms of reference were narrow'. They were narrow because that is all Professor Pearce was asked to deal with. It does not follow that, because Professor Pearce has not turned his mind to the legal issue, if you like, of what ministerial responsibility is and because his terms of reference are narrow, this report has nothing to do with Senator Collins's position here. It has a lot to do with it, as can be seen from paragraph 48 of the conclusions:

speech.para: I conclude that the advice to the Minister was not sufficient to alert him to the fact that he was adopting a process that did not involve deposit requirements by signing the Determination.
The inference from all that is that is what the Minister was entitled to have.

para.tab: Somebody else might then have gone ahead and attacked the department and Senator Collins's advisers. But this report—in my view, it seems a very reasonable report—says that, given the time and situation, it is understandable that the people who were to advise the Minister did not alert him sufficiently on this occasion. But as far as the Minister is concerned in terms of this report, there is absolutely no criticism of him.

talk.start.para: —He was not asked to.

—Of course he was not asked to, that is true. But because he was not asked that specific question—whether the Minister should be hung and laid out to dry—it does not follow that what is in this report is of no consequence to that question. Of course what he said in this report is of vital consequence to that question.

para.tab: What does it mean if it does not reflect on the Minister's position? Professor Pearce says in that paragraph:

speech.para: I conclude that the advice to the Minister was not sufficient to alert him to the fact that he was adopting a process that did not involve deposit requirements by signing the Determination.

Paragraph 48 was not put in the report as a consequence of Professor Pearce being asked to tell us about the rights or wrongs of the Minister. It was not put in there because he was asked in wide terms to look at the matter from go to whoa. Of course he was not asked that.

para.tab: The fact that it is in the report reflects on the issue that is before us as to whether or not the Minister should have pursued a different course. On that question it is of great significance. Professor Pearce—an outstanding man and one for whom Senator Alston, who is leading this debate on behalf of the Opposition, said he has nothing but respect—said in paragraph 54:

speech.para: In my view the conclusion is inescapable that it was a mistake for the departmental officers not to bring certain aspects of the tendering process to the attention of the Minister.
I will leave out the next sentence, but he goes on to say:
I find that an error of judgement was made but that is all that it was—an error of judgement.
As Senator Alston himself has said, an error of judgment is not a negligent act.

para.tab: What comes out of this report is that a most unfortunate consequence flowed from the Minister not being advised correctly, but that that did not arise from any negligence, dishonesty or gross dereliction of duty; it arose from a set of circumstances which Professor Pearce sets out in his report.

Those opposite could produce evidence which is contrary to Professor Pearce's report or attack his conclusions, but they must remember that they are doing it from the point of view—and I do not say this in any pejorative away, because it is the same on this side of the chamber—of a group of people who want to get Senator Collins. The Opposition has been quite open about that.

talk.start.para: —Come on! Only to keep him responsible.

—I hope Senator Walters speaks on this matter. I will be very sorry when she leaves this chamber because she has contributed a great deal to it, but she must answer the problem that Senator Alston and Senator O'Chee have created for her; that is, that they both spoke in a polemic fashion. If they speak in that fashion, then a polemic has been directed against Senator Collins. If, on the other hand, opposition senators want to analyse this report from Professor Pearce, perhaps they ought to take it to an independent legal source. However, they had better be careful of the advice that they get, because legal advice is not necessarily always correct. However, it would be given dispassionately and without bias.

para.tab: Honourable senators should accept this report, as I do, as the work of a competent and honest person who tried to do his best on the basis of all the evidence given to him. I understand from what Senator Collins has said that opposition senators will have that evidence next week. But, on the basis of all that evidence, Professor Pearce has reached that conclusion.

Earlier this week a war crimes trial was concluded and the jury found the defendant not guilty. A lot of people may have been disappointed about that, but people—Mr Leibler, for example—said that that was the verdict of the jury. Perhaps they were disappointed or upset, but they accepted what the jury said.

talk.start.para: —They weren't restricted in their terms.

—The honourable senator says that they were not restricted in their terms. I do not suggest that this is the position of those opposite, but there are certain occasions when, no matter what one says, one will go down. An example is the case of original founder of the Christian faith to which all of us in here adhere so strongly—no matter what he said before the tribunal, he was going to go down.
—And he did.
—Yes, and he did.
—You are not trying to draw an analogy.

—I have always found Senator Bishop to be a very fair person with a clear and unbiased mind, and there might be sufficient evidence to convince her. But I think my getting up here and making this speech will have absolutely no effect on the Opposition in general. Senator MacGibbon says that I am taking up time. I would be more than happy to conclude my speech and sit down on the basis that I am wasting time if Opposition senators would do the same and let this matter rest. If, on the other hand, Senator MacGibbon or any of his colleagues are going to get up over the next few days and speak against Senator Collins, then I will continue to speak.

para.tab: Another indication of the sort of attitude that has been directed against Senator Collins is that when anybody speaks against him, when anybody tries to drag him down, that is all very pertinent to the proceedings here; that is sufficient to hold up government business or any other matter that comes before the chamber. But as soon as anybody gets up—such as me, in my very inadequate way—and tries to defend the Minister, that is a waste of time.

I do not want to impugn Senator MacGibbon; I just want to continue on the theme that he has raised so well. Why is it a fact that when anybody wants to defend Senator Collins he or she is wasting time? An Opposition frontbencher has said that I am wasting time because I dare to get up and say that if we look at the issue fairly, this report from a professor whom everybody acknowledges has an outstanding legal mind exonerates Senator Collins. When Opposition senators get up and denigrate the report from the same professor and make allegations against Senator Collins in emotional terms with high language, high rhetoric and very grand gestures, that is all very pertinent to the parliamentary process.

Senator MacGibbon suggests, I take it—this is another interpretation of what he said—that this debate is a waste of time. People might well agree that we should get on to something more important than this, but I somehow feel—no doubt Senator MacGibbon will be speaking to his colleagues to see whether he can get them to sit down—that we will go round and round the mulberry bush trying to do poor Senator Collins in. He is, I know, a sensitive soul—

talk.start.para: —Who hasn't had a day off in six months.

—That is right, and I can guarantee that he is not going to get a day off over the next week. Returning to this report, it is a valid, properly thought out and properly articulated report. It addresses issue after issue in a dispassionate, unbiased way. The report concludes with paragraph 55, which reads:

speech.para: I do not consider that my inquiry has revealed any systemic deficiency in the Department's practices, nor has it revealed a general want of capability in any officers of the Department.

That has great significance to the question of whether Senator Collins ought to resign. I have heard him say, `Well, if the whole department, the whole system, is in a state of disrepair, if I have let it get out of order, out of control, and the officers are just absolutely awful, then of course I am responsible for that department'. But I repeat that Professor Pearce says:
I do not consider that my inquiry has revealed any—
not any—
systemic deficiency in the Department's practices, nor has it revealed a general want of capability in any officers of the Department.
He does not say, `Look, I have found a bit of systemic deficiency and perhaps one or two officers who want capability'. He has used the word `any'.

para.tab: Professor Pearce has put this down to an error of judgment not, as I said before, to negligence, a want of care, tiredness or anything else; just a wrong judgment, and we can all make wrong judgments. Paragraph 47 states:

speech.para: However, there is no doubt—
not `a little bit of doubt'—
that at the time when the Determination was prepared, the officers of the Department did not consider such a requirement necessary and this influenced the form of their advice to the Minister.

That was what the wrong judgment was. On the basis of this report, how can we condemn the Minister? How can we condemn the department? How can we condemn the officers of the department? What we can say is: there was an error of judgment; is there something we can put into operation which will prevent further errors of judgment? That is what this discussion should be all about, but it will not be. It will be a fruitless, dead, tired argument about whether Senator Collins ought to resign, which he is not going to do. We all know that. According to this report, there is no basis for his doing that.

talk.start.para: —But you said that when you were defending Richo.

—I think Richo was got—and I use that word advisedly—in a way that was not, in my view, fair. He was not got in terms of his administration of his department. He was got because of guilt by association, which is something that I have always been against.
—That has nothing to do with the Pearce report.
—As Senator Collins has reminded me, that has nothing to do with this matter. If we rely on the report by Professor Pearce, this argument ought to stop here and now.

speech.speaker: Kemp Sen C.R.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Pearce report and to respond to some of the matters which have been raised in this debate. Certainly, one can endorse the high qualities of the man who put the report together. One can naturally assume that he has brought a fair mind to this process. But having read the report carefully and having looked at the material which is published in that report, I think that equally fair-minded people could reach very different conclusions from those reached in this report.

para.tab: We are faced with a problem of probably the greatest bungle in electronic media policy making in this country since the introduction of TV in 1956. I have listened to Senator Collins and Senator Bourne, and I find it hard to believe that no-one appears to have been responsible for this incident. The Minister does not appear to have been responsible. The department seems to have made an error of judgment. The Minister's staff seem to have been completely exonerated of any suggestion of careless work. From Senator Bourne's comments, we can see that she does not seem to feel that the Minister has any particular responsibility for the administration of his department. In her opinion, the Minister has been the victim of a malicious and conniving department which wants to put forward its own views.

The problem with this report is the type of inquiry which was established by the Minister. It was a private inquiry, at which the evidence was taken in confidence and no transcripts were made. As a result, we have to rely entirely on the interpretations—

talk.start.para: —The integrity of Professor Pearce.

—No, the interpretations that Professor Pearce has placed on the material which has been given to him. I express my serious concern—and raise this in the hope that the Australian Democrats will reflect on their position on this particular issue—at the fact that when we have an inquiry with excessively narrow terms of reference, where the hearings are taken in camera and where, even at the end of this inquiry, we cannot get hold of the transcripts and all the material which was presented to that inquiry, this inquiry itself is in that sense flawed. I believe we need a proper inquiry into the bungles which have constantly surrounded the administration of this Minister in the area of pay TV.

para.tab: On the evidence that is published in this report, one can come to very different conclusions. For example, as Senator Cooney related, Professor Pearce came to the conclusion in paragraph 55 that the inquiry had not revealed any systemic deficiency in the department's practices, nor had it revealed a general want of capability in any officers of the department. What we saw in a sense, as Professor Pearce said, was simply an error of judgment. I put to the Minister that this report shows a department with very shabby and very careless practices. One only has to turn to paragraph 15, which states:

speech.para: I commenced the inquiry by examining the relevant departmental files. It could not be said that these were in as good a state of presentation as one normally expects from departmental files.
The next paragraph reads:

I appreciate and understand this explanation. However, it has made my task more difficult in that it has obliged officers to rely very often on their memory for what was and was not discussed on various occasions, particularly at meetings.
Then the report says:
In these circumstances, it is not surprising that my questions have often elicited an `I cannot recall' response.
Professor Pearce, in the evidence that he has published, shows that this department is not following proper departmental practices.

talk.start.para: —That is outrageous.

—It is writ large—the Minister should read paragraphs 15 and 16 about the paperwork of the department. Then we go on to find out how the particular determination, which in the end has caused all this trouble for the Minister, was drafted. Professor Pearce apparently has the original document, and in paragraph 21 he states:

speech.para: The origin of this document and its status are not entirely clear.

Great paperwork by a well-run department! When one goes through this document one finds on every page prize examples of departmental failure and sloppy paperwork. Then we get to the Minister's office—no wonder the department is so sloppy because the Minister's office is so sloppy in its paperwork. Senator Collins should have a look at paragraph 29, which states:

The minute was hand delivered to the Minister's office on 4 January 1993. It was not logged-in in the normal fashion. However, if standard practice was followed, it would have been sent to the Minister's Darwin office. However, I am informed that there is no record of this having occurred and the document cannot at present be found.
What great paperwork and great office work! The paragraph continues:
It thus appears there is no certainty that it was ever placed before the Minister.

We have here an example of the department being unable to find the actual basis on which the original determination was drafted. This determination went through various drafts, but when the department looked back and tried to check its origin it found it very difficult to find who drafted it and where. The document then appeared in the Minister's office and was not logged in. But we then find that the document was read by one of the Minister's staffers. That staffer apparently gave the document to the Minister and said it was okay to sign.

talk.start.para: —Read what Professor Pearce said.
—I happen to have been an adviser to a former Minister.
—We've been told you were lousy.

—When I was an adviser we never had the bungles that the Minister constantly has in his department. I do not take great credit for that, but I know that when someone says that a document is okay to be signed, presumably that person has read it through carefully.
—Oh, God.

—What is the point of that person saying that the document is okay to be signed? The ministerial adviser has apparently advised the Minister to sign the document and the Minister was apparently prepared to sign it without careful reading. As Senator O'Chee said, this is presumably one of the more important documents to pass over the Minister's desk since he took over the reins of the department.
—Was it?

—It probably was. Let us say it was one of them. Recognising that pay TV is a matter of high public interest, an area in which major players from the media are involved and an area of considerable interest to the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, what would a Minister exercising normal ministerial responsibilities have done? I will tell the Senate what that Minister should have done. If the Minister was not happy with the briefing he was given he should have called over the officers of his department and asked to be taken very carefully through the particular document. But, of course, the Minister did not do that. As far as the Minister was concerned this was just another piece of paper which some unnamed adviser had apparently said was okay to sign and that was exactly what the Minister did.

para.tab: This really focuses on the role of the Minister and his role in dealing with important bits of paper which pass over his desk. This is where I profoundly differ with the emphasis of Senator Bourne's speech. I believe the Minister cannot be absolved from responsibility in this area. When documents of high public controversy pass over his desk, the Minister has a key responsibility to satisfy himself that the document is sound in every respect. That is what the Minister failed to do. That is why I believe Professor Pearce said at the start of the report:

speech.para: . . . it should be observed that the Terms of Reference do not require me to comment on issues arising from the doctrine of ministerial responsibility.
I hope Professor Pearce notes that immediately this report was brought down the Minister tried to use it to absolve himself of any blame in this matter.

para.tab: This is a matter of great seriousness; it is not trivial. I believe that the final determination in this area will have quite a profound effect on the doctrine of ministerial responsibility in this country. It will also go to the heart of what particular role a department has and what actions should be taken in a department which has clearly failed, I believe, in a number of key areas. There is nothing in the Pearce report which shows that any action will be taken in the department.

In the months to come I will be interested to inquire at the Senate estimates committees how many of the officers in this department received performance-based pay bonuses. That will be a very interesting exercise. It will be interesting to get the Minister's answer as to whether the senior officers in this department, whose paperwork was so sloppy and who—at least in Professor Pearce's own words—were responsible for a major error of judgment, receive these very generous performance-based pay rises.

This is a very important report. It should be very extensively debated and considered in this Parliament. It has many lessons for us, not the least of which is—for the Australian Democrats—that if we want a full inquiry into a major government bungle, that inquiry should be carried out by a Senate select committee which can take its evidence in public.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: —Tonight we are debating the Pearce report that has been tabled today by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). The crux of the whole matter is that the terms of reference for the inquiry did not require Professor Pearce to make any comment at all about the Minister's responsibility in this affair. The terms of reference state:

speech.para: 1.What were the processes followed by the Department in the preparation for the Minister. . .
2.What were the reasons for the non-inclusion in that draft Determination . . .
3.What was the form of advice to the Minister . . .
4.Was that advice sufficient to alert the Minister . . .
5.Was the non-inclusion of deposit requirements . . .

talk.start.para: —It is implicit in that one.

—They relate only to the department. The terms of reference say, `Was the advice by the department sufficient to alert the Minister?' There is nothing about the Minister's responsibility—and I will come to that in a minute. If these terms of reference had included a No. 6, `Did the Minister act in a responsible manner?', then this report would have had something to do with whether or not the Minister was responsible and could have absolved the Minister from responsibility. But they did not, and Senator Collins cannot claim that he is absolved by this report. The basic flaw was in the terms of reference. That is underlined by Professor Pearce when he states in the report:

speech.para: I did not seek an amendment to the Terms of Reference, noting their narrow compass and the short period for completion of the inquiry (it should be observed that the Terms of Reference do not require me to comment on issues arising from the doctrine of ministerial responsibility).

Professor Pearce specifically says that he has nothing to do with the Minister's responsibility in this matter, only with the department's responsibility. The Minister has been very critical of the Opposition criticising this report in any way and says that, because we do, we are criticising Professor Pearce. That is not true, and the Minister really cannot get away with that. Bearing in mind that we cannot look at the Minister's responsibility, that we can only look at the department's responsibility, let us see whether we agree with some of the evidence that Professor Pearce has put before us. He starts off by saying:
I commenced the inquiry by examining the relevant departmental files.
My colleague has quoted some of this, but I would like to quote a bit more. He goes on to say:

It could not be said these were in as good a state of presentation as one normally expects from departmental files. Papers do not always appear chronologically, folios are not always numbered and officers who have accessed them have not so indicated on the file cover. It is also to be observed that notes have not always been made of the outcome of meetings. These deficiencies were explained as flowing from the extraordinary pressure under which the officers of the Department were working in bringing the . . . scheme to fruition . . . senior officers were required to work very long hours.

Professor Pearce goes on making excuses for the officers because they were under pressure. That is never an excuse; it can never be considered an excuse for inefficiency. Regularly in this place, officers are under pressure. Regularly in this place, people work long hours. We senators work long hours and, indeed, our all night sittings do not absolve us from responsibility. Just because one is tired does not mean that one absolves oneself from all responsibility.

para.tab: Professor Pearce went on to say, `I appreciate and understand this explanation' that everyone was so tired. He does not say that, but that is what he was talking about. He continued:

speech.para: However, it has made my task more difficult in that it has obliged officers to rely very often on their memory . . .
Lovely, is it not? No notes, no efficiency; just, `I think, perhaps, I am not quite sure'. He goes on:

The events in question occurred five or six months ago and at that time when the officers were weary and were in many cases about to go on leave. In these circumstances, it is not surprising that my questions have often elicited an `I cannot recall' response.

An efficient department and an efficient office of the Minister said, `We were all too tired; about to go on leave; it's been a gruelling session; we didn't write it down; we didn't do it efficiently; we didn't make the necessary notes; we didn't indicate what occurred at the meetings; and we can't remember—we can't recall'. Professor Pearce said that he had received full cooperation from the Minister's staff, but they could not remember. He believed, quite legitimately, that they could not remember. They were not efficient, they had not written down a thing—how could they remember something that happened six months earlier? He went on to say:
Legal advice as to the validity of the proposed scheme was sought from the Attorney-General's Department.
In relation to matters that were going on about that time, he said:

. . . a document was circulating within the Department that appears to be either a draft Determination or a draft Information Memorandum. This document includes the statement that tenderers for a pay-TV licence `are not required to pay a deposit to enter the process'. The origin of this document and its status are not entirely clear.
Nobody could remember. On page 9 of the report Professor Pearce says:
I find this surprising as a deposit system is applicable to the sale of . . . MDS licences . . .

So it was applicable then, but nobody thought about it with regard to the pay TV licence. We go on and find that the senior officers had a meeting in December and there were changes to the determination arising from that meeting.

talk.start.para: —Have a look at the date; Christmas Eve.
—What a dreadful thing! They had a meeting on Christmas Eve, so that absolves them from thinking clearly and from having any responsibility or being efficient. Professor Pearce says:

speech.para: Among changes . . . arising from those meetings was the inclusion of the requirement for an application fee . . .
If that was there, surely to heavens some discussion occurred about whether a deposit was necessary? But they assure us that it was not even discussed.

para.tab: He deals with the urgency surrounding this. The officers of the department wanted it all done before the election. Professor Pearce says that the urgency was one of the problems of the mess-up. The urgency was because they wanted it done prior to the election. He said that they sent the determination off to the Attorney-General's Department and two senior officers of the Minister's department believed—assumed—that it would go to the Office of Commercial Law within the Attorney-General's Department. Professor Pearce says:

speech.para: It would have been prudent for the Department of Transport and Communications to have checked whether the Office of Commercial Law had been consulted. . .

But it did not. The department took it for granted—good, efficient stuff! As has been said before, the draft determination was delivered to the Minister's office under cover of a minute dated 4 January. The report states:
It was not logged-in in the normal fashion.
Good, efficient stuff! The same old thing. The report continues:

However, if standard practice was followed, it would have been sent to the Minister's Darwin office. However, I am informed that there is no record of this having occurred and the document cannot at present be found.
The office still cannot find it—good, efficient stuff!

para.tab: From this report we cannot claim that the department was other than inefficient—it did not keep the proper minutes; it did not even log-in the minute. It has been criticised all the way through. Yet, eventually, Professor Pearce says that under the circumstances, because the officers were tired, because they had had a gruelling time, because they were worn out, because some people were on holidays, the department only made an error of judgment. That is not so. I am not being critical of Professor Pearce; I am saying that I do not agree with him. The Minister's office was absolutely irresponsible, inefficient and just incompetent.
The question now is: does the Minister have any bearing on this at all? Professor Pearce says:
In a perfect world the Minister's advisers would have gone through the minutes and Determination and alerted the Minister to the absence of deposit requirements.

speech.para: He does not say that under normal circumstances, when a Minister reads something like this, he should ask his advisers or his departmental officers, `Is there anything special in this I should know? Is there anything in this that could create a problem?'. Every Minister does this, or should. I remind Senator Lees, who is here at the moment, that that is what Senator Collins thinks, too, because on a censure motion on cost overruns on the wharf, he said:
If you are big enough to accept the salary, then you have to be big enough to perform and to earn it. Those two Ministers last week demonstrably did not do that.
He went on to say:
A Minister has only to consider what is likely to come up, what he is likely to get his head kicked in on, and brief himself for it. It is his responsibility.

What the Minister should have said to his staff—and what Professor Pearce did not refer to, because he did not have a term of reference that enabled him to do so—is, `What am I likely to get my head kicked in on? I want brief myself on that. It is my responsibility'. Those were the words that the Minister used. I would not use them. I would say to my staff or my department, `What is in this that could cause me problems? What is controversial? Brief me.' The Minister did not do that. That was his prime mistake—his irresponsibility. He signed a document that he did not read fully—he says himself he did not read it fully—because he had a memo that said, `Okay, sign'. He did just that.

para.tab: In his concluding remarks, Professor Pearce says:

speech.para: I consider that, having regard to the sensitivity of the tendering process in relation to pay-TV licences, it would have been appropriate for the Minister to have been given a fuller briefing on the way in which it was to operate. That this was not done was a product of a number of circumstances.

He went on to say such things as that it needed to be done quickly because they wanted it fixed up before the election; that they had just finished a gruelling period in parliament; that they were tired, and that people were on holidays. Let me just tell the Minister, because I think it is pretty important, that no other profession could ever get away with that.

para.tab: My husband was an obstetrician and gynaecologist. He may have been up all night doing deliveries, but he would come home, get dressed and then go back to his office. He is not absolved of any responsibility towards the first patient he sees just because he is tired. He is not absolved of any responsibility if he has a new sister assisting him. He is not absolved of any responsibility because he has had a gruelling year and has been working for six months with only one day off. This Minister would not know what work was. If he talked about two years without a day off he might be talking about something more applicable, but to whinge in here that he was tired and had had only one day off in six months is not something that I would be proud of if I were him. He would not know what work was.

Again the excuse was that the Minister had been in the portfolio only a short time and was the fourth incumbent in a period of two months. Being a new Minister is no excuse not to accept responsibility and say, `The buck stops with me'. When a medico sees a patient he does not have an excuse if he is new and he is tired—or, as in this case, if it is Christmas Eve and there is an election coming up. These are the excuses that this Minister has been using in the Senate. He accepts the money and, as he himself says, `If you accept the money, then you must accept the responsibility'. That is no less than the Senate accepts, and expects of any Minister in this place.

speech.speaker: Bishop Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: —This is a very limited report. I reiterate the remarks of my colleagues on this side of the chamber in saying that Professor Pearce points out on the first page of his report:

speech.para: . . . it should be observed that the Terms of Reference do not require me to comment on issues arising from the doctrine of ministerial responsibility.

Therefore, that question remains to be tested. To my mind, there are several questions to which the Senate requires answers that are not canvassed at all in this report and were not required to be canvassed by the terms of reference. It seems to me that the proper vehicle for doing this is a Senate committee of inquiry.

para.tab: These are the points that I think need to be traversed. The judgment in the Australian Capital Equity Pty Ltd case sets out the details of the determination that was made for the tender process for MDS licences. It sets out that one determination was made on 1 October 1992, in advance of the power conferred by section 92A of the Broadcasting Services Act, which was conferred on 5 October. It then cites section 92A of the Act:

speech.para: For the purposes of subsection 92A(1) of the Act, a licence granted under the Act for a multi-point distribution station referred to in column 2 and described in column 3 of item 66 in schedule 1 is a licence of a kind for which the Minister may determine a price-based allocation system.

On 9 December 1992, a press notice invited tenders to be submitted for those licences. It was called a price-based allocation. On 7 January 1993, the Minister in writing revoked the determination made in October 1992, known as determination No. 1, and at the same time, under the heading `Radiocommunications: Allocation of multi-point distribution system licences', determination No. 2, determined another tender-based allocation system for granting multi-point distribution station licences.

para.tab: He then sets out the terms of the tender. Those terms are remarkably similar to the terms of tender set out in the price-based tender system for satellite licences. The only difference is that clause 5 states that:

speech.para: (1)Any tender made to the Secretary must:

para.tab: (a)be in writing,
(b)be in a sealed envelope, and
(c)contain a deposit of five per cent of the amount bid.

speech.para: The clause then goes on to provide that any tender not accompanied by the deposit would not be a valid tender. This particular tender for MDS licences is price-based. It contained the five per cent deposit. The questions that need to be asked are these: who were the people who drew up the determination for the Minister to sign on 7 January 1993? What processes did they go through to determine that there needed to be a deposit paid on that occasion—

talk.start.para: —With MDS?

—With MDS licences. We need to know who determined that a price-based system was properly set out and consistent with having a five per cent deposit paid. What was it that changed people's minds when it came to satellite licences?

para.tab: Section 93 of the Act states not that the Minister may have a price-based system but that the Minister shall have a price-based system. In the first case, for MDS licences, the Minister elected to have a price-based system and had a five per cent deposit. In the case of the satellite licences, the Minister had no such option; he was required by the Parliament to have a price-based system. Precedent would have dictated that a five per cent deposit would be paid.

When I read Professor Pearce's report, I read that, basically, the substance of the determination was decided on 24 December 1992. When I look at the judgment in the MDS case I note that on 23 December, that is, the day before, the notice published in the
Commonwealth of Australia Gazette
under the heading of `Invitations to tender' contained the price-based tender application concerning MDS licences. In other words, discussion of these two tenders was going on simultaneously.

What is it about the Minister's office that had officers deciding that for MDS licences a five per cent deposit was to be paid, but in respect of satellite licences there was to be no deposit? Professor Pearce says at paragraph 25 of his report:

speech.para: The officers attending these meetings in December—
the meetings that took place between 17 and 24 December 1992—
said that the requirement of payment of a deposit was not discussed.
How can that be so, when at the same time the Minister had in his office a similar tender process which required such a deposit?

para.tab: Professor Pearce then goes on to say that the officers discussed the desirability of imposing a fee. They also noted that a fee could not exceed the cost of processing. Later in the report, it is said that the $500 fee would only be a small part of the cost of processing such an application.
Term of reference No. 2 states:

speech.para: What were the reasons for the non-inclusion in that draft Determination of deposit requirements for the tendering process?
Paragraph 32, which is cited often through the report, states:
All officers of the Department who were involved in the policy discussions relating to the Determination were asked this question.

Why did some officers decide that there would be no deposit for satellite licences? Presumably they must have been talking to the same officers who determined that the MDS system had to have a deposit. Yet they say they did not discuss the question of a deposit with regard to satellite licences. That makes no sense to me, particularly when paragraph 32 further states:
The responses were numerous and varied.

Professor Pearce then sets out nine of them. Six out of the nine mention a deposit requirement. How is it that on 23 December the Minister's department published in the
Commonwealth of Australia Gazette
a price based system requiring a deposit, with the determination to be settled on 7 January, and that on 24 December the same department said that it did not even discuss the question of a deposit, yet it had settled what was to go into the determination?

para.tab: I will now turn to paragraph 21 of the report. There is a curious series of events whereby it is said that a document was circulating in the department, which seems to have been in the department since about mid-November. Paragraph 21 states:

speech.para: . . . it is not possible to be more precise about the time—a document was circulating within the Department that appears to be either a draft Determination or a draft Information Memorandum. This document includes the statement that tenderers for a pay-TV licence `are not required to pay a deposit to enter the process'.

Some discussion had to have gone on, bearing in mind that the question of both the MDS licences and the satellite licences were all on the agenda from the beginning of October in the Minister's department, were in evidence before courts and are now mentioned in reports. Paragraph 21 continues:
The origin of this document and its status are not entirely clear.
Why is it not clear? It continues:

It seems to have been drafted within the Broadcasting Review and Pay-TV Section, Development and Planning Branch, Broadcasting Policy Division, of the Department. It was then sent to the Legal and General Branch to be drafted in the form of a Determination. Legal Branch declined to do this. . .
Why did it decline? Why would the legal branch decline to draft a determination?

talk.start.para: —Read on.
—I will. Did the legal branch draft the determination for the MDS licence? We do not know. The report continues:

speech.para: Legal Branch declined to do this and advised the Section that it should itself prepare a draft for settling by the Office of Legislative Drafting-

talk.start.para: —That is the reason. You have not read it.

—I am now reading it to the Minister. The legal branch declined. We do not know the reasons why it declined. The report simply says that it `advised'. Where is the advice? Is it a formal advice? Is it a written advice? If so, where it is? What were the reasons given for its declining? For what reasons did it say that the section should itself prepare the draft for settling by the Office of Legislative Drafting in the Attorney-General's Department?

para.tab: When we go further into the report we find that that course of action was followed, but the draft was sent off to the Attorney-General's Department and addressed to the secretary. Officers then said that they presumed someone from the commercial section would give some legal advice, but it did not take place. Only the drafting people looked at it. Why is that so? If there was a presumption that it was sent in that form, why did nobody follow it up? Why did nobody ask for the legal opinion if that is what they anticipated should happen? The report states in paragraph 26:

Two senior officers in the Department . . . thought that the draft Determination would be reviewed by the Office of Commercial Law within the Attorney-General's Department as a result of it being sent to the Secretary.

speech.para: Nobody in their right mind would make such a presumption.

talk.start.para: —That is what he goes on to say. Read it.
—The Minister will have his turn in a moment. The report continues:

speech.para: This did not occur and the Determination was reviewed only by the Office of Legislative Drafting.

Why? Why did the officers who sent it on for what they thought was some appraisal not follow it up? The report states that it was marked urgent but contained no request for general advice. In other words, people are saying, `We thought they would have a look at it and give us advice, but we did not ask for any'. Why not?

para.tab: Also, what procedure was followed with regard to the MDS licences? Presumably there had been discussion about why it was thought proper to have a five per cent deposit for the MDS licences; it was felt correct that this was the formula to be followed. If one looks at FM licences which occurred in an earlier period, one finds that a $10,000 deposit was required even for those licences, as distinct from a fee.

talk.start.para: —Fifty!

—It was $10,000 for the FM licences and I will cite the documents, but the Minister can have his turn in a moment. The other matter of significance is shown in paragraph 28 of the report which states:

speech.para: An officer of the Office of Legislative Drafting did suggest a number of changes of an essentially drafting nature to the Department of Transport and Communications and a new version of the Determination incorporating these changes was prepared. This version—
and this is the one which was altered by the Office of Legislative Drafting in the Attorney-General's Department—
was submitted—
and I stress, `submitted'—
to the Minister for his signature on 11 January 1993.

The MDS determination was submitted to the Minister for his signature on 7 January. On 7 January he signed an MDS licence tender which required a five per cent deposit. On 11 January—four days later—he signed another determination, this time for satellite licences, with a completely different system, that is, a $500 fee and no five per cent deposit. This occurred four days later and the Minister did not ask the question, `Why the difference?'.

para.tab: The essence of Professor Pearce's report is that the officer submitted the determination to the Minister and that is precisely what it is. I am often given documents by my staff; the documents are submitted to me for signature. I do not simply sign them. I read them, and if there are things wrong in them that I do not believe are consistent with precedent or the things that I believe are right, I ask about it and have it altered if it is wrong. It is not good enough for me in my office to say that I do not have time to read things and therefore I will just sign them. I do not, and it is not good enough for the Minister to say that either.

The Minister has signed two competing documents: both price based systems; both for licences in the telecommunications area; one where he has elected to exercise his discretion to use the price based system; and one where the Parliament has said it is mandatory. It is the same system; different terms and conditions—deposit required in one and not in the other. Why?

As I said, the terms of reference given to Professor Pearce to investigate these matters are simply too narrow for enough information to be brought before the Senate for anybody to make a proper decision or a proper finding. In this matter it is simply a question of making sure that the taxpayers of Australia get good government. Governments make policy; bureaucrats administer policy. When an Act requires the determination of the Minister, that is exactly what it means. The Minister is charged with the responsibility of making a decision and putting it into practice. It is not the responsibility of the bureaucrat; it is the responsibility of the Minister.

Whereas Professor Pearce concludes at the end of his report that officers in the department made an error of judgment, that is a perfectly proper finding for him to make because he has seen the evidence. But it is irrelevant to the question of whether or not the Minister exercised ministerial responsibility and sufficient care in carrying out the responsibility he was charged with by the legislation which required him to make a determination—not the bureaucrats to make the determination; the Minister to make the determination. That is the question.

Many more questions need to be answered—with regard to the precedent that was set and with regard to the people who were involved in both sets of tender documents—to ascertain why one lot required a five per cent deposit and one lot did not. We simply cannot deduce that there was some general ethos in the department that somehow a five per cent deposit was a hurdle. It clearly was not. There was no consistent view.

What we have not seen is why the difference. We can achieve that only if we have a proper Senate inquiry to adduce all the evidence so that a decision can then be made. The aim at the end of the day is to ensure that Ministers know what ministerial responsibility is about and bureaucrats know what their responsibility is about in terms of administering policy made by executive government. Those are the questions that the Senate ought properly inquire into and get to the bottom of. What flows from the answers to those questions is another issue altogether.

I know that Senator Bourne made some statements earlier today, but I ask the Democrats to look at those questions that I have set out to the Senate in the last 20 minutes. We require answers to them. At the end of the day it is the Senate's responsibility—the responsibility of all of us who are elected and who are not part of the Executive—to ensure that taxpayers' money is wisely spent and that we get peace, welfare and good government. A Labor Party backbencher is no more a member of executive government than you or I. It is our responsibility to see that we carry out what we are elected to the Parliament to do. I sincerely believe that on this occasion the best and, indeed, only way that can now be done is to have a Senate committee of inquiry and ascertain all the facts, which are much broader than the terms of reference that were given to Professor Pearce.

speech.speaker: Kernot Sen C.

talk.start.para: —As Senator Bourne said, the Australian Democrats accept the umpire's decision. We asked for an independent umpire, and we got one. We accept Professor Pearce's decision. He appears to have had full access to the witnesses and the documents. However, I make one personal comment. He appears to me to have had an extremely compassionate view of the human dimensions of all this. He refers to the stress, the tiredness and the need for leave. He talks about the human dimension in the assumptions that were made about what the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) needed to know.

para.tab: In some respects, it is quite reassuring to know that a former ombudsman has this view of the world, this compassion, but as a new leader I am very conscious of the whole notion of office administration. Despite Professor Pearce's acceptance of the explanations, I am quite concerned about his findings and the comments he makes regarding departmental files and the way the Minister's office was administered. The Minister himself acknowledged this a couple of weeks ago. This report is quite damning, in my view—leaving aside the acceptance of the explanations—of departmental procedures and the Minister's office administration. It begs a couple of questions that I do not think have been raised. Paragraph 15 of Professor Pearce's report states:

speech.para: . . . in November 1992, senior officers were required to work very long hours, many of them in Parliament House. Adherence to usual public service paper procedures was not possible.
If that is true, we ought to look at that. That should not happen. We might need to design new systems.

talk.start.para: —That is the Minister's task.

—Yes. I expect the Minister is listening to these comments and is prepared take them on board. I have to agree with Senator Kemp's point, in relation to paragraph 16, that it is difficult to accept that so much of this report is based on Professor Pearce's comment that officers very often had to rely on their memory. It is just like this whole debate: we are all relying on our memory of who said what to whom.
—It is very unsatisfactory.
—It is unsatisfactory. It is a worry in respect of the evidence. However, Senator Kemp did not refer to paragraph 18, which states:

speech.para: . . . I do not believe that there has been any attempt made to conceal the truth.

I am prepared to accept Professor Pearce's word on that. Another issue which I do not think has been touched on—and I am trying to be constructive about what we can learn from this debacle—is the role of advisers.

talk.start.para: —Ministerial advisers.

—Ministerial advisers. In the short time that I have been here, many of the ministerial advisers that I have had to deal with often appear to be more political appointments than people who are across the breadth of the policy issues. At paragraph 52, Professor Pearce comments:

speech.para: The comparatively recent phenomenon of Ministers having advisers on their staff does not remove this obligation from a Department.

This obligation is for departmental officers to bring matters of significance to the attention of the Minister. I wonder whether a situation has evolved where so many assumptions are made about what the role of that adviser ought to be that departmental advisers need to think more clearly about whether they are fulfilling their role or whether they are relying on advisers. Despite the fact that advisers may say that they are much more likely to be concerned with political policy issues than process, I wonder whether this delineation remains clear enough. Professor Pearce, at paragraph 54, states:
In my view the conclusion is inescapable that it was a mistake for the departmental officers not to bring certain aspects of the tendering process to the attention of the Minister.
He goes on to say:
. . . this inaction was readily explicable in terms of the circumstances that existed at the time . . .
He concludes:

I find that an error of judgement was made but that is all that it was—an error of judgement. I find no basis whatsoever for any suggestion that the departmental officers deliberately failed to advise the Minister that the payment of a deposit was not part of the tendering process.

That is what we asked Professor Pearce to look at. That is what he has concluded. I do not believe that there has been any conspiracy in this matter, but I do believe that we should be concerned about the exposure that we have in front of us of lack of due process and lack of due responsibility. I do not believe that that exposure on this matter is sufficient to warrant the resignation of this Minister. We still have an open mind on the matter of an inquiry. As honourable senators would know, we are awaiting the documents on that.

speech.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —I will try to be brief. Before I get onto the actual matters that I want to address, I want to respond directly to what Senator Kernot has said about ministerial advisers. But I run the risk—
—Don't do it!

—No, I will do it. I think it is a very legitimate matter which has to be responded to—and I do have strong views about it. Once again, one cannot win with the Opposition on this. If I accept responsibility, as I did two weeks ago as the
Hansard
shows and as Senator Kernot pointed out, for what I acknowledge was a defect in my own office's procedures because of the January break—and I can assure honourable senators that it will never happen again; it all seemed reasonable at the time—I am then accused by Senator Alston of trying to take credit rather than responsibility.

para.tab: So I am not going to bother about those opposite because they have been totally in opposition on this. That was demonstrated in a profound way, and in my view, a disgraceful way, last week. Having identified the serious problem with the satellite process, having identified the solution to it and agreed with that, they then refused to support the legislation that fixed it. Thanks to the Australian Democrats, that became law last Friday. To put this in perspective, because that became law last Friday, it will probably, for that process, not have cost it a day.

One cannot automatically assume—and I think Senator Kernot would agree with me—as Senator Alston did within 24 hours, that these two companies that have won the current bid will necessarily fall over. But they may. The fact that this became law last Friday fixed that. There will be hardly a day lost, in the final outcome, on the satellite start. So I am not going to bother too much any more about the perceptions of the Opposition on this matter.

I do have strong views about ministerial advisers. I have never ever appointed a ministerial adviser on the basis of factional allegiance or even party allegiance. From time to time I have got into trouble with people in my party because I will not. I freely admit here in the Senate that on a number of occasions I have been approached by someone saying, `Look, you should put somebody on your staff', et cetera. I have rebuffed every single approach that has ever been made to me on that basis. My ministerial staff are appointed as a result of their professional ability. Without even straining my brain—

talk.start.para: —I was not talking about your staff.
—No, I know that the honourable senator was. I happen to agree with her views on this, and I do not mind telling her that. Just without even thinking, I have three—
—It has nothing to do with this matter.

—It has got everything to do with it, because it is a matter directly raised by this report. I am pleased that Senator Kernot, alone in this debate so far, has acknowledged that it is a critical report. The human factors are mentioned. But I think it is a fair reading of the document—and I am sure that Senator Kernot will read it again—to say that although they are mentioned it is just for the completeness of the report. I do not think there is any excusing by Professor Pearce in nailing it down.

para.tab: Without even straining my brain, I can think of three of my advisers who are not even members of the Labor Party. There is no requirement in my office for any of them to be that. I am interested in people who have professional qualifications.

The other thing about my staff, Senator Kernot, is that most of them have been with me for a very long time. My senior private secretary, Jack Lake, has worked for me on and off for 15 years. He is a very good trained economist. Barbara Jones, who runs my Darwin office, has been with me for almost the same period. My press secretary, Brian Johnstone, has been with me for over 10 years. They are very competent staff.

But I will not allow the problem that occurred in January to occur again. That has been put to rest already. As Senator Kernot has pointed out, I did acknowledge this two weeks ago, and everybody in the Opposition overlooked it. I just wanted to address directly that concern that Senator Kernot raised.

The most disappointing thing about the debate here this afternoon is that, having moved mountains to get this report into the Senate five days ahead of its scheduled time, not a single Opposition member—and I regret to say that includes Senator Bishop—has clearly even bothered to read it. What those opposite have done is pick out the paragraphs that suit them and skip the ones that do not. I will give the Senate one glaring example of this from the speech made by Senator Bishop, and it was disgraceful. Have a look at the
Hansard
tomorrow to confirm whether this is right or wrong.

Senator Bishop quoted from paragraph 26 of the Pearce report. I might add that the reason I immediately recognised this is that I happen to think this is one of the most serious errors that were made, and I want to talk about that. She then went on to say, `Professor Pearce says nothing about that. He doesn't say why it happened or anything else'. Have a look at the
Hansard
tomorrow. She then skipped straight from paragraph 26 to paragraph 28. She actually said, `I will go to paragraph 28'. She left out paragraph 27—she went straight across it. The reason she left it out is that it does not suit her argument. This is one of the most serious errors that were made.
Professor Pearce makes a highly critical statement in the report about this assumption that the commercial law section was involved. He states:

speech.para: The assumption that the draft Determination would be considered by other sections of Attorney-General's Department in addition to the Office of Legislative Drafting when it was addressed in the manner . . . was not well founded.

That is a highly critical statement. But Senator Bishop conveniently skipped across that paragraph. The facts are—and it is very disappointing—that after the criticism of the past three weeks about Ministers who do not sit down and read every line contained in determinations, when I finally get the umpire's verdict—and the
Hansard
will clearly show this—not a single Opposition member, from Senator Alston down to Senator Bishop, bothers to read it. They just pull the paragraphs out that suit them and skip across the paragraphs that do not suit them.

para.tab: I will return to paragraph 27 which Senator Bishop left out and make a few comments. I said a couple of weeks ago—and I have turned out to be right—that in my view the real cause of this very serious problem could probably be likened to an aircraft accident. I said half jokingly that I should have had the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation look at this matter, and I will tell the Senate why. They are system experts and they really know their stuff. Major airline accidents have always got one thing in common. A series of events occur, and fortunately it happens rarely, each one of which does not seem to be a major problem at the time but because they occur together a disaster results. Honourable senators should read this report. Senator Kernot was right to say that it is highly critical, but only for anyone who has bothered to read all of it.

What this report points out clearly is that a whole series of errors occurred. The report, quite unblushingly, gives the reasons for those errors—which I find unsatisfactory as does Professor Pearce.
