That is why they are outlined in the report. Professor Pearce makes a highly critical comment that these assertions `were not well founded'. Senator Bishop skipped over this.

This report has indicated that a whole lot of errors did occur, which at the time did not seem to be major problems to the officers. If I wanted to single one out, and I do, it is the very issue that Senator Bishop tried to skip over. What appeared to me to be a serious error in this matter, from my end of it, was that it was clear that the officers had conscientiously and carefully attempted to implement the Government's policy.

I ask Senator Kernot to look at the Attorney-General's advice and the clues in there and it will be found that this was the department's `preferred position'. The officers had laid down all these hurdles and they had sent them off to the Attorney-General's Department. Have a look at the hurdles, one of which was to have a look at the viability of the company. The department sent a letter back saying, `You can't do any of this'. The letter did not say, `You can't put a deposit on', but it said, `You can't put any of these conditions on'.

What then happened—and this is pure speculation on my part, but I publicly speculated about it—in terms of the succession of errors, was that the officers, as Professor Pearce sets out in the report, then sent their readjusted model to the Attorney-General's Department. There was an assumption made that the commercial law section of the department looked at it, and it did not. Professor Pearce, in a very critical comment, said, `That was not a well founded assumption'. But every senator on the other side of the chamber has ignored that. It is a very important omission.

I believed all along that what would be found at the end of the day was that these officers conscientiously went about delivering the Government's policy—or Parliament's policy. In fact, the Opposition wanted to go further than we were going to go with it. The officers clearly got the determination checked by the Attorney-General's Department for completeness. They had an officer from DITAC working with them who attended to all the industry matters, which were done very well and properly done. They sent it off to the Attorney-General's Department and they assumed that it was going to commercial scrutiny. What has been obvious to me from day one is that it did not get that commercial scrutiny. That is a serious error in hindsight.

I would like to tell the Senate what has been done about it since by the secretary of the department, and I will table these documents. Since this happened, it is not intended—and this is contained, as Senator Alston knows, in the Broadcast Services Act—for the department to have much of an ongoing role now in tender processes. The Spectrum Management Agency is going to take over all the spectrum management tenders, and it was always intended that the ABA should handle all the future licences.

Despite that, the secretary to the department has appointed to the staff of DOTAC two commercial lawyers from the commercial law section of the Attorney-General's legal practice. They are now working full-time for DOTAC. The secretary has already recognised that this was a flaw. Professor Pearce is highly critical of it. If I had to pick out one error, this is the major one that caused the problem.

talk.start.para: —It's still no excuse.

—Of course it is not an excuse. Professor Pearce does not excuse it and neither does the secretary. I will table the names of the officers concerned and a brief resume of their experience. They have now been appointed full-time to DOTAC. Having said that, I do not want to canvas the report much more, because it stands and speaks for itself.
—Hear, hear!

—I agree with Senator Cooney. It is a shame nobody opposite even bothered reading it. I refer again to the
Canberra Times
article about Professor Pearce. I need to restate this in terms of what was said on the other side of the chamber the other day. There is one key paragraph in the article. The headline reads, `Arbiter has a history of speaking his mind'—an independent person. The second paragraph reads:

para.tab: He has not, however, always been satisfied with the performance of governments or ministers: it is not to be assumed that he is a "reliable" outside investigator so far as Senator Bob Collins is concerned.

speech.para: Dead right. The article goes on to list the criticisms Professor Pearce made of the Government when he was Commonwealth Ombudsman. I think it is about time that all this attacking the umpire stopped. An independent person was appointed—an outstandingly qualified one. He has reported; accept his report. I have been sitting in here now for three weeks, night and day. Everyone has been having a great deal of fun with this issue, and I do not deny them that.

talk.start.para:
—No, I am not talking about people in here. The press is entitled to have had fun with it. It has been a major issue and it has had its bizarre aspects. I am not complaining about any of that. What I am complaining about is this: I have sat here and listened to the most disorderly debate, and I mean that in a real sense. Offensive personal imputations against members, impugning their integrity, are against the Standing Orders of this Parliament—and they are usually cracked down on very quickly. They are absolutely disorderly and not allowed. But have a look at the
Hansard
record. I copped it. I did not ever jump up and take a point of order, or ask for something to be withdrawn—although it was finally too much for the President, and he did. Two major imputations were made. First of all, I was accused by Senator Alston, a lawyer, of perjuring myself in the Federal Court—
—I said—

—No, no. Have a look at the
Hansard
—`a pious perjurer'. I was harangued by Senator O'Chee for 20 minutes on the same subject. Senator O'Chee said publicly how he felt about debates. Have a look at what he said; it is in the press. He said that what one has to do when one is debating is `get pumped up with adrenaline and feel like biting off a budgie's head'. I have to say this about Senator O'Chee, based on his performance this afternoon: I would not be too sure about that. I reckon that a match between Senator O'Chee and a budgerigar would be pretty even. I reckon you could take a fair bet that it would probably go the whole 15 rounds with a TKO to the budgie in the last round.

para.tab: I do find it offensive—profoundly offensive—that for 20 minutes I get accused by Senator O'Chee of perjuring myself under oath in the Federal Court on a matter that still has not been resolved. I have copped that for three weeks. I object to being called a liar. I object to it being said that I have misled Parliament. I object to being accused—as I was in here—of committing unlawful acts, that is, of issuing directions knowing that they were unlawful. All that was said by Senator Alston. And there was the outrageous charge—and I never protested or tried to have it withdrawn—that I perjured myself in the Federal Court. As I said earlier today—and I say this with some feeling; it is not political rhetoric or flourish—this report absolutely nails every one of those assertions.

I will finish with what I started with today. The reason Professor Pearce, rightly, did not comment on ministerial responsibility is that there are a thousand interpretations of it. I gave mine, and I think it is the real one. Ministers resign—have a look at the record—on three grounds: firstly, if they lose the confidence of the Prime Minister and their colleagues—and I have not; secondly, if they commit major personal improprieties, either inside or outside Parliament—and I have not; or, thirdly, if they lie, if they mislead the Parliament. What this report does, if it does nothing else, is indicate that every single thing I have told this Senate for three weeks was honest and truthful. On those three grounds, it is outrageous, in my view, to even suggest that I should resign as a Minister.

I finish by saying this to Senator Kernot: I have just tabled one piece of evidence about what is being done to correct this problem. I can assure Senator Kernot and, indeed, the Senate that all of the defects, in both my own office and the department, will be corrected.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.title: AUSTRALIAN WOOL REALISATION COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by
Senator Faulkner
:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: At the end of the motion, add ", but the Senate is of the opinion that the retention in legislation of any time limit sends the wrong signals to an uncertain wool market".

speech.para: The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Amendment Bill 1993 seeks to extend the wool debt repayment schedule from seven years to eight years. Honourable senators may remember that when the commission was established in 1991 it inherited a $2.7 billion debt and a 4.6 million bale stockpile, and was given seven years to repay the debt and dispose of the stockpile. However, a lack of buyers and a downturn in wool prices prompted industry fears that the Wool Realisation Commission would be forced into a fire sale of the stockpile wool. The Federal Government responded by promising to extend the repayment program from seven years to eight years, meaning that no wool would have to be sold from the stockpile next year and the Government could determine repayments.

para.tab: While the Federal coalition welcomes the extension, we believe that the strict debt reduction schedule should be abolished, thereby reassuring a still uncertain market that there will be no fire sale. The fact that this Bill is before us underscores the plight of the wool industry from the woolgrowers, their families and their communities all the way up to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission.

The figures speak for themselves. Last year, the loss to the average woolgrower business was nearly $40,000; this year it will be close to $34,000; next year, ABARE says, it will be over $34,000; in other words, an average of $107,000 in just three years. Even worse, the slide in property values has reduced equity and, in so doing, reduced the capacity of many woolgrowers to demonstrate viability, thereby making it harder for them to borrow and harder to survive.

The reality is that Australia's total rural debt has blown out from $10.6 billion in 1987 to $15.6 billion last year, and it is still climbing despite the drop in interest rates. This debt, assuming an average rate of 14 per cent after bank and other charges, means that the total farm interest bill is just over $2 billion a year. That is more than the total net farm value of farm production this year.

Complicating matters is the fact that the current stockpile of 3.9 million bales has barely shifted in the last nine months and continues to hang over the industry. The wool pipeline is full. So full, in fact, that wool is being held in brokers' or buyers' sheds around the country and in various forms at other points in the pipeline. Over the years wool has lost market share to cotton and synthetics, declining from some 10 per cent of the total market share for fibre in 1950-51 to just 4.4 per cent of an admittedly larger market in 1991-92.

During the years of the reserve price scheme, particularly towards the end, production was encouraged by the relative security of the industry and the prices that farmers felt they would receive for their product. The Australian sheep population hit a high of 173 million in 1990. With improved productivity in the industry and the higher fleece weights, on average, production soared to unprecedented levels. However, last year total sheep numbers fell to 151 million.

In the face of encroaching debt and relatively low prices, farmers are voluntarily making difficult decisions about off-loading, not breeding or even contracting numbers. The forecast total production figure for greasy wool this year is 851 million kilograms, while next year the figure is expected to come down to 805 million—still above the long-term average. Some estimates put it as low as 700 million kilograms. Fortunately, this provides scope for wool to be sold from the stockpile, without depressing sales, through the auction system.

The Federal coalition believes that the Federal Government could and should do more for the wool industry. For example, the Federal Government could slacken the strings controlling the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and give it more flexibility to go out and market stockpile wool. It could also remove the transparency in the Australian Wool Realisation Commission's operations so that buyers do not know how much the commission is selling or at what price and, by virtue of these two factors, what their competitors are up to.

By not abandoning the debt repayment schedule, the Federal Government has lost an important opportunity to reassure the market and instil much-needed confidence. Instead, the Federal Government has chosen to extend the repayment deadline. While this extension acknowledges the difficulties facing the industry, it also risks a burst in market confidence, followed by an even greater uncertainty in 12 months time. Ironically, the sooner we can restore confidence, the sooner prices are likely to recover, and the faster the debt can be repaid. Growers have a vested interest in the rapid repayment of the debt because they are stuck with the costs of servicing the debt and stockpiling the wool.

Along with the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr John Anderson, I welcome the Federal Government's offer of $50 million for interest rate subsidies under the exceptional circumstances provision of the RAS. However, is it enough? As I mentioned earlier, Australia's farm debt is now a staggering $15.6 billion, and interest payments on that debt amount to around $2 billion a year. If the new interest rate subsidies reach every woolgrower, and it is estimated that about 90 per cent need them, the subsidies will be worth only $1,000 a farmer—a paltry figure, considering the generosity displayed by this Federal Labor Government to waterside workers, the better cities program and, as we have seen in recent days in documents before the Senate, specifically and directly to the trade unions.

The Federal Government also talks about helping farmers meet world best practice. It is important to remind the Government that the Australian broadacre farm sector is one of the most productive in the world and that its productivity improvements should be regarded as a model by the rest of the community, and indeed by the world.

The farm sector has a record of which it can be extremely proud. However, I would like to draw to the attention of honourable senators one of the most fundamental issues facing the sector—that is, the lack of profitability and its potential to hold back any future productivity gains. The Federal Government continues to sidestep the fact that taxes on farming inputs amount to a three to five per cent penalty in our international competitiveness. It is an issue that the Government must confront, not simply in international trade competitiveness but in our capacity to hold at bay imports from countries such as New Zealand. No business can consistently afford to give its competitors that sort of advantage. The reality is that a Federal coalition government would have removed this burden.

According to Treasury figures, farm sector inputs are taxed at over $1 billion; another $1.3 billion dollars is levied in the food processing sector; and the Australian farm pays about $8,000 in cost inputs resulting from non-rebatable tax costs on production. In the light of these figures, the Federal coalition pleads with the Federal Government to ensure the survival of the farm sector both for the people involved and, indeed, for the nation. I trust that the Government will address the many structural issues shackling the farm sector and finally give it the opportunity to operate in a long-term, internationally competitive environment.

talk.start.para: —Despite its current declining fortunes, the Australian wool industry still has a massive impact on the Australian economy and, therefore, on the living standards of every Australian. The legislation we are dealing with this evening in relation to that very important industry—the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Amendment Bill 1993—as has been indicated by my colleague Senator Tambling, is not being opposed by the coalition. That does not mean that we necessarily agree with the intent of this legislation—in fact, that is why Senator Tambling has moved an amendment—nor do we agree that the legislation can provide the results which we believe are essential at this time for the wool sector.

para.tab: This Bill does no more than re-arrange, by delaying, the debt repayment program. It is no more than a short-sighted delaying action when the Government should be tackling the big picture of debt repayment scheduling. While, obviously, growers and the industry in general will in part welcome the payment extension from seven to eight years that is delivered by this legislation, it is not an answer to the problems, and that is equally recognised by the industry.

Being grateful for being handed small mercies is no solution to the stress the industry is feeling. But the passage of this Bill is necessary, despite its massive deficiencies, as a stopgap. The coalition is, therefore, in a catch-22 situation. If we do not support the Bill, the repayment time frame will remain at seven years. Supporting the legislation is the least damaging alternative of two not very practical options. The coalition's view remains that the strict debt repayment schedule should be abolished if the wool industry is to regain any confidence and surety in its dealings.

There is no point covering old ground tonight about the destructive decisions which led to the borrowing, which left us with $2.3 billion dollars worth of debt on the part of growers and the debilitating wool stockpile. These have been debated ad nauseam and it is to be hoped that responsibility has now been accepted by those involved. I simply remind the present Minister that as long ago as August 1989, when everything still appeared rosy, I warned the Government in a question to the then Minister, Senator Button, of gathering storm clouds. Sadly, that warning was ignored. However, beyond that experience of recent years relating to the collapse of the reserve price scheme, successive governments have, over many years, brought the industry to its present financial difficulties.

As I have said numerous times in this Parliament, the interrelated mechanisms of tariff protection and centralised wage fixing have for most of this century caused a transfer of incomes, savings and wealth from farmers and miners in general, and woolgrowers in particular, to urban industries, their owners and employees. One consequence of that is that woolgrowers do not now have the store of savings which would otherwise be available to them to tide them over the current crisis. This has been made worse by this Labor Government's failure to have an adequate IED scheme operating in more recent years. Another consequence is that it raises the question of justice and equity in the face of any criticism of suggestions of taxpayer-funded assistance for woolgrowers in their present difficulties.

As colleagues would well recognise, I am the last person to advocate subsidies for any group, especially of a sort that would hide future market realities from producers and encourage uneconomic production. However, provided long-term viability is encouraged, assistance for woolgrowers in the current circumstances could be seen as quite fair and simply repayment for the subsidy the wool industry has provided to the urban community for some 90 years.

If such assistance is to be provided, it must be directed towards the future health of the industry, and the focus for that must be on better marketing. Achieving that is in turn dependent on getting agreement—which at present does not seem to exist within the industry—on how it should: firstly, develop new markets; secondly, consolidate its present market position both at home and overseas; thirdly, be responsive to global needs by being active rather than reactive; fourthly, address through organised grower education the clearly stated overseas concerns about our inconsistent wool quality; and, fifthly, run an effective marketing campaign.

The crisis caused by past soaring wool prices, the debt past decisions created and the stockpile have masked these other concerns and goals, which must be addressed just as urgently. We cannot negotiate a global strategy for the Australian wool industry until we deal with quality control, marketing and, crucially, identify new markets for the commodity at the same time as we are negotiating how to deal with the stockpile and the debt repayment. This is no time to be submerged totally in the crisis management of the debt and the stockpile, although finding the correct solution to the stockpile problem is of paramount importance.

There will always be a strong market for our top quality wool at the exclusive end of global garment manufacturing and designer fashion. This is, of course, the creme de la creme of the industry, but not our bread and butter. Wool of lesser quality is on a steady and, many say, irreversible decline globally for use in clothing. This has been created mainly by changing lifestyles, airconditioned offices and homes and economic factors.

It is perceived that wool costs more, takes more care and time to look after and does not have the resilience and longevity of man-made fibres. A lack of awareness of cool wool has continued the perception that wool is too warm to wear most of the year and inside. This was identified and stated quite clearly by the International Wool Secretariat more than two years ago. Barely a month goes by without information being released to the media about new man-made fibres which are seen as a replacement for wool in mid and lower price range garment manufacture.

While marketing can hold back the tide of change to some extent, it is definitely time to look for new markets away from clothes, especially away from mid-range clothing. We must also face up to the fact that our local wool advertising campaigns have not been the success that we would have hoped. The `Get real, get wool' campaign, which we are told cost a small fortune to produce, received accolades from the advertising industry but made little impact on consumers.

We are apparently now about to see a campaign which uses the elderly to explain to the young the benefits of wool. I am sure that we will be watching with interest for reports on this campaign's effectiveness. I am informed that the theory behind it relates to the younger generation apparently being willing to take advice from grandparents but not from parents. It is the young who are targeted because of IWS research which indicates that they have no fibre knowledge and as little interest.

It is an interesting marketing concept, but can it sell wool? The bottom line is that, if our home-grown advertising cannot increase sales in Australia, what hope do we have overseas? We have a major problem when all the available research shows that, while consumers recognise the Woolmark label, they have no idea what it actually means. We need effective advertising if we are to increase interest and knowledge, let alone sales, just as we need consistent quality of the product if we are to be trusted overseas.

In terms of quality, if we wish to be a global market force, we cannot treat wool any differently from the way we treat motor vehicle components, for example. They have to be above Australian standard to be accepted overseas. We are showing in that industry that we can do it, and I believe that, equally, we can do it in the wool industry. We cannot sit and chew grass in contemplation and say that wool is any different. As long as some see wool as being different, it will not attain the consistent quality essential for global market acceptance.

We are all familiar with what the British company Marks and Spencers thinks of our wool. It says that the best is brilliant, but that it can just as often be dreadful. That is a damming indictment for a country which made its international trade name with wool. We must educate and educate and educate our growers to ensure that inferior quality wool is never allowed to leave Australia.

The other issue which must be addressed is the cost of production for growers. This is a direct government responsibility and relates to my earlier remarks regarding the many years of income transfer from woolgrowers to others. At long last, the costly burden of tariffs is being lifted from the woolgrowers' weary backs. But this Labor Government, beholden to its union mates, continues to allow archaic industrial relations arrangements to persist, which reduce productivity and therefore increase production costs throughout Australia. This detrimentally affects woolgrowers' indirect costs.

More direct are the specific industrial relations practices in the shearing industry which reduce efficiency and increase costs. On top of that, woolgrowers have to suffer the continuing rorts and inefficiencies in the transport chain in moving their wool to the final users, that is, unnecessarily high costs in land transport, at the waterfront and in shipping. They also have to bear the burden of a high level of input taxes, which the coalition would have removed had we now been in government and which was referred to a few moments ago by my colleague Senator Tambling.

The Government continues to drag the chain on all these essential reforms. If this sounds like I am digressing from the legislation, far from it; these are simply examples of how we are failing to look at the big picture. As long as we do so, the wool crisis will stay exactly that—a major crisis. This legislation is no different. It is a bandaid and nothing more. The coalition, therefore, refuses to do more than simply allow its passage. To do anything else in the current circumstances would be to make the problem worse. However, I conclude by making the point strongly that answering the difficulties with non-solutions is a pathetic way for a government to go about its business.

speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para:
—This evening we are debating the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Amendment Bill 1993. In order to fit in with Senator Evans's new-found interest in declarations of interest, I declare my interest as a woolgrower.
The Australian Wool Realisation Commission was established during 1991-92 for the sole purpose of eventually paying off the debt which remained after the collapse of the reserve price scheme. On its establishment, the AWRC inherited a debt of $2.7 billion and a stockpile of 4.6 million bales. During 1991-92 the AWRC sold 538,000-odd bales, valued at $331 million. During the first half of the following year, 1992-93, the AWRC sold only 98,000-odd bales, worth $58 million.

para.tab: Since then, sales from the stockpile have virtually ceased, with stockpile sales for the season to 30 April totalling 110,000 bales, worth in the vicinity of $58 million. During 1991-92, storage costs were approximately $26 million and interest charges were $258 million. On a per bale basis this is $8 for storage and approximately $60 for interest. As per the AWRC's inventory, the value of the stockpile at the end of 1991-92 totalled $2.4 billion, or approximately $585 per bale. I do not think the value of the wool in the stockpile would be anywhere near that figure because, besides the fact that we have a debt, the stockpile is deteriorating. The wool is losing its springiness due to double dumping. In addition, it is losing its yolk and is being stained by the steel bands around the bales, which are rusting.

The basis of this Bill is the Government's original request that the AWRC meet a minimum schedule of repayments over seven years. This was later replaced, at the industry's urging, with a cumulative debt reduction scheme, which provided for a maximum outstanding debt at the end of each year of the program as follows: in 1992, $2,698 million—in other words, $2.69 billion; in 1993, $2.398 billion; in 1994, $1.998 billion; in 1995, $1.498 billion; in 1996, $948 million; in 1997, $398 million; and then by 1998 it would go to zero. That is the position we were in. Now, with the serious problems that the Australian wool industry has, this Government, after much pressure, has decided to bring in this Bill which simply extends the repayment by one year, and one year only.

Most of the other points that need to be raised have been made by other speakers. In my remaining time, I would like to explode a few myths about the wool industry in Australia today. I read a very interesting article by Henry Haszler, an economist with 25 years experience from Latrobe University. Some of his comments certainly are in line with my philosophy on the wool industry.

I would like to challenge the fairly common view that `greedy' woolgrowers are to blame for the collapse of the reserve price scheme and, therefore, are entirely responsible for the wool debt. According to this view, the key issue for wool policy is how to get woolgrowers to repay the debt incurred in amassing the wool stockpile and not the stockpile itself. First, the wool debt is an irretrievable cost and, secondly, we have a very big stockpile overhanging the market and affecting the market itself. I cannot see at this stage how imposing additional costs on woolgrowers for debt repayments could possibly be in the national interest.

Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics data shows that woolgrowers stood to lose $33,700 a farm on average in 1992-93, bringing the average business operating losses to about $105,700. This is not new news. These figures have been around for a while now. It is little wonder that a lot of growers have been driven to suicide as a result of these financial pressures.

It is not clear, though, to what extent woolgrowers should be held responsible for the debt. The industry incurred the debt during the operation of the reserve price scheme. But at all stages the industry body, the Australian Wool Corporation, was represented by Government Ministers, growers and processors of wool. So it was not entirely the woolgrowers who ran the whole situation.
We have to work out how to treat the policy errors of the Government. How much of that $2.6 billion worth of debt is due to Government policy errors?

This Government has not taken any responsibility whatsoever for the mistakes it made. I know that we have had trotted out in this place and a lot of other places the damage done by Mr Kerin when he went overseas and gave ironclad guarantees. I know that Senator Sherry has heard about this ad nauseam, but that does not mean it is not correct. In fact, what has been said is correct. Some damage did occur. I have already spoken about the decisions that were taken by the government representatives on the board of the industry body.

The Wool Marketing Act 1987 passed a large measure of the control over the setting of the minimum reserve price to the wool industry. It also enabled the Government to continue to use its powers to collect the wool tax and make the scheme compulsory. A decision to allow the MRP to be set so very high was made by the Government in May 1988 and it was implemented on 1 July 1988. I have raised this issue in the Senate ad nauseam, but it is still relevant. A decision was made in May to lift the reserve price from around 700c a kilo to 870c per kilo. By 1 July, the indicator, which was 1,300c per kilo when this decision was made, had dropped to 1,000c per kilo. There was only a 130c difference between the minimum reserve price and the price indicator and it was a disaster.

The Government stood by for two years, from 1 July 1988 to 1 July 1990, without interfering at all—it had the power to interfere, as did the wool corporation—and the wool industry collapsed. The wool corporation was made up of non-woolgrowers, so we have to finally realise that the moral responsibility of all this debt does not lie entirely with the woolgrowers. It is a problem that has to be addressed.

The first decision created a moral hazard for the industry, placing even careful wool industry leaders under enormous pressure to set the MRP higher. The Government had its advisers. It gave the wool corporation the power to set the minimum reserve price where it liked, and it was okayed by the Minister. It was when the general body of woolgrowers wanted the reserve price to be higher that we ran into trouble. As I said, it was obvious that, before the price of 870c per kilo was implemented on 1 July, we would be running into trouble.

There are other precedents where the Government has made mistakes in administering policy, and has gone in and helped the industry out. The collapse of the State Bank of South Australia is a South Australian Government blunder, and the Federal Government has promised to pick up the cost of some of its mistakes. There is ample precedence for the Government could do something to help the wool industry. The woolgrowers certainly do not want a total handout for the $2.6 billion debt, but the Government made mistakes and it should accept certain responsibility.

At present, the wool industry in Australia is probably in the worst situation ever. When I have complained about this during the past six months, I have been told, `You know what the problems are; what are your solutions?'. I, and others, have advocated certain solutions, but they have not been listened to or publicised very much because of the Federal and State elections. I read a very interesting article in today's
Financial Review
. It is headed `Australia in bid to revive wool trade with Russia'. One of the solutions which I was advocating was that we have to create demand with non-traditional buyers. One non-traditional buyer that I have suggested is eastern Europe, where the President lead a delegation, of which I was part. Russia and the United States are also not buying enough.

The article in the
Financial Review
does give us a ray of hope. It states:

speech.para: The first Australian wool shipments have already arrived in Czech Republic and the Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Crean, is to visit Prague next month to try and boost sales

I admire the decision of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). I have been writing to him for six months; a lot of times I have not even got an answer. That was the solution that I and, no doubt, others were giving to him. At least the Minister will find out first hand how we can better our trade. The article goes on:

para.tab: Poland in particular needs a complete overhaul of its textile industry—

speech.para: We saw that when we were there—
and the introduction of new technologies, along with staff retraining and introduction of modern management skills.

para.tab: The next step could be to draw Australian investment into the central European wool industry through the privatisation of the region's mills . . .

speech.para: If we get in there with equity, we will make sure that our wool goes into that industry rather than some other country's wool, because many other countries do grow some very good wool. Dealing with Russia, the article states:

para.tab: The Russian textile industry is so short of funds that mills are unable to buy from local woolgrowers—

speech.para: that is, their own local woolgrowers—

para.tab: Russian industry analysts also estimate that between 30 and 50 per cent of the textile industry's capital equipment needs to be completely replaced.

speech.para: This is where our chance lies. Australia could put equity into this third country which has high technology in a tripartite approach and set up a long-term demand for our wool. I will leave it at that. I welcome the decision by Mr Crean to visit these countries.

para.tab: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry), is at the table listening to the debate. The Government has to take responsibility for that section of the $2.6 billion debt where the former Minister made mistakes—we all make mistakes. The Government advisers in the corporation who made mistakes should also accept their share of the responsibility. I am sure that in seven years time the industry will have met its side of the bargain and repaid this debt and reduced the stockpile.

speech.speaker: West Sen S.M.

talk.start.para: —Tonight, with the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Amendment Bill 1993, we are having, for the third or fourth time, a debate on the wool industry. Much water has passed under the bridge, but what still remains is that the wool industry is in dire straits. Some areas are in even more difficulty because, compounded upon the low commodity prices, they also have drought, although we are not discussing that tonight.

para.tab: I was pleased to hear some of the points that were made by those opposite. However, I would disagree with their suggestion that we abolish the retention of time limits on the legislation. That would send the wrong signals to everybody. It does not answer the question of how and from whom would the debt be recovered. We are extending the debt repayment by 12 months because the $118 million that is due for debt repayment in 1993-94 is already to hand. It means there is no need for the commission to go out and actually have to sell wool in this next financial year to face its debt repayments. If we removed the time limit from the legislative schedule it would remove the need for the commission to put wool on to the market, but we would be increasing the debt, because the debt has to be serviced. If we chose not to sell the wool, who would service that debt and how would it be serviced? We have not heard about that tonight.

When the announcement was made about the time extension for the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, many people overlooked the point that Senator Panizza just briefly raised; that is, it is the intention of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to travel around during the break before the Budget sittings to our wool buying countries. He will not only look at what those countries perceive to be the problems but also encourage them to get back into the marketplace and to buy the product. He will remind them of just how good our product and our industry is. No-one would quibble that wool is the best fibre product available in the marketplace because it is so versatile—it is warm, it is cool and it is everything one could want. However, we need to keep reminding people of that.

The other aspect of this debate is the review of the wool industry. Nobody seems to have looked very much at that. There have been calls here tonight to improve the marketing and promotion of wool, and to improve the standard of the clip and the way it is prepared. These questions will be answered by the review and it is important to look at its terms of reference. The review will look at:

speech.para: .the influences affecting the Australian and International demand, supply and price of wool over the next decade;

.cost-effective means of creating a sustained increase in the international market for wool, with particular emphasis on the marketing efforts of the International Wool Secretariat, and the promotional arrangements for other natural fibres such as cotton.
.the commercial orientation and effectiveness of the current structures for:

para.tab: .management of wool promotion, marketing and sale;

.
research and development policy;
.management of the wool stockpile, consistent with the prudent management of the debt and stockpile;
.increasing the value added to wool in Australia including in respect of the issues raised in the Report of the Task Force on Wool Processing;
.engaging in more active and innovative marketing, including futures trading.

speech.para: The review will also look at:

.factors affecting the profitability of wool production in Australia, the alternatives to wool production and the adjustment into other activities for wool producers with limited long-term prospects; and
.the adequacy and efficiency of the social justice and structural adjustment measures as they apply to the wool industry.

This review will address a number of the issues that the industry itself perceives and identifies as key issues that have to be addressed. This will help the wool industry go into the 21st century and beyond with a product that not only meets the demands of the suppliers but also provides an adequate income for the producers.

para.tab: This Bill tonight is not just about the extension of time from seven years to eight years for the Wool Realisation Commission to wind up; it also involves the terms of reference for an inquiry into the industry. That inquiry will be one of the most significant things that has happened in this industry. It is a very important industry to this nation; if our woolgrowers are suffering in this crisis, and we produce the best wool available, I would not like to know what is happening to woolgrowers in other countries. However, at present, our main concern is with woolgrowers here in Australia. This very good package goes some way towards addressing those needs. We should also be aware that these moves have had a lot of support from many grower and farmer organisations in the country. I have much pleasure tonight in supporting this Bill.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1993, which we are speaking on tonight, is part of a package to try to solve the deep crisis that is afflicting the wool industry and, of course, through that, much of rural Australia. No doubt all of us are aware, through either personal experience or from watching television at night, of the crisis that is afflicting people in the drought stricken areas of Australia. I remind all honourable senators that, whether they grow sheep and produce wool in a drought affected area or in an area that is receiving good rainfall, the crisis in the wool industry affects people in the same way, because we have an enormous uncertainty about the price of wool in the future, an enormous debt overhanging the industry and, of course, the problem with the stockpile.

para.tab: I speak tonight not only to those honourable senators who are present in the chamber but also to Senator Austin Lewis who said last night, when we were looking at bringing on this debate, that he would listen to the quite lengthy list of speakers on this Bill tonight and would look forward to at least one of them coming up with a solution to the industry. I think he was being quite cynical, but I say to Senator Lewis that my solution to the crisis for wool may, indeed, be found through the review process that is going on into the marketing of wool and the future treatment of the stockpile. I certainly hope it is.

The solution will not be found by trying to redesign the bureaucracy that has built up around the wool industry, particularly through the Australian Wool Corporation and now the Wool Realisation Commission, but in destroying the bureaucracy around the wool industry and breaking down the industry into units that can be handled not only by growers but also by entrepreneurs who want to find new ways of processing wool, new woollen products and new ways of taking woollen products into new international markets.

There is absolutely no doubt that the bureaucracy that has surrounded the wool industry in Australia for so long now has ensured that the change that is required to move into a rapidly changing world, and to cope with rapidly changing tastes and rapidly changing economics, has simply not occurred. Most of us know from personal experience that the more distant bureaucracies and large corporations are from their members and constituents, the more inefficient those industries will be. This can relate to bureaucratic government departments or large bureaucratic private sector organisations.

I believe that until the Government in particular and the wool industry specifically come to grips with the problem of the size of the bureaucracy, the vested interests that are involved in controlling the stockpile, in marketing wool and in undertaking the research and development into wool, there will be no long-term solution. I said in my contribution to the debate on wool a couple of weeks ago that if the owners of a stockpile of a product, say, Ford motor cars, experience a massive decrease in the demand for motor cars and a massive increase in supply and have a few acres of parking space out in Geelong or somewhere filled with those products, the last thing they will do in trying to sell that stockpile is create a bureaucracy. They will not be looking to funding people who live and work in that bureaucracy with big salaries and telling them to spend X amounts on research and development and X amounts on marketing.

What one would do if one were dinkum about getting rid of the stockpile, returning some certainty to the industry and returning it to equilibrium, would be to ensure that one had some highly motivated entrepreneurial individuals who were responsible for getting that product into the marketplace and getting a return for it as quickly as possible. One could not do better than getting a couple of thousand hungry used car salesmen out there selling the product.

talk.start.para: —Or real estate salesmen.

—Or real estate salesmen, or even hungry politicians. I say quite seriously that I am not advocating a way of breaking down the bureaucracy or breaking down the system that has been set up, but that we move from the present highly centralised, highly bureaucratic structure to a system where we can involve as many entrepreneurs and sales oriented people as possible.

para.tab: Until the world market and the industry itself—the growers and everyone else involved in the wool industry—can see a reduction in the stockpile and a significant reduction in the debt, then certainty will not return to the industry and people will not invest in it. Those involved in the industry will not increase investment in new equipment, new technologies, new products and new ways of marketing the product until this massive stockpile and associated debt are eradicated.

I cannot see a solution in extending the repayments schedule and extending the life of the stockpile for another year. Of course, it is an important palliative in the short term, but in the long term there needs to be a radical solution to the problem. I think that it will involve a destruction of the bureaucracy that is built around it.

There are enormous vested interests built up in this industry and in the Australian Wool Corporation and it is associated bodies. What I am advocating today is that the solution to the problem is to destroy the bureaucracy, to walk over those vested interests and to ensure that the sale of wool and the stockpile in the interim is put in the hands of people who are about selling and getting a return as quickly as possible.

I must say that my experience in the last couple of months, in talking to woolgrowers and others who are now coming into the business of trying to find new markets, is quite pleasing. Some entrepreneurs I have met, such as those who are associated with the wool insulation business and who are trying to find alternative uses for wool, do not have a good relationship with the Australian Wool Corporation and its associated bodies. This reflects the bureaucratic inertia of such organisations in that those concerned cannot get answers or cooperation from the Wool Corporation because clearly some of the ideas that are being put forward by entrepreneurs are not in the mainstream.

These people are going behind the back of the realisation commission, behind the back of the Australian Wool Corporation, doing deals with growers, buying wool straight out of sheds and doing deals with overseas mills and, basically, ignoring the bureaucracy that is surrounding the wool industry. If that is what can happen in such a highly structured, centralised bureaucratic system that we have at the moment—if we can have these sorts of entrepreneurs working on the edges of the industry, trying to make a dollar out of solving the crisis—I wonder what could happen if we broke down the massive bureaucracy, got rid of the structure we have at the moment and opened the whole thing up.

I hope my words have given Senator Austin Lewis a ray of hope. I suggest, particularly in light of the review that the Minister, Mr Crean, announced some weeks ago, that what the industry needs is not just a restructuring of the wool corporation and the setting up of new committees and new bureaucratic structures. Indeed, we should take the opportunity to say we have a real problem, to say that what has happened in the past 20 years has not worked for the industry. If we are going to solve the deep problems of the wool industry for all of rural Australia, we should take this opportunity to make some very radical change.

talk.start.para: —This debate really holds no pleasure for me, like all those people involved in the rural area, former wool farmers, and people who have associations with the bush. These people are absolutely disgusted and dismayed at what is happening to the wool industry. I was very pleased to see that the Parliamentary Secretary to Mr Crean, Senator Sherry, my colleague from Tasmania, was here earlier; I presume he is coming back. I hope he is here to hear what I say.

para.tab: What we are talking about tonight has been well laid out by previous speakers. We are trying to extend the period for the debt repayment on our stockpile from seven to eight years and make available $50 million for interest rate subsidies. At a time when we need leadership, direction and a united approach to try to put the wool industry back on track, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Amendment Bill can be classed only as a very small contribution to what is a huge problem.

There are a large number of speakers on this Bill. The time we have is limited, but I am pleased to see there are so many speakers—and so there should be. The whole matter of the wool stockpile, the debt, the drought and everything else associated with the wool industry at the moment can rightly be called a natural disaster of unprecedented length. Here we are in 1993 with the lowest wool prices in 50 years, coupled with Australia's farm debt, now a staggering $15.6 billion, with an annual interest bill in the order of $12 billion. It is almost getting to the stage of what is happening with our Government and its debt.

The only suggestion and action from the Government is to provide an interest subsidy of $50 million and to defer the debt repayment for one year. On top of that, the Government has set up the 30th review we have had into the wool industry, chaired by Mr Garnaut. Let us hope that this 30th review will come up with something which may be of some help.

We all know that the major problem facing the wool industry at the moment is the stockpile—some 3.9 million bales. Just to give some idea of the magnitude of that, the other day I read that it equates to 11.7 million filing cabinets. Stacked one on top of the other, it would measure 5.9 million metres high, compared with Mount Everest which is a mere 8,848 metres high.

When I was having a game of tennis today I worked out that the two tennis courts we were on would probably hold, with a bit of luck, 1,000 thousand bales of wool. If we multiply that by 4,000 we get some idea of the quantity of wool that is waiting to be sold.

Who do we blame for all of this? It is very easy to blame the Government and the wool corporation. I suppose that, for starters, they are the ones we should look at. Over the years we have seen the wool corporation and the International Wool Secretariat waste millions of dollars on extravagant and useless wool promotions. I suppose that was fair enough when wool was selling at 1,000c a kilogram. Who amongst the woolgrowers, including myself, was ever going to question the wool corporation?

Nevertheless, in 1990 I did—at an Agricultural Outlook Conference here in Canberra. I had not been in this place very long. At a private briefing given to us by the chairman of the wool corporation, Hugh Beggs, he said that the wool stockpile then stood at 2.5 million bales. I said, `Are you sure that it is not 3.5 million bales?'. He said, `No, of course it's not'. A week later we found out that it was 3.5 million bales. He not only misled me but he also misled Australia by making that sort of statement. Obviously he was misled, too, because he was reported as saying—a very remarkable quote, which he will probably never put in a frame over the top of his bed—`We are lucky, those of us in the wool industry, in having a product which is almost infinitely marketable'.

On that same day I also asked whether the wool corporation had a fall-back position if anything went wrong with the reserve price scheme, which was experiencing a bit of drama. At that time the reserve price was about 860c. It had just fallen back to 700c when Mr Kerin said that it was immutable and was never going to be moved. It was amazing to me that a multi-million dollar corporation that had been running the wool industry for so long did not have a fall-back position or an emergency plan.

Of course, when we blame the wool corporation, we have to say that the Federal government of the time must take its share of the blame. We all remember—it has been spoken about here tonight—that the fiddling of the reserve price scheme did nothing but create uncertainty in the world wool markets. We all remember the approval of the 870c a kilogram floor price. The money—I hope I declared the fact that I am a woolgrower—that I was paying out of my wool account, which was not all that big, was going into an account to buy back the wool I was selling. When it was reduced to 700c a kilogram, with about three million bales in stock, the situation was quite ridiculous. The iron-clad guarantee that Mr Kerin gave did not last very long; in fact, it eroded very quickly. I have heard of some buyers losing heaps of money. One buyer lost $50 million. It is no wonder that those people buying our wool lost faith in the industry.

Another casualty of the wool crisis has been the CSIRO's Wool Research and Development Corporation. Because of the drop in the price of wool, the amount of money that went into that organisation has dropped from $52 million in 1990 to $29 million this financial year. That has not only put at risk 150 jobs; it also going to put at risk the critical research carried out by that corporation.

Senator Cooney would remember how, during our time on the animal welfare committee, we had an insight into the wonderful work the corporation is doing. Things such as the flystrike program, the worm-free sheep program, scouring technology, permacrease and Siromark which it has been involved with over the years will be seriously affected by the downturn in the wool industry.

Madam Acting Deputy President, as a member of the rural and regional affairs committee, you would know that we have been in the ideal situation over the last year or so, during the drought inquiry that we conducted and now the present shearing industry inquiry, to observe just what is happening out in the bush and the effect it is having on not just the farmers or the woolgrowers but everybody who is concerned with this industry. I do not think anybody comprehends the effect that this whole matter is having on rural and regional Australia. Everybody is affected and everybody should be concerned.

Now I want to talk about solutions. Some of the proposed solutions have been mixed and varied. Premier Goss in Queensland said we should burn the wool stockpile. Another suggested solution, from the CWA, was that we should knit it away. Another suggestion, from a well-known economist from the economics department of La Trobe University, Mr Peter Bardsley, was that we should double the wool tax—and that was to raise the incomes of the wool producers of this country. I do not know which of those would solve the problem. I do not think any of them would.

The Wool Council of Australia is now calling for the amalgamation of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Wool Research and Development Corporation. Only a couple of years ago the Wool Council was calling for them to be split up because it believed they could do a better job separately. Now it is talking about getting them back together. So we are all over the place at the moment.

I noted in a press article the other day that the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, Mac Drysdale, has warned that unless the Russian economic situation improves we will never win back our third largest market. That leads me, in the last minute or so of the time available to me, to say that I appreciate the efforts Senator Sherry made on my behalf to allow me to see the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean)—I think it was around 1 o'clock last Friday morning. I believe that is where the answer is. We have to get out there and sell this wool, and promote it, even if we have to take a few risks.

At present the Wool Realisation Commission has one hand tied behind its back. It does not have the flexibility it needs. We have proposals coming forward all the time. Some of them are quite weird and some of them need investigation. One of the proposals that Senator Sherry and I know about is an offer by the Latvian Government, through Vis Feldmanis—a Tasmanian whom Senator Sherry would know, who is acting on behalf of the National Bank of Latvia—to sell half of its leading mills to Australian interests at bargain basement prices in exchange for wool and cash.

They are the sorts of deals we should be looking at, and there are quite a few of them out there. Unfortunately, the Wool Realisation Commission does not have the flexibility to deal with those types of offers. If the wool corporation was a commercial operation rather than a semi-government operation, I believe it would have that flexibility.

So we have to use more aggressive marketing and more imagination to try to reverse the trend whereby we have lost market share to cotton and synthetics. In 1950-51, for instance, when dags were bringing a pound a pound, we had 10 per cent of the market. Last financial year, 1991-92, we had 4.4 per cent of the market.

I note today from our local paper in Hobart that a team of woolgrowers went to America and talked to the people over there about wool. They found that people in America, the consumers of our wool, are worried about the prickly effect of it. They are worried about this and that. Think of the millions of dollars that have been spent through the wool corporation trying to promote our wool over the years. It is millions of dollars down the drain if the man in the street in Los Angeles believes that wool is not the right fibre. If that is the case, all I can say is that all the money that the woolgrowers and the Government have put into wool promotion for so long has been for nothing.

Senator Sherry has the job in front of him to convince his Minister that some changes have to be made. I hope that, as a result of this debate tonight, the suggestions that he has already and those that he will hear around Australia from more learned people than myself will go a long way towards turning around what has been, and is, one of the great industries in this country.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Amendment Bill is one part of a four-part approach the Government is taking to the wool crisis. The measures include interest rate subsidies, maintenance of the wool tax, restructuring of the debt and an inquiry. Much of what has been said here tonight has canvassed the broad issues. A good deal of what has been said has a strong element of truth to it in terms of the way the Australian Wool Realisation Commission has operated and the complete failure of the old scheme of reserve price mechanisms.

para.tab: It is a bit unfortunate that some people still seem to hark back to those days. In my own State as late as 5 May the agriculture Minister was still suggesting that the reason for the crisis in the wool industry was the changing of that scheme. He made that point to the Victorian Parliament and effectively blamed John Kerin for the crisis in the wool industry. An interesting observation that people make about the crisis in the industry is that people have learnt so little about it.

It is unfortunate that some people in Victoria, such as the Premier, have maintained a similar very negative attitude towards the proposals that have been advanced by this Government to address what is obviously a very serious problem. The Premier indicated that he thought the proposals that the Federal Government was bringing forward were no more than a bandaid package. It is little wonder that in Victoria, with the foot-in-mouth approaches that the Premier has taken, the transport Minister is currently organising a challenge against the Premier and is openly canvassing votes within the party room. It is common knowledge that the Premier himself is backgrounding journalists in an attempt to undermine and discredit his own transport Minister. It is those sorts of attitudes, that are reflected in Victoria, that I find quite disappointing. They indicate the depth of ignorance that still exists within certain parties in Victoria.

Of the approximately 8,000 woolgrowers in Victoria, about 2,000 will be seeking financial assistance this financial year. The crisis is quite pronounced. However, it is not just the woolgrowers who are affected by this crisis. This point has been made by other speakers, but I think it needs to be emphasised, because it is not often addressed in public debate. Australian shearers, for instance, have played a vital role in the development of the wool industry and have a proud record of advancing working conditions for all Australians. Their incomes have also been slashed. Many growers are using the present crisis within the industry to undermine and attack workers' wages and conditions.

I hope that the recent debate which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has raised about New Zealand shearers coming to this country will be raised again in New Zealand. It has been estimated that up to half of our qualified shearers are currently unemployed as a result of the influx of large numbers of people from New Zealand who are accepting conditions of work in breach of awards. We have also recently seen award decisions of the commission being challenged.

talk.start.para: —There is no justification for saying that. They don't breach awards at all.

—There is plenty of justification for saying that. There is a real problem in this country which simply cannot be addressed by looking at the wool industry merely in terms of what happens up to the farm gate. The proposed inquiry will offer some real alternatives; it will examine other means of securing additional markets. It is one to thing to talk about the situation in eastern Europe—and I think that has to be done, in terms of the Minister seeking additional markets internationally—but we also need to examine the other people who are directly affected by the crisis in the wool industry.

para.tab: I have mentioned the shearers. Perhaps the textile workers in this country also have a real interest in what happens to this industry. As has been stated here tonight, there have bee some problems with people developing alternative markets for our woolclip.

Senator Barney Cooney and I have had brought to our attention the fact that the textile industry in Victoria is suffering very badly. But there are other ways—for example, value adding—of attracting markets and developing industries. So the wool stockpile could be used for other purposes.

We have seen proposals such as using wool for insulation. In my previous employment at the Ministry of Planning and Housing in Victoria, I had some involvement in the trialling of wool bats. The BWIU, in conjunction with entrepreneurs, was seeking to find alternatives to synthetic fibres. Although that has fallen a bit by the wayside, it is another area which I trust the Minister will be able to pursue after the inquiry reports.

In my view, the whole notion that we have to provide assistance to the wool industry is essentially correct. However, it is important that the States also play a role in that process. I note that measures have been taken in Western Australia and Victoria. However, I am concerned about recent steps in Victoria to make sure that the money is actually available. There have been suggestions that the source of that money has been identified and its availability has to be guaranteed. I think basically the proposals before the Senate are worthy of support and I trust that all honourable senators will support them.

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, may I commence by saying how pleasing it is to have you in the chair this evening and to enjoy your stewardship over these proceedings. I am concerned, however, that the woolgrowers of Australia, and the people who are dependent on them for their living, are being sold short by a government whose penny-pinching attitude will exacerbate the situation in which many of our woolgrowers find themselves at this point in time. Why? Because the Government has taken an attitude that says, `Instead of giving flexibility to the realisation of the stockpile, we are merely going to postpone the crisis for another 12 months by extending the debt repayment schedule for another 12 months'.

para.tab: What is desperately needed at this point is quite simply an abandonment of the debt repayment schedule. We need to take whatever steps are necessary to ensure that we do not flood the market with the wool that is currently in the stockpile; to ensure that we do not depress the prices that farmers are getting for what they produce so that the farmers who are still left in the industry—heaven knows we have lost enough to date—will have a chance to get a decent rate of return.

That would also allow us to achieve one other thing: at only a very small rate of realisation it is possible for us to set a zero tax for woolgrowers in so far as the Wool Realisation Commission is concerned. That 4 1/2 per cent of tax is worth something like $27 a bale. It is very important that we do everything in our power to maximise the cash flow of our woolgrowers.

Just a couple of moments ago we heard Senator Carr make a plea on behalf of shearers. I am not going to get into the rights and wrongs of the shearing industry, nor am I going to go into detail about the rates that shearers get, but it is interesting to note, as Senator Panizza interjected, that the rates for shearers have gone up. There are many in this country who would argue that if the rates for shearers had stayed the same, the shearers would actually be making more money than they are now. But the point is this: unless we can maximise the cash flow of the woolgrowers, there will be fewer and fewer shearers working because there will be less opportunity for woolgrowers to pay those shearers to shear the sheep.

There are people in Queensland, in the areas around the Warrego, who are shearing their entire flock themselves. Senator Boswell brought to the attention of the media a story of one young man who was spending months and months single-handedly shearing his flock because he could not afford the cost of having them shorn. Every single dollar of tax that the Government puts on woolgrowers is a further impediment to the prosperity of the industry. That is why those of us on this side support the amendment that has been moved, which points out that the inflexibility of the Government's approach to this problem, the retention of a time limit, sends all the wrong signals to the wool market. It sends to it a signal that this Government is not willing to back the wool industry. It sends to it a signal that the Government is unwilling to take the steps necessary to return prosperity to woolgrowers.

What the market wants from us is simply confidence. The market wants to believe that we believe in the wool industry at a time when we can finance our stockpile at interest rates that are very low compared with what we have been paying in the past. Now more than ever is the time for us to be saying, `Yes, we are willing to carry the financing cost of the stockpile because we know that at the end of the day we will recoup it and more'.

We can finance this stockpile at 7 1/2 per cent. We could hold the stockpile for 14 years, pay the interest, sell the wool at the end and still come out on top. But instead, the Government has given the industry just one year of grace in the extension of the debt repayment schedule for the Wool Realisation Commission. The wool industry deserves better from its government than the treatment it has received, which is merely an extension of one year in the debt repayment schedule.
Do not forget that this industry financed the development of inland Australia and was a principal export earner for this nation for most of its history. Its members now come before this Parliament saying, `We desperately need assistance'—and these are proud people.

Madam Deputy President, you would understand how I felt last night when I received a call from a young man from Surat who phoned to say that he had been unable to continue working on the family farm. The farm had not had any rain for 12 months and he had to go off and earn money as a pilot in the Northern Territory to try to get some cash flow to help keep the farm going. His story is the story of thousands and thousands of wool-growing families. These are people for whom the rural adjustment scheme is not a hope of salvation but an absurdity. Under the criteria they cannot qualify for RAS because the Government assesses them as not being viable enough. These are people for whom the promise of assistance is held further than arm's reach.

The Government does the wool industry a grave wrong in not extending the debt repayment schedule further or abandoning it so that the wool industry knows that we will not flood the market with more wool in 12 months time, so that the wool industry knows that we are willing to hold on to the stockpile until the price comes up. If we release wool into the market in large quantities, or give the industry reason to believe that we will do so, the only consequence will be a reduction in the price. That does not just mean a reduction in the earnings of woolgrowers, but a reduction in the earnings of shearers, truckies and everybody else in this country. Hundreds of thousands of people in this country are dependent on the wool industry.

The rural industries in this country are at a point of crisis where they deserve consideration from a government with a big picture vision. Whilst interest rates are relatively low, the Government ought to put together a scheme of debt refinancing for agricultural industries. It would be easy to do and would have manifest benefits.

At the moment we have a situation where the banks which are carrying the rural debt have been forced to make massive provisions against the possibility that the people who owe the money to the banks, the farmers in particular, will not be able to repay. I do not know what the level of provisioning is by banks against debts in the rural industry. It is probably about 30c in the dollar. But if the Government was willing to borrow the money at low interest rates to refinance those farmers and, therefore, buy the debts off the banks, an immediate tax benefit would come to the Government, because the banks that had already made provisions at, say, 70c in the dollar would all of a sudden be realising their loans at something like 90c to 100c in the dollar.

The loss that the banks had previously incurred would be brought on to the balance sheet as a capital gain—as a profit. Therefore, a portion of that money—something like half of the difference—would be recouped in increased taxes next year. There would be an immediate increase in government revenue. More importantly, not only would it give us the opportunity to finance the rural industries of this country at low interest rates over a long period of time, it would also guard against the possibility of the banks making further provisions.

Around Charleville and the red soil country people are selling their farms for $2 an acre. One can pick up a 60,000 acre farm for $120,000 with the house thrown in. What level of losses will the banks suffer if that is the sort of return they get on their loans? One must remember that these loans were made at a time when property sold for a much higher price and the level of indebtedness now surely well exceeds the level of money being realised when those farms go on the market.

The Government must be willing to put a long-term financing package together for the wool industry and other agricultural industries which desperately need this assistance. The question is, do we want to have farmers? Do we want people producing agricultural exports? Do we want people providing the incentive for small towns and regional centres to continue to exist, or will we throw them to the wolves because it does not suit the Government? At a time when money is to be found in plenty for those in the trade union movement, and at a time when the Government seems to find extra money to send travelling players and minstrels around the country to entertain the masses, one wonders why it is that the backbone of this nation's economy has been left so desperately undefended by our Federal Government.

In conclusion, I can only say that this country and every single Australian has enjoyed the prosperity which has come from the hard work and labour of our farmers for decades and decades. How can we call ourselves Australians if, at this hour of crisis, we now turn our backs on the people who have done so much for our country? I think of my friends in Queensland who have not had rain for three years but who are soldiering on and on. I believe we owe it to them and to all the woolgrowers and primary producers in this country. We owe it to the young fellow who phoned me last night and said he had to get a job as a pilot in the Northern Territory. We owe it to the bloke who sheared his entire flock on his own because he could not afford to get shearers. We owe it to that industry to put something back and say `Thank you' for what it has done for us.

talk.start.para: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Amendment Bill 1993, which we support because it extends to the wool industry the period of the Government guarantee from seven to eight years to cover the additional year of debt. The wool industry would be in a much better position to trade its way out of its entrenched troubles if there were fewer bodies administering and handling its various activities.

para.tab: Essentially, this Bill is all about the activities surrounding those people whom I might call the liquidators—the people who have the responsibility of getting rid of the wool. What people have not realised is that there is a vast difference between a marketer and a liquidator. Their approaches to selling and distribution are entirely different. So we have a fundamental problem with the attitudes and philosophies of a group of people who have the job of liquidating wool.

One of the biggest mistakes the liquidators made was having a schedule of their realisation over time. If you have to sell a commodity over a definite period, you never send out a signal to your customers as to the quantity and value of the commodity that you are going to dispose of over the various time schedules. The sooner we get back to a system of trying to market our wool internationally in a proper way, the sooner we will be able to trade our way out of difficulty. That means some restructuring, such as getting rid of a number of the bodies that have a finger in the wool handling pie.

There is some hope on the horizon; in recent weeks there has been some increase in price. I remind the Senate of a matter that I have raised in my own State. We must recognise that nowadays, in effect, we have two stockpiles. There is the official stockpile, which is causing so much heartburn, and there is another one which is equally as important and which requires consideration. That is wool which is stockpiled not only in farmers' sheds, brokers' houses, warehouses and other places, but around the world in noil form, semi-processed stock and so on.

We have to be careful when we start talking about burning wool, giving wool away and so on. A solution requires the pooling of the various managerial ideas that have been around, including one from the Country Women's Association about encouraging people to knit more. Obviously with the price down, more people will feel encouraged to knit.

One of the problems in marketing wool is that industry leaders and Ministers have not visualised the sort of industry they want in the long term. In the past the industry has been based on a high price for that section of the clip known as the fine micron end, from 19 microns down. But if we are going to return to buoyant earnings across the spectrum, we have to refocus on wool as a broad use, multi-use fibre and not just as an exclusive fibre commanding very high prices. We have to look at more average prices, and focus on an increased demand for the product as a whole rather than on wool as a specialty fibre. If we concentrate in the next few years on wool as a specialty fibre there will be no future for this great industry.

I add a word of warning as one who spent a number of years in the wool industry. A lot of people do not realise that by withholding supply we are wrecking the long-term interests of the industry, because wool must flow through the system. Once the processors stop using wool and move to synthetics, it is very hard to get back. Because of the low prices in eastern Europe and elsewhere, we have a great opportunity to get people back into producing woollen products. For this purpose, we must restructure. We must have a sense of direction regarding where the future of this once great industry should lie.

speech.speaker: Bell Sen R.J.

talk.start.para: —I respect the advice given by Senator Watson. I know of his experience in the industry, and I think it is important that we be generous enough to recognise the merit in what he says. What is unfortunate about this debate is that too much of the material that has been printed so far in our newspapers and too much of the wordage that has been delivered in places such as this have suffered from the same inadequacy. It has been theory delivered in isolation—not just isolation from the real world, but isolation from other theories and other ideas.
