It is the lack of respect that we have given to other ideas that has made it so much more difficult to make progress with this problem.

para.tab: The trouble is that we all suffer from the delusion that our theories will actually have an impact on the problem, but our individual theories will not. Even what I have just said is wrong. There is not one problem; there is not one single fix for the wool industry. The industry suffers from manifold problems. It has demands which can be met only by a cooperative strategy—a strategy which addresses a variety of ways to achieve profitability for our wool industry.

Time after time in this place we spout platitudes. Tonight we have seen honourable senators trying to curry favour with a few people here and a few people there. Time and time again, written speeches describing the situation are read out with great passion; facts are read out about the status of the industry by speaker after speaker. Each speaker is attempting to demonstrate his or her intimate knowledge of the problem, as if to say: `I share your problems. I told the Parliament all about it. I am the one who represented you in that place'. There is a lot of gnashing of teeth and much wailing, much flailing of arms goes on, but there is little tangible action. And it is tangible action that is required.

If we do not see gnashing of teeth, we see the frantic scribbling of pens in the creation of an endless stream of press releases. Honourable senators know the sort to which I am referring: the one-page press releases with the quick headline grabbing cop-out, such as burn the stockpile; freeze it; trigger it; knit it; give it away; weave it into blankets for aid. Mr Tuckey, who is a member in the other place, calls these snake oil remedies, and I agree with him.

Each of these solutions is impractical and impossible to deliver on its own. During the last debate that we had on this subject a few days ago, I said—and I know that the entire chamber agrees with me—that burning would be an incredible logistical exercise. It would require huge amounts of energy. The transport that would be required even to burn the stockpile would be costly. One cannot just light a match and throw it into a warehouse.

We have heard criticism of the other snake oil remedies, such as how many jumpers would need to be knitted. If we gave it away, we would still owe billions of dollars to the people we borrowed money from to buy the stockpile. The transport costs could well add on a few million dollars to that process. The funny thing is—and if this problem were not so serious it would be funny—that this has been recognised. In an article by Mark Irving in the
Age
of 1 May, Barry Jackson from the Australian Wool Corporation said of the stockpile:

speech.para: And if we gave it away to knitters, we'd need to spend $12 a kilo to convert it into yarn. That would cost $8.4 billion. . .
We should not take such suggestions at face value, but with a little enlightenment aimed at considering them carefully. I am not dismissive of them, and I will address that in a few moments.

para.tab: I want to make sure that we critically evaluate the concept that there is a quick fix. More complicated fixes have been mentioned by other people. These people are the ones who deliver the comprehensive plans, who want to change the parameters entirely and want to establish new triggers, new rules, new floor prices, new thresholds and so on. These particular solutions are characterised by a lot of noise and a lot of fanfare. But in fact there is very little likelihood of our seeing the revolution that would be necessary for the implementation of those particular plans. I say that because these well-intentioned plans do not recognise the politics of the present situation. The politics is that almost all of the comprehensive plans would require a revolution to implement—and it should not be about revolution.

Senator O'Chee was asking for a reshaping of finance. I agree with a lot of what Senator O'Chee said in that regard, but we must be careful—and we heard this expression a lot during the debate about the level of the wool tax some years ago—not to throw the baby out with the bath water. The comprehensive plans would require a revolution to implement. The thing that best describes these plans is that they are cheap shots, fired in the knowledge that the person making the comprehensive plan is seldom required to explain or take responsibility for its implementation.

What I am trying to get across to the Senate is not a belittlement of such plans because sometimes many of them sell well as books. I think the plans are well-intentioned but politically unwise because there is too much point scoring, too much politicking and too much self-aggrandisement about this whole question. We do this and then wonder why the electorate is so cynical, why there is no national swell of enthusiasm about any particular plan and why people are not actually leaping to follow a particular path.

We are really just filling the air with words. I think it is about time we actually stopped and started to listen to each other. We should begin by recognising the merits of each other's arguments and building on those things that can he done. I will start the ball rolling tonight. I will recognise that Senator Panizza and Senator Crane were perfectly accurate in an earlier debate on this topic when they introduced a number of the features into the argument.

Mr Tuckey, in the other place, suggested that there should really be a government sponsored attempt made to establish a retail outlet in Japan, for example, as a show case for what could be done. What he was proposing was not another one of those trial plots or combined retail ventures in private industry, but he was talking about government intervention to establish such a proposal. I think that is great. Government intervention and support is what is needed and such a suggestion would certainly receive the whole-hearted support of the Australian Democrats. I think we ought to look beyond party politics and recognise the merit of some of these proposals.

Mr McLachlan in the other place suggested selling a specific amount of the stockpile at an early discount. He suggested that the rest of the stockpile would be less of a problem if, for example, a significant portion of the stockpile—whether that be a quarter, a third or a half—be sold at an early discount. I suggest there is some merit in that proposal as well and I would like to build on it a bit. I suggest—and Senator Panizza was saying something similar to this a few days ago—that the wool that we sell in the first instance should not be sold to our traditional wool markets and not sold for the traditional uses to which wool has been put, but rather for uses which are novel and which do not compete with our traditional wool markets.

That sounds just a bit easy to say, but I will continue that theme and fill it out because examples of it have been given. Part of what Senator Panizza was saying some days ago was that such uses need aggressive marketing. Senator Crane added some of the novel uses which need to be expanded upon. Those who are interested in the wool industry already know that a huge potential exists for the replacement of imported wool used in the manufacture of carpet in Australia. I do not know what the exact percentage is at the moment but, not long ago, 85 per cent of the wool used in Australia to manufacture carpet was imported. We imported it from New Zealand, Pakistan, Uruguay, Argentina—from a number of places which honourable senators would be surprised to know we traded with.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Sherry, would be aware that situated in the city in which he lives is one of Australia's fine carpet wool manufacturing companies. At that establishment in Devonport, the factory is willing to—and does—buy all carpet wool which is produced in Tasmania, yet it still imports a huge amount from overseas. At first glance, it might be thought that the superfine merino or the wool we produce for other uses may not be suitable for carpet, but that is not the case at all. The best, strongest wool for carpet is in the order of 32 microns, but it is possible to use wool of 28 microns or even finer in the manufacture of carpets, provided one can buy it cheaply enough. And this is where I suggest the circle can be completed.

The other day Senator Panizza described a considerable portion of the stockpile as being bellies, skirtings, crutchings and whatever else. I told Senator Panizza of an entrepreneur who has managed to sell such wool to India for use in carpet, regardless of its micron. The fact was that it was cheap wool. This is where the discounted wool from the stockpile could be used. I suggest that such wool should be made available to Australia's carpet industry at the discount about which I have just been speaking. One source of a subsidy to pay for that discount is the $250 million which is necessary to meet storage and interest payments. That is a cost at the moment, but if the quantity of wool were removed it would no longer be a cost. That gives a hint of the source of the subsidy which could be used to attract the discount to provide that wool.

Many other things which are imported could be replaced with low cost, low quality wool. Again, those who are interested and informed in the wool industry recognise the fact that synthetic woolpacks can be replaced with woollen woolpacks, and have been, successfully. When I suggest there ought to be action rather than words, a very good example of government action would be to facilitate the development of the industry—which already exists, which needs expanding—by expanding the provision of woollen woolpacks to replace the synthetic ones.

As those in the wool industry know, synthetic woolpacks seemed attractive at first. When I was first involved in the wool industry we used hessian woolpacks, even before core sampling. At the time we took a few pounds of wool out of the top of the hessian pack, used that for display and repacked and restitched later. I did not like synthetic packs when they were introduced because they were awkward to handle, slippery and burned the inside of one's forearms when trying to move the things around. I think it would be great if we were able to replace those packs. I know what they are called in the industry, but I will not use that term here; it was not a favourable term that was used to describe the new breed of synthetic woolpacks. It would be a great day to return to a natural fibre, nothing which could be better than wool.

A bounty for the production of such items is the sort of government action, initiative and intervention which would provoke a greater use of such material. I think the same government action is consistent with the support for what I previously described as snake oil remedies. They are only snake oil remedies when the proponent writes a letter to the editor and says, `I reckon we ought to knit the stockpile', or whatever. They become useful if the Government has the capacity to recognise their usefulness and to take action which would facilitate that use. The CWA has taken action; it is instructing children, particularly Victorian school children, in the fine art of knitting. In this Senate I remember challenging other senators to knit a square for National Wool Day last year. My square may not have been all that impressive but at least I completed it. I am disappointed that so few senators took up the challenge.

I am not suggesting for one moment that the Government fund every idea that flashes through the mind of every writer of a letter to the editor. I am suggesting that the Government demonstrate active consideration of a variety of actions, initiate an aggressive, broad-fronted attack on the matter and recognise the merit of the sorts of suggestions being made about alternative marketing strategies by the coalition. I am happy to admit that flashier thinkers than I have come up with alternative strategies which have merit. That is the step which is necessary to take in this place. Instead of politicking, it should recognise the merit of each other's arguments. I am happy to admit that some of the alternative marketing strategies suggested by the coalition have merit. I would like to see the Government recognise that.

This legislation demonstrates that the Government recognises its responsibility to do something about the industry but it does not demonstrate the fact that it is doing everything possible. While what we hear from the coalition demonstrates concern, it does not demonstrate that that responsibility is being shared. There are many other areas of government where the coalition positively wallows in the Government's misfortune. We see it every day; whether it is the statistics or the indicators about unemployment, the balance of trade or inflation, a sort of glee comes across the coalition when a set of bad figures come across.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish.

—It does; it happens every day. Senator Patterson should admit it. None of that gloating helps the industry and it certainly will not help the wool industry. Instead of doing that, as I indicated earlier, some of the factors that have been mentioned here are outside the competence of the Government. It is like the Government taking credit for the relief of the drought some years ago. But it cannot be blamed for everything and, in the same vein, the rest of us cannot avoid responsibility. I believe we have the responsibility to be constructive, to recognise suggestions which have merit and to support those measures which can assist the industry.

—The purpose of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Amendment Bill 1993 is to extend the repayment of accumulated debt of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission from seven to eight years. While not opposing this Bill, because the rescheduling gives the woolgrowers an extra year to repay the wool debt, I believe it is important to join with my colleagues in pointing out to the Government the problems it has created and which it is currently perpetuating in the wool industry.

para.tab: In the last three years there has been a dramatic downturn in prices, a rapid and large accumulation of stocks and the abandonment of the reserve price scheme. This combination has placed the wool industry under a number of short to medium-term pressures. The most important of these is the cost of servicing debt incurred via the stockpile; the challenge of managing and disposing of the stockpile; the economic and social impact of a substantial decline in woolgrowers' incomes; and the need to adjust productive capacity. Add to this the disaster of one of this century's worst droughts and it should be obvious that the people of rural Australia certainly need assistance.

Unfortunately, it is not obvious that the Government will take more effective action than the measures that we have in this Bill before us today. The very serious plight of the Australian wool industry and those players in it, including many people who are not woolgrowers, needs to be urgently addressed. The crisis extends well beyond woolgrowers and their families. The crisis involves everyone in rural communities whether they be directly employed as woolgrowers or whether they make up part of the community that services the wool growing industry. In fact, entire rural communities face nothing short of economic and social devastation if the current disastrous prices prevail in the wool industry.

Business losses for the average woolgrower over the last three years totalled $100,000 and similar losses are expected this year. The current stockpile of 3.9 million bales has barely shifted in the last nine months and it is an ominous shadow over the future of the entire industry. The forecast total production figure for greasy wool this year is 851 million kilograms. Next year this is anticipated to come down to 805 million; however, some estimates put it as low as 700 million kilograms. This provides further scope for wool to be sold from the stockpile without necessarily depressing the effect on sales through the auction system.

We plainly believe that the Government could have done more for the wool industry in this hour of critical need. For example, the Government has failed to address the call from the Wool Council of Australia for a 12-month waiving of the 4.5 per cent debt repayment component of the wool tax. This single measure would have helped all woolgrowers. The Government could also have taken the opportunity with this Bill to slacken the strings which control the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. It could have given the AWRC increased flexibility to go out and market wool from the stockpile rather than wait for buyers to come to it.

The Government could have removed from public scrutiny the operations of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission so that buyers would not know how much wool the commission was selling or at what price it was selling it and, therefore, what other buyers were doing. The Government could have allowed the commission to establish more markets, develop innovative trade deals and new uses for wool, but it has not gone down that path. Above all, the Government had the opportunity to send a clear signal to the market that there would be absolutely no chance of a fire sale of the wool stockpile. The Government has failed to do any of these things.

In this Bill the Government has chosen to extend the repayment deadline by one year. This is a welcome move, but it really only puts the problem off for another year. In fact, it gives woolgrowers unfounded confidence only for them to find that the problem is still there when the repayment schedule advances 12 months further down the track. The coalition and the woolgrowers themselves do not deny the need to repay the debt. Growers have a vested interest in the rapid repayment of the debt, otherwise they will be burdened with the cost of servicing it and paying for the stockpiling of wool. These are additional costs that this wool industry could well do without.

The Government also conveniently ignores the fact that it removed drought from the natural disaster relief arrangements and so it is partly responsible for the crisis in many areas of the country, including many woolgrowing areas, now affected by drought. There seems to be a broad acceptance that drought is a recurring theme in this country. It is something that rural Australians have to be prepared to confront and to plan for when they can. However, given the economic climate in which farmers have been operating for the last few years, this task has been made exceptionally difficult. It is worth observing in any case that the severity of the current drought puts it into a category which no rural producer could possibly hope to plan for.

Additionally, it is important to note that Australia's rural sector is one of the most productive in the world and that our productivity improvements in recent years have shown the rest of the Australian community what productivity improvement is really all about. It has a record of which it can be extremely proud.

Unfortunately, this Government continues to fail to introduce the policies that are necessary to help this very worthwhile industry. This Bill is not a significant step forward in solving the wool crisis. There are many measures which the Government could have introduced along with this Bill, but it has failed to act. I cannot oppose the Bill because it does give small relief, but I implore the Government to act more effectively to help this industry by implementing some of the measures that the coalition has outlined today.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —I tagged my name onto the end of the speakers list because there are a few specific observations that I would like to make about the wool package. The wool industry, probably Australia's greatest rural industry, is in desperate trouble. All honourable senators recognise that. People are coming up with so many different plans, and we have heard many of them tonight.

para.tab: The Government has brought forward two packages: the Federal Government wool package, which is before us at the moment, worth $44.6 million, and the drought package, worth $6 million. In round terms, the two packages assist the wool industry by around $50 million. As well as this, $160 million has been provided under RAS.

The wool industry now has assistance of around $200 million in interest subsidies and farm exits. This is a lot of money—no-one would argue that it is not. But I point out to people, particularly Government supporters, who would say this is a lot of money that in 1983 the Fraser-Anthony Government devoted the equivalent of about $700 million to saving the rural industries. We can debate that backwards and forwards, but this Government is the government at the moment and obviously its preferred options are not with the farmers. It has its own interests and people whom it wants to look after; unfortunately, the farmers do not fall into that category.

There are about 60,000 woolgrowers who produce wool in some quantity. To the best of my knowledge, 18,000 to 19,000 dedicated woolgrowers produce about 48 per cent of the total wool output. The average farm loss for a wool producer is around $40,000, and 91 per cent of those 18,000 to 19,000 people are in that category and are losing money. About only nine per cent of woolgrowers are actually running at a profit. I would like to know how they are doing so; it is beyond me how anyone could make a profit out of wool with the way prices are at the moment.

Every kilo of wool sold at auction costs growers $2 to produce. The average debt in Queensland is around $250,000 per farm. We are told that growers are at risk if their equity is under 70 per cent. In Queensland, equity is around 58 per cent, and I imagine it would be the same in western New South Wales. Very many properties and farmers are at risk.

Both packages contained in this Bill introduced today assist farmers. The wool package assists 5,700 farmers and the drought package assists another 820 farmers. So roughly 6,500 farmers out of 18,000 are receiving some sort of RAS assistance. I rose to speak tonight to bring this point to the attention of the Senate: what is happening to the other 12,000 farmers who are not receiving RAS? Some of them have off-farm investments and are not eligible for RAS, but there are a great many more who are not receiving any assistance at all. There are 4,500 farmers or their wives who are on Job Search allowance and there are 200-odd on farm household support.

Mr Crean went out to the west of Queensland and told the farmers that there was assistance for them. Mrs Greer, the lady from Thargomindah or somewhere out west of Queensland, was very grateful to see Mr Crean. Mr Crean made various statements in the media that there would be assistance for these particular hard-pressed growers affected by not only drought but also the low wool price.

In effect, the only assistance available to those types of people, people that are at the desperation stage with no income because of drought and low commodity prices, is that of farm household support. When people do accept that, they are taking the first step towards exiting their property. Farm household support, which is the equivalent of Job Search allowance or unemployment benefit, is a loan. It is a loan for a period of nine months, and if the grower goes over that period, he has to pay back that loan and exit the property. That is why only 200 people so far have availed themselves of farm household support: people are terrified that if they take it they will have to pay it back, eventually sell their homes and get a $45,000 exit grant.

While this package caters for about 6,500 people, it is not an adequate package. There are very many—up to 50 per cent—woolgrowers who are not receiving any assistance at all and they desperately need that assistance. Therefore, I believe that when Mr Crean goes out and makes statements that there is help, that there is assistance from the Government, he is not completely telling the facts as they are. While he is correct in some ways, in that there is assistance for people who have to exit, that assistance is not helping people stay on the farm.

I hope that Senator Sherry or those in the advisers' box can correct me on my next point because I would love to be proven wrong on it, but I do not think I am. I believe that up to 50 per cent of woolgrowers who are in desperate straits and need interest rate subsidies are not receiving those subsidies. These two packages, in effect, top up the already existing clients of RAS and lift their interest rate subsidy from 50 per cent to 75 per cent or even, on some occasions, 100 per cent. As I said before, if Senator Sherry has received some advice to prove me wrong and if he can assure me that that interest rate subsidy is flowing to the wool producers who are in need of it, I will be the happiest person in the Senate. I know that the hour is late and that we have a couple of extra Bills to get through, but if Senator Sherry can allay my fears on that point, I will be very grateful.

speech.speaker: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: —I would like to deal with a number of matters in terms of the debate tonight. Firstly, I thank those senators who have taken part in this debate. I know that the last speaker, Senator Boswell, is quite ill. It is a mark of his commitment that he took part in the debate, given the difficult circumstances that I know he is in.

para.tab: Generally, the tenor of the debate tonight has been very positive. I intend to deal with points that have been raised by a number of speakers. I include in the positive comments the comments of my colleagues Senator Carr and Senator West. Senator West, who has been a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs with me, has had a longstanding interest in this area, as indeed have other senators opposite who are on that same committee, including Senator Calvert, a fellow Tasmanian.

Firstly, I will deal briefly with the causes of the problems we face in the wool industry. I will then deal fairly briefly with the measures that the Government has proposed, some points made by speakers opposite and the reaction to the package proposed by the Government. Finally, I will make some comments about the theme of the amendment moved by the Opposition.

Firstly, in terms of the causes of the current problems of the wool industry, there is no doubt that the Australian Wool Corporation kept the price of wool too high for too long. There is no doubt that that is the primary reason we have the problems we have today. But let us be honest about it: all the politicians of all the political parties in both this place and the other place accepted that situation for a long time. All political parties supported the floor price scheme for almost 20 years. So when we are apportioning blame, we have to remember that it is all very well to look back at the circumstances surrounding the increasing of the floor price scheme, but very few politicians in either chamber envisaged what was going to happen.

Secondly, there is an international recession. I know that some people tend to scoff at the effect of the international recession, but there is no doubt that it has had a substantial effect on our wool markets. Coupled with that we have the situation in the former Soviet Union and the Eastern bloc. Whilst I welcome the political and economic changes that are occurring there, they have certainly had unforeseen consequences for the demand for wool. We really face a quite serious problem in terms of what is happening in the former Soviet Union and the Eastern bloc. I have been reading some briefing notes on what is occurring in those areas. Unfortunately, much of our traditional wool market has been replaced by synthetics from other countries. That causes me some concern about our long-term prospects of regaining the market. We have also had some problems with contracts with China. I think they are the main reasons why we are in the situation we are in, and why we are debating this issue tonight.

I have already commented about the lack of vision from all sides as to what was ahead, but I have been in contact with a Tasmanian woolgrower, a Mr McKenzie. I have a copy here of a local newspaper containing an article with the headline, `Wool crisis is looming' and written by a Mr McKenzie, who on 6 December 1989 rather accurately predicted what would happen. I will quote what he wrote in the article:
Having spent more than 40 years actively engaged in the wool industry, it is with much regret and sadness that I watch the potential, if not actual crisis, that may befall this great industry.

As an active opponent of the floor price scheme at its inception, mainly because of the basic economic flaw that when you trade in the world arena there is no way you can continue to tell the markets what they must pay for your commodity.

When the reserve price scheme was first implemented, the price of wool was at such a low level that sheep numbers were falling and our competitors, such as synthetics, were getting squeezed by cost increases as a follow-on from the tremendous hike in oil prices.
The success of the floor price plan to date in my opinion has been suspect and purely hypothetical.
As with any comparisons, there must be a `control' to measure it by.
Assume, however, that the scheme has had some success, the costs now can be potentially horrific.
The floor price has long since departed from its original charter (due to the pressure from growers), to be just that, a floor price to become a price pusher.

speech.para: The article goes on and it really is extremely accurate in predicting what would happen in the industry.

para.tab: The legislation before us tonight is but one part of the initiatives taken by the Government in a sound, solid and very broadly based package. I will not go into all the details, but the package is composed of four basic parts. Firstly, the Commonwealth is funding up to $44.6 million under the exceptional circumstance provisions of the rural adjustment scheme. I will return shortly to the contribution made by government above and beyond that. Secondly, the Government has determined that the wool tax will be maintained at 8.5 per cent for 1993 and 1994. Thirdly—and this is the central issue of tonight's legislation—there will be a restructuring of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission's debt repayment schedule by extending the debt schedule from seven to eight years.

In addition, the Government has announced a review committee to be chaired by Professor Garnaut. I know Senator Boswell has some reservations about his background, but we should not concentrate too much on his attitudes to tariffs. I believe he is a very competent person, who, together with the other two members, Mr Rod Price and Mr Stephen Bennett, should be able to come up with some long-term measures and solutions in addition to what has been proposed by the Government to date.

Fourthly, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) is to undertake an overseas trip. This is very important because today I noted some criticism in the media about overseas trips by politicians. Both sides of the Senate would recognise that these trips can play an important part, and Minister Crean's trip overseas will play an important part in helping to assess the market.

Other people have put forward various measures. One suggestion is that we burn the wool stockpile. That is rather ironic, given that one of the great advantages of wool is that it does not burn. In fact, it would cost tens of millions of dollars to burn the wool stockpile. This was first proposed by a Frenchman. The second irony is in the nationality of the gentleman who proposed it—I forget his name—given the attitude of the French towards commodity prices and the support they give within the European Community. I was very concerned that such a far-sighted, responsible and dedicated premier as the Premier of Queensland, Mr Goss, picked up the suggestion. I thought that was particularly regrettable.

There have been other suggestions that it should be given away in the form of aid. Again, I think that is a little impractical. It would be very hard to track where the wool ended up, and I think it could well be a double-edged sword if it were given away. We have had suggestions from the CWA that it should be knitted. Certainly that would make some small contribution to reducing the wool pile, but I do not think it would address the central problem.

I mentioned earlier the contributions under RAS. I have been informed that the Government underwriting through RAS of the total rural debt in this country—and I do not have the breakdown of the wool debt—is some $3.2 billion. I am not suggesting for one moment that there is a payout of $3.2 billion, but the underpinning of interest support on $3.2 billion is not an insubstantial amount of money that is being provided to the rural sector. I do not know the portion that is going to the wool industry, but it would be very substantial.

Regarding the comments from the Opposition tonight, I welcome Senator Tambling's general contribution. He said that the Federal Government could slacken the string controlling the Australian Wool Realisation Commission so that it could better market the wool. I have already outlined that the package does include a review by Professor Garnaut, and hopefully that will include a review of marketing arrangements. I would like to make a comment here on the marketing of wool. It is not necessarily money that is spent on the marketing of wool. I am informed that over the last 10 years $1.2 billion has been spent on various aspects of wool marketing. That is an amazing figure. If we have spent all this money, what has been the result? It really is quite astounding. Of that, $277 million has been contributed by Government. So we have spent an enormous amount of money on marketing, but it has not necessarily been the solution to the problem.

Regarding some of the other contributions, again, Senator Panizza's was generally positive. He challenged the notion that greedy woolgrowers had led to the current situation. I do not for one moment suggest on behalf of the Government that it is the fault of greedy woolgrowers. I have to say that if any of us were in the circumstances of woolgrowers where we were being offered a higher price for what we were producing, I do not think too many of us would knock that higher price back. I do not think any of us would knock it back. He made the point that the scheme was compulsory, but there were not too many woolgrowers clamouring to get out of the compulsory scheme because of the prices they were receiving.

Senator Panizza made the point that the Government should make a greater contribution—without being specific about what the contribution should be—but I made the point earlier about the contribution through RAS of the underpinning of the support of $3.2 billion. Regarding our non-traditional markets and marketing, Senator Panizza referred to eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. I have alluded to some of the problems that we face in getting back into that market. It will be particularly difficult.

I suspect that Senator Campbell's comments concerning the bureaucracy in the wool industry are probably right. I think he has a good point that there are so many vested interests and such a significant bureaucracy that supposedly is looking after the wool industry, and yet it seems to have not been doing a particularly effective job. Certainly I think that is one of the areas which needs a total review.

The situation we have today is a pretty damning indictment of the various bodies in the wool industry, not to mention the various leaders of the wool industry. I referred to a media article earlier. I will not embarrass Mr Lempriere or Mr Cleland by further quoting what they said about the problems we were not going to face in terms of the wool stockpile. Unfortunately, I think there was a lack of vision by some of the persons in the wool industry at that time.

I agree totally with Senator Campbell and a number of other speakers who commented that this crisis is affecting the entire community. I have been to rural and regional areas as a member of the rural and regional affairs committee and, recently, in my capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. There is no doubt that the wool crisis is ricocheting through the entire rural community and industry. It is affecting not just the woolgrowers and their families; it is also affecting small country communities and rural Australia as a whole. Ultimately, it will have a very substantial effect on our balance of payments and, in turn, the entire economy and community in Australia.

I am very pleased that Senator Calvert approached the Minister about some positive contacts that he had made with the Latvian Government in an attempt to sell wool. I am glad to see that Senator Calvert made such a positive contribution to the debate. Senator Watson referred to fewer bodies administering the wool industry. I think he picked up the theme to which Senator Campbell referred. Senator Watson raised a new issue that should be remembered; that is, the two stockpiles that we face—the official one and the unofficial one.

The legislation before us tonight is relatively simple. It increases the amount of time for the sale of the stockpile from 7 years to 8 years. That is a responsible measure. We cannot extend the debt repayment period indefinitely. That would simply compound many of the problems that we face. The Opposition has suggested that we extend the debt, but that simply would not address the problem. Being conscious of the time, I conclude by suggesting that the legislation should be supported. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROTECTION OF THE SEA (OIL POLLUTION COMPENSATION FUND) BILL 1993
PROTECTION OF THE SEA (IMPOSITION OF CONTRIBUTIONS TO OIL POLLUTION COMPENSATION FUND-GENERAL) BILL 1993
PROTECTION OF THE SEA (IMPOSITION OF CONTRIBUTIONS TO OIL POLLUTION COMPENSATION FUND-CUSTOMS) BILL 1993

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by

:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I will not detain the Senate too long at this late hour to consider the Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Bill 1993 and related Bills. Basically, the purpose of these Bills is to give effect to the International Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution Damage 1971. The subsequent legislation to ratify Australia's compliance with this international convention basically means that nine Australian oil companies which import into Australia 150 tonnes of contributing oil per year will be required to pay a combined total in the current year of $138,000, and just over a half a million dollars annually, to an international fund which will ensure that, in the event of a catastrophe involving oil spilt from an oil tanker, we will receive compensation of up to half a billion dollars to help in the cleaning up of oil spills.

para.tab:
In Australia there has been wide public attention drawn to the potential for oil spill disasters in recent times with the
Kirki
disaster off the north-west coast of my home State of Western Australia. Not so long ago there was the
Exxon Valdez
disaster off Alaska which cost in excess of $1 billion for the initial clean-up, with estimates of up to $4.2 billion to date for economic loss and long-term damage from that spill.

The Opposition supports the passage of this Bill and the principle of ensuring protection of the sea generally. I am sure all honourable senators, all members of this Parliament and most Australians would agree that we need to ensure that not only are there sensible incentives upon those who carry oil at sea—those who export, import and trade in oil—but also sensible incentives aimed at avoiding disasters in the first place.

The issue of compensation after a shipping accident needs to be looked at. More importantly, the Government and all members of Parliament need to ensure that we have a sensible set of laws in place to ensure prevention of any offshore oil disaster. As the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, has made clear on a number of occasions, particularly during Question Time, these matters naturally fall into the realms of international treaties and agreements. We all know—particularly as a result of the recent inquiry and report entitled
Ships of shame: inquiry into ship safety
—that we do have disasters waiting to happen off the shores of nations all around the world. There is a rapidly ageing fleet of oil carriers, flag of convenience ships, very lax regulations internationally with ships registered in Liberia and Panama, rapidly ageing, out-of-date and lower level technology in the area of navigation and problems concerning the accreditation of skippers, navigational skills and so forth.

It is very hard for a nation as small as Australia to have much influence in this area. By ratification of this treaty and enactment through legislation, we are playing a small but important part in committing ourselves to the important principle of trying to prevent oil spills and disasters and ensuring that there is an international fund for compensation of oil pollution damage.

Most Australians live near the coastline and we all value the quality of the coastal environment for our own recreational and economic purposes. Australia can count itself lucky that we have yet to suffer the serious consequences of an oil disaster of the nature of the
Exxon Valdez
disaster off Alaska. The
Kirki
incident last year was a reminder that we are very vulnerable; we have a long coast and a lot of shipping movement off our coast. There is an enormous tonnage of oil travelling up and down the shipping passage between the Great Barrier Reef and the mainland of Queensland. It is absolutely crucial that Australia does everything it can to ensure that we minimise the risk of a disaster and have the infrastructure in place so that if such a disaster takes place it can be controlled and cleaned up. I am reliably informed that we do not have in place the sort of infrastructure we require so that, in the event of some disaster, we can limit it very quickly.

In the case of the
Sanko Harvest
disaster off the south-west coast of Esperance—it did not involve oil; it was a large bulk carrier handling wheat—there was enormous indecision and bureaucratic bungling in trying to ensure that relief and rescue operations got down to the remote coast off Esperance very quickly. If that had been an oil disaster, it could have despoiled a very important section of the Australian coastline.

I reiterate that the Opposition supports the passage of this Bill. We certainly support more preventative measures by the Government to ensure that we do not have an
Exxon Valdez
-type disaster or a
Kirki
-type disaster occurring off the Australian coast.

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —The Protection of the Sea (Oil Pollution Compensation Fund) Bill will improve the compensation and liability regime for oil pollution in Australian waters. It will give effect to the 1971 International Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution Damage and to the subsequent protocols to the convention which have increased liability limits. It refers specifically to the carriage of oil in tankers into Australia.

para.tab:
The current situation is so grossly inadequate that any improvement has to be seen as a major step forward. The Australian Democrats certainly support this package of Bills. However, the convention and associated protocols are not as stringent as they ought to be and certainly do not represent international best practice. The amount of compensation that could be claimed under the convention, as amended by the 1992 protocol, is still woefully inadequate when contrasted with the cost of the clean-up of a major oil spill. Senator Campbell has already mentioned that it cost $1 billion for the
Exxon Valdez
clean-up.

Australia has been relatively lucky so far, given our huge coastline and the volume of traffic passing along it, particularly in certain areas. We can refer here to the 2,000 large ships which pass through the Great Barrier Reef each year, including more than 100 tankers carrying crude oil, petrol and diesel. I said in a press release earlier this year in response to the
Braer
oil spill off the coast of the Shetland Islands that only good luck had prevented a similar accident on the Australian coast. Should it happen, and again I reflect the words of Senator Campbell a few moments ago, it seems as though our ability to get to those sites quickly and prevent serious damage is woefully limited.

The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics estimates that there is a 48 per cent chance of a major oil spill from tankers in Australian waters over the next five years and a 93 per cent chance over the next 20 years. In other words, there is roughly a fifty-fifty chance that a major oil spill will happen in Australia in the reasonably near future.

The Government has certainly made some significant changes to regulations to improve ship safety in recent years. One of these has been the introduction of compulsory pilotage in that part of the Great Barrier Reef between Cairns and the tip of Cape York. Given that the Torres Strait and the inner route of the Great Barrier Reef have the highest accident rate in Australian waters, this was a very welcome move. However, the system only applies to the northern half of this inner route. Treacherous and hazardous areas in the Torres Strait and further south along the reef also need to be protected.

The second change was to adopt amendments under the MARPOL agreement to make double hulls mandatory for tankers and to eventually phase out single hulls. Although the effectiveness of double hulls has been surrounded by controversy internationally, the Democrats nonetheless believe that this is a positive step.

These changes highlight the fact that the best approach to combat oil pollution at sea is to set in place stringent preventive measures—that is, prevention rather than attempting to pay the cost of clean-up after a spill has occurred. Australia has in place a national plan and a reef plan specifically designed to cope with a spill in the Great Barrier Reef. However, the reef plan is being revised to cope with an oil spill of only 10,000 tonnes. The
Kirki
spilt 17,700 tonnes off the coast of Western Australia in July 1992; the
Exxon Valdez
spewed some 36,000 tonnes into the pristine Prince William Sound in March 1989; and the
Braer
spilt roughly 60,000 tonnes of oil into an area renowned for its wildlife. Clearly, there is potential for a very large spill. The plan is inadequate and should be upgraded, because there is a very real threat in this area.

Prevention also requires that the recommendations of the
Ships of shame: inquiry into ship safety
report be implemented without delay. The report has been highly praised by interested parties and deserves international recognition. Whilst rust buckets and `lepers of the sea', as Senator Collins so aptly described the
Kirki
, traverse Australian waters, even the toughest liability and compensation provisions could not prevent a serious pollution accident from occurring in our waters. A strict international regimen is, however, extremely important. As long as we maintain our addiction to oil, and as long as there remains an international shipping trade in this non-renewable resource, accidents will happen.

That brings me to the Bills before the Senate. The Democrats have some concerns over the stringency of the regimen contained in the relevant international conventions. Firstly, the fund convention, as amended by the 1992 protocol, does not make compensation available for damage to natural resources where these resources are not traded in the marketplace.

In 1980 the International Oil Pollution Compensation Fund Assembly unanimously adopted a resolution stating that the assessment of compensation `is not to be made on the basis of an abstract quantification of damage calculated in accordance with theoretical models'. The assembly established a special working group to explore this issue. It found that compensation for environmental damage could only be granted where the claimant sustained quantifiable economic loss. We believe that is a defect in the present system.

This was a very strict interpretation of damage and did not allow compensation for non-traded natural resources. The 1992 protocol to amend the fund convention addresses this issue further; it uses the definition of `pollution damage' contained in the 1992 protocol to amend the civil liability convention. The latter document has an improved definition of pollution damage. It states:

speech.para: . . . compensation for impairment of the environment other than loss of profit from such impairment shall be limited to costs of reasonable measures of reinstatement actually undertaken or to be undertaken.

This new definition avoids the task of quantifying the decline in value of a natural resource as a result of an oil spill, but it continues to limit liability for natural resource damage. The key issue that has not been addressed in the protocol, and hence in this legislation, is the problem of assessing the monetary value of loss of aesthetic value, wildlife or ecological systems that have no economic value. Mans Jacobsson, the Director of the IOPC fund, actually said that `the marine environment does not have a direct economic value'.

para.tab: The problem is essentially one of property rights. Property rights tend to be either deficient or non-existent for clean water or clean air, and too costly to enforce when they do exist. The fund assembly, along with shipowners and insurers, has clearly rejected the notion of compensation for other, more ecologically oriented, economic values such as option and existence values. Admittedly, these are very difficult to define. The Resource Assessment Commission has made some progress on this issue by conducting surveys using the contingency valuation method, which was used during the Kakadu inquiry.

It is impractical to expect that this kind of definition of pollution damage to natural resources will be adopted in the very near future in any further protocols amending the convention. However, the US Oil Pollution Act of 1990 does provide some guidance as to how an improved definition could be used. The OPA 1990 allows for the cost of restoration, rehabilitation or replacement, plus the diminution in value of resources pending restoration. The diminution of value aspect contrasts significantly with the limited definition in the 1992 protocol. The OPA 1990 also provides that the cost of assessing harm to natural resources is added to the total cost to ensure that natural resource damage cases do not fail merely because funding for assessments is unavailable.

Secondly, there is also major doubt over whether indigenous people would be able to use the convention to claim for loss of natural resources where the legal ownership of the natural resources is in doubt. This bears very much on the Mabo case. If a local community hunts or gathers food as a livelihood, there is no guarantee that the community would be able to claim for the loss of untraded goods—that is, goods in which there was not a dollar value.
In addition, where a community uses a natural resource for cultural or spiritual reasons there would be no recourse for compensation. In contrast, the OPA of 1990 specifically allows Indian tribes and foreign governments to recover damages through legal action.

Thirdly, the compensation limits set out in the protocol are too restrictive. The amount of compensation available under the new legislation will immediately increase to some $120 million, according to the Minister's second reading speech. We will have to wait at least five years for this amount to be raised to $400 million depending on when the 1992 protocol comes into force. It is worth restating the fact that the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics estimates that there is a fifty-fifty chance of a major oil spill from tankers in Australian waters in the next five years.

In contrast, the US OPA-90 established a federal oil spill liability trust fund which allows compensation of up to $1 billion per incident. Of this amount, $500 million can be paid for damage to natural resources. In addition, $1 billion can be authorised by the federal fund. Although this seems a very high limit, it is sobering to remember that
Exxon Valdez
spent $US3 billion on cleaning up the Prince William Sound spill and a further $1 billion in settlement of law suits by the US federal and Alaskan governments.

Finally, there is the question of the limits to liability. The 1992 protocol to amend the civil liability convention states that a shipowner is not entitled to limit liability if it is proved that the pollution damage resulted from his or her own act committed with intent to cause damage, or recklessly and knowing that damage would result. This definition is far too strict. The US OPA-90 allows for unlimited liability where gross negligence or wilful misconduct occurs on the part of the responsible party or the party's agent, employee or contractee. Gross negligence allows for liability other than that contained in the 1992 protocol amending the civil liability convention. The 1992 protocol amending the fund convention does not allow unlimited liability as the protocol relates to oil importers rather than shipowners; however, the issue of whether importers of oil should be made jointly liable for damages, rather than shipowners alone, is a matter which should be given consideration.

The Democrats are keen to see that this package of Bills is referred to the Senate standing committee in such a way that a number of groups wanting to give evidence to that committee will be able to appear before it. Under the present terms of reference to the committee that is not possible, so at the end of this speech I will be moving an amendment to the terms of reference to the committee. The Democrats do not believe, however, that at this stage there is any likelihood of any amendments being forthcoming to this legislation. We are quite happy for it to go ahead at this second reading stage.

The Democrats support an approach which will offer the greatest protection to the Australian coastline as well as the best regime for liability and compensation. No doubt a US-style Bill in Australia would be bitterly opposed by the oil, shipping and insurance industries; however, ultimately, it must be the protection of the marine and coastal environment and the establishment of strict avenues of justice for parties affected by a major spill which are accorded the highest priority. I move:

At end of motion, add ", but the order of the Senate of 19 May 1993 referring the bills to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure be modified to provide that the committee report on or before 17 August 1993".

speech.para: The reason for this, quite simply, is that there are a number of groups wanting to give evidence to the industry, science and technology committee. Those groups would find it quite impossible to do that before Monday, which is the current reporting date. I understand that both the Government and the Opposition are quite happy with extending that time limit. It allows sufficient time for the Government to meet the 20 February deadline by which time this legislation must not only come into effect but also have been notified internationally for at least 90 days.

speech.speaker: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

talk.start.para:
—The possibility of oil pollution in Australian waters has not been considered a great risk by many in the oil industry or in some Federal government departments until very recently. An indication of a change of attitude on this question is the package of legislation that we are debating here tonight. Certainly the
Ships of shame
program which so vividly examined the issue on commercial television recently, points to the enormous risks that are placed on the coastline of Australia every day due to the shipping of petroleum and petroleum products in Australian coastal waters.

para.tab: There is no doubt that this package of legislation, which implements the provisions of the International Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution Damage 1971, is an integral part of the international and national legislative program that has been established to ensure that safety standards are maintained and that compensation is available to third parties when pollution damage occurs. However, it is disappointing that after all these years this legislation is now being pushed through at the last opportunity to enable Australia to comply with its international obligations.

This legislation and other legislation associated with the International Maritime Organisation and the oil industry is very complex and requires careful scrutiny to ensure that the interests of all Australians as well as the Australian environment are protected by their provisions. Senator Coulter has already gone through some of the complex and important questions that need to be addressed. I will not go over them at this point, but I do intend to support the referral to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which I hope will have an opportunity to engage in a further discussion of these issues.

Australia has an enormous coastline on this island continent, together with fragile ecosystems such as mangroves and, of course, important reef systems such as the ones at Ningaloo and the Great Barrier Reef. We need to ensure that the legislation that is designed to protect the coastline and provide compensation to those whose lives will be affected by pollution damage is comprehensive and appropriate.

I therefore think that the proposal to refer this legislation to the Senate Standing Committee is to be commended. I hope that this will allow sufficient time to enable proper public consultation on this issue, as I am aware that some members of the community would welcome the opportunity to express their concerns about the issues associated with this legislation. In that regard, I support the delay of the reporting of the committee's findings until the first day of the Budget session in order to facilitate that consultation process.

In closing, I cite an article by Michael White, QC, in the
Australian Law Journal
of March 1993 entitled `Oil pollution in the Australian and New Zealand Region'. He points out very appropriately that government and departmental inquiries usually follow after disasters, and says:

speech.para: What would be more beneficial for Australia and New Zealand would be an adequately funded, wide ranging inquiry into marine pollution generally and oil spills in particular. The experience from other countries suggests that this will only occur after there has been a major casualty. Where such an inquiry has been held (as in the UK and, more recently, in the US and Canada) it has been the starting point for useful initiatives.

The very recent example of the
Kirki
disaster off the coast of Western Australia has already been mentioned. A very fortunate series of events involving wind direction and currents carried the oil away from the coast and averted a disaster of mammoth proportions. Therefore, in supporting the amendment that has been proposed, I also call on our Government to follow the committee report with such a wide-ranging inquiry that will look at the preventive aspects that we need to address to protect our coastline and environment.

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

talk.start.para: —I thank those senators who have spoken for their general support of this important legislation. It is not appropriate at this hour to say much about legislation on which there is agreement. To make it clear, I reiterate that there is also procedural agreement, that is, agreement about the proposal put by Senator Coulter concerning how the subsequent stages of this legislation should be dealt with.

para.tab: Indicating as I do that the Government does not object to the reference of the Bills to the standing committee, I want to reiterate the importance the Government places on the need to have this legislation passed through the Senate early in the Budget sittings to meet the timetable for giving effect to the international fund convention.

I know the timing is set to achieve that and at this stage there is no problem, but it is important to put that on the record. As everybody here would know, the adoption of the convention and the protocols and the passage of the Bills currently before the Senate will place Australia in the international forefront of providing compensation for damages caused by oil pollution from tankers. That is where most of us would want to be. Some might want to be further in the forefront, but generally that is the recognised position of Australia in these matters.

I welcome the support of senators for this important piece of legislation. I look forward to the committee's consideration and the subsequent passage of the legislation early in the Budget session. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1993 is not opposed by the Opposition. One might say, `Well thank you very much. You can sit down', but I would like to make a few brief remarks. The Bill seeks to remedy a constitutional defect in the Bankruptcy Act 1966, as amended only recently in this chamber. If the Act is not amended in accordance with this Bill, the process of collecting compulsory contributions from bankrupts will be weakened.

para.tab: The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill, which we are dealing with now, and which amends the Bankruptcy Act, seeks to fix this constitutional defect I have referred to. It came into effect in 1991 under the compulsory income contribution regime introduced at the time. Under that regime, a trustee is able to make an assessment of the income that a bankrupt is likely to derive during the period of bankruptcy. Where the income is assessed at being above a certain level or threshold, the bankrupt is liable to make contributions from his or her income of 50c in each dollar above that amount. A particular section of the Bankruptcy Act enables a trustee to file a certificate in a court of competent jurisdiction in respect of amounts of these compulsory contributions which a bankrupt has refused or failed to pay.

The Bill which made amendments to the Act in 1991 provided that such a certificate would operate and would be enforceable as if it were a final judgment of the court in which it had been filed. It is that section that this Bill seeks to amend. The reason is this: the validity of that section is being challenged in the High Court, and the Government believes that challenge will be successful. If it is successful, then the income contribution regime of bankrupts will be put at risk. So it seems appropriate that we make the change.

The challenge rests on the trustee's certificate being given the status of a judgment of the relevant court, thereby allegedly allowing a person who does not hold judicial office to exercise judicial power in that the trustee files this certificate and it is then a judgment of the court. That defect will be remedied when this Bill is passed. The trustee will still be able to file a certificate stating the nature of the debt and the amount owed, and in any proceedings that are instituted that certificate will be prima facie evidence of those things, but not a judgment as though proceedings had been carried and decided in favour of the trustee. In other words, in order to get a judgment, proceedings will have to be carried out. The trustee will not have, in effect, the capacity to make a judgment of a relevant court.

I mention this only because it is a fundamental issue in a few lines of a Bill that was not picked up here. I notice that Senator Foreman tabled the
Alert Digest
of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills a few minutes ago. I happen to be on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, and it did not so adequately scrutinise the bankruptcy amendments in 1991 to pick up this problem. Nor did anyone in this chamber pick it up. The reason it was not picked up is that, as has happened every November-December since I have been in Parliament—that is, since 1985—a huge number of Bills suddenly appears out of I do not know where and these have to be considered in a rush. Every year we on this side—and I am told it has been the same when we have been in government, so I do not make these remarks in any partisan sense—say, `This is ridiculous; mistakes will be made'. And every year the Government says, `You are a bunch of incompetents. You have held up our program. You are responsible for all of this. We want these Bills'. So a guillotine is introduced and through they go.

The consequence of dealing with legislation like that, of rushing things through, is that fundamental mistakes like this are made. If we add up the salaries of all these people here, the cost of running this whole show—I use that word not to denigrate the place but just to be inclusive of everybody involved—the taxpayer is entitled to say, `What are you doing? Two years later you are fixing up a fundamental mistake. As soon as it is pointed out to you it is as obvious as the days are long. It should jump out from the page at any of us. The reason you have made that mistake is that you will not slow down and give legislation the proper consideration it deserves'.

I feel quite sure that if the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills had been given a longer period in which to consider this Bill, it would have picked up the mistake. I feel confident that if this chamber had been given a greater opportunity to consider this Bill, this mistake would have been picked up. I am not simply saying that if we slow down we will find these problems and fix them—the taxpayer is entitled to be annoyed that we have not done that—I want to add to that the cost of this kind of mess-up.

I do not know who will pay for these High Court proceedings. I do not know who will have to pay the full cost in the end, but it will be very substantial. That is part of the cost of justice. An inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is looking at how well Parliament does its job—our incapacity to legislate in a way that people understand; our incapacity to get it right, so that we have more amendments and poor Joe and Jane Blow in the street, who are expected to know what the law is, have not got a hope of understanding because there are so many amendments coming through.

I will not go so far as to say that this is a disgrace, but we all had the opportunity to spot this error and none of us did. We should take a copy of this Bill and, not so much frame it, but leave it on our desks as a reminder of what happens when we rush things through. I am pleased to support the changes to fix up the mess that we made.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to detain the Senate overly long. However, I feel that I ought to make a few comments on the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1993 at the second reading stage. The intention of the Bill is to rectify a technical problem with the existing legislation. As Senator Vanstone has said, the technical problem is that, under the current legislation, a trustee who makes a determination as to the contribution which a bankrupt should make is making a judicial decision without being a judicial officer. For a long time it has been accepted that a trustee in bankruptcy is an officer of the court, but that is very different from being a judicial officer, because the trustee does not have judicial power.

para.tab: I have a couple of suggestions in relation to this process. I still feel that we do not have it right. The reason why we do not have it right is simply this: the amendments before us tonight will make the certificate of the trustee prima facie evidence of the amount which the bankrupt has an obligation to contribute. The consequence of this amendment is that an application still has to be made to the court, because that is the competent authority. That, of course, costs money. The reason why trustees are generally very unsuccessful in getting contributions from bankrupts is simply that in many cases they are appointed to an estate that does not have any money in it, especially in complex cases where the bankrupt has so arranged his affairs that, at the date of the appointment of the trustee, there are not even any realisable assets or apparently realisable assets that will put money into the trustee's hands so that he can then proceed to carry out a proper investigation.

The intention behind the original amendment to the Act, which we had in 1991, was to streamline the process so that a trustee could get a determination of a bankrupt's obligation to pay without having to go to the expense of commencing an action in the Federal Court or in the Supreme Court, say, in Queensland, under cross-vesting legislation. What we now have is a halfway house. I understand—and Minister Bolkus may correct me if I am wrong—that the trustee still has an obligation to commence an action and to make an application to the court. All this legislation does is reduce the evidentiary obligations of the trustee upon making the application. The best way these particular matters can be resolved is in the same way in which the Act currently deals with the continuing effect of bankruptcy after the normal three-year discharge period.

As honourable senators know, a bankrupt is automatically discharged after a period of three years. When Senator Tate was Minister he made changes to the Act such that a bankrupt could be discharged early if it was shown, under certain circumstances, that the person concerned had adequately, sufficiently and in good faith discharged his obligations as a bankrupt under the Act and there was no public policy reason for maintaining him in bankruptcy.

There were also changes made to keeping bankrupts in bankruptcy longer. But the underlying principle of discharge from bankruptcy was not displaced. That principle is that a trustee generally can object to the discharge of a bankrupt by lodging an objection to discharge with the registrar in bankruptcy of the Federal Court in the jurisdiction in which the sequestration order was made.

I suggest that an appropriate way to deal with this may well be that a trustee in bankruptcy makes an application to the registrar for a declaration along similar terms that the bankrupt has an obligation to contribute a certain amount of money per week, per month or per annum. That declaration can then be overturned by an application, by the bankrupt or on the bankrupt's behalf, to the court itself so that the trustee is not actually making a judicial decision. The effect of that would be to enable trustees to quickly get an obligation from the bankrupt to make a contribution, and then it rests upon the bankrupt to make an application to the court to vary that determination or set it aside.

A bankrupt is able to get legal aid, but a trustee in bankruptcy, who is appointed to an estate that has no assets or no apparent realisable assets, cannot get legal aid to bring the application to court, notwithstanding the fact that the application may well be for the benefit of numerous creditors as individuals. Of course the argument could be made that the trustee would have a right to get money under section 305 of the Act from the former office of Inspector-General in Bankruptcy which is now ITSA—the Insolvency and Trustee Service of Australia.

The problem with that is that section 305 funding for trustees is very limited. Some five or six years ago moneys were easily obtainable by trustees under section 305, but as a result of urging from the then Inspector-General of Bankruptcy, Mr Wenn, there were a flood of applications under section 305, and as a result it is now very difficult to get funding under section 305 of the Act. We cannot say that it is easy for the trustee to make an application; it is actually very difficult. The reason I say all of these things is that frequently there are cases where the estate is very complex and there are no apparent realisable assets but where the bankrupt still has a strong earning stream that derives from various investments or other business activities associated with the bankrupt and where it is not possible to succeed under the trust busting provisions that were introduced into the Act 1987-88.

I hate to say this to the chamber, but I think we may not have it right yet and I think some further consideration needs to be given. I am loathe to say that for the simple reason that we have changed the Bankruptcy Act so many times in the past couple of years that it is getting very difficult for the profession adequately to administer the Act.

The reason it is more difficult for a trustee in bankruptcy to administer the Act than it is for an ordinary accountant practising in some other area of accountancy is that in accountancy generally there are clients who are volunteers in their fate. But in the case of bankruptcy, where a private trustee is appointed, the situation almost invariably arises where bankrupts are anything but a volunteer in their fate. In those few cases where the bankrupt has presented a debtor's petition and a private trustee in bankruptcy has been appointed, frequently the allegation is made that the trustee is going to go soft on the bankrupt.

It is very, very difficult for a trustee to actually enforce the Act when many changes are made. Because bankrupts are not willing participants in their own bankruptcy, they frequently look for every possible avenue to avoid compliance with the Act. That is why the Act has to be simple and that is why we have to minimise the number of changes that are made. Over the next 12 to 18 months we will probably see more changes to the Act. I would only hope that, when those changes occur, they are comprehensive and properly done, and that the Act is then left as it is so that the profession can get on with the job of administering the Act as it is intended, to the benefit of the general public. Proper administration of bankruptcy is very important for the business community, for confidence and for ensuring the economy functions properly.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.
