talk.start.para: —I want to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter that I raised today in Question Time. It is a matter which not many people would be aware of but one which is of vital importance to Australia's rural communities. This matter relates to sales tax paid by primary producers and farm machinery dealers.

para.tab: Honourable senators may be aware that primary producers can register with the Tax Office for exemption from sales tax. The intention is that our farmers, who contribute so much to our export earnings as well as our quality of life, will not be burdened by sales tax when buying goods for use in primary production. In addition, farm machinery dealers can register with the Tax Office for an exemption from paying sales tax, on the basis that they are selling mainly to exempt primary producers, and this is commonsense. If a farmer can buy goods from a supplier and not pay sales tax, it makes sense that the farm machinery dealer who sells almost exclusively to primary producers can buy those same goods free of sales tax.

Last year I, along with many senators, fought to ensure that under the new sales tax legislation the right of farm machinery dealers to register for exemption was retained. We fought so that dealers already suffering a massive downturn in business due to the rural recession would not have to pay an extra cost that they said would put them out of business. So it saddens me to have to bring to the attention of the Senate an apparent anomaly in the current sales tax legislation which means that our rural communities will contribute an extra $10 million a year in sales tax.

The problem with this new streamlined sales tax system, which is a contradiction in terms, is that farm machinery dealers, and ultimately primary producers, will end up paying sales tax on reconditioned farm machinery. This is because dealers must pay sales tax on spare parts bought to recondition farm machinery. A farmer buying a spare part to repair a tractor or any other piece of machinery can buy that spare part free of sales tax but the farm machinery dealer must pay sales tax. Who will the dealer most likely sell a second-hand tractor or harvester to? A sales tax exempt primary producer, of course. The end result is that dealers will put up the price of reconditioned farm machinery by the amount of sales tax that they have to pay on those spare parts.

One dealer has told me that he spends an average of $3,000 reconditioning each piece of second-hand farm machinery that is traded in. It is not uncommon for a dealer to spend $10,000 reconditioning a header. Sales tax applied at 20 per cent means an extra $2,000 per second-hand header. Because of the reduced number of dealerships in the country now, even if a dealer sells only 50 reconditioned headers a year, on average he will have to pay out $100,000 in sales tax, which cannot be refunded. I use this case as an example to stress the seriousness of the situation for all rural Australians. How many farmers in Australia at present can afford to pay an extra $2,000, or anything extra, for a second-hand piece of machinery? How many dealers can afford to absorb an extra $100,000 in sales tax?

My office was first alerted to this apparent anomaly in the sales tax legislation when we contacted many dealers throughout rural South Australia to inquire how the new system was working. We were told that dealers were confused about the new system because it was poorly implemented and poorly explained. These dealers had each implemented the streamlined sales tax system differently. All dealers expressed fear of an audit in case they had got it wrong. One dealer complained that he had used three systems over the last three months and he still was not sure whether he had got it right.

Fortunately, this situation is now being clarified and at last information is getting through to dealers; however, I cannot be so positive about the situation regarding sales tax on spare parts. Because of the downturn in the rural economy, the price of new machinery is out of the reach of many farmers and they now look to reliable reconditioned machinery. Naturally, the proportion of second-hand machinery sold by farm machinery dealers has increased. Anyone who has seen the statistics that have been released in the last few days will realise just how much they have increased.

One dealer on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula—an area that over the past three years, during this rural recession, has suffered greatly due to drought, high interest rates and the fall in commodity prices—has told me that 75 per cent of the machinery he sells now is second-hand. Farm machinery dealers provide an invaluable service to farmers across Australia. They sell new and used agricultural machinery to farmers as well as provide parts and maintenance.

As a normal part of business, dealers buy used machinery such as tractors and harvesters from farmers as a trade-in on new machinery. Dealers have to recondition that traded-in stock to make it acceptable to a prospective buyer. Some repairs are only minor but, because farmers and primary producers are holding on to their machinery for much longer, most of the traded-in machinery requires major repairs and a substantial outlay by the dealer, who has no guarantee that that piece of machinery will be sold.

I do not think I need to spell out how farm machinery dealers across Australia have reacted to the news that they will have to pay sales tax on all spare parts used to recondition second-hand machinery. It is of little comfort to them that the Australian Taxation Office has advised the Tractor and Machinery Association of Australia that sales tax is payable because dealers are using the parts for the business's own use and the parts have not been sold directly to a sales tax exempt primary producer. As with everything else the dealer stocks, the spare parts could be sold directly to the primary producer free of sales tax. There is not even a chance of a refund of the sales tax when the machinery is sold to an exempt primary producer.

talk.start.para: —Are you reading your speech?

—I am getting through it all; do not worry. Farm machinery dealers must carry the cost and pass it on to farmers. I think we all know that dealers cannot afford to carry the cost. The whole situation is ridiculous because the dealer will ultimately end up selling the reconditioned equipment to an exempt farmer. Surely it is perfectly logical that a dealer buying spare parts to recondition machinery which will be sold to a tax exempt primary producer should not pay sales tax on these parts.

para.tab: The Government gave assurances through a Senate committee that no additional sales tax would be imposed on farm machinery dealers, but there is no doubt that dealers will be forced to pass on the cost of this sales tax impost to the primary producers. This indirect tax will cost Australian farmers an estimated extra $10 million a year. This is a conservative estimate. Try explaining that to farmers in New South Wales and Queensland, who are experiencing drought, or to farmers in South Australia, who are currently desperately waiting for rain to sow their crops. As I said, this $10 million figure is only a conservative estimate that has been provided to me by the Tractor and Machinery Association. With the increasing number of farmers buying second-hand machinery, it is only feasible that this figure will rise considerably.

I cannot stress enough the importance of the farm machinery dealers to farmers across Australia. Australian farmers are some of the most efficient in the world and in order to maintain this efficiency they need a support network of manufacturers and dealers. Dealers not only provide a valuable service to farming communities, but they also provide jobs in country centres throughout Australia.

Farm machinery dealers have suffered alongside farmers in this rural crisis. Figures from the Farm Machinery Dealers Association show that the number of dealers in Australia has declined from 2,400 in 1986 to approximately 600 at the current time, which is almost a quarter of the number of dealers that there were in 1986. This is not surprising when one looks at the drop in sales of machinery in the 1980s. In 1983 there were 1,685 retail sales of combine harvesters—that is, both power take-off and self-propelled harvesters—in Australia. In 1992, this figure had dropped to 450, which was actually an improvement on the disastrous figure of 1991 when only 220 machines were sold Australia wide.

Almost 12,000 tractors were sold in 1983 and only 5,798 were sold in 1991. Overall, 16,500 people have been lost from farm machinery dealerships across Australia since 1984. That is 16,500 people our rural communities could not afford to lose and 16,500 people our unemployment queues could not afford to gain.

Statistics released by the Tractor and Machinery Association of Australia for the first quarter of this year indicate that the industry is once again facing a tough year for tractor and farm equipment sales. After some signs of recovery in 1992, this year's opening quarter is little better than in 1991, the worst year on record for the industry.

I look forward with interest to the TMA's state of the industry report due for release next Thursday, 27 May, at the association's annual conference in Canberra. The report is expected to predict a conservative outlook for tractor sales.

The downturn in farm machinery sales has implications for agriculture as a whole. Farmers are aware of the vital role that machinery plays in supporting agriculture and the effect that modern equipment has on farm productivity. The Government must also recognise this connection. The TMA is concerned that several years of dismal sales have caused a major downturn within the farm machinery industry and the survival of its remaining manufacturing and service base looks very fragile. The TMA's president, Mr John Henchy, has stated:

speech.para: Constructive, long term planning for the recovery of Australian agriculture and some incentives for farmers to invest in modern equipment are badly needed.

However, far from giving incentives, all the Government has given the industry is a new tax worth $10 million. If this causes more farm machinery dealers to close, even more farmers will be left with a depleted service. Not only will they have to travel further to their dealer, but also their productivity will also drop because they will have to wait longer for spare parts and service when their machinery breaks down.

para.tab: Australian farmers have always prided themselves on their efficiency compared to the rest of the world. But we risk falling behind other countries if we let farm machinery dealers go out of business and we allow farm machinery to run down further. The Tractor and Machinery Association has sent three letters to the Federal Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) about this situation. Apparently this issue is not deemed important enough even for a reply. I call on the Government to respond to this matter immediately. This apparent sales tax anomaly is nothing more than a revenue collecting exercise, but it is one that will have tragic consequences unless it is removed.

The Australian Taxation Office has apparently been very helpful to the farm machinery industry, despite the confusion caused by the legislation. But the Tax Office has been powerless to act because it is the legislation that is at fault. I therefore call on the Government to immediately remove this extra $10 million burden on the farm machinery industry—a burden which any sane person would know cannot be carried by Australia's rural community.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para:
—I want to use the opportunity of the first reading debate for the package of Bills dealing with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park to deal with two matters. The first relates to today's report that Dr Geoff Chapman, described in the
Sydney Morning Herald
this morning as the hero of racing's anti-GST campaign, has quit the Sydney turf. He is quoted as saying:

speech.para: It's a slow way of going broke.
Of course it is, in view of the economic conditions imposed on all industries, particularly the racing industry, by the recession that we had to have.

para.tab: Dr Chapman is reported as considering his future on the Gold Coast, with a return to medicine most likely. As Dr Chapman, in my experience, listens entirely with an open mouth, he will have great difficulty in discovering his patients' symptoms unless he changes the style that, quite frankly, marked his disgraceful performance before the election.

Dr Chapman is quoted in this morning's
Sydney Morning Herald
as saying:

speech.para: Training racehorses just isn't economically viable.

Yet before the election he attacked the Opposition, and he is described by the
Sydney Morning Herald
as `one of the most effective racing representatives' on the question of attacking the GST. The paper states:
He received wide exposure, and was on Paul Keating's thank-you list the day after the election.

I might add that the Prime Minister, Mr Paul Keating, went to visit Dr Chapman's stables, the Lord Ben Lodge, after Dr Chapman had participated in one of the most disgraceful and dishonest political campaigns I have ever struck. He simply told lies and repeated those lies, and he knew them to be lies. I was pleased that the owner of those stables, Mr John Dunnon, dissociated himself from Mr Keating's visit and expressed his concern about what Mr Keating's economic policies and his Government had done both to racing and Mr Dunnon's interest in property which had in fact forced him to dispose of those stables.

para.tab:
Let us get the facts exactly right. Dr Geoff Chapman may have been the hero of racing's anti-GST fight as far as Mr Max Presnell of the
Sydney Morning Herald
who wrote this morning's report is concerned, but he was a disgrace to those people who expect industry leaders to tell the truth. Dr Chapman's campaign against the GST was based on lies and distortion. The centrepiece of his campaign was his totally false claim that amateur owners—about 90 per cent of racehorse owners in Australia—would have to pay a GST on prize money. That was simply false. He knew it to be false and yet he kept on repeating it for the benefit of his mate, Mr Keating. Weeks before Dr Chapman came out with this politically based lie—

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Is it in order for Senator Baume to libel and slander an individual outside this place when that individual does not have the right to come in and respond? It is a gutless act on his part. He should be saying this outside the Parliament and not inside it. This act of cowardice is something we are used to from this individual.
—Order! Senator Bolkus will withdraw those two words, `gutless' and `cowardice'.
—Why are they out of order?
—I am saying that they are unparliamentary.
—If you say they are unparliamentary, Mr Deputy President, I withdraw.
—There is no point of order.

—That kind of frivolous point of order is the sort of thing I expect from Senator Bolkus who does not have the capacity to recognise the truth. I am now telling the truth about a disgraceful and dishonest campaign in which Dr Chapman enjoyed participating.

para.tab: Weeks before Dr Chapman came out with this politically based lie, with other leaders in the racing industry he had attended a meeting with me accompanied by an accountant who was advising the racing industry. This accountant had clearly explained to these racing industry leaders, including Dr Chapman—who, as I said, appeared to spend that time listening open-mouthed—that there would be no GST on prize money earned by amateur owners who make up more than 90 per cent of all owners in Australia. Because of that knowledge, no other leaders of the racing industry in Australia supported Dr Chapman's lies. They would not support him and that is why he was the outspoken hero. He was the only leader of that industry who kept on repeating that lie and kept on getting massive media cover for that lie.

This knowledge that it was a lie, told to him by his own industry's advising accountant, did not stop Dr Chapman from spreading it. It had the effect of making him look a hero while the other racing industry representatives were made to look like wimps for not participating in it. It was interesting to note that some newspapers, such as the
Sun-Herald
, found it attractive and interesting to run Dr Chapman's nonsense, but would not run with anything like the same enthusiasm the comments made by leading trainers like Tommy Smith, for example, who said that the industry would benefit overall from a GST. Here we have leading racing people saying that what Chapman was saying was absolute nonsense, his own accountant was telling him and yet he continued to repeat this kind of lie.
The facts are that racing under the Keating administration is being destroyed. At least Chapman is right to that extent. It is not economic. He said:

speech.para: Training racehorses just isn't economically viable.

I remind the Senate that under the GST the trainers of racehorses would have had all GST expenditures refunded to them. So Chapman was wrong on almost every score. Sure, there were some problems for some amateur owners, and there was no doubt that there was a need to address them, but there was certainly nothing like the sorts of problems that Chapman pretended were arising.

para.tab: The simple fact is that racing is being damaged seriously. Local and provincial race clubs are in serious financial difficulties, not because of anything the Federal Parliamentary Liberal Party has done, but basically because of what this Federal Government has done to the economy. That is why racing is in trouble. That is why Dr Chapman is being forced out of racing. That is why he will have to go back to medicine. I just want to say in conclusion that if ever there were a man who is deservedly reaping the proceeds of what he sowed, it is Dr Chapman. I hope that if he returns to medicine his integrity in that field will be a lot greater than it was in racing and in his political stunts to serve the interests of the Labor Party.

I now want to very briefly deal with another matter. Mr Deputy President, you will be aware that a notice of motion I gave to this chamber was ruled out of order on three grounds the day before yesterday. It was a notice which was supposed to be whimsical. It was, in fact, a poem which rewrote a verse about the Duke of Plaza-Toro from the
Gondoliers
written by W.S Gilbert. That verse in its original form seemed to me to be very appropriate to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) because it went like this:

speech.para: In enterprise of martial kind,
When there was any fighting,
He led his regiment from behind—
He found it less exciting.
But when away his regiment ran,
His place was at the fore, O—
That celebrated,
Cultivated,
Underrated
Nobleman,
The Duke of Plaza-Toro!

There is no doubt that the Minister was quite prepared to have his bureaucracy suffer the slings and arrows in this matter while he was safely in the rear—or was it safely in Darwin?—not reading, not understanding, not caring about what the documents actually said. I get the impression that when the trouble started he certainly was the first to depart, to say, `It is not my fault; it is someone else's'. Whatever the report today said about the fault of the department, I must say that it is incredible that no Minister would have asked the department, `Is there anything you should point out to me in this matter which is significant?' In any event, I changed this verse to read as follows:
In enterprise like Pay TV
When there was any tendering
He left the job to bureaucrats
Especially by gendering
And while he took his salary
His staff all suffered rough-ups
That error-maker, gross mistaker,
Overweight incompetent
The Minister for stuff-ups.

There is scope in this chamber for a bit of humour, sarcasm and reasonable whimsy. It did have a sharp touch, but are we not taking ourselves a bit seriously when we will not allow that kind of thing to appear in the record of the Parliament? It seems to me extraordinary that we are taking ourselves so seriously.

para.tab: One of the things that disturbs me about this place is the savagery, the nastiness and the unpleasant exchange, such as we have seen from Senator Bolkus tonight. There is no way one could pretend that that had an edge of humour, that it had any grace or that it had anything going for it except bad temper, irritation and a lack of most of the decencies that one would expect from a Minister of the Crown.

talk.start.para: —How can you say that with a straight face?

—Would Senator Faulkner like to keep quiet for a change? By way of disorderly interjection, Senator Faulkner must by now have some kind of record for a Minister of the Crown. It would be a marvellous idea if the decorum of this place was assisted by Senator Faulkner behaving himself for a change. The point I was trying to make before Senator Faulkner's gibberish was that surely there is scope in this place for a little bit of humour. I know that Senator Faulkner is a persistent joke in this chamber, but I want some real humour and I had hoped that this notice of motion would be seen as such. I regret that apparently there is no scope in this chamber for that kind of expression, which one would hopefully say is a little bit of wit.

interject.speaker: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Before I call Senator Faulkner, I would like to refer to a point of order that was raised during Senator Baume's speech. I ruled that there was no point of order, and that was correct. But I would like to remind honourable senators, although only a few of us are here, that certain resolutions were agreed to by the Senate on 25 February 1988 in relation to parliamentary privilege. I think it is worth while reminding ourselves of them occasionally. Resolution No. 9 states:

interject.para: (1) That the Senate considers that, in speaking in the Senate or in a committee, Senators should take the following matters into account:
(a) the need to exercise their valuable right of freedom of speech in a responsible manner;
(b) the damage that may be done by allegations made in Parliament to those who are the subject of such allegations and to the standing of Parliament;
(c) the limited opportunities for persons other than members of Parliament to respond to allegations made in Parliament;
(d) the need for Senators, while fearlessly performing their duties, to have regard to the rights of others; and
(e) the desirability of ensuring that statements reflecting adversely on persons are soundly based.
(2) That the President, whenever the President considers that it is desirable to do so, may draw the attention of the Senate to the spirit and the letter of this resolution.
I do not say that to detract in any way from anything that Senator Baume said. But, seeing that the matter was raised, I thought I should bring it to the attention of the Senate.

para.tab: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —As I have done on previous occasions, I wish to speak about the hours of sitting of this Senate. I know that I am compounding the ill, but the situation really has reached a crisis point in relation to the staff of this chamber and the staff of other parliamentary departments. Senator Chamarette may have some angst about the prolongation of the business of the Senate, but I would remind her that her predecessor attributed her leaving this place to stress-related diseases in relation to her performance as a senator.

para.tab: I am not concerned, as I have said on previous occasions, about the senators themselves. I wish to refer to previous speeches that I have made in relation to this very serious matter: first on 5 May 1992, and subsequently on 12 November 1992. The Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 imposes a duty of care on Commonwealth employers to `provide a safe and healthy workplace for staff, and to design and plan work schedules which minimise any unwanted effects on the physical and psychological wellbeing of employees'.

Senator Faulkner, as the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, has an obligation to ensure that these absurd working hours for the staff of this Senate are not continued. I believe that he shares my feelings about the Senate's hours of sitting. But there is an obligation. It seems absolutely incredible hypocrisy that this Government—which is composed of shop stewards, union representatives and former State secretaries of the Labor Party and which occupies the treasury bench—should impose on the people who work in this place work practices that any employer would be prosecuted for in the courts of the land. Yet, the Government is imposing these work practices not only on senators themselves but also on its own employees.

One may think that this is just the ravings of somebody who is trying to make a point that is perhaps of no great significance. I understand that these practices have gone on for years. I have been here three years and I have been approached by senators in a medical capacity to give advice on their stress-related disorders. I know that some senators from both sides of the chamber are suffering at the moment because this chamber has been sitting for three weeks. Yet here we are still sitting in the early hours of Friday morning. I understand that last week some estimates committees sat until 2.30 a.m.

In October 1991 the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff engaged a consultant to review its working environment and work practices. The key consideration was the hours of duty worked by
Hansard
reporters. I understand that some changes have been made to address this problem. In the 1991-92 annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff there is a reference to the high number of claims submitted by staff during 1990-91.

As at 30 June 1992, the department had 16, or 4 1/2 per cent of the total staff, active compensation claims against it. That was an increase of six over the previous period. In other words, there are the equivalent of 16 full-time employees off at any one time within this department. I have estimated the cost of compensation claims to be about $15,000 a week in relation to this department. This is much higher than any other industry that I am aware of. So, apart from anything else, there is a financial consideration to be looked at.

The International Labour Organisation defines night work as `occupational activity during that period of the day usually reserved for sleep'. It actually defines the hours of night work. We are asking the employees—the
Hansard
reporters, the Clerk and the deputy clerks of the Senate—to engage in night work beyond the definition of the International Labour Organisation. If that does not get through to the Labor Party, nothing will. Those opposite have to take cognisance of this.

There are only three reasons that the International Labour Organisation says are acceptable for night work: one is technical, in other words the continuous operation of industrial processes; the second is economic; and the third is social—for example, hospital workers, police and people who work for newspapers. Many people can acclimatise to this providing these conditions become an habitual part of their occupation. If they are not acclimatised to these situations, decreased well-being may be associated with night work and in up to 15 to 20 per cent of cases the symptoms actually progress to health disorders. Night work is the most difficult part of shift work and extended hours.

In this place we are asking people to start work at 10.00 a.m. and go right through until the early hours of the next day. It is interesting that many of the major disasters that have occurred in the world have occurred during night work periods. For instance, the Three Mile Island disaster, the Chernobyl accident and the Bhopal disaster all occurred during night work hours because the work had an effect on the health of the workers.

One only has to see Senator Collins's behaviour today and his reactions through the week. Admittedly, I understand he is living on a lettuce leaf at the moment—he said that he has lost 17 kilograms. Not only is he hypoglycaemic, that is fairly obvious from his behaviour, but he also erects this wall of sound to counteract debate. If ever there were a wall of sound that becomes a primeval scream for help, Senator Collins is the best example I can give. He is emitting a primeval scream for help and the wall of sound is a reaction to the stress that he is under. He is obviously under stress. I commend the surrealist paintings that are going around at the moment to you, Mr Deputy President, because they give a fair example of what I am referring to in relation to Senator Collins. There are stress related disorders primarily related to this. They may help Senator Collins in some respects because they include reduced appetite, but they also cause sleep anomalies, nervous disorders, fatigue, gastric and digestive disorders, et cetera.

Think of the effects on the social and family life of the people who work in this building. The feeling of being cut off from the community and of not participating in the social life and collective responsibilities that occur. That also happens to senators. We have it in this whoopee land that is our work environment; we ourselves, and the people upon whom we inflict the way in which we behave. It prevents the formation of normal social contacts. Do not tell me that there is normal behaviour in relation to social contacts in this place when one comes in in the morning at about 8.00 a.m. and leaves, if one is lucky—and I again apologise that it is now nearly 12.30 a.m.—the following day. Mr Deputy President, what sort of social contact have you had today, other than controlling the Senate?

I noticed one of the Ministers was sharing a bottle of wine with one of the reporters when he got called back here. I thought that he was doing pretty well, from what I observed of him in the dining room at the time. He has the reputation of doing pretty well in the dining room at times with some of the reporters. He got cut off in his prime—if that is the word—when the division bells rang. I saw he was still here at midnight, so I suspect that all did not go as well as he might have hoped.

talk.start.para: —Don't wave your hand at me when you say that.

—No—does Senator Faulkner feel guilty? I would not expect that. There are effects on work performance as well. Normal humans are day oriented. I think that after habituation in this climate perhaps that could not be said of my colleagues because we become night oriented—in fact, disoriented—in this environment. It is a fact of life that there is a circadian rhythm within the human being. Most of our body's functions show maximal activity by day and minimal activity by night and it affects behaviour, alertness, reaction times and mental capacity.

para.tab: It is important to note that politicians are worse off than shift workers because the night work and extended hours of work are not constant. We never quite know whether we are going to be here at midnight or whether we are going to be here at 3 a.m. We can even go on in an interrupted fashion not being aware as to what is going to occur from one moment to the next. This has been fairly evident in behaviour tonight with the adjournment being abrogated and then a disruption as to whether we were or were not going to have particular Bills debated. There is a problem associated not only with the extended hours of work and the inconstancy but also with the fact that politicians, in particular, do not have time to condition themselves to the conditions of work as do shift workers.

Mr Deputy President, people are not machines. We cannot expect these people who work within the confines of the department to turn on and turn off just as we switch the lights on and off. I note tonight that the Deputy Clerk of the Senate has been frequently coughing and needing to clear her throat. It is believed by many people that an illness is going through the department at the moment. I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, in most cases it is not at all physical. I have had to stave off people who want antibiotics for this illness. It is a classic stress-related disorder where people get run-down and start getting coughs and colds or similar symptoms.

Something has to be done. I will keep on talking in this vein and I will bring this matter to the attention of the Senate while this practice continues. The obligation is on the Government to control the business of the Senate so that this does not occur. I seize this opportunity tonight. It is very early in the legislative program; it is time to take remedial action before it becomes an absolute scandal, not only in relation to the stress-related disorders of the workers within this department but also in relation to the associated costs because, ultimately, the taxpayer will have to pay.

talk.start.para: —Senator Herron has made one of his usual diatribes about wellbeing and health and the stress that long hours—
—I hope you listened to it.

—I was forced to, I am afraid. He spoke about the stress that long hours present in this chamber. This represents extreme irony and hypocrisy. I therefore take the opportunity to put on the public record that it is the lack of respect shown by coalition senators for the program of Bills under discussion that has led both to the lateness of the hour for discussion of Bills which were scheduled for much earlier in the day and to delaying all their colleagues from going home. Coalition senators spent hours on repetitive and tedious questioning of Senator Collins, then they spent hours repeating themselves on the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill. It is exactly this game playing that has resulted in the cynicism and despair of Australian people with politicians and the irrelevance of the political agenda to people's real concerns. Senator Herron talks of the hypocrisy that senators impose on staff working conditions that violate occupational health and safety standards—
—I did not speak earlier today.

—Well, he was very much alone; most of his colleagues spoke at great length. I ask what Senator Herron has done within the ranks of the coalition to reduce the burden that we place on
Hansard
reporters and the Senate staff. The Government does not have control of the business when the coalition plays games and holds us up and presents other matters when we have particular matters under discussion and on schedule. It is an irony that at this very moment both Senator Herron's speech and mine are increasing the burden on
Hansard
and Senate staff. My only consolation is that I have made a brief comment rather than pontificated about the very conditions for which we are responsible.
—Mr Deputy President—
—Oh!

—The Minister can `oh' as much as he likes across the chamber; I came in here to address the Senate for two minutes on what Senator Chamarette so shamefully said about such an eminent person as Dr Herron speaking on medical matters. I have heard a lot of diatribe from Senator Chamarette before in this place. She is laying into us for keeping the staff here. With whom did she vote on the adjournment division? She was right over there with the Labor Party. Since she has been in this chamber she has done nothing else but vote with the Labor Party. She calls herself a member of the Greens. Well, I believe that she is far left of the Labor Party and, as far as I am concerned, she is a member of the Labor Party. She has a hide—
—It really is time to go home.
—It is time to go home. Senator Chamarette has the hide to criticise Dr Herron's comments on medical matters. There are a lot of things that Dr Herron says to me—
—Senator Herron!

—Yes, Senator Dr Herron. He says things to me that I might think are diatribes, but they certainly do not concern medical matters. Senator Herron and I are quite good friends in this place and he says a few things that I might regard as diatribes, but they certainly do not relate to medical matters.
—What are they on?

—It does not matter; it could be sport or something like that or it could be our opinion of you, Senator Faulkner. There is no-one in this chamber whom I will listen to more than I will listen to Senator Herron when he speaks on medical matters. I think Senator Chamarette should come back into this place and apologise for what she said.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.

para.tab: (a) The CH&MRC is an internal departmental committee with the primary function of advising the Repatriation Commission on health and medical research and making funding recommendations to the Commission on research which is proposed to be carried out in the Repatriation General Hospitals (RGHs). Other main functions of the committee are to review project grant applications, arrange independent scientific review of new research proposals, and to review progress and final reports for existing funded projects;

(b) the committee meets once a year in the Central Office of the Department in Canberra. The Chairperson, the Senior Executive Services officer with responsibility for the research program and the Committee Secretary are all based in Canberra. The majority of the members are based at RGHs (one representative from each hospital);
(c) its members & (d) organisations its members represented are:
Rear Admiral Neil Ralph AO DSC—Services Member Repatriation Commission
Mr A Edgar—Assistant Secretary (Hospital Services), Health Program, DVA
Dr G Killer—Principal Medical Adviser, Health Program, DVA
Associate Professor Michael Field—Faculty of Medicine University of Sydney) (represents RGH Concord)
Dr Mark Cooper—RGH Heidelberg
Dr Rick Jackson—Faculty of Medicine University of Queensland (represents RGH Greenslopes)
Associate Professor Lindon Wing—Department of Clinical Pharmacology Flinders Medical Centre, Adelaide (represents RGH Daw Park)
Dr Alan James—Visiting Specialist (Respiratory Medicine), Perth (allied health professional representative)
(vacant) Researcher—John Curtin School of Medical Research
(vacant) Committee Secretary—Hospital Services Branch Health Program, DVA

(e) in the past 12 months, the committee has reviewed all new and continuing research projects funded in RGHs by the Repatriation Commission and has met to formulate funding recommendations to the Commission for the 1993 calendar year; and

(f) the CH&MRC, which is responsible for the allocation of $900,000 per annum for research activities, is funded direct from departmental administrative appropriations. The cost of its operation for the past four financial years is estimated to be around $5,000 per year. The CH&MRC does not receive any other Commonwealth funding.

answer.to.qon.title: Employment, Education and Training: Media Releases

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

para.tab: (1) Does the department routinely disseminate or circulate all or some of the media releases of its responsible Minister or Ministers, to organisations apart from national media organisations; if so, for what reasons are Ministerial media releases circulated by the department, and to how many individuals or organisations.

(2) For each, and which, Ministerial media release circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the releases, and how many copies of the releases were circulated.

(3) Does the department circulate copies of some or all of the speeches made by the Minister; if so, for each of those circulated in the past 18 months, what was the estimated cost of printing and circulating the speech and how many copies of the speech were circulated.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) The Department does routinely disseminate media releases by the portfolio Ministers to organisations apart from the national media.

The Department has a responsibility to advise interest groups, relevant associations and the wider community of matters affecting its programs and services. Such announcements are usually made by the Ministers and advised to interest groups and others by distribution of the media release.
The releases are circulated by two methods:
(a) The Department engages the NewsNet organisation to fax broadcast the media release to interested organisations or individuals on the day of issue.

The Department maintains a composite of lists of organisations/individuals who have requested information about specific subjects. This list has about 850 listings, divided into 30 interest-group categories including journalists. The broadcast list for any media release depends on the subject of the release. It is unusual that any one media release broadcast would exceed 300 individual faxes.
(b) On a monthly basis the Department produces a summary of the media releases issued for that period.
The publication is mailed to 415 external and 83 internal organisations/individuals who can nominate which media release(s) they would like to receive. These are then mailed.

(2) During the past 18-months Ministers issued 287 media releases. The cost of NewsNet for that period was about $71,000. For the period October 1991 to October 1992 the Department mailed out approximately every two months a publication of major media releases at a cost of about $2,000 an issue, including external printing and mail house costs. A new system was introduced in November 1992 and a summary of media releases is now prepared monthly. The approximate monthly cost of this is $85 for in-house printing and distribution. This gives a total of $83,425 for the 18 month period. Therefore the approximate average cost of distribution of each media release is $291.
Media releases are usually reproduced using general purpose photocopiers in the Department and the cost of printing media releases cannot be isolated from other reproduction costs.

Records are not kept on the distribution of each release. The distribution is individually tailored to the subject matter of the release. There has been no particular need to maintain records in such detail. It is not possible, therefore, to provide details of the distribution on a release-by-release basis.

(3) The Department has no established mechanism for the distribution of speeches. Occasionally, in response to a specific request, a copy of a speech is mailed. As this is not a regular or frequent event no records are maintained. The cost is very small.

answer.to.qon.title: CYSS: Sexual Harassment and Discrimination Claims

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

para.tab: (1) Were community committees of the former Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) covered by insurance against sexual harassment and discrimination claims by employees; if not, why not.
(2) Have claims been made against former CYSS schemes for sexual harassment and discrimination; if so, by whom.
(3) What has it cost the Department in: (a) legal fees; and (b) compensation payments, for claims of sexual harassment and discrimination against CYSS schemes.
(4) Are SkillShare schemes covered by insurance against sexual harassment and discrimination claims by employees; if not, why not.
(5) Have claims been made against SkillShare groups for sexual harassment and discrimination by employees.
(6) What has been the cost to the Department in: (a) legal fees; (b) compensation payments, for claims of sexual harassment and discrimination against SkillShare programs.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) No. Given that the program no longer operates, the use of the resources required to identify the full range of reasons for this decision is not justified.

(2) There were 2 claims before the Human Rights Commission involving CYSS committees for alleged sexual harassment in 1986. Following advice from the Attorney-General's Department I have decided that the names of the two claimants should not be disclosed.
(3) (a) $61,437.16. (b) Deeds of agreement were finalised in both instances without any admission of liability on the part of either party. Both agreements contain a non-disclosure clause.

(4) Under the SkillShare Insurance Program the SkillShare Directors and Officers Liability Insurance does provide coverage to Sponsor body personnel against sexual harassment/discrimination claims by employees where it can be proved that there has been a wrongful act. However, the coverage provided is in relation to the alleged financial loss suffered by the plaintiff and does not extend to bodily injury and/or mental injury claims. Furthermore, no insurance cover will provide protection for criminal charges including fines, penalties and punitive damages.

There is also legal liability protection for the Sponsor group for compensation/damages under the General and Products Liability Policy if the third party can prove that he/she suffered humiliation or mental anguish as a result of proved sexual harassment.
SkillShare Sponsors are incorporated bodies and may take out additional insurance beyond the SkillShare Insurance Program if they see the need.
(5) My Department has found no record of any such claim.
(6) (a) Nil. (b) Nil.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 12 May 1993:

para.tab: (1) What would be the position of the States if Australia is to become a republic.
(2) Would the Governors of each State be appointed by the Queen or by the new Australian Head of State.
(3) What arrangement does the Prime Minister have with the relevant State Governments to alter their constitutions.

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) and (2) The terms of reference of the Republic Advisory Committee require it to report on options describing the minimum constitutional changes necessary to achieve a viable Federal Republic of Australia. One of the terms of reference requires the committee to report on the implications for the States. I have no wish to appear to pre-empt the committee's report by engaging in speculation of the kind the honourable senator's question invites.
(3) None.

question.speaker: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 May 1993:

para.tab:
(1) Did Mr John Doohan, of 21 Bartlett Street, Willagee in Western Australia, write to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 23 December 1991 requesting him to initiate an inquiry into the circumstances of the sinking of the HMAS
Sydney
on or about 19 November 1941.

(2) Did Mr Doohan, in that and other correspondence, advise the Prime Minister, his office and the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) that evidence is available to justify initiation of the requested inquiry and that the Western Australian-based Sydney Research Group is agreeable to provide, with others, significant material for that purpose.
(3) Did the Prime Minister instruct the Minister for Defence to attend to Mr Doohan's request for an inquiry.

(4) Did the Prime Minister's office receive a facsimile from Mr Doohan on 16 November 1992, informing the Prime Minister that the Minister for Defence had demanded from Mr Doohan evidence capable of disproving the official German-sourced versions of the loss of the HMAS Sydney and that Mr Doohan, on behalf of relatives of people who died on the HMAS
Sydney
, accepted the Minister's demand and undertook to provide that evidence.
(5) Are the Prime Minister and the Government prepared to initiate the requested inquiry if it can

question.para: be shown that the official version is incorrect or untrue.

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) Yes.

(2) In his correspondence to the Prime Minister of 23 December 1991 and 15 July 1992, Mr Doohan claimed evidence existed to suggest a cover-up of the sinking of the HMAS
Sydney
.

(3) Mr Doohan's correspondence to the Prime Minister on the loss of HMAS
Sydney
was referred to the Minister for Defence for response, as the issues raised by Mr Doohan fell within the Defence portfolio.

(4) Mr Doohan's facsimile dated 16 November 1992 to the Office of the Prime Minister referred to correspondence from the Minister for Defence dated 8 October 1992 responding to claims made by Mr Doohan concerning the sinking of HMAS
Sydney
. The Minister had informed Mr Doohan that there was a limit to the amount of resources his Department could expend on this issue. He therefore advised Mr Doohan that unless irrefutable evidence was produced which disproved the accepted version of what happened to HMAS
Sydney
he now considered the matter closed. In his facsimile Mr Doohan confirmed his `intended compliance' with the request for such evidence.

(5) At this juncture there is no justification for an inquiry. As far as the Department of Defence and the Naval Historical Section is able to ascertain, no such evidence exists. Nor has Mr Doohan as yet provided relevant, verifiable evidence. The Minister for Defence in his correspondence to Mr Doohan of 8 October 1992 noted that defence historians believed there is insufficient hard evidence to warrant the type of open-ended research Mr Doohan advocates. The Government has no objections to Mr Doohan pursuing his private investigations through the Australian Archives and other avenues, but believes his case would be best assessed by reputable historians and their academic peers in relevant fields.
